Ekaṃ suvaṇṇapātiṃ katvā aññā dve tisso lohapātiyo suvaṇṇavaṇṇe karoti, tato janapadaṃ gantvā kiñcideva aḍḍhaṃ kulaṃ pavisitvā – ‘‘suvaṇṇabhājanāni kiṇathā’’ti vatvā agghe pucchite samagghataraṃ dātukāmā honti. Tato tehi – ‘‘kathaṃ imesaṃ suvaṇṇabhāvo jānitabbo’’ti vutte, ‘‘vīmaṃsitvā gaṇhathā’’ti suvaṇṇapātiṃ pāsāṇe ghaṃsitvā sabbā pātiyo datvā gacchati. Mānakūṭaṃ nāma hadayabhedasikhābhedarajjubhedavasena tividhaṃ hoti. Tattha hadayabhedo sappitelādiminanakāle labbhati. Tāni hi gaṇhanto heṭṭhāchiddena mānena – ‘‘saṇikaṃ āsiñcā’’ti vatvā antobhājane bahuṃ paggharāpetvā gaṇhāti, dadanto chiddaṃ pidhāya sīghaṃ pūretvā deti. Sikhābhedo tilataṇḍulādiminanakāle labbhati. Tāni hi gaṇhanto saṇikaṃ sikhaṃ ussāpetvā gaṇhāti, dadanto vegena pūretvā sikhaṃ chindanto deti. Rajjubhedo khettavatthuminanakāle labbhati. Lañjaṃ alabhantā hi khettaṃ amahantampi mahantaṃ katvā minanti. Ukkoṭanādīsu ukkoṭananti assāmike sāmike kātuṃ lañjaggahaṇaṃ. Vañcananti tehi tehi upāyehi paresaṃ vañcanaṃ. Tatridamekaṃ vatthu – eko kira luddako migañca migapotakañca gahetvā  āgacchati , tameko dhutto – ‘‘kiṃ bho, migo agghati, kiṃ migapotako’’ti āha. ‘‘Migo dve kahāpaṇe, migapotako eka’’nti ca vutte ekaṃ kahāpaṇaṃ datvā migapotakaṃ gahetvā thokaṃ gantvā nivatto – ‘‘na me bho, migapotakena attho, migaṃ me dehī’’ti āha. Tena hi – dve kahāpaṇe dehīti. So āha – ‘‘nanu te bho, mayā paṭhamaṃ eko kahāpaṇo dinno’’ti? ‘‘Āma, dinno’’ti. ‘‘Idaṃ migapotakaṃ gaṇha, evaṃ so ca kahāpaṇo, ayañca kahāpaṇagghanako migapotakoti dve kahāpaṇā bhavissantī’’ti. So ‘‘kāraṇaṃ vadatī’’ti sallakkhetvā migapotakaṃ gahetvā migaṃ adāsīti. Nikatīti yogavasena vā māyāvasena vā apāmaṅgaṃ pāmaṅganti, amaṇiṃ maṇinti, asuvaṇṇaṃ suvaṇṇanti katvā patirūpakena vañcanaṃ. Sāciyogoti kuṭilayogo, etesaṃyeva ukkoṭanādīnametaṃ nāmaṃ. Tasmā – ukkoṭanasāciyogo, vañcanasāciyogo, nikatisāciyogoti, evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Keci aññaṃ dassetvā aññassa parivattanaṃ sāciyogoti vadanti. Taṃ pana vañcaneneva saṅgahitaṃ. Chedanādīsu chedananti hatthacchedanādi. Vadhoti māraṇaṃ. Bandhoti rajjubandhanādīhi bandhanaṃ. Viparāmosoti himaviparāmoso, gumbaviparāmosoti duvidho. Yaṃ himapātasamaye himena paṭicchannā hutvā maggappaṭipannaṃ janaṃ musanti, ayaṃ himaviparāmoso. Yaṃ gumbādīhi paṭicchannā musanti, ayaṃ gumbaviparāmoso. Ālopo vuccati gāmanigamādīnaṃ vilopakaraṇaṃ. Sahasākāroti sāhasikakiriyā. Gehaṃ pavisitvā manussānaṃ ure satthaṃ ṭhapetvā icchitabhaṇḍānaṃ gahaṇaṃ. Evametasmā chedana…pe… sahasākārā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamoti. Iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyyāti.
commentary_english:
10. *Bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhāti*: “The undertaking of seed-group and being-group” means disrupting, by way of cutting, splitting, cooking, etc., the undertaking of the five kinds of seed-group, namely, *mūlabīja* (root-seed), *skandhabīja* (trunk-seed), *phaḷubīja* (shoot-seed), *agrabīja* (tip-seed), and *bījabīja* (seed-seed); as well as the being-group of any blue grass, tree, etc. from whatever source. This is the meaning.

*Ekabhattikoti*: “Taking one meal” means the two meals: the morning meal (*pātarāsabhatta*) and the evening meal (*sāyamāsabhatta*). Among those, the morning meal is limited by the time before midday (*antomajjhanhikena*), the other [meal] is from midday upwards until dawn (*anto aruṇena*).

Therefore, even someone eating ten times during before midday (*antomajjhanhike*), is still someone who takes one meal (*ekabhattikova*).

With reference to this, it is said, “one who takes one meal” (*ekabhattiko*).

*Rattiyā bhojanaṃ ratti*, eating at night is night, ceasing from that, is ceasing from night (*rattūparato*).

After midday (*majjhanhike*) until sunset (*sūriyatthaṅgamanā*), eating is called unseasonable eating (*vikālabhojanaṃ*).

Having ceased from that, one abstains from unseasonable eating (*vikālabhojanā*).

When did he abstain? From the day of renouncing on the bank of the Anomā River (*anomānadītīre pabbajitadivasato paṭṭhāya*).

Because it is not in accordance with the teaching (*sāsanassa ananulomattā*), showing what is disorderly and improper (*visūkaṃ paṭāṇībhūtaṃ dassanaṃ*) is *visūkadassanaṃ* (improper seeing).

By oneself dancing, causing to dance, etc., dance (*naccā*) and song (*gītā*) and instrumental music (*vāditā*), even ultimately seeing dance etc. flourishing like peacock dances etc. (*mayūranaccādivasenapi pavattānaṃ naccādīnaṃ*) is a disorderly showing (*visūkabhūtā dassanā*), thus *naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā* (dance, song, instrumental music, improper seeing).

For monks and nuns, it is not proper to cause dance etc. (*naccādīni*) to be performed by oneself, or to cause [them] to be performed by others, or to see performances (*passituṃ*).

Among garlands etc., a garland (*mālā*) is whatever kind of flower (*pupphaṃ*).

Smell (*gandho*) is whatever kind of fragrant substance (*gandhajātaṃ*).

Unguent (*vilepanaṃ*) is causing color to the skin (*chavirāgakaraṇaṃ*).

There, wearing, it is called sustaining (*dhāreti*), filling what is lacking, it is called adorning (*maṇḍeti*), enjoying through the scent and through the color of the skin, it is called beautifying (*vibhūseti*).

*Ṭhānaṃ* (basis) is called cause (*kāraṇaṃ*).

Therefore, whatever flowers, garlands etc. (*mālādhāraṇādīni*) the masses do with immoral intention (*dussīlyacetanāya*), abstaining from that is the meaning.

High couches (*uccāsayanaṃ*) are called exceeding the measure (*pamāṇātikkantaṃ*).

Large couches (*mahāsayananti*) are improper spreads (*akappiyapaccattharaṇaṃ*).

Abstaining from that (*tato*), is the meaning.

Gold (*suvaṇṇaṃ*) is the noble metal (*jātarūpaṃ*).

Silver (*rajataṃ*) is a *kahāpaṇa* coin, a copper *māsaka* coin, a resin *māsaka* coin, a wooden *māsaka* coin—whatever is used in commerce (*vohāraṃ gacchanti*).

Abstaining from accepting both of those (*tassa ubhayassāpi paṭiggahaṇā*), he neither takes it himself (*na uggaṇhāti*), nor causes another to take it (*na uggaṇhāpeti*), nor approves of what has been put aside (*na upanikkhittaṃ sādiyatīti*). This is the meaning.

*Āmakadhaññapaṭiggahaṇāti*: “Accepting raw grain” [means] accepting even the seven kinds of raw grain (*āmakadhaññassa*), enumerated as rice (*sāli*), *vīhi*, barley (*yava*), wheat (*godhūma*), *kaṅgu*, *varaka*, and *kudrūsaka*.

Not only accepting those (*na kevalañca etesaṃ paṭiggahaṇameva*), but even touching them (*āmasanampi*) is not proper for monks (*bhikkhūnaṃ na vaṭṭatiyeva*).

*Āmakamaṃsapaṭiggahaṇāti*: “Accepting raw meat” means here, except when it is specially allowed (*aññatra odissa anuññātā*), accepting raw meat and fish (*āmakamaṃsamacchānaṃ paṭiggahaṇameva*) is not proper for monks (*bhikkhūnaṃ na vaṭṭati*), not even touching [them] (*no āmasanaṃ*).

*Itthikumārikapaṭiggahaṇāti*: “Accepting women and girls” means here, a woman (*itthī*) is one who has gone in between men (*purisantaragatā*), the other is called a girl (*kumārikā nāma*). Accepting and touching those (*tāsaṃ paṭiggahaṇampi āmasanampi*) is simply improper (*akappiyameva*).

*Dāsidāsapaṭiggahaṇāti*: “Accepting male and female slaves” means here, accepting those (*tesaṃ paṭiggahaṇaṃ*) is not proper only by means of [them being] male and female slaves (*dāsidāsavaseneva*).

“I give a monastic attendant (*kappiyakārakaṃ dammi*), I give a gardener (*ārāmikaṃ dammī*)”—when it is said thus (*evaṃ vutte*), it is proper (*vaṭṭati*).

Among sheep and goats etc. (*ajeḷakādīsu*), regarding fields, building sites and boundaries (*khettavatthupariyosānesu*), the principle of what is proper and improper (*kappiyākappiyanayo*) should be investigated according to the Vinaya (*vinayavasena upaparikkhitabba*).

There, a field (*khettaṃ nāma*) is that in which spring crops grow (*yasmiṃ pubbaṇṇaṃ ruhati*).

A building site (*vatthu nāma*) is that in which autumn crops grow (*yasmiṃ aparaṇṇaṃ ruhati*).

Or where both grow (*yattha vā ubhayampi ruhati*), that is a field (*taṃ khettaṃ*).

Land prepared for that purpose (*tadatthāya akatabhūmibhāgo*) is a building site (*vatthu*).

By the head of fields and building sites (*khettavatthusīsena*), here also, ponds and tanks etc. (*vāpitaḷākādīnipi*) are included (*saṅgahitāneva*).

*Dūteyyaṃ vuccati* is called the work of a messenger (*dūtakammaṃ*), taking a letter or message (*paṇṇaṃ vā sāsanaṃ vā gahetvā*) sent by laypeople (*gihīnaṃ pahitaṃ*) and going there and there (*tattha tattha gamanaṃ*).

*Pahiṇagamanaṃ vuccati* is called the minor going (*khuddakagamanaṃ*) of one sent from house to house (*gharā gharaṃ pesitassa*).

*Anuyogo nāma* is called doing both of those (*tadubhayakaraṇaṃ*).

Therefore, *anuyogāti* is [called] the practice of messengers and errand-goers (*dūteyyapahiṇagamanānaṃ*).
In this way, the meaning should be understood here.
*Kayavikkayā* means *kaya* and *vikkayā*.
In *tulākūṭa*, etc., *kūṭa* means deception.
There, *tulākūṭa* is of four kinds, namely: *rūpakūṭa*, *aṅgakūṭa*, *gahaṇakūṭa*, and *paṭicchannakūṭa*.
There, *rūpakūṭa* means making two equal balances, taking with a large [weight], and giving with a small one.
*Aṅgakūṭa* means, while taking, pressing the balance with the hand on the back side, and while giving, [pressing] the front side.
*Gahaṇakūṭa* means, while taking, grasping the rope at the root, and while giving, at the tip.
*Paṭicchannakūṭa* means making the balance hollow, putting iron powder inside, and while taking, tilting it to the back side, and while giving, to the front side.
*Kaṃsa* is called a gold plate; deceiving with that is *kaṃsakūṭa*.
How? Making one gold plate, and making two or three other metal plates of golden color, then going to a town, entering some modest family, and saying, "Buy golden vessels!" When the price is asked, they are willing to give a higher price.
Then they say, "How is the golden quality of these to be known?" When told, "Examine and take them," after rubbing the gold plate on a stone, he gives all the plates and leaves.
*Mānakūṭa* is of three kinds based on *hadayabheda*, *sikhābheda*, and *rajjubheda*.
There, *hadayabheda* is obtained at the time of measuring ghee, oil, etc.
When taking those, with a measuring container with a hole at the bottom, saying "Pour slowly!", after causing much to drip into the inner vessel, he takes it; when giving, closing the hole, quickly filling it, he gives.
*Sikhābheda* is obtained at the time of measuring sesame, rice, etc.
When taking those, slowly raising the top, he takes it; when giving, quickly filling it, cutting off the top, he gives.
*Rajjubheda* is obtained at the time of measuring fields and land.
Not obtaining profit, indeed, they measure the field, making even a small one large.
Among *ukkoṭana*, etc., *ukkoṭana* means taking the profit to make the ownerless into the owner.
*Vañcana* is deceiving others by those various means.
There, this is one story: a hunter, having taken a deer and a fawn, is coming; a cheat tells him, "Sir, what is the price of the deer? What is the price of the fawn?"
When told, "The deer is two *kahāpaṇas*, the fawn is one," giving one *kahāpaṇa*, having taken the fawn, having gone a little, he returns, "Sir, I don't need the fawn, give me the deer!"
Then [the hunter says]: "Then give two *kahāpaṇas*!"
He says, "Sir, didn't I give you one *kahāpaṇa* before?" "Yes, you gave it."
"[Then] take this fawn, and that *kahāpaṇa*, and this fawn worth a *kahāpaṇa*, so there will be two *kahāpaṇas*."
He, recognizing that he is speaking a reason, having taken the fawn, did not give the deer.
*Nikati* is deceiving with a likeness, making something unseemly seemly, making something that is not a gem seem like a gem, or making something that is not gold seem like gold, by means of skill or by means of magic.
*Sāciyoga* is crooked conduct; this itself is the name of *ukkoṭana*, etc.
Therefore, *ukkoṭanasāciyoga*, *vañcanasāciyoga*, *nikatisāciyoga*—in this way, the meaning should be seen here.
Some say that showing one thing and exchanging it for another is *sāciyoga*.
That, however, is included in deception itself.
Among *chedana*, etc., *chedana* is cutting off the hand, etc.
*Vadha* is killing.
*Bandha* is binding by means of ropes, etc.
*Viparāmosa* is of two kinds: *himaviparāmosa* and *gumbaviparāmosa*.
That which, at the time of snowfall, being covered by snow, deceive people walking on the path—this is *himaviparāmosa*.
That which, being covered by bushes, etc., deceive—this is *gumbaviparāmosa*.
*Ālopa* is called the act of plundering villages, towns, etc.
*Sahasākāra* is a violent act.
Having entered a house, placing a weapon on the chest of people, taking desired goods.
Thus, the ascetic Gautama refrains from mutilating… robbery… and violence.

Or, bhikkhus, a common person, when speaking in praise of the Tathāgata, might speak thus:

mula_pali: 11. ‘‘‘Yathā  vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhaṃ anuyuttā viharanti, seyyathidaṃ seyyathīdaṃ (sī. syā.) – mūlabījaṃ khandhabījaṃ phaḷubījaṃ aggabījaṃ bījabījameva pañcamaṃ pañcamaṃ iti vā (sī. syā. ka.); iti evarūpā bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 11. “Whereas some honorable *śramaṇa*s (ascetics) and *brāhmaṇa*s (Brahmins), while living on food offered in faith, remain engaged in the destruction of seeds and plants (*bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambha*), namely: plants propagated from roots (*mūlabījaṃ*), stems (*khandhabījaṃ*), joints (*phaḷubījaṃ*), cuttings (*aggabījaṃ*), and seeds (*bījabījameva pañcamaṃ*)—the *śramaṇa* (ascetic) Gotama abstains from such destruction." Thus, monks (*bhikkhave*), would an ordinary person (*puthujjano*) praise the qualities (*vaṇṇaṃ*) of the *Tathāgata*.
commentary_pali: 11. Idāni  majjhimasīlaṃ vitthārento ‘‘yathā vā paneke bhonto’’tiādimāha. Tatrāyaṃ anuttānapadavaṇṇanā. Saddhādeyyānīti kammañca phalañca idhalokañca paralokañca saddahitvā dinnāni. ‘Ayaṃ me ñātī’ti vā, ‘mitto’ti vā, idaṃ paṭikarissati, idaṃ vā tena katapubbanti vā, evaṃ na dinnānīti attho. Evaṃ dinnāni hi na saddhādeyyāni nāma honti . Bhojanānīti desanāsīsamattametaṃ, atthato pana saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā cīvarāni pārupitvā senāsanāni sevamānā gilānabhesajjaṃ paribhuñjamānāti sabbametaṃ vuttameva hoti. Seyyathidanti nipāto. Tassattho katamo so bījagāmabhūtagāmo, yassa samārambhaṃ anuyuttā viharantīti. Tato taṃ dassento mūlabījantiādimāha. Tattha mūlabījaṃ nāma haliddi, siṅgiveraṃ, vacā, vacattaṃ, ativisā, kaṭukarohiṇī, usīraṃ, bhaddamuttakanti evamādi. Khandhabījaṃ nāma assattho, nigrodho, pilakkho, udumbaro, kacchako, kapitthanoti evamādi. Phaḷubījaṃ nāma ucchu, naḷo, veḷūti evamādi. Aggabījaṃ nāma ajjakaṃ, phaṇijjakaṃ, hiriveranti evamādi. Bījabījaṃ nāma pubbaṇṇaṃ aparaṇṇanti evamādi. Sabbañhetaṃ rukkhato viyojitaṃ viruhanasamatthameva ‘‘bījagāmo’’ti vuccati. Rukkhato pana aviyojitaṃ asukkhaṃ ‘‘bhūtagāmo’’ti vuccati. Tattha bhūtagāmasamārambho pācittiyavatthu, bījagāmasamārambho dukkaṭavatthūti veditabbo.
commentary_english:
11. Now, expanding on the intermediate level of morality, he says, "Just as some venerable ones..." and so on.

Herein lies the explanation of terms that are not obvious.

"Faith-offerings" means gifts given with conviction in action (karma) and its result (phala), in this world (ihaloka) and the next world (paraloka).

The meaning is that gifts are not given thinking, "This is my relative (ñātī)," or "my friend (mitto)," or "This one will reciprocate," or "This was done by him previously."

Indeed, things given in this way are not called faith-offerings (saddhādeyyāni).

"Foods" is merely a summary designation, but in reality, faith-offerings include eating foods (bhojanāni bhuñjitvā), wearing robes (cīvarāni pārupitvā), making use of lodgings (senāsanāni sevamānā), and using medicine for the sick (gilānabhesajjaṃ paribhuñjamānā)—all of this is already included in what was said.

"Seyyathidam" is a particle (nipāto).

What is the meaning of that? Which is the seed-group (bījagāma) and the being-group (bhūtagāma) to which [monks] are devoted and in which they dwell?

Then, showing that, he says, beginning with "root-seed" (mūlabīja).

There, "root-seed" (mūlabīja) means turmeric (haliddi), ginger (siṅgiveraṃ), sweet flag (vacā), white sweet flag (vacattaṃ), *atis* root (ativisā), black hellebore (kaṭukarohiṇī), vetiver root (usīraṃ), nutgrass (bhaddamuttakanti), and so forth (evamādi).

"Stem-seed" (khandhabīja) means the Bodhi tree (*assattho*), the banyan tree (*nigrodho*), the Indian rock fig (*pilakkho*), the cluster fig (*udumbaro*), the Indian cedar (*kacchako*), the portia tree (*kapitthanoti*), and so forth (evamādi).

"Joint-seed" (phaḷubīja) means sugarcane (*ucchu*), reed (*naḷo*), bamboo (*veḷūti*), and so forth (evamādi).

"Shoot-seed" (aggabīja) means *ajjakaṃ*, *phaṇijjakaṃ*, *hiriveranti*, and so forth (evamādi).

"Seed-seed" (bījabīja) means grains (*pubbaṇṇaṃ*), vegetables (*aparaṇṇanti*), and so forth (evamādi).

All of this, when separated from a tree (rukkhato viyojitaṃ) and capable of sprouting (viruhanasamathameva), is called "seed-group" (*bījagāmo*).

But that which is not separated from the tree (rukkhato pana aviyojitaṃ) and is not dry (asukkhaṃ) is called "being-group" (*bhūtagāmo*).

There, the disturbance of the being-group (*bhūtagāmasamārambho*) is an offense requiring expiation (*pācittiyavatthu*), and the disturbance of the seed-group (*bījagāmasamārambho*) is an offense of wrong-doing (*dukkaṭavatthūti*)—this should be understood (*veditabbo*).

mula_pali: 12. ‘‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ sannidhikāraparibhogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti , seyyathidaṃ – annasannidhiṃ pānasannidhiṃ vatthasannidhiṃ yānasannidhiṃ sayanasannidhiṃ gandhasannidhiṃ āmisasannidhiṃ iti vā iti evarūpā sannidhikāraparibhogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 12. “Or he might say: ‘Whereas some honorable *śramaṇas* (*samaṇa*) and *brāhmaṇas*, while living on food offered by the faithful, engage in the use of stored-up goods (*sannidhikāraparibhoga*), such as stored-up food (*annasannidhi*), stored-up drinks (*pānasannidhi*), stored-up clothes (*vatthasannidhi*), stored-up vehicles (*yānasannidhi*), stored-up beds (*sayanasannidhi*), stored-up perfumes (*gandhasannidhi*), and stored-up delicacies (*āmisasannidhi*)—the *śramaṇa* Gotama abstains from the use of stored-up goods.’ Thus, *bhikkhus*, the ordinary person, speaking in praise of the *Tathāgata*, might speak.
commentary_pali: 12.Sannidhikāraparibhoganti sannidhikatassa paribhogaṃ. Tattha duvidhā kathā, vinayavasena ca sallekhavasena ca. Vinayavasena tāva yaṃ kiñci annaṃ ajja paṭiggahitaṃ aparajju sannidhikārakaṃ hoti, tassa paribhoge pācittiyaṃ . Attanā laddhaṃ pana sāmaṇerānaṃ datvā, tehi laddhaṃ ṭhapāpetvā dutiyadivase bhuñjituṃ vaṭṭati, sallekho pana na hoti. Pānasannidhimhipi eseva nayo. Tattha pānaṃ nāma ambapānādīni aṭṭha pānāni, yāni ca tesaṃ anulomāni. Tesaṃ vinicchayo samantapāsādikāyaṃ vutto. Vatthasannidhimhi anadhiṭṭhitaṃ avikappitaṃ sannidhi ca hoti, sallekhañca kopeti, ayaṃ pariyāyakathā. Nippariyāyato pana ticīvarasantuṭṭhena bhavitabbaṃ, catutthaṃ labhitvā aññassa dātabbaṃ. Sace yassa kassaci dātuṃ na sakkoti, yassa pana dātukāmo hoti, so uddesatthāya vā paripucchatthāya vā gato, āgatamatte dātabbaṃ, adātuṃ na vaṭṭati. Cīvare pana appahonte satiyā paccāsāya anuññātakālaṃ ṭhapetuṃ vaṭṭati. Sūcisuttacīvarakārakānaṃ alābhena tato parampi vinayakammaṃ katvā ṭhapetuṃ vaṭṭati. ‘‘Imasmiṃ jiṇṇe puna īdisaṃ kuto labhissāmī’’ti pana ṭhapetuṃ na vaṭṭati, sannidhi ca hoti, sallekhañca kopeti. Yānasannidhimhi yānaṃ nāma vayhaṃ, ratho, sakaṭaṃ, sandamānikā, sivikā, pāṭaṅkīti; netaṃ pabbajitassa yānaṃ. Upāhanā pana pabbajitassa yānaṃyeva. Ekabhikkhussa hi eko araññatthāya, eko dhotapādakatthāyāti, ukkaṃsato dve upāhanasaṅghāṭā vaṭṭanti. Tatiyaṃ labhitvā aññassa dātabbo. ‘‘Imasmiṃ jiṇṇe aññaṃ kuto labhissāmī’’ti hi ṭhapetuṃ na vaṭṭati, sannidhi ca hoti, sallekhañca kopeti. Sayanasannidhimhi sayananti mañco. Ekassa bhikkhuno eko gabbhe, eko divāṭhāneti ukkaṃsato dve mañcā vaṭṭanti. Tato uttari labhitvā aññassa bhikkhuno vā gaṇassa vā dātabbo; adātuṃ na vaṭṭati. Sannidhi ca hoti, sallekhañca kopeti. Gandhasannidhimhi bhikkhuno kaṇḍukacchuchavidosādiābādhe  sati gandhā vaṭṭanti. Te gandhe āharāpetvā tasmiṃ roge vūpasante aññesaṃ vā ābādhikānaṃ dātabbā, dvāre pañcaṅguligharadhūpanādīsu vā upanetabbā. ‘‘Puna roge sati bhavissantī’’ti pana ṭhapetuṃ na vaṭṭati, sannidhi ca hoti, sallekhañca kopeti. Āmisanti vuttāvasesaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Seyyathidaṃ, idhekacco bhikkhu – ‘‘tathārūpe kāle upakārāya bhavissatī’’ti tilataṇḍulamuggamāsanāḷikeraloṇamacchamaṃsavallūrasappitelaguḷabhājanādīni āharāpetvā ṭhapeti. So vassakāle kālasseva sāmaṇerehi yāguṃ pacāpetvā paribhuñjitvā ‘‘sāmaṇera, udakakaddame dukkhaṃ gāmaṃ pavisituṃ, gaccha asukaṃ kulaṃ  gantvā mayhaṃ vihāre nisinnabhāvaṃ ārocehi; asukakulato dadhiādīni āharā’’ti peseti. Bhikkhūhi – ‘‘kiṃ, bhante, gāmaṃ pavisissathā’’ti vuttepi, ‘‘duppaveso, āvuso, idāni gāmo’’ti vadati. Te – ‘‘hotu, bhante, acchatha tumhe, mayaṃ bhikkhaṃ pariyesitvā āharissāmā’’ti gacchanti. Atha sāmaṇeropi dadhiādīni āharitvā bhattañca byañjanañca sampādetvā upaneti, taṃ bhuñjantasseva upaṭṭhākā bhattaṃ pahiṇanti, tatopi manāpaṃ manāpaṃ bhuñjati. Atha bhikkhū piṇḍapātaṃ gahetvā āgacchanti, tatopi manāpaṃ manāpaṃ gīvāyāmakaṃ bhuñjatiyeva. Evaṃ catumāsampi vītināmeti. Ayaṃ vuccati – ‘‘bhikkhu muṇḍakuṭumbikajīvikaṃ jīvati, na samaṇajīvika’’nti. Evarūpo āmisasannidhi nāma hoti. Bhikkhuno pana vasanaṭṭhāne ekā taṇḍulanāḷi, eko guḷapiṇḍo, catubhāgamattaṃ sappīti ettakaṃ nidhetuṃ vaṭṭati, akāle sampattacorānaṃ atthāya. Te hi ettakampi āmisapaṭisanthāraṃ alabhantā  jīvitāpi voropeyyuṃ, tasmā sace ettakaṃ natthi, āharāpetvāpi  ṭhapetuṃ vaṭṭati. Aphāsukakāle ca yadettha kappiyaṃ, taṃ attanāpi paribhuñjituṃ vaṭṭati. Kappiyakuṭiyaṃ pana bahuṃ ṭhapentassāpi sannidhi nāma natthi. Tathāgatassa pana taṇḍulanāḷiādīsu vā yaṃ kiñci caturatanamattaṃ vā pilotikakhaṇḍaṃ ‘‘idaṃ me ajja vā sve vā bhavissatī’’ti ṭhapitaṃ nāma natthi.
commentary_english:
12. "Accumulation-and-use" means the use of what has been accumulated.

Therein, there are two kinds of talk: according to the *Vinaya*, and according to self-effacement (*sallekha*).

Firstly, according to the *Vinaya*, whatever food has been accepted today becomes something to be accumulated if it is kept until the next day; in using it, there is an offense entailing confession (*pācittiya*).

But having given what was obtained by oneself to novices (*sāmaṇera*) and having had what was obtained by them kept, it is allowable to eat on the second day; but that is not self-effacement (*sallekha*).

And the same rule applies in the case of accumulating drinks.

Therein, "drink" means eight drinks beginning with mango juice, and whatever is in accordance with them.

The decision regarding them has been stated in the *Samantapāsādikā*.

In the case of accumulating robes, there is accumulation if there is a robe that has not been designated or dispensed with; and it obstructs self-effacement (*sallekha*); this is a roundabout way of speaking.

But without a roundabout way, one should be content with three robes; having obtained a fourth, it should be given to another.

If one is not able to give to just anyone, and there is someone whom one wants to give to, and he has gone for instruction or questioning, it should be given as soon as he has arrived; it is not allowable not to give.

But when a robe is lacking, it is allowable to keep it until the time allowed, expecting that it will be ready.

If one cannot obtain people who can sew robes using a needle and thread, it is allowable to perform a *Vinaya* transaction and keep it even after that.

It is not allowable to keep it thinking, "When this one is worn out, where will I obtain another like it?"; and it is accumulation, and it obstructs self-effacement (*sallekha*).

In the case of accumulating vehicles, "vehicle" means a palanquin (*vayha*), a chariot (*ratha*), a cart (*sakaṭa*), a litter (*sandamānikā*), a palanquin (*sivikā*), a sedan chair (*pāṭaṅkī*); this is not a vehicle for one who has gone forth (as a renunciate).

However, footwear (*upāhanā*) is indeed a vehicle for one who has gone forth.

For one monk, one pair of footwear is for the wilderness, and one is for washing the feet; at most, two pairs of footwear are allowable.

Having obtained a third, it should be given to another.

Indeed, it is not allowable to keep it thinking, "When this one is worn out, where will I obtain another?"; and it is accumulation, and it obstructs self-effacement (*sallekha*).

In the case of accumulating beds, "bed" means a cot (*mañca*).

For one monk, one cot is for indoors, and one is for a daytime resting place; at most, two cots are allowable.

Having obtained more than that, it should be given to another monk or to the Order; it is not allowable not to give it.

And it is accumulation, and it obstructs self-effacement (*sallekha*).

In the case of accumulating fragrances, fragrances are allowable for a monk when there is an ailment such as itching, scabies, skin disease, etc.

Having had those fragrances brought, when that disease has subsided, they should be given to others who are sick, or they should be taken to doors, five-finger houses, places of incense, etc.

It is not allowable to keep them thinking, "They will be useful when there is disease again"; and it is accumulation, and it obstructs self-effacement (*sallekha*).

"Relish" is to be understood as what has been stated above.

For example, here a certain monk—thinking, "It will be useful at such-and-such a time"—has sesame seeds, husked rice, green grams, *māsa* beans, coconut shells, salt, fish, meat, dried meat, ghee, oil, molasses, pots, etc. brought and keeps them.

In the rainy season, having had rice gruel (*yāgu*) cooked by novices early in the morning, and having consumed it, he sends a novice, saying, "Novice, it is difficult to enter the village in the mud and water. Go to such-and-such a family and announce my being in the monastery; bring curd (*dadhi*) etc. from such-and-such a family."

Even when the monks say, "Venerable sir, are you going to enter the village?", he says, "It is difficult to enter, friend, the village now."

They go thinking, "Good, venerable sir, stay here, we will search for alms and bring them."

Then that novice, having brought curd (*dadhi*) etc., and having prepared rice and side dishes, offers it; even while he is eating that, attendants send food, and he eats what is liked and liked.

Then monks take alms food (*piṇḍapāta*) and come, and he eats what is liked and liked, even what is for the neck.

In this way, he spends even four months.

This is called, "A monk lives a family life like a tonsured man, not a monastic life (*samaṇajīvika*)."

Such an accumulation of relish is what it is called.

However, in a monk's dwelling place, it is allowable to keep this much for the sake of thieves who may arrive at the wrong time: one *nāḷi* of husked rice, one lump of molasses, ghee to the amount of one quarter.

For if they do not obtain even this much means of hospitality, they might even deprive one of life; therefore, if there is not this much, it is also allowable to have it brought and kept.

And at a time of discomfort, it is allowable to use oneself whatever is allowable there.

However, even for one keeping a lot in an allowable hut, there is no accumulation.
Furthermore, the *Tathāgata* has nothing set aside, such as a measure of rice grains or anything else, or even a piece of rag that is four spans in size, thinking, "This will be mine today or tomorrow."

mula_pali: 13. ‘‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ visūkadassanaṃ anuyuttā viharanti, seyyathidaṃ – naccaṃ gītaṃ vāditaṃ pekkhaṃ akkhānaṃ pāṇissaraṃ vetāḷaṃ kumbhathūṇaṃ kumbhathūnaṃ (syā. ka.), kumbhathūṇaṃ (sī.) sobhanakaṃ sobhanagharakaṃ (sī.), sobhanagarakaṃ (syā. kaṃ. pī.) caṇḍālaṃ vaṃsaṃ dhovanaṃ hatthiyuddhaṃ assayuddhaṃ mahiṃsayuddhaṃ mahisayuddhaṃ (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī.) usabhayuddhaṃ ajayuddhaṃ meṇḍayuddhaṃ kukkuṭayuddhaṃ vaṭṭakayuddhaṃ daṇḍayuddhaṃ muṭṭhiyuddhaṃ nibbuddhaṃ uyyodhikaṃ balaggaṃ senābyūhaṃ anīkadassanaṃ iti vā iti evarūpā visūkadassanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 13. “Or, some honorable ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered in faith, remain engaged in attending such unsuitable shows as these: dancing (*nṛtyam*), singing (*gītam*), instrumental music (*vāditam*), theatrical performances, narrations, hand-clapping music (*pāṇissaraṃ*), cymbals (*vetāḷaṃ*), *kumbhathūṇaṃ*, *kumbhathūṇaṃ*, *kumbhathūṇaṃ*, displays of beautiful houses, displays of beautiful cities, the *caṇḍāla*, bamboo dances (*vaṃsaṃ*), bone-washing (*dhovanaṃ*), elephant fights (*hatthiyuddhaṃ*), horse fights (*assayuddhaṃ*), buffalo fights (*mahiṃsayuddhaṃ*), bull fights (*usabhayuddhaṃ*), goat fights (*ajayuddhaṃ*), ram fights (*meṇḍayuddhaṃ*), cock fights (*kukkuṭayuddhaṃ*), quail fights (*vaṭṭakayuddhaṃ*), stick fights (*daṇḍayuddhaṃ*), boxing (*muṭṭhiyuddhaṃ*), wrestling, military exercises, parades, and displays of troops. The ascetic Gotama refrains from attending such displays." Thus, indeed, mendicants, might an ordinary person describe the virtues of the *tathāgata*.
commentary_pali: 13. Visūkadassanesu naccaṃ nāma yaṃ kiñci naccaṃ, taṃ maggaṃ gacchantenāpi gīvaṃ pasāretvā daṭṭhuṃ na vaṭṭati. Vitthāravinicchayo panettha samantapāsādikāyaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Yathā cettha, evaṃ sabbesu sikkhāpadapaṭisaṃyuttesu suttapadesu. Ito parañhi ettakampi avatvā tattha tattha payojanamattameva vaṇṇayissāmāti. Pekkhanti naṭasamajjaṃ. Akkhānanti bhāratayujjhanādikaṃ. Yasmiṃ ṭhāne kathīyati, tattha gantumpi na vaṭṭati. Pāṇissaranti kaṃsatāḷaṃ, pāṇitāḷantipi vadanti. Vetāḷanti ghanatāḷaṃ, mantena matasarīruṭṭhāpanantipi eke. Kumbhathūṇanti caturassaambaṇakatāḷaṃ, kumbhasaddantipi eke. Sobhanakanti naṭānaṃ  abbhokkiraṇaṃ, sobhanakaraṃ vā, paṭibhānacittanti vuttaṃ hoti. Caṇḍālanti ayoguḷakīḷā, caṇḍālānaṃ sāṇadhovanakīḷātipi vadanti. Vaṃsanti veḷuṃ ussāpetvā kīḷanaṃ. Dhovananti aṭṭhidhovanaṃ, ekaccesu kira janapadesu kālaṅkate ñātake na jhāpenti, nikhaṇitvā ṭhapenti. Atha nesaṃ pūtibhūtaṃ kāyaṃ ñatvā nīharitvā aṭṭhīni dhovitvā gandhehi makkhetvā ṭhapenti. Te nakkhattakāle ekasmiṃ ṭhāne aṭṭhīni ṭhapetvā ekasmiṃ ṭhāne surādīni ṭhapetvā rodantā paridevantā suraṃ pivanti. Vuttampi cetaṃ – ‘‘atthi, bhikkhave , dakkhiṇesu janapadesu aṭṭhidhovanaṃ nāma, tattha hoti annampi pānampi khajjampi bhojjampi leyyampi peyyampi naccampi gītampi vāditampi. Atthetaṃ, bhikkhave, dhovanaṃ, netaṃ natthīti vadāmī’’ti (a. ni. 10.107). Ekacce pana indajālena aṭṭhidhovanaṃ dhovanantipi vadanti. Hatthiyuddhādīsu bhikkhuno neva hatthiādīhi saddhiṃ yujjhituṃ, na te yujjhāpetuṃ, na yujjhante daṭṭhuṃ vaṭṭati. Nibbuddhanti mallayuddhaṃ. Uyyodhikanti yattha sampahāro dissati. Balagganti balagaṇanaṭṭhānaṃ. Senābyūhanti senāniveso, sakaṭabyūhādivasena senāya nivesanaṃ. Anīkadassananti – ‘‘tayo hatthī pacchimaṃ hatthānīka’’ntiādinā (pāci. 324) nayena vuttassa anīkassa dassanaṃ.
commentary_english:
13. Inappropriate sights: it is not allowed to stretch out one's neck to watch any kind of dance (*naccaṃ*), even when going along the road.
The detailed explanation should be understood in the way already stated in the *Samantapāsādikā*.
Just as here, so in all the *sutta* passages connected with the training rules (*sikkhāpada*).
Hereafter, indeed, we will describe only the meaning in each place without saying even this much.
They watch a troupe of actors (*naṭasamajjaṃ*).
*Akkhāna* means things like battles (*bhāratayujjhanādikaṃ*).
It is not allowed even to go to the place in which it is spoken.
*Pāṇissara* means a cymbal (*kaṃsatāḷaṃ*); they also call it *pāṇitāḷaṃ*.
*Vetāḷa* means a thick cymbal (*ghanatāḷaṃ*); some say it also means raising a dead body with a mantra (*mantena matasarīruṭṭhāpanaṃ*).
*Kumbhathūṇa* means a four-sided *ambaṇaka* cymbal; some also say *kumbhasadda*.
*Sobhanaka* means scattering around by actors (*naṭānaṃ abbhokkiraṇaṃ*), or something that makes beautiful (*sobhanakaraṃ*); it is said to mean skillful thought (*paṭibhānacittaṃ*).
*Caṇḍāla* means playing with iron balls (*ayoguḷakīḷā*); they also call it the *caṇḍāla*’s game of sharpening (*sāṇadhovana*) stones.
*Vaṃsa* means playing by raising a bamboo pole (*veḷuṃ ussāpetvā kīḷanaṃ*).
*Dhovanā* means washing bones (*aṭṭhidhovanaṃ*); it seems that in some countries, when a relative has died (*kālaṅkate ñātake*), they do not cremate him, but bury him.
Then, recognizing that his body has become putrid, they take it out, wash the bones (*aṭṭhīni dhovitvā*), anoint them with perfumes, and keep them.
At the time of a festival (*nakkhattakāle*), they put the bones in one place and liquor, etc., in another place, and while weeping and lamenting, they drink liquor.
And this was said: “Monks, there is such a thing as bone-washing (*aṭṭhidhovanaṃ*) in the southern regions; there there is food, drink, things to eat, things to consume, things to lick, things to drink, dancing, singing, and music.
Monks, I say that this bone-washing exists; it is not non-existent” (A.
Ni.
10.
107).
But some say that washing bones (*aṭṭhidhovanaṃ*) is also called *dhovanā* by means of illusion (*indajālena*).
In elephant fights, etc., it is not allowed for a monk to fight with elephants, etc., nor to have them fight, nor to watch them fighting.
*Nibbuddha* means wrestling matches (*mallayuddhaṃ*).
*Uyyodhika* means wherever fighting (*sampahāro*) is seen.
*Balagga* means the place for counting the army (*balagaṇanaṭṭhānaṃ*).
*Senābyūha* means an army encampment (*senāniveso*), the arranging of the army (*senāya nivesanaṃ*) in the form of a wagon encampment, etc.
*Anīkadassana* means seeing an army (*anīkassa dassanaṃ*) which was described in the way beginning, “Three elephants [constitute] a rear elephant squadron (*hatthānīka*)” (Pāci.
324).

mula_pali: 14. ‘‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ jūtappamādaṭṭhānānuyogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti, seyyathidaṃ – aṭṭhapadaṃ dasapadaṃ ākāsaṃ parihārapathaṃ santikaṃ khalikaṃ ghaṭikaṃ salākahatthaṃ akkhaṃ paṅgacīraṃ vaṅkakaṃ mokkhacikaṃ ciṅgulikaṃ ciṅgulakaṃ (ka. sī.) pattāḷhakaṃ rathakaṃ dhanukaṃ  akkharikaṃ manesikaṃ yathāvajjaṃ iti  vā iti evarūpā jūtappamādaṭṭhānānuyogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 14. “Or he might say: “Whereas some honorable ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered in faith, indulge in the following games, which are occasions for negligence: aṭṭhapada, dasapada, ākāsa, parihārapatha, santika, khalika, ghaṭika, salākahattha, akkha, paṅgacīra, vaṅkaka, mokkhacika, ciṅgulika, pattāḷhaka, rathaka, dhanuka, akkharika, manesika, yathāvajja—the ascetic Gotama abstains from such games and recreations.” Indeed, monks, that is how an ordinary person might describe the praise of the Tathāgata.
commentary_pali: 14. Pamādo  ettha tiṭṭhatīti pamādaṭṭhānaṃ. Jūtañca taṃ pamādaṭṭhānañcāti jūtappamādaṭṭhānaṃ. Ekekāya pantiyā aṭṭha aṭṭha padāni assāti aṭṭhapadaṃ dasapadepi eseva nayo. Ākāsanti aṭṭhapadadasapadesu viya ākāseyeva kīḷanaṃ. Parihārapathanti bhūmiyaṃ nānāpathamaṇḍalaṃ katvā tattha tattha pariharitabbaṃ, pathaṃ pariharantānaṃ kīḷanaṃ. Santikanti santikakīḷanaṃ. Ekajjhaṃ ṭhapitā sāriyo vā sakkharāyo vā acālentā nakheneva apanenti ca upanenti ca, sace tattha kāci calati, parājayo hoti, evarūpāya kīḷāyetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Khalikanti jūtaphalake pāsakakīḷanaṃ. Ghaṭikā vuccati dīghadaṇḍakena rassadaṇḍakaṃ paharaṇakīḷanaṃ. Salākahatthanti lākhāya vā mañjiṭṭhikāya vā piṭṭhodakena vā salākahatthaṃ  temetvā – ‘‘kiṃ  hotū’’ti bhūmiyaṃ vā bhittiyaṃ vā taṃ paharitvā hatthiassādirūpadassanakīḷanaṃ. Akkhanti guḷakīḷā. Paṅgacīraṃ vuccati paṇṇanāḷikaṃ, taṃ dhamantā kīḷanti. Vaṅkakanti gāmadārakānaṃ kīḷanakaṃ khuddakanaṅgalaṃ. Mokkhacikā vuccati samparivattanakīḷā, ākāse vā daṇḍakaṃ gahetvā bhūmiyaṃ vā sīsaṃ ṭhapetvā heṭṭhupariyabhāvena parivattanakīḷāti vuttaṃ hoti. Ciṅgulikaṃ vuccati tālapaṇṇādīhi kataṃ vātappahārena paribbhamanacakkaṃ. Pattāḷhakaṃ vuccati paṇṇanāḷikā. Tāya vālukādīni minantā kīḷanti. Rathakanti khuddakarathaṃ. Dhanukanti khuddakadhanumeva. Akkharikā vuccati ākāse vā piṭṭhiyaṃ vā akkharajānanakīḷā. Manesikā nāma manasā cintitajānanakīḷā. Yathāvajjaṃ nāma kāṇakuṇikhujjādīnaṃ yaṃ yaṃ vajjaṃ, taṃ taṃ payojetvā dassanakīḷā.
commentary_english:
14. *Pramāda* exists here, therefore it is a *pramādaṭṭhāna*.

Gambling and that which is a place of *pramāda* is *jūtappamādaṭṭhāna*.

In each row there are eight *padas*, therefore it is *aṭṭhapada*, and the same principle applies to ten *padas*.

*Ākāsanti* means playing in the *ākāsa* as in *aṭṭhapada* and *dasapada*.

*Parihārapathanti* means having made various *pathamaṇḍalas* on the ground, one should avoid them in that location; it is playing while avoiding the path.

*Santikanti* is *santikakīḷanaṃ*.

Having placed pieces or pebbles together in one place, without moving them, they remove and add with their nails. If anything there moves, there is defeat; this is an epithet for that kind of game.

*Khalikanti* is playing dice on a gambling board.

*Ghaṭikā* is called a game of striking a short stick with a long stick.

*Salākahatthanti* means having soaked the hand with lac, *mañjiṭṭhikā*, or rice-flour water and striking the ground or wall while saying, "What will it be?" is a game of showing forms such as elephants and horses.

*Akkanti* is playing with balls.

*Paṅgacīraṃ vuccati* means a leaf-pipe; they play while blowing it.

*Vaṅkakanti* is a small plow, a plaything of village children.

*Mokkhacikā vuccati* is a game of turning around; having taken a stick in the air or having placed the head on the ground, it is said to be a game of turning around in an upward and downward manner.

*Ciṅgulikaṃ vuccati* is a revolving wheel made of palm leaves etc., by the force of the wind.

*Pattāḷhakaṃ vuccati* is a leaf-pipe.

With that, they play while measuring sand etc.

*Rathakanti* is a small chariot.

*Dhanukanti* is just a small bow.

*Akkharikā vuccati* is a game of knowing letters in the sky or on a surface.

*Manesikā nāma* is a game of knowing what is thought in the mind.

*Yathāvajjaṃ nāma* is a game of showing by applying whatever defect there is in the blind, the crippled, the hunchbacked, etc.

mula_pali: 15. ‘‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te  evarūpaṃ uccāsayanamahāsayanaṃ anuyuttā viharanti, seyyathidaṃ – āsandiṃ pallaṅkaṃ gonakaṃ cittakaṃ paṭikaṃ paṭalikaṃ tūlikaṃ vikatikaṃ uddalomiṃ ekantalomiṃ kaṭṭissaṃ koseyyaṃ kuttakaṃ hatthattharaṃ assattharaṃ rathattharaṃ hatthattharaṇaṃ assattharaṇaṃ rathattharaṇaṃ (sī. ka. pī.) ajinappaveṇiṃ kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇaṃ sauttaracchadaṃ ubhatolohitakūpadhānaṃ iti vā iti evarūpā uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 15. “Or (yathā vā pana eke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te) he might say: ‘Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins (samaṇabrāhmaṇā) remain addicted to such high and luxurious beds and seats (uccāsayanamahāsayanaṃ anuyuttā viharanti), such as: chairs (āsandiṃ), couches (pallaṅkaṃ), woollen coverlets with long fleece (gonakaṃ), variegated coverlets (cittakaṃ), white woollen coverlets (paṭikaṃ), woollen coverlets embroidered with flowers (paṭalikaṃ), quilts stuffed with cotton (tūlikaṃ), woollen coverlets embroidered with animal figures (vikatikaṃ), woollen coverlets with hair on both sides (uddalomiṃ) or on one side (ekantalomiṃ), silk coverlets (koseyyaṃ), carpets (kuttakaṃ), elephant-rugs (hatthattharaṃ or hatthattharaṇaṃ), horse-rugs (assattharaṃ or assattharaṇaṃ), chariot-rugs (rathattharaṃ or rathattharaṇaṃ), choice spreads of antelope-hide (ajinappaveṇiṃ), couches with awnings (kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇaṃ), or with red cushions at both ends (souttaracchadaṃ ubhatolohitakūpadhānaṃ), the ascetic Gotama refrains from such high and wide beds (evarūpā uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo).’ It is in this way, monks (bhikkhave), that the ordinary person (puthujjano), when speaking in praise of the Tathāgata (tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno), would speak (vadeyya)."
commentary_pali: 15.Āsandinti pamāṇātikkantāsanaṃ. Anuyuttā viharantīti idaṃ apekkhitvā pana sabbapadesu upayogavacanaṃ kataṃ. Pallaṅkoti pādesu vāḷarūpāni ṭhapetvā kato. Gonakoti dīghalomako mahākojavo, caturaṅgulādhikāni kira tassa lomāni. Cittakanti vānavicittaṃ uṇṇāmayattharaṇaṃ. Paṭikāti uṇṇāmayo setattharaṇo. Paṭalikāti  ghanapupphako uṇṇāmayattharaṇo. Yo āmalakapattotipi vuccati. Tūlikāti tiṇṇaṃ tūlānaṃ aññatarapuṇṇā tūlikā. Vikatikāti sīhabyagghādirūpavicitro uṇṇāmayattharaṇo. Uddalomīti ubhayatodasaṃ uṇṇāmayattharaṇaṃ, keci ‘‘ekatouggatapuppha’’nti vadanti. Ekantalomīti ekatodasaṃ uṇṇāmayattharaṇaṃ. Keci ‘‘ubhatouggatapuppha’’nti vadanti. Kaṭṭissanti ratanaparisibbitaṃ koseyyakaṭṭissamayapaccattharaṇaṃ. Koseyyanti ratanaparisibbitameva kosiyasuttamayapaccattharaṇaṃ. Suddhakoseyyaṃ pana vaṭṭatīti vinaye vuttaṃ. Dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana ‘‘ṭhapetvā tūlikaṃ sabbāneva gonakādīni ratanaparisibbitāni na vaṭṭantī’’ti vuttaṃ. Kuttakanti soḷasannaṃ nāṭakitthīnaṃ ṭhatvā naccanayoggaṃ uṇṇāmayattharaṇaṃ. Hatthattharaṃ assattharanti  hatthiassapiṭṭhīsu attharaṇaattharakāyeva. Rathattharepi eseva nayo. Ajinappaveṇīti ajinacammehi mañcappamāṇena sibbitvā katā  paveṇī. Kadalīmigapavarapaccattharaṇanti kadalīmigacammaṃ nāma atthi, tena kataṃ pavarapaccattharaṇaṃ; uttamapaccattharaṇanti attho. Taṃ kira setavatthassa upari kadalīmigacammaṃ pattharitvā sibbetvā karonti. Sauttaracchadanti saha uttaracchadena, uparibaddhena rattavitānena saddhinti attho. Setavitānampi heṭṭhā akappiyapaccattharaṇe sati na vaṭṭati, asati pana vaṭṭati. Ubhatolohitakūpadhānanti sīsūpadhānañca pādūpadhānañcāti  mañcassa ubhatolohitakaṃ upadhānaṃ, etaṃ na kappati. Yaṃ pana ekameva upadhānaṃ ubhosu passesu rattaṃ vā hoti padumavaṇṇaṃ vā vicitraṃ vā, sace pamāṇayuttaṃ, vaṭṭati. Mahāupadhānaṃ pana paṭikkhittaṃ. Alohitakāni dvepi vaṭṭantiyeva. Tato uttari labhitvā aññesaṃ dātabbāni. Dātuṃ asakkonto mañce tiriyaṃ attharitvā upari paccattharaṇaṃ datvā nipajjitumpi labhati. Āsandīādīsu pana vuttanayeneva paṭipajjitabbaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ – ‘‘anujānāmi, bhikkhave, āsandiyā pāde chinditvā paribhuñjituṃ, pallaṅkassa vāḷe bhinditvā paribhuñjituṃ, tūlikaṃ vijaṭetvā bimbohanaṃ kātuṃ, avasesaṃ bhummattharaṇaṃ kātu’’nti (cūḷava. 297).
commentary_english:
15. *Āsandī* means a seat exceeding the standard size.

Regarding "being engaged in dwelling," this statement is made with reference to this, but the expression "use" is applied to all instances.

*Pallaṅka* means made by placing *vāḷarūpa* on the legs.

*Gonaka* means having long hair, a large woolen rug; its hairs are said to exceed four *aṅgulas*.

*Cittaka* means a variegated woolen spread with various woven patterns.

*Paṭikā* means a woolen white spread.

*Paṭalikā* means a woolen spread with dense flowers.

It is also called *āmalakapattoti*.

*Tūlikā* means a *tūlikā* filled with one of three types of cotton.

*Vikatikā* means a woolen spread variegated with forms of lions, tigers, and other animals.

*Uddalomī* means a woolen spread with tufts on both sides; some say "having flowers sprouting on one side."

*Ekantalomī* means a woolen spread with tufts on one side.

Some say "having flowers sprouting on both sides."

*Kaṭṭissa* means a *paccattharaṇa* made of *koseyya* and *kaṭṭissa* interwoven with jewels.

*Koseyya* means a *paccattharaṇa* made of *kosiya* threads, interwoven with jewels.

It is said in the *Vinaya* that pure *koseyya* is allowable.

In the *Dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathā*, however, it is said: "Except for the *tūlika*, all *gonaka* and other spreads interwoven with jewels are not allowable."

*Kuttaka* means a woolen spread suitable for sixteen dancing girls to stand and dance on.

*Hatthattharaṃ assattharaṃ* means coverings spread on the backs of elephants and horses.

The same rule applies to carriage coverings.

*Ajinappaveṇī* means a *paveṇī* made by sewing together antelope hides to the size of a bed.

*Kadalīmigapavarapaccattharaṇaṃ* means there is something called *kadalīmigacammaṃ*, with that a superior *paccattharaṇa* is made; the meaning is an excellent spread.

It seems they spread the *kadalīmigacammaṃ* over a white cloth and sew it together to make it.

*Sauttaracchada* means with an upper covering, together with a red canopy fastened above, is the meaning.

A white canopy is not allowable if there is an unallowable *paccattharaṇa* underneath; if there is not, it is allowable.

*Ubhatolohitakūpadhānaṃ* means a pillow for the head and a pillow for the feet; a *mañca* has a red pillow on both sides, this is not allowable.

But if there is only one *upadhāna* and it is red or the color of a lotus or variegated on both sides, if it is of suitable size, it is allowable.

A large *upadhāna* is prohibited.

Even two un-reddish ones are allowable.

Having obtained more than that, they should be given to others.

If one is unable to give, one may spread it crosswise on the *mañca*, and having placed a *paccattharaṇa* on top, one may lie down.

With regard to *āsandī* and other such things, one should proceed in accordance with the method stated.

Indeed, it was said: “I allow you, monks, to use a high couch after cutting its legs down to size, to use a luxurious couch after removing the images of predatory animals, to make a pillow after removing the cotton down from the cotton-down quilt, and to make floor covers of the rest” (*Cūḷava*.
297).

mula_pali: 16. ‘‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ maṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānānuyogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti, seyyathidaṃ – ucchādanaṃ parimaddanaṃ nhāpanaṃ sambāhanaṃ ādāsaṃ añjanaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ mālāvilepanaṃ (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī.) mukhacuṇṇaṃ mukhalepanaṃ hatthabandhaṃ sikhābandhaṃ daṇḍaṃ nāḷikaṃ asiṃ khaggaṃ (sī. pī.), asiṃ khaggaṃ (syā. kaṃ.) chattaṃ citrupāhanaṃ uṇhīsaṃ maṇiṃ vālabījaniṃ odātāni vatthāni dīghadasāni iti vā iti evarūpā maṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānānuyogā  paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 16. “Or he might say: ‘Whereas some venerable ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* (brāhmaṇā), while living on the food given in faith, remain engaged in such pursuits that involve self-adornment and embellishment, such as rubbing the body with scented powder (*ucchādana*), massaging (*parimaddana*), bathing (*nhāpana*), shampooing (*sambāhana*), using mirrors (*ādāsa*), ointments (*añjana*), garlands, scents (*mālāgandhavilepana*), applying cosmetics, face-powder (*mukhacuṇṇa*), applying face-ointment (*mukhalepana*), wearing bracelets (*hatthabandha*), headbands (*sikhābandha*), carrying decorative walking sticks (*daṇḍa*), ornamented medicine tubes (*nāḷika*), swords (*asi*), rapiers (*khagga*), sunshades (*chatta*), embroidered sandals (*citrupāhana*), turbans (*uṇhīsa*), gems (*maṇi*), yak-tail fans (*vālabījani*), long-fringed white robes (*odātāni vatthāni dīghadasāni*)—the *samaṇa* Gotama refrains from such activities of self-adornment.’ Thus, *bhikkhus*, the ordinary person, when speaking in praise of the *Tathāgata*, might speak."
commentary_pali: 16. Ucchādanādīsu mātukucchito nikkhantadārakānaṃ sarīragandho dvādasavassapattakāle nassati, tesaṃ sarīraduggandhaharaṇatthāya gandhacuṇṇādīhi ucchādenti, evarūpaṃ ucchādanaṃ na vaṭṭati. Puññavante pana dārake ūrūsu nipajjāpetvā telena makkhetvā hatthapādaūrunābhiādīnaṃ saṇṭhānasampādanatthaṃ parimaddanti, evarūpaṃ parimaddanaṃ na vaṭṭati. Nhāpananti tesaṃyeva dārakānaṃ gandhādīhi nhāpanaṃ. Sambāhananti mahāmallānaṃ viya hatthapāde muggarādīhi paharitvā bāhuvaḍḍhanaṃ. Ādāsanti yaṃ kiñci ādāsaṃ pariharituṃ na vaṭṭati. Añjananti alaṅkārañjanameva. Mālāti baddhamālā vā abaddhamālā vā. Vilepananti yaṃ kiñci chavirāgakaraṇaṃ. Mukhacuṇṇaṃ mukhalepananti mukhe kāḷapīḷakādīnaṃ haraṇatthāya mattikakakkaṃ denti, tena lohite calite sāsapakakkaṃ denti, tena dose khādite tilakakkaṃ denti, tena lohite sannisinne haliddikakkaṃ denti, tena chavivaṇṇe ārūḷhe mukhacuṇṇakena mukhaṃ cuṇṇenti, taṃ sabbaṃ na vaṭṭati. Hatthabandhādīsu  hatthe vicitrasaṅkhakapālādīni bandhitvā vicaranti, taṃ vā aññaṃ vā sabbampi hatthābharaṇaṃ na vaṭṭati, apare sikhaṃ bandhitvā vicaranti. Suvaṇṇacīrakamuttalatādīhi ca  taṃ parikkhipanti; taṃ sabbaṃ na vaṭṭati. Apare catuhatthadaṇḍaṃ vā aññaṃ vā pana alaṅkatadaṇḍakaṃ gahetvā vicaranti, tathā itthipurisarūpādivicittaṃ bhesajjanāḷikaṃ suparikkhittaṃ vāmapasse olaggitaṃ; apare kaṇṇikaratanaparikkhittakosaṃ atitikhiṇaṃ asiṃ, pañcavaṇṇasuttasibbitaṃ makaradantakādivicittaṃ chattaṃ, suvaṇṇarajatādivicitrā morapiñchādiparikkhittā upāhanā, keci ratanamattāyāmaṃ caturaṅgulavitthataṃ kesantaparicchedaṃ dassetvā meghamukhe vijjulataṃ viya nalāṭe uṇhīsapaṭṭaṃ bandhanti, cūḷāmaṇiṃ dhārenti, cāmaravālabījaniṃ dhārenti, taṃ sabbaṃ na vaṭṭati.
commentary_english:
16. In the matter of cleaning and rubbing the body etc. (*ucchādanādi*): the body odor of infants who have emerged from their mother's womb disappears after twelve years. To remove the bad smell of their bodies, they clean or rub them with fragrant powders, etc. Such cleaning is not allowed.

Furthermore, if they were to have a fortunate child lie on their thighs, rub oil on him, and massage his hands, feet, thighs, navel, etc. (*hatthapādaūrunābhiādi*) in order to develop their proper form, such massage is not allowed.

Bathing (*nhāpana*) means bathing those same infants with fragrance etc. (*gandhadi*).

*Saṃbāhana* means developing the arms by striking the hands and feet of great wrestlers with clubs, etc. (*muggarādi*).

*Ādāsa* means that it is not allowed to avoid any kind of mirror.

*Añjana* means only the act of decorating with ointment (*alaṅkārañjana*).

*Mālā* means either a bound garland (*baddhamālā*) or an unbound garland (*abaddhamālā*).

*Vilepana* means any kind of coloring of the skin (*chavirāgakaraṇa*).

*Mukhacuṇṇa* and *mukhalepana* mean that they give clay paste (*mattikakakka*) to remove blackheads etc. (*kāḷapīḷakādi*) on the face; when the blood moves, they give mustard paste (*sāsapakakka*); when the *doṣa* is consumed, they give sesame paste (*tilakakka*); when the blood is settled, they give turmeric paste (*haliddikakka*); when the skin color is raised, they powder the face with face powder (*mukhacuṇṇakena*). All that is not allowed.

In the matter of hand ornaments etc. (*hatthabandhādi*): they wander around tying various conch shells and skull fragments (*vicitrasaṅkhakapālādīni*) on their hands. That, or any other kind of hand ornament (*hatthābharaṇa*), is not allowed. Others wander around tying up their hair (*sikhāṃ bandhitvā*).

They surround it with gold thread, pearl vines, etc. (*suvarṇacīrakamuttalatādi*); all that is not allowed.

Others wander around carrying a decorated staff (*alaṅkatadaṇḍaka*) of four cubits length (*catuhatthadaṇḍa*), or any other kind of staff, and also a well-decorated medicine tube (*bhesajjanāḷika*) with various forms of men and women, etc. (*itthipurisarūpādi*) hanging on their left side (*vāmapasse olaggitaṃ*); others [carry] a very sharp sword (*asiṃ atitikhiṇaṃ*) in a sheath surrounded by *kaṇṇika* jewels (*kaṇṇikaratanaparikkhittakosaṃ*), a parasol (*chattaṃ*) sewn with five-colored thread (*pañcavaṇṇasuttasibbitaṃ*), decorated with crocodile teeth, etc. (*makaradantakādi*), sandals (*upāhanā*) decorated with various gold, silver, etc. (*suvaṇṇarajatādi*), surrounded by peacock feathers, etc. (*morapiñchādi*). Some, showing a hair parting (*kesantaparicchedaṃ dassetvā*) that is a *ratana* measure in length and four *aṅgulas* in width, tie a turban band (*uṇhīsapaṭṭaṃ bandhanti*) on their forehead (*nalāṭe*) like a lightning flash (*vijjulataṃ viya*) in a cloud's face (*meghamukhe*), wear a crest jewel (*cūḷāmaṇiṃ dhārenti*), carry a yak-tail fan (*cāmaravālabījaniṃ dhārenti*). All that is not allowed.

mula_pali: 17. ‘‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ anuyuttā viharanti, seyyathidaṃ – rājakathaṃ corakathaṃ mahāmattakathaṃ senākathaṃ bhayakathaṃ yuddhakathaṃ annakathaṃ pānakathaṃ vatthakathaṃ sayanakathaṃ mālākathaṃ gandhakathaṃ ñātikathaṃ yānakathaṃ gāmakathaṃ nigamakathaṃ nagarakathaṃ janapadakathaṃ itthikathaṃ itthikathaṃ purisakathaṃ (syā. kaṃ. ka.) sūrakathaṃ  visikhākathaṃ kumbhaṭṭhānakathaṃ pubbapetakathaṃ nānattakathaṃ lokakkhāyikaṃ samuddakkhāyikaṃ itibhavābhavakathaṃ iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānakathāya paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 17. “Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on the food offered in faith, engage in frivolous talk (tiracchānakathaṃ), such as talk about kings (rājakathaṃ), talk about thieves (corakathaṃ), talk about high officials (mahāmattakathaṃ), talk about armies (senākathaṃ), talk about dangers (bhayakathaṃ), talk about wars (yuddhakathaṃ), talk about food (annakathaṃ), talk about drink (pānakathaṃ), talk about clothes (vatthakathaṃ), talk about beds (sayanakathaṃ), talk about garlands (mālākathaṃ), talk about perfumes (gandhakathaṃ), talk about relatives (ñātikathaṃ), talk about vehicles (yānakathaṃ), talk about villages (gāmakathaṃ), talk about market towns (nigamakathaṃ), talk about cities (nagarakathaṃ), talk about countries (janapadakathaṃ), talk about women (itthikathaṃ), talk about men (purisakathaṃ), talk about heroes (sūrakathaṃ), street gossip (visikhākathaṃ), talk at the well (kumbhaṭṭhānakathaṃ), talk about departed ancestors (pubbapetakathaṃ), varied talk (nānattakathaṃ), worldly stories (lokakkhāyikaṃ), sea stories (samuddakkhāyikaṃ), talk about being and non-being (itibhavābhavakathaṃ), the ascetic Gotama abstains from such frivolous talk. Thus, bhikkhus, the ordinary person, when speaking in praise of the Tathāgata, might speak."
commentary_pali: 17. Aniyyānikattā saggamokkhamaggānaṃ tiracchānabhūtā kathāti tiracchānakathā. Tattha rājānaṃ ārabbha mahāsammato mandhātā dhammāsoko evaṃ mahānubhāvotiādinā nayena pavattā kathā rājakathā. Esa nayo corakathādīsu. Tesu asuko rājā abhirūpo dassanīyotiādinā nayena gehassitakathāva tiracchānakathā hoti. Sopi nāma evaṃ mahānubhāvo khayaṃ gatoti evaṃ pavattā pana kammaṭṭhānabhāve tiṭṭhati. Coresu mūladevo evaṃ mahānubhāvo, meghamālo evaṃ mahānubhāvoti tesaṃ kammaṃ paṭicca aho sūrāti gehassitakathāva tiracchānakathā. Yuddhepi bhāratayuddhādīsu asukena asuko evaṃ mārito, evaṃ viddhoti kāmassādavaseneva kathā tiracchānakathā. Tepi nāma khayaṃ gatāti evaṃ pavattā pana sabbattha kammaṭṭhānameva hoti. Api ca annādīsu evaṃ vaṇṇavantaṃ gandhavantaṃ rasavantaṃ phassasampannaṃ khādimha bhuñjimhāti kāmassādavasena kathetuṃ na vaṭṭati. Sātthakaṃ  pana katvā pubbe evaṃ vaṇṇādisampannaṃ annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ sayanaṃ mālaṃ gandhaṃ sīlavantānaṃ adamha, cetiye pūjaṃ karimhāti kathetuṃ vaṭṭati. Ñātikathādīsu pana ‘‘amhākaṃ ñātakā sūrā samatthā’’ti vā ‘‘pubbe mayaṃ evaṃ vicitrehi yānehi vicarimhā’’ti vā assādavasena vattuṃ na vaṭṭati. Sātthakaṃ pana katvā ‘‘tepi no ñātakā khayaṃ gatā’’ti vā ‘‘pubbe mayaṃ evarūpā upāhanā saṅghassa adamhā’’ti vā kathetuṃ vaṭṭati. Gāmakathāpi suniviṭṭhadunniviṭṭhasubhikkhadubbhikkhādivasena vā ‘‘asukagāmavāsino sūrā samatthā’’ti  vā evaṃ assādavasena na vaṭṭati. Sātthakaṃ pana katvā ‘‘saddhā pasannā’’ti vā ‘‘khayavayaṃ gatā’’ti vā vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Nigamanagarajanapadakathādīsupi eseva nayo. Itthikathāpi vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādīni paṭicca assādavasena na vaṭṭati, saddhā pasannā khayavayaṃ gatāti evameva vaṭṭati. Sūrakathāpi ‘nandimitto nāma yodho sūro ahosī’ti assādavasena na vaṭṭati. Saddho ahosi khayaṃ gatoti evameva vaṭṭati. Visikhākathāpi ‘‘asukā  visikhā suniviṭṭhā dunniviṭṭhā sūrā samatthā’’ti assādavasena na vaṭṭati. Saddhā pasannā khayavayaṃ gatāti evameva vaṭṭati. Kumbhaṭṭhānakathāti udakaṭṭhānakathā, udakatitthakathātipi vuccati, kumbhadāsikathā vā, sāpi ‘‘pāsādikā naccituṃ gāyituṃ chekā’’ti assādavasena na vaṭṭati; saddhā pasannātiādinā nayeneva vaṭṭati. Pubbapetakathāti atītañātikathā. Tattha vattamānañātikathāsadiso vinicchayo. Nānattakathāti purimapacchimakathāhi vimuttā avasesā nānāsabhāvā niratthakakathā. Lokakkhāyikāti ayaṃ loko kena nimmito, asukena nāma  nimmito. Kāko seto, aṭṭhīnaṃ setattā; balākā rattā. Lohitassa rattattāti evamādikā lokāyatavitaṇḍasallāpakathā. Samuddakkhāyikā nāma kasmā samuddo sāgaro? Sāgaradevena khato, tasmā sāgaro. Khato meti hatthamuddāya sayaṃ niveditattā ‘‘samuddo’’ti evamādikā niratthakā samuddakkhāyanakathā. Bhavoti vuḍḍhi. Abhavoti hāni. Iti bhavo, iti abhavoti yaṃ vā taṃ vā niratthakakāraṇaṃ vatvā pavattitakathā itibhavābhavakathā.
commentary_english:
17. Talk that is contrary to leading to heaven and liberation is animal talk (*tiracchānakathā*).

Regarding that, talk about a king, proceeding in this way: "Mahāsammata, Mandhāta, Dhammaśoka had such great power," is talk of kings (*rājakathā*).

This is the way with talk of thieves and so on.

Among these, talk such as, "Such and such a king is handsome and good-looking," is worldly talk and also animal talk (*tiracchānakathā*).

But when it proceeds, "So and so, who was so powerful, came to destruction," it remains within the realm of meditation.

Among thieves, "Mūladeva was so powerful, Meghamāla was so powerful," considering their actions, "Oh, hero!" is worldly talk and also animal talk (*tiracchānakathā*).

And in battle, "In the Bhārata battle and so on, so and so was killed thus, was wounded thus," talk driven by satisfaction of sense-desires is animal talk (*tiracchānakathā*).

But when it proceeds, "Even they came to destruction," then talk in each case conforms to a meditation subject (*kammaṭṭhāna*).

Moreover, in regard to food and so forth, it is not right to talk according to the satisfaction of sense-desires, saying, "We chewed, we ate, we drank, we used what looked like this, smelled like this, tasted like this, was like this to touch."

But it is right to speak meaningfully, doing thus: "Formerly, we gave food, drink, clothing, beds, garlands, and perfumes that looked like this and so on to the virtuous; we made such offerings at the shrine."

Regarding talk of relatives and so on, it is not right to say, driven by satisfaction of sense-desires, "Our relatives are brave and capable," or "Formerly, we went about in such diverse vehicles."

But it is right to speak meaningfully, doing thus: "Even those relatives of ours have passed away," or "Formerly, we gave sandals like this to the Order (*saṃgha*)."

Talk of villages, whether they are good or bad to live in, easy or hard to get alms in, or "The inhabitants of such and such a village are brave and capable," is not right if driven by satisfaction of sense-desires.

But it is right to speak meaningfully, doing thus: "They have faith (*śraddhā*), they have confidence (*prasanna*)," or "They have come to destruction and have passed away."

The same method applies to talk of market towns, cities, districts, and so on.

Talk of women, dwelling on appearance, figure, and so forth, is not right if driven by satisfaction of sense-desires; only if it proceeds thus: "They have faith (*śraddhā*), [they are] confident (*prasanna*), [they] have come to destruction and dissolution" is it right.

Talk of heroes, saying, "Nandimitta was a soldier, a hero," is not right if driven by satisfaction of sense-desires.

Only if it proceeds thus: "He had faith (*śraddhā*), he has come to destruction," is it right.

Talk of street inhabitants, saying, "The people of such and such a street are easy to live with, brave, capable," is not right if driven by satisfaction of sense-desires.

Only if it proceeds thus: "They have faith (*śraddhā*), [they are] confident (*prasanna*), [they] have come to destruction and dissolution" is it right.

Talk of the bathing place is talk of the water-station, talk of the water-ford is also said, or talk of the servant girl at the water pot. Even that, "She is delightful, skilled in dancing and singing," is not right if driven by satisfaction of sense-desires; only with the method beginning with "They have faith (*śraddhā*), [they are] confident (*prasanna*)" is it right.

Talk of the dead is talk of past relatives (*atītañātikathā*).

The definition there is similar to talk of present relatives.

Talk of trivialities is meaningless talk of different kinds (*nānāsabhāvā*) that is not included in the former and later talk.

Talk of the origin of the world is, "This world was created by whom? It was created by so and so."

"A crow is white because its bones are white; a crane is red."

"Because its blood is red"—talk of this kind is talk of the Lokāyatas, sophists (*vitaṇḍa*), and chatter (*sallāpa*).

Talk of the origin of the sea is: "Why is the sea (*samudda*) called *sāgara*? Because it was excavated by the god Sāgara, therefore [it is called] *sāgara*."

"It was excavated by me," because he himself declared it with a hand gesture (*hatthamuddā*), "[it is called] sea (*samudda*)"—talk of this kind is meaningless talk of the origin of the sea.

Being (*bhava*) is growth (*vuḍḍhi*).

Non-being (*abhava*) is decline (*hāni*).

Saying, "Thus there is being (*bhava*), thus there is non-being (*abhava*)," talk asserting that for some meaningless reason or other there is consequently existence; there is consequently non-existence, is talk of being and non-being.

mula_pali: 18. ‘‘‘Yathā  vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ viggāhikakathaṃ anuyuttā viharanti, seyyathidaṃ – na tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāsi, ahaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāmi, kiṃ tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānissasi, micchā paṭipanno tvamasi, ahamasmi sammā paṭipanno, sahitaṃ me, asahitaṃ te, purevacanīyaṃ pacchā avaca, pacchāvacanīyaṃ pure avaca, adhiciṇṇaṃ te viparāvattaṃ, āropito te vādo, niggahito tvamasi, cara vādappamokkhāya, nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosīti iti vā iti evarūpāya viggāhikakathāya  paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 18. “Or he might say: ‘Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on the food offered by the faithful, engage in wrangling argumentation, such as: “You don’t understand this *dharma* and *vinaya* (doctrine and discipline) — I do!” “How could you understand this *dharma* and *vinaya*?” “Your way is all wrong — mine is right!” “I am consistent — you aren’t!” “You said last what you should have said first, and you said first what you should have said last!” “What you took so long to think up has been refuted!” “Your argument has been overthrown, you’re defeated!” “Go on, save your doctrine!” “Unravel it if you can!” the *śramaṇa* (ascetic) Gotama abstains from such wrangling argumentation.’ Thus it is, *bhikkhus* (monks), that an ordinary person, when speaking in praise of the *Tathāgata* (Thus Gone One), might speak.
commentary_pali: 18.Viggāhikakathāti viggahakathā, sārambhakathā. Tattha sahitaṃ meti mayhaṃ vacanaṃ sahitaṃ siliṭṭhaṃ atthayuttaṃ kāraṇayuttanti attho. Asahitaṃ teti tuyhaṃ vacanaṃ asahitaṃ asiliṭṭhaṃ. Adhiciṇṇaṃ te viparāvattanti yaṃ tuyhaṃ dīgharattāciṇṇavasena suppaguṇaṃ, taṃ mayhaṃ ekavacaneneva viparāvattaṃ parivattitvā ṭhitaṃ, na kiñci jānāsīti attho. Āropitote vādoti mayā tava doso āropito. Cara vādappamokkhāyāti dosamocanatthaṃ cara, vicara; tattha tattha gantvā sikkhāti attho. Nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosīti atha sayaṃ pahosi, idānimeva nibbeṭhehīti.
commentary_english:
18. *Viggāhikakathā* means *viggahakathā*, which means *sārambhakathā*.
There, "My words are coherent, distinct, meaningful, and based on reason," is the meaning.
"Your words are incoherent and indistinct."
"What you have long been accustomed to, because of prolonged familiarity, is well-established, whereas what I state with a single word has been overturned and transformed; you know nothing," is the meaning.
"I have attributed a fault to you, claiming, 'A charge has been brought against you.'"
"Conduct yourself so as to be released from the charge, practice so as to be freed from the fault; go here and there and train," is the meaning.
"Unravel it! Or, if you are able to, then if you are able yourself, unravel it right now!"

mula_pali: 19. ‘‘‘Yathā  vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti, seyyathidaṃ – raññaṃ, rājamahāmattānaṃ, khattiyānaṃ, brāhmaṇānaṃ, gahapatikānaṃ, kumārānaṃ ‘‘idha gaccha, amutrāgaccha, idaṃ hara, amutra idaṃ āharā’’ti iti vā iti evarūpā dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 19. “Or, he might say: ‘Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, after consuming food given in faith (saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni), remain engaged in running errands and messages (dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti) for kings (raññaṃ), ministers of state (rājamahāmattānaṃ), nobles (khattiyānaṃ), Brahmins (brāhmaṇānaṃ), householders (gahapatikānaṃ), or youths (kumārānaṃ), saying: “Go here (idha gaccha), go there (amutrāgaccha), take this (idaṃ hara), bring that from there (amutra idaṃ āharā)”’—the ascetic Gotama refrains from such errand-running (dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo).’ Thus, monks (bhikkhave), an ordinary person (puthujjano), speaking in praise (vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno) of the Tathāgata (tathāgatassa), might speak (vadeyya).
commentary_pali: 19. Dūteyyakathāyaṃ idha gacchāti ito asukaṃ nāma ṭhānaṃ gaccha. Amutrāgacchāti tato asukaṃ nāma ṭhānaṃ āgaccha. Idaṃ harāti ito idaṃ nāma hara. Amutra idaṃ āharāti asukaṭṭhānato  idaṃ nāma idha āhara. Saṅkhepato pana idaṃ dūteyyaṃ nāma ṭhapetvā pañca sahadhammike ratanattayassa upakārapaṭisaṃyuttañca gihīsāsanaṃ aññesaṃ na vaṭṭati.
commentary_english:
19. In the matter of sending a messenger, "go here," meaning "go from here to a place called such-and-such."
"Come there," meaning "come from there to a place called such-and-such."
"Take this," meaning "take this from here."
"Bring this there," meaning "bring this from such-and-such a place here."
In brief, furthermore, having established this as a matter for messengers, the five qualities in accordance with the Dharma, connected with the benefit of the Triple Gem, and the teaching for householders, do not befit others.

mula_pali: 20. ‘‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te kuhakā ca honti, lapakā ca nemittikā ca nippesikā ca, lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīṃsitāro ca lābhena lābhaṃ nijigiṃ bhitāro (sī. syā.), lābhena ca lābhaṃ nijigīsitāro (pī.) iti iti vā, iti (syā. kaṃ. ka.) evarūpā kuhanalapanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 20. “Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered by the faithful, are given to scheming (*kuhakā*), chattering (*lapakā*), hinting (*naimittikā*), belittling (*nippesikā*), and pursuing gain with gain (*lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīṃsitāro ca*), the ascetic Gotama abstains from such kinds of scheming and talking (*evarūpā kuhanalapanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti*).” It is in this way, *bhikkhus*, that a worldling (*puthujjanaḥ*) would speak when speaking in praise of the *Tathāgata*.'
commentary_pali: 20.Kuhakātiādīsu tividhena kuhanavatthunā lokaṃ kuhayanti, vimhāpayantīti kuhakā. Lābhasakkāratthikā hutvā lapantīti lapakā. Nimittaṃ sīlametesanti nemittikā. Nippeso sīlametesanti nippesikā. Lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīsanti  magganti pariyesantīti lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīsitāro. Kuhanā, lapanā, nemittikatā, nippesikatā, lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīsanatāti etāhi samannāgatānaṃ puggalānaṃ etaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthārena panetā kuhanādikā visuddhimagge sīlaniddeseyeva pāḷiñca aṭṭhakathañca āharitvā pakāsitāti.
commentary_english:
20. Because they deceive and astonish the world with threefold deceptive things, beginning with *kuhakāti*, they are called *kuhaka*.

Because they become attached to gain and honor, and they prattle, they are called *lapaka*.

Because they make a sign ( *nimittaṃ*) of virtue (*sīla*), they are called *naimittika*.

Because they make a pressure (*nippeso*) of virtue (*sīla*), they are called *nippesika*.

Because they seek and search for gain through gain, they are called those who seek gain through gain (*lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīsitāro*).

Scheming (*kuhanā*), talking (*lapanā*), hinting (*naimittikatā*), belittling (*nippesikatā*), pursuing gain with gain (*lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīsanatā*)—this is an appellation for persons endowed with these qualities.

This is a brief explanation (*ayamettha saṅkhepo*).

But these things, beginning with scheming (*kuhanā*), have been explained in detail in the *Visuddhimagga*, in the section on virtue (*sīlaniddese*), by bringing in both the Pali canon and the commentaries.

mula_pali: 21. ‘‘‘Yathā  vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti , seyyathidaṃ – aṅgaṃ nimittaṃ uppātaṃ supinaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ mūsikacchinnaṃ aggihomaṃ dabbihomaṃ thusahomaṃ kaṇahomaṃ taṇḍulahomaṃ sappihomaṃ telahomaṃ mukhahomaṃ lohitahomaṃ aṅgavijjā vatthuvijjā  khattavijjā khettavijjā (bahūsu) sivavijjā bhūtavijjā bhūrivijjā ahivijjā visavijjā vicchikavijjā mūsikavijjā sakuṇavijjā vāyasavijjā pakkajjhānaṃ saraparittāṇaṃ migacakkaṃ iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 21. “Or he might say: ‘Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on the food offered by the faithful, earn their living by wrong means of livelihood, by such base arts as: telling fortunes from the marks on a person’s limbs (*aṅga*), divining by means of omens (*nimitta*) and signs, portents (*uppāta*), dreams (*supina*), body marks (*lakkhaṇa*), divination from what mice have gnawed (*mūsikacchinnaṃ*), fire oblations (*aggihomaṃ*), oblations from a ladle (*dabbihomaṃ*), oblations of husks (*thusahomaṃ*), oblations of rice-powder (*kaṇahomaṃ*), oblations of rice grains (*taṇḍulahomaṃ*), oblations of ghee (*sappihomaṃ*), oblations of oil (*telahomaṃ*), oblations from the mouth (*mukhahomaṃ*), oblations of blood (*lohitahomaṃ*), reading the finger-tips (*aṅgavijjā*), house and garden lore (*vatthuvijjā*), skill in charms (*khattavijjā*), ghost lore (*bhūtavijjā*), earth-house lore (*bhūrivijjā*), snake lore (*ahivijjā*), poison lore (*visavijjā*), scorpion lore (*vicchikavijjā*), rat lore (*mūsikavijjā*), bird lore (*sakuṇavijjā*), crow lore (*vāyasavijjā*), guessing the future based on the wings, charms to protect oneself from arrows, interpreting the circles made by deer’—the ascetic Gotama refrains from such wrong means of livelihood. Thus, monks, might an ordinary person, when speaking in praise of the *Tathāgata*, speak."
commentary_pali: 21. Ito paraṃ mahāsīlaṃ hoti. Aṅganti hatthapādādīsu yena kenaci evarūpena aṅgena samannāgato dīghāyu yasavā hotītiādinayappavattaṃ aṅgasatthaṃ. Nimittanti nimittasatthaṃ. Paṇḍurājā kira tisso muttāyo muṭṭhiyaṃ katvā nemittikaṃ pucchi – ‘‘kiṃ me hatthe’’ti? So ito cito ca vilokesi, tasmiñca samaye gharagolikāya makkhikā gayhantī muttā, so ‘‘muttā’’ti āha. Puna ‘‘katī’’ti puṭṭho kukkuṭassa tikkhattuṃ ravantassa saddaṃ sutvā ‘‘tisso’’ti āha. Evaṃ taṃ taṃ ādisitvā nimittamanuyuttā viharanti. Uppātanti  asanipātādīnaṃ mahantānaṃ uppatitaṃ, tañhi disvā ‘‘idaṃ bhavissati, evaṃ bhavissatī’’ti ādisanti. Supinanti yo pubbaṇhasamaye supinaṃ passati, evaṃ vipāko hoti; yo idaṃ nāma passati, tassa idaṃ nāma hotītiādinā nayena supinakaṃ anuyuttā viharanti. Lakkhaṇanti iminā lakkhaṇena samannāgato rājā hoti, iminā uparājātiādikaṃ. Mūsikacchinnanti undūrakhāyitaṃ. Tenāpi hi ahate vā vatthe anahate vā vatthe ito paṭṭhāya evaṃ chinne idaṃ nāma hotīti ādisanti. Aggihomanti  evarūpena dārunā evaṃ  hute idaṃ nāma hotīti aggijuhanaṃ. Dabbihomādīnipi aggihomāneva, evarūpāya dabbiyā īdisehi kaṇādīhi hute idaṃ nāma hotīti evaṃ pavattivasena pana visuṃ vuttāni. Tattha kaṇoti kuṇḍako. Taṇḍulāti sāliādīnañceva tiṇajātīnañca taṇḍulā. Sappīti gosappiādikaṃ. Telanti tilatelādikaṃ. Sāsapādīni pana mukhena gahetvā aggimhi pakkhipanaṃ, vijjaṃ parijappitvā juhanaṃ vā mukhahomaṃ. Dakkhiṇakkhakajaṇṇulohitādīhi juhanaṃ lohitahomaṃ. Aṅgavijjāti pubbe aṅgameva disvā byākaraṇavasena aṅgaṃ vuttaṃ, idha aṅgulaṭṭhiṃ disvā vijjaṃ parijappitvā ayaṃ kulaputto vā no vā, sirīsampanno vā no vātiādibyākaraṇavasena aṅgavijjā vuttā. Vatthuvijjāti gharavatthuārāmavatthādīnaṃ guṇadosasallakkhaṇavijjā. Mattikādivisesaṃ disvāpi hi vijjaṃ parijappitvā heṭṭhā pathaviyaṃ tiṃsaratanamatte, ākāse ca asītiratanamatte padese guṇadosaṃ passanti. Khattavijjāti abbheyyamāsurakkharājasatthādisatthaṃ. Sivavijjāti susāne pavisitvā santikaraṇavijjā, siṅgālarutavijjātipi vadanti. Bhūtavijjāti bhūtavejjamanto. Bhūrivijjāti bhūrighare vasantena uggahetabbamanto. Ahivijjāti sappadaṭṭhatikicchanavijjā ceva sappāvhāyanavijjā ca. Visavijjāti yāya, purāṇavisaṃ vā rakkhanti, navavisaṃ vā karonti visavantameva vā. Vicchikavijjāti vicchikadaṭṭhatikicchanavijjā. Mūsikavijjāyapi  eseva nayo. Sakuṇavijjāti sapakkhakaapakkhakadvipadacatuppadānaṃ rutagatādivasena sakuṇañāṇaṃ. Vāyasavijjāti kākarutañāṇaṃ, taṃ visuññeva satthaṃ, tasmā  visuṃ vuttaṃ. Pakkajjhānanti paripākagatacintā. Idāni ‘‘ayaṃ ettakaṃ jīvissati, ayaṃ ettaka’’nti evaṃ pavattaṃ ādiṭṭhañāṇanti attho. Saraparittāṇanti sararakkhaṇaṃ, yathā attano upari na āgacchati, evaṃ karaṇavijjā. Migacakkanti idaṃ sabbasaṅgāhikaṃ sabbasakuṇacatuppadānaṃ rutañāṇavasena vuttaṃ.
commentary_english:
21. Now, as for the higher morality ( *mahāsīlaṃ* ) .

*Aṅga*: the *aṅgasatthaṃ* is so called because it deals with the science of bodily marks (*aṅga*), stating that a person endowed with such and such a mark in his hands, feet, etc., will be long-lived and famous.

*Nimitta* means the science of omens (*nimittasatthaṃ*).

It is said that King Paṇḍu once held three pearls in his fist and asked an interpreter of omens, “What is in my hand?” The latter looked here and there, and at that moment a house-lizard caught a fly and dropped a pearl. So he said, “Pearls!”

Again, when asked, “How many?” on hearing the sound of a cock crowing three times, he said, “Three!”

Thus, having instructed them in this and that, they live devoted to omens.

*Uppāta* means the great portents such as the falling of thunderbolts, etc. On seeing them, they declare, “This will happen, thus it will happen.”

*Supina* means that if someone sees a dream early in the morning, such and such will be the result; if someone sees such and such a thing, such and such will happen to him. In this way, they live devoted to dream interpretation.

*Lakkhaṇa* means that a king is endowed with such and such marks; this one will be a sub-king, etc.

*Mūsikacchinna* means gnawed by mice (*undūrakhāyitaṃ*).

Furthermore, if a cloth, whether new (*ahata*) or old (*anahata*), is cut thus and so from here onwards, such and such will be the result. Thus they declare.

*Aggihoma* means offering into the fire. If an offering (*hute*) of this kind is made with wood of this nature, such and such will be the result; hence, the act of offering into the fire (*aggijuhanaṃ*).

*Dabbihoma*, etc., are also kinds of fire offerings (*aggihoma*). But because it is said that if an offering is made with a ladle (*dabbiyā*) of this kind, with grains (*kaṇādīhi*) of this sort, such and such will be the result, they are stated separately according to the course of events.

There, *kaṇoti* means a winnowing basket (*kuṇḍako*).

*Taṇḍula* means grains of rice (*sāli*) and other cereals (*tiṇajātīnaṃ taṇḍulā*).

*Sappi* means ghee made from cow’s milk (*gosappiādikaṃ*).

*Tela* means sesame oil, etc. (*tilatelādikaṃ*).

Furthermore, taking mustard seeds (*sāsapādīni*) in the mouth and throwing them into the fire, muttering spells (*vijjaṃ parijappitvā*), is called a mouth-oblation (*mukhahomaṃ*).

Offering with the right eye, knee, blood, etc. (*dakkhiṇakkhakajaṇṇulohitādīhi*), is called a blood-oblation (*lohitahomaṃ*).

*Aṅgavijjā*: Previously, *aṅga* was stated because having seen a limb (*aṅgameva*) itself, the limb is stated based on grammar (*byākaraṇavasena*). Here, having seen a measuring rod (*aṅgulaṭṭhiṃ*) and having calculated the science (*vijjaṃ parijappitvā*), this one is either a family man or not, either endowed with glory or not; thus, *aṅgavijjā* is stated based on the grammar, etc.

*Vatthuvijjā* is the science of discerning the merits and demerits of house sites, park sites, etc. (*gharavatthuārāmavatthādīnaṃ guṇadosasallakkhaṇavijjā*).

Having seen the special qualities of the soil (*mattikādivisesaṃ*), and having calculated the science, they see the merits and demerits in a region thirty *ratanas* below the earth (*pathaviyaṃ*) and eighty *ratanas* above in the sky (*ākāse*).

*Khattavijjā* means sciences (*sattha*) such as archery (*abbheyyam*), secret lore (*āsurakkhara*), royal science (*rājasattha*), and so on.

*Sivavijjā* is the science of pacification practiced by entering a charnel ground (*susāne pavisitvā santikaraṇavijjā*); some also call it jackal-howling science (*siṅgālarutavijjātipi vadanti*).

*Bhūtavijjā* means a mantra for dealing with spirits (*bhūtavejjamanto*).

*Bhūrivijjā* means a mantra which should be learned while dwelling in a Bhūri house (*bhūrighare vasantena uggahetabbamanto*).

*Ahivijjā* means the science of treating snake bites (*sappadaṭṭhatikicchanavijjā*), as well as the science of snake charming (*sappāvhāyanavijjā*).

*Visavijjā*: By means of which they either protect old poison (*purāṇavisaṃ rakkhanti*), create new poison (*navavisaṃ karonti*), or simply make poisonless (*visavantameva vā*).

*Vicchikavijjā* means the science of treating scorpion stings (*vicchikadaṭṭhatikicchanavijjā*).

The same rule applies to mouse-science (*mūsikavijjāyapi eseva nayo*).

*Sakuṇavijjā* means bird-lore (*sakuṇañāṇaṃ*) based on the cries, gait, etc. of winged (*sapakkhaka*), wingless (*apakkhaka*), two-footed (*dvipada*), and four-footed (*catuppadānaṃ*) creatures.

*Vāyasavijjā* means crow-cry-lore (*kākarutañāṇaṃ*); this is a separate science (*satthaṃ*), therefore it is stated separately.

*Pakkajjhāna* means thought that has reached maturity (*paripākagatacintā*).

Now, the meaning is that "this one will live so long, that one so long," thus proceeding, is called knowledge of prediction (*ādiṭṭhañāṇanti attho*).

*Saraparittāṇa* means protection from arrows (*sararakkhaṇaṃ*), such that the arrow does not come upon oneself; this is the science of repelling arrows (*karaṇavijjā*).

*Migacakka* means this is all-inclusive, stated based on knowledge of the cries of all birds and quadrupeds (*idaṃ sabbasaṅgāhikaṃ sabbasakuṇacatuppadānaṃ rutañāṇavasena vuttaṃ*).
