mula_pali: 22. ‘‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti, seyyathidaṃ – maṇilakkhaṇaṃ vatthalakkhaṇaṃ daṇḍalakkhaṇaṃ satthalakkhaṇaṃ asilakkhaṇaṃ usulakkhaṇaṃ dhanulakkhaṇaṃ āvudhalakkhaṇaṃ itthilakkhaṇaṃ purisalakkhaṇaṃ kumāralakkhaṇaṃ kumārilakkhaṇaṃ dāsalakkhaṇaṃ dāsilakkhaṇaṃ hatthilakkhaṇaṃ  assalakkhaṇaṃ mahiṃsalakkhaṇaṃ mahisalakkhaṇaṃ (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī.) usabhalakkhaṇaṃ golakkhaṇaṃ ajalakkhaṇaṃ meṇḍalakkhaṇaṃ kukkuṭalakkhaṇaṃ vaṭṭakalakkhaṇaṃ godhālakkhaṇaṃ kaṇṇikālakkhaṇaṃ kacchapalakkhaṇaṃ migalakkhaṇaṃ iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 22. Or he might say: ‘Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on the food offered in faith, earn their living by wrong livelihood, by such base arts as: the marks of jewels (*maṇilakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of cloths (*vatthalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of sticks (*daṇḍalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of weapons (*satthalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of swords (*asilakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of arrows (*usulakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of bows (*dhanulakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of armaments (*āvudhalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of women (*itthilakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of men (*purisalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of boys (*kumāralakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of girls (*kumārilakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of male slaves (*dāsalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of female slaves (*dāsilakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of elephants (*hatthilakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of horses (*assalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of buffaloes (*mahiṃsalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of bulls (*usabhalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of cows (*golakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of goats (*ajalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of rams (*meṇḍalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of cocks (*kukkuṭalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of quails (*vaṭṭakalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of iguanas (*godhālakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of earrings (*kaṇṇikālakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of tortoises (*kacchapalakkhaṇaṃ*), the marks of deer (*migalakkhaṇaṃ*).’ Thus it is that the ascetic Gotama abstains from wrong livelihood, from such base arts. Thus, monks, would an ordinary person, speaking in praise of the *Tathāgata*, speak.
commentary_pali: 22.Maṇilakkhaṇādīsu evarūpo maṇi pasattho, evarūpo apasattho, sāmino ārogyaissariyādīnaṃ hetu hoti, na hotīti, evaṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādivasena maṇiādīnaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ anuyuttā viharantīti attho. Tattha āvudhanti ṭhapetvā asiādīni avasesaṃ āvudhaṃ. Itthilakkhaṇādīnipi yamhi kule te itthipurisādayo vasanti, tassa vuḍḍhihānivaseneva veditabbāni. Ajalakkhaṇādīsu pana evarūpānaṃ ajādīnaṃ maṃsaṃ khāditabbaṃ, evarūpānaṃ na khāditabbanti ayaṃ viseso veditabbo. Api  cettha godhāya lakkhaṇe cittakammapiḷandhanādīsupi evarūpāya godhāya sati idaṃ nāma hotīti ayaṃ viseso veditabbo. Idañcettha vatthu – ekasmiṃ kira vihāre cittakamme godhaṃ aggiṃ dhamamānaṃ akaṃsu. Tato paṭṭhāya bhikkhūnaṃ mahāvivādo jāto. Eko āgantukabhikkhu taṃ disvā makkhesi. Tato paṭṭhāya vivādo mandībhūto hoti. Kaṇṇikalakkhaṇaṃ piḷandhanakaṇṇikāyapi gehakaṇṇikāyapi vasena veditabbaṃ. Kacchapalakkhaṇaṃ godhālakkhaṇasadisameva. Migalakkhaṇaṃ sabbasaṅgāhikaṃ sabbacatuppadānaṃ lakkhaṇavasena vuttaṃ.
commentary_english:
22. Concerning the characteristics of jewels (*maṇi-lakkhaṇa*), etc., this kind of jewel (*maṇi*) is praised, this kind is unpraised; it is the cause of the owner's health (*ārogya*) and dominion (*aissariya*), etc., and it is not. Thus, those who are engaged in the characteristics (*lakkhaṇa*) of jewels (*maṇi*), etc., according to color (*vaṇṇa*), shape (*saṇṭhāna*), etc., live accordingly.
There, having set aside "weapons" (*āvudha*), the remaining weapons (*āvudha*) are swords (*asi*), etc.
Also, the characteristics of women (*itthilakkhaṇa*), etc., in whatever family (*kula*) these women (*itthi*) and men (*purisa*), etc., live, should be understood according to their increase (*vuḍḍhi*) or decrease (*hāni*).
Moreover, regarding the characteristics of goats (*ajalakkhaṇa*), etc., the meat (*maṃsa*) of this kind of goat (*aja*), etc., should be eaten, and the meat of this kind should not be eaten; this distinction (*visesa*) should be understood.
Furthermore, here, regarding the characteristics (*lakkhaṇa*) of an iguana (*godhā*), when there is an iguana (*godhā*) of this kind even in paintings (*cittakamma*) and ornaments (*piḷandhana*), etc., it is called this; this distinction (*visesa*) should be understood.
And this is the story here: in a certain monastery (*vihāra*), in a painting (*cittakamma*), they made an iguana (*godhā*) blowing (*dhamamāna*) on a fire (*aggi*).
From then on, a great dispute (*mahāvivāda*) arose among the monks (*bhikkhūnaṃ*).
One visiting monk (*āgantukabhikkhu*), seeing that, reviled it.
From then on, the dispute (*vivāda*) became weakened (*mandībhūto*).
The characteristic (*lakkhaṇa*) of an earring (*kaṇṇika*) should be understood according to the type of ornamental earring (*piḷandhanakaṇṇikā*) or a house earring (*gehakaṇṇikā*).
The characteristic (*lakkhaṇa*) of a tortoise (*kacchapa*) is just like the characteristic (*lakkhaṇa*) of an iguana (*godhā*).
The characteristic (*lakkhaṇa*) of a deer (*miga*) is said to be all-inclusive (*sabbasaṅgāhikaṃ*), according to the characteristics (*lakkhaṇavasena*) of all quadrupeds (*sabbacatuppadānaṃ*).

mula_pali: 23. ‘‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti, seyyathidaṃ – raññaṃ niyyānaṃ bhavissati, raññaṃ  aniyyānaṃ bhavissati, abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ upayānaṃ bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ  apayānaṃ bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ upayānaṃ bhavissati, abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ apayānaṃ bhavissati, abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ jayo bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ parājayo bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ jayo bhavissati, abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ parājayo bhavissati, iti imassa jayo bhavissati, imassa parājayo bhavissati iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 23. “Or, some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food given in faith, maintain their lives through wrong livelihood, by means of base arts, such as predicting: ‘The king will march forth; the king will not march forth; our king will advance; the foreign king will retreat; the foreign king will advance; our king will retreat; our king will be victorious; the foreign king will be defeated; the foreign king will be victorious; our king will be defeated; thus there will be victory for this one, defeat for that one.’ Thus, the ascetic Gotama abstains from wrong livelihood, from such base arts." Thus, mendicants, a common person, speaking in praise of the *Tathāgata*, might speak.
commentary_pali: 23.Raññaṃ niyyānaṃ bhavissatīti asukadivase asukanakkhattena asukassa nāma rañño niggamanaṃ bhavissatīti evaṃ rājūnaṃ pavāsagamanaṃ byākaroti. Esa nayo sabbattha. Kevalaṃ panettha aniyyānanti vippavutthānaṃ puna āgamanaṃ. Abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ upayānaṃ bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ apayānanti antonagare amhākaṃ rājā paṭiviruddhaṃ bahirājānaṃ upasaṅkamissati, tato tassa paṭikkamanaṃ bhavissatīti evaṃ raññaṃ upayānāpayānaṃ  byākaroti. Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo. Jayaparājayā pākaṭāyeva.
commentary_english:
23. He predicts the departure of kings, saying, "On such a day, under such a constellation, the going forth (*niggamana*) of a king named so-and-so will occur"; thus, he declares the banishment and departure of kings.
This method applies to all instances.
However, here, *aniyyāna* means the return of those who have been away.
"[Predicting:] The approach (*upayāna*) of the internal kings will occur, the retreat (*apayāna*) of the external kings [will occur]. In the inner city, our king will approach the opposing external king, and then his retreat (*paṭikkamana*) will occur." Thus, he declares the approach and retreat (*upayānāpayāna*) of kings.
This method applies to the second passage as well.
Victory and defeat are clearly evident.

mula_pali: 24. ‘‘‘Yathā  vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti, seyyathidaṃ – candaggāho bhavissati, sūriyaggāho suriyaggāho (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī.) bhavissati, nakkhattaggāho bhavissati, candimasūriyānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, candimasūriyānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati, nakkhattānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, nakkhattānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati, ukkāpāto bhavissati, disāḍāho bhavissati, bhūmicālo bhavissati, devadudrabhi devadundubhi (syā. kaṃ. pī.) bhavissati, candimasūriyanakkhattānaṃ uggamanaṃ ogamanaṃ saṃkilesaṃ vodānaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipāko candaggāho bhavissati, evaṃvipāko sūriyaggāho bhavissati, evaṃvipāko nakkhattaggāho bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ candimasūriyānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ candimasūriyānaṃ  uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ nakkhattānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ nakkhattānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipāko ukkāpāto bhavissati, evaṃvipāko disāḍāho bhavissati, evaṃvipāko bhūmicālo bhavissati, evaṃvipāko devadudrabhi bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ candimasūriyanakkhattānaṃ uggamanaṃ ogamanaṃ saṃkilesaṃ vodānaṃ bhavissati iti vā  iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 24. “Or he might say: ‘Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on the food offered by the faithful, earn their living by a wrong means of livelihood, by such debased arts as predicting: there will be an eclipse of the moon (candaggāho bhavissati), an eclipse of the sun (sūriyaggāho bhavissati), an eclipse of a constellation (nakkhattaggāho bhavissati); the sun and the moon will go on their proper courses (candimasūriyānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati); there will be an aberration of the sun and moon (candimasūriyānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati); the constellations will go on their proper courses (nakkhattānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati); there will be an aberration of a constellation (nakkhattānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati); there will be a fall of meteors (ukkāpāto bhavissati); there will be a skyblaze (disāḍāho bhavissati); there will be an earthquake (bhūmicālo bhavissati); there will be an earth-roar (devadudrabhi bhavissati); there will be a rising and setting (uggamanaṃ ogamanaṃ), a darkening and brightening (saṃkilesaṃ vodānaṃ) of the moon, the sun, the stars; and ‘such will be the outcome of these things’ (evaṃvipāko candaggāho bhavissati, evaṃvipāko sūriyaggāho bhavissati, evaṃvipāko nakkhattaggāho bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ candimasūriyānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ candimasūriyānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ nakkhattānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ nakkhattānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipāko ukkāpāto bhavissati, evaṃvipāko disāḍāho bhavissati, evaṃvipāko bhūmicālo bhavissati, evaṃvipāko devadudrabhi bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ candimasūriyanakkhattānaṃ uggamanaṃ ogamanaṃ saṃkilesaṃ vodānaṃ bhavissati)’, the ascetic Gotama refrains from such base arts and wrong means of livelihood.’ This is how, monks, an ordinary person might speak in praise of the Tathāgata."
commentary_pali: 24.Candaggāhādayo asukadivase rāhu candaṃ gahessatīti byākaraṇavaseneva veditabbā. Api ca nakkhattassa aṅgārakādigāhasamāyogopi nakkhattagāhoyeva. Ukkāpātoti ākāsato ukkānaṃ patanaṃ. Disāḍāhoti disākālusiyaṃ aggisikhadhūmasikhādīhi ākulabhāvo viya. Devadudrabhīti sukkhavalāhakagajjanaṃ. Uggamananti udayanaṃ. Okkamananti atthaṅgamanaṃ. Saṃkilesanti avisuddhatā. Vodānanti visuddhatā. Evaṃ vipākoti lokassa evaṃ vividhasukhadukkhāvaho.
commentary_english:
24. Lunar eclipses, and the like, are to be understood merely through grammatical convention, [stating that] on such and such a day, Rāhu will seize the moon (candaṃ gahessati).
Moreover, the conjunction of planets, starting with Mars, is also a planetary influence (nakkhattassa aṅgārakādigāhasamāyogopi nakkhattagāhoyeva).
A falling meteor (ukkāpāto) means the falling of meteors from the sky (ākāsato ukkānaṃ patanaṃ).
"Disturbance of the quarters" (disāḍāho) means the impurity of the quarters, a state of confusion, as with fire, flames, smoke, and the like (aggisikhadhūmasikhādīhi ākulabhāvo viya).
"Divine drums" (devadudrabhī) means the rumbling of dry clouds (sukkhavalāhakagajjanaṃ).
Rising (uggamananti) means sunrise (udayanaṃ).
Setting (okkamananti) means sunset (atthaṅgamanaṃ).
Defilement (saṃkilesanti) means impurity (avisuddhatā).
Cleansing (vodānanti) means purity (visuddhatā).
Thus, the result (vipāko) for the world (lokassa) is thus the bringing of various joys and sorrows (evaṃ vividhasukhadukkhāvaho).

mula_pali: 25. ‘‘‘Yathā  vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti, seyyathidaṃ – suvuṭṭhikā bhavissati, dubbuṭṭhikā bhavissati, subhikkhaṃ bhavissati, dubbhikkhaṃ bhavissati, khemaṃ bhavissati, bhayaṃ bhavissati, rogo bhavissati, ārogyaṃ bhavissati, muddā, gaṇanā, saṅkhānaṃ, kāveyyaṃ, lokāyataṃ iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 25. "Or he might say: 'Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on the food offered in faith, earn their living by wrong means of livelihood, by such debased arts as predicting: there will be good rainfall, there will be bad rainfall, there will be a good harvest, there will be a bad harvest, there will be security, there will be danger, there will be disease, there will be health; or they earn their living by accounting ( *muddā*), computation ( *gaṇanā*), calculation ( *saṅkhānaṃ*), the composing of poetry ( *kāveyyaṃ*), and worldly speculation (*lokāyataṃ*)—the ascetic Gotama refrains from such base arts and wrong means of livelihood.' It is in this way, monks, that an ordinary person, when praising the Thus-Gone One (*tathāgata*), might speak."
commentary_pali: 25.Suvuṭṭhikāti devassa sammādhārānuppavecchanaṃ. Dubbuṭṭhikāti avaggāho, vassavibandhoti vuttaṃ hoti. Muddāti hatthamuddā. Gaṇanā vuccati acchiddakagaṇanā. Saṅkhānanti saṅkalanasaṭuppādanādivasena piṇḍagaṇanā. Yassa sā paguṇā hoti, so rukkhampi disvā ettakāni ettha paṇṇānīti jānāti. Kāveyyanti ‘‘cattārome, bhikkhave, kavī. Katame cattāro? Cintākavi, sutakavi, atthakavi, paṭibhānakavī’’ti (a. ni. 4.231). Imesaṃ catunnaṃ kavīnaṃ attano cintāvasena vā; ‘‘vessantaro nāma rājā ahosī’’tiādīni sutvā sutavasena vā; imassa ayaṃ attho, evaṃ taṃ yojessāmīti evaṃ atthavasena vā; kiñcideva disvā tappaṭibhāgaṃ kattabbaṃ karissāmīti evaṃ ṭhānuppattikapaṭibhānavasena vā; jīvikatthāya kabyakaraṇaṃ. Lokāyataṃ  vuttameva.
commentary_english:
25. *Suvuṭṭhikā* means the proper sending forth of rain by the gods.
*Dubbuṭṭhikā* means drought, it has been said, is an obstruction to rain.
*Muddā* means hand-seal (*hastamudrā*).
*Gaṇanā* is called unbroken counting (*acchiddakagaṇanā*).
*Saṅkhāna* means calculating the total amount of something such as gathering and producing.
He whose skill is perfected, even seeing a tree, knows how many leaves are on it.
*Kāveyya* means "These four, *bhikkhus*, are poets (*kavī*)."
Which four? The thought-poet (*cintākavi*), the learning-poet (*sutakavi*), the meaning-poet (*atthakavi*), the ready-wit-poet (*paṭibhānakavī*)" (A.
Ni.
4.
231).
For these four poets, either by their own thought; or having heard things such as "there was a king named Vessantara," or by learning; or "this is its meaning, thus I will connect it," thus by meaning; or having seen something small, "I will do what is appropriate to it," thus by ready wit that has arisen in the place; or composing poetry for the sake of livelihood.
*Lokāyata* has already been said.

mula_pali: 26. ‘‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti , seyyathidaṃ – āvāhanaṃ vivāhanaṃ saṃvaraṇaṃ vivaraṇaṃ saṃkiraṇaṃ  vikiraṇaṃ subhagakaraṇaṃ dubbhagakaraṇaṃ viruddhagabbhakaraṇaṃ jivhānibandhanaṃ hanusaṃhananaṃ hatthābhijappanaṃ hanujappanaṃ kaṇṇajappanaṃ ādāsapañhaṃ kumārikapañhaṃ devapañhaṃ ādiccupaṭṭhānaṃ mahatupaṭṭhānaṃ abbhujjalanaṃ sirivhāyanaṃ iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english: 26. “Or he might say: ‘Whereas some honorable ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food given in faith, maintain their lives by wrong livelihood, by such base arts as: arranging for invocations (*āvāhanaṃ*), marriages (*vivāhanaṃ*), betrothals (*saṃvaraṇaṃ*), divorces (*vivaraṇaṃ*), uniting, separating, making people lucky (*subhagakaraṇaṃ*) or unlucky (*dubbhagakaraṇaṃ*), procuring abortions (*viruddhagabbhakaraṇaṃ*), using spells to bind the tongue (*jivhānibandhanaṃ*), binding the jaw (*hanusaṃhananaṃ*), making the hands jerk (*hatthābhijappanaṃ*), causing deafness, getting answers with a mirror (*ādāsapañhaṃ*), a girl-medium (*kumārikapañhaṃ*), a *deva* (*devapañhaṃ*); worshipping the sun (*ādiccupaṭṭhānaṃ*) or Great Brahma (*mahatupaṭṭhānaṃ*), breathing fire (*abbhujjalanaṃ*), invoking the goddess of luck (*sirivhāyanaṃ*), the ascetic Gotama refrains from such base arts and wrong livelihood.’ Thus, bhikkhus, would an ordinary person describe the qualities of the *Tathāgata*."
commentary_pali: 26.Āvāhanaṃ nāma imassa dārakassa asukakulato asukanakkhattena dārikaṃ ānethāti āvāhakaraṇaṃ. Vivāhananti imaṃ dārikaṃ asukassa nāma dārakassa asukanakkhattena detha, evamassā vuḍḍhi bhavissatīti vivāhakaraṇaṃ. Saṃvaraṇanti saṃvaraṇaṃ nāma ‘ajja nakkhattaṃ sundaraṃ, ajjeva samaggā hotha, iti vo viyogo na bhavissatī’ti evaṃ samaggakaraṇaṃ. Vivaraṇaṃ nāma ‘sace viyujjitukāmattha, ajjeva viyujjatha , iti vo puna saṃyogo na bhavissatī’ti evaṃ visaṃyogakaraṇaṃ. Saṅkiraṇanti ‘uṭṭhānaṃ vā iṇaṃ vā dinnaṃ dhanaṃ ajja saṅkaḍḍhatha, ajja saṅkaḍḍhitañhi taṃ thāvaraṃ hotī’ti evaṃ dhanapiṇḍāpanaṃ. Vikiraṇanti ‘sace payogauddhārādivasena dhanaṃ payojitukāmattha, ajja payojitaṃ diguṇacatugguṇaṃ hotī’ti evaṃ dhanapayojāpanaṃ. Subhagakaraṇanti piyamanāpakaraṇaṃ vā sassirīkakaraṇaṃ vā. Dubbhagakaraṇanti tabbiparītaṃ. Viruddhagabbhakaraṇanti viruddhassa vilīnassa aṭṭhitassa matassa gabbhassa karaṇaṃ. Puna avināsāya bhesajjadānanti attho. Gabbho hi vātena, pāṇakehi, kammunā cāti tīhi kāraṇehi vinassati. Tattha vātena vinassante nibbāpanīyaṃ sītalaṃ bhesajjaṃ deti, pāṇakehi vinassante pāṇakānaṃ paṭikammaṃ karoti, kammunā vinassante pana buddhāpi paṭibāhituṃ na sakkonti. Jivhānibandhananti mantena jivhāya bandhakaraṇaṃ. Hanusaṃhanananti  mukhabandhamantena yathā hanukaṃ cāletuṃ na sakkonti, evaṃ bandhakaraṇaṃ. Hatthābhijappananti hatthānaṃ parivattanatthaṃ mantajappanaṃ. Tasmiṃ kira mante sattapadantare ṭhatvā jappite itaro hatthe parivattetvā khipati. Kaṇṇajappananti kaṇṇehi saddaṃ assavanatthāya vijjāya jappanaṃ. Taṃ kira jappitvā vinicchayaṭṭhāne yaṃ icchati, taṃ bhaṇati, paccatthiko taṃ na suṇāti, tato paṭivacanaṃ sampādetuṃ na sakkoti. Ādāsapañhanti ādāse devataṃ otāretvā pañhapucchanaṃ. Kumārikapañhanti kumārikāya sarīre devataṃ otāretvā pañhapucchanaṃ. Devapañhanti dāsiyā sarīre devataṃ otāretvā pañhapucchanaṃ. Ādiccupaṭṭhānanti jīvikatthāya ādiccapāricariyā. Mahatupaṭṭhānanti tatheva mahābrahmapāricariyā. Abbhujjalananti mantena mukhato aggijālānīharaṇaṃ. Sirivhāyananti ‘‘ehi siri, mayhaṃ sire patiṭṭhāhī’’ti evaṃ sirena siriyā avhāyanaṃ.
commentary_english:
26. *Āvāhana* means: "Bring the girl from such and such family on such and such a day for this boy!" This is called the act of *āvāhana*.

*Vivāhana* means: "Give this girl to such and such boy on such and such a day, thus prosperity will come to her!" This is called the act of *vivāhana*.

*Saṃvaraṇa* means: *Saṃvaraṇa* is: "Today is a beautiful day, may you be harmonious today, thus separation will not occur for you!" This is called the act of harmonizing (*samaggakaraṇa*).

*Vivarana* means: "If you want to separate, separate today, thus reunion will not occur for you!" This is called the act of disuniting (*visaṃyogakaraṇa*).

*Saṅkiraṇa* means: "Whether it is effort, debt, or given wealth, gather it today, indeed, what is gathered today will be stable!" This is called the accumulation of wealth (*dhanapiṇḍāpana*).

*Vikiraṇa* means: "If you want to use wealth through investment, etc., what is invested today will be doubled or quadrupled!" This is called the investment of wealth (*dhanapayojāpana*).

*Subhagakaraṇa* means either making [someone] dear and pleasing or making [someone] endowed with glory.

*Dubbhagakaraṇa* means the opposite of that.

*Viruddhagabbhakaraṇa* means the act of [dealing with] a pregnancy that is contrary, dissolved, unformed, or dead.

Furthermore, giving medicine for non-destruction is the meaning.

Indeed, a fetus is destroyed by wind (*vāta*), by minute organisms, and by karma; thus, it is destroyed by three causes.

There, when it is destroyed by wind, one gives cooling medicine that alleviates; when it is destroyed by minute organisms, one performs a counter-action for the minute organisms; when it is destroyed by karma, even Buddhas are not able to prevent it.

*Jivhānibandhana* means binding the tongue with a mantra.

*Hanusaṃhanana* means binding in such a way that one is not able to move the jaw with a mouth-binding mantra, thus, this is the act of binding.

*Hatthābhijappana* means the recitation of mantras for the purpose of turning the hands.

Having stood at a distance of seven steps while reciting that mantra, the other person turns the hands and throws [something].

*Kaṇṇajappana* means the recitation of knowledge (*vijjā*) with the ears for the purpose of not hearing sounds.

Having recited that, whatever he wishes in the place of judgment, he speaks that, the opponent does not hear that, therefore he is not able to produce a response.

*Ādāsapañha* means asking a question by causing a deity to descend into a mirror.

*Kumārikapañha* means asking a question by causing a deity to descend into the body of a maiden.

*Devapañha* means asking a question by causing a deity to descend into the body of a female servant.

*Ādiccupaṭṭhāna* means attending to the sun for the sake of livelihood.

*Mahatupaṭṭhāna* means attending to Mahābrahmā in the same way.

*Abbhujjalana* means bringing forth flames of fire from the mouth with a mantra.

*Sirivhāyana* means thus invoking Śrī with the head by saying, "Come, Śrī! Be established on my head!".

mula_pali: 27. ‘‘‘Yathā  vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti, seyyathidaṃ – santikammaṃ paṇidhikammaṃ bhūtakammaṃ bhūrikammaṃ vassakammaṃ vossakammaṃ vatthukammaṃ vatthuparikammaṃ ācamanaṃ nhāpanaṃ juhanaṃ vamanaṃ virecanaṃ uddhaṃvirecanaṃ adhovirecanaṃ sīsavirecanaṃ kaṇṇatelaṃ nettatappanaṃ natthukammaṃ añjanaṃ paccañjanaṃ sālākiyaṃ sallakattiyaṃ dārakatikicchā mūlabhesajjānaṃ anuppadānaṃ osadhīnaṃ paṭimokkho iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti – iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya. ‘‘Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, appamattakaṃ oramattakaṃ sīlamattakaṃ, yena puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
mula_english:
27. “Or he might say: ‘Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, having lived on the food given in faith, earn their living by wrong livelihood, by such base arts, such as: performing propitiatory rites (śantikamma), performing vows (paṇidhikamma), performing exorcism (bhūtakamma), performing acts for prosperity (bhūrikamma), performing ceremonies for rain (vassakamma), performing ceremonies against rain (vossakamma), performing rites for a building site (vatthukamma), performing rites for the consecration of a building site (vatthuparikamma), ceremonial rinsing (ācamana), ceremonial bathing (nhāpana), offering sacrifices (juhana), inducing vomiting (vamana), inducing purging (virecana), inducing upward purging (uddhaṃvirecana), inducing downward purging (adhovirecana), inducing head purging (sīsavirecana), administering ear oil (kaṇṇatela), applying eye salves (nettatappana), performing nasal treatments (natthukamma), applying collyrium (añjana), applying counter-collyrium (paccañjana), performing eye surgery (sālākiyaṃ), performing general surgery (sallakattiyaṃ), treating children (dārakatikicchā), providing root medicines (mūlabhesajjānaṃ anuppadānaṃ), and prescribing herbal remedies (osadhīnaṃ paṭimokkho).’ Thus does the ascetic Gotama abstain from wrong livelihood by such base arts. This is how, monks, a worldling, speaking in praise of the *Tathāgata*, might speak.

“These, monks, are those trifling and insignificant matters, those minor details of mere moral virtue (sīlamattakaṃ), that a worldling would refer to when speaking in praise of the *Tathāgata*.
commentary_pali: 27.Santikammanti devaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā sace me idaṃ nāma samijjhissati, tumhākaṃ iminā ca iminā ca upahāraṃ karissāmīti samiddhikāle kattabbaṃ santipaṭissavakammaṃ. Tasmiṃ pana samiddhe tassa karaṇaṃ paṇidhikammaṃ nāma. Bhūrikammanti bhūrighare vasitvā gahitamantassa payogakaraṇaṃ. Vassakammaṃ vossakammanti ettha vassoti puriso, vossoti paṇḍako . Iti vossassa  vassakaraṇaṃ vassakammaṃ, vassassa vossakaraṇaṃ vossakammaṃ. Taṃ pana karonto acchandikabhāvamattaṃ pāpeti, na liṅgaṃ antaradhāpetuṃ sakkoti. Vatthukammanti  akatavatthusmiṃ gehapatiṭṭhāpanaṃ. Vatthuparikammanti ‘‘idañcidañcāharathā’’ti vatvā vatthubalikammakaraṇaṃ. Ācamananti udakena mukhasuddhikaraṇaṃ. Nhāpananti aññesaṃ nhāpanaṃ. Juhananti tesaṃ atthāya aggijuhanaṃ. Vamananti yogaṃ datvā vamanakaraṇaṃ. Virecanepi eseva nayo. Uddhaṃvirecananti uddhaṃ dosānaṃ nīharaṇaṃ. Adhovirecananti adho dosānaṃ nīharaṇaṃ. Sīsavirecananti sirovirecanaṃ. Kaṇṇatelanti kaṇṇānaṃ bandhanatthaṃ vā vaṇaharaṇatthaṃ vā bhesajjatelapacanaṃ. Nettatappananti akkhitappanatelaṃ. Natthukammanti telena yojetvā natthukaraṇaṃ. Añjananti dve vā tīṇi vā paṭalāni nīharaṇasamatthaṃ khārañjanaṃ. Paccañjananti nibbāpanīyaṃ sītalabhesajjañjanaṃ. Sālākiyanti salākavejjakammaṃ. Sallakattiyanti sallakattavejjakammaṃ. Dārakatikicchā vuccati komārabhaccavejjakammaṃ. Mūlabhesajjānaṃ anuppādananti iminā kāyatikicchanaṃ dasseti. Osadhīnaṃ paṭimokkhoti khārādīni datvā tadanurūpe vaṇe gate tesaṃ apanayanaṃ.
commentary_english:
27. *Santikamma* means going to a shrine and saying, "If this thing of mine succeeds, I will make this and this offering to you." *Santipaṭissavakamma* is what should be done at the time of success.
When that is successful, its doing is called *paṇidhikamma*.
*Bhūrikamma* means dwelling in a house with many [people] and applying a spell that has been learned.
*Vassakamma* and *vossakamma*: Here, *vassa* means a man, *vossa* means a eunuch.
Thus, the making of a man into a eunuch is *vassakamma*, the making of a eunuch into a man is *vossakamma*.
But in doing that, one brings about merely the state of being without desire; one is not able to make the gender disappear.
*Vatthukamma* means the establishing of a dwelling on a site where a site has not been made.
*Vatthuparikamma* means saying, "Bring this and this," and then doing a sacrifice to the site.
*Ācamana* means the cleansing of the mouth with water.
*Nhāpana* means causing others to bathe.
*Juhana* means offering oblations to the fire for their sake (*agni-juhana*).
*Vamana* means giving a potion and causing vomiting.
The same rule applies to *virecana* too.
*Uddhaṃvirecana* means the elimination of humors upward.
*Adhovirecana* means the elimination of humors downward.
*Sīsavirecana* means head-purging (*sirovirecana*).
*Kaṇṇatela* means concocting medicinal oil for the purpose of binding the ears, or for healing wounds.
*Nettatappana* means eye-soothing oil (*akkhitappanatela*).
*Natthukamma* means combining with oil and doing nasal medication (*natthukaraṇa*).
*Añjana* means alkaline collyrium (*khārañjana*) capable of eliminating two or three layers.
*Paccañjana* means cooling medicinal collyrium (*sītalabhesajjañjana*) that should be applied.
*Sālākiya* means eye-surgery (*salākavejjakamma*).
*Sallakattiya* means general surgery (*sallakattavejjakamma*).
*Dārakatikicchā* is called pediatric medicine (*komārabhaccavejjakamma*).
"The non-production of root medicines" indicates physical medicine (*kāyatikicchana*).
"Removing of herbs" means giving alkaline substances, etc., and when there is a wound conforming to that, their removal.

mula_pali: 28. ‘‘Atthi , bhikkhave, aññeva dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ. Katame ca te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ?
mula_english:
28. "There are, monks, other *dharmas* (teachings, principles) that are profound (*gambhīrā*), difficult to see (*duddasā*), difficult to understand (*duranubodhā*), peaceful (*santā*), excellent (*paṇītā*), beyond the sphere of reasoning (*atakkāvacarā*), subtle (*nipuṇā*), to be experienced by the wise (*paṇḍitavedanīyā*), which the *Tathāgata*, having realized them by his own super-knowledge (*abhiññā*) and directly experienced (*sacchikatvā*), proclaims (*pavedeti*), and about which those who would truthfully (*yathābhuccaṃ*) praise (*vaṇṇaṃ*) the *Tathāgata* would rightly (*sammā*) speak (*vadamānā vadeyyuṃ*)."

"And what are those *dharmas*, monks, that are profound (*gambhīrā*), difficult to see (*duddasā*), difficult to understand (*duranubodhā*), peaceful (*santā*), excellent (*paṇītā*), beyond the sphere of reasoning (*atakkāvacarā*), subtle (*nipuṇā*), to be experienced by the wise (*paṇḍitavedanīyā*), which the *Tathāgata*, having realized them by his own super-knowledge (*abhiññā*) and directly experienced (*sacchikatvā*), proclaims (*pavedeti*), and about which those who would truthfully (*yathābhuccaṃ*) praise (*vaṇṇaṃ*) the *Tathāgata* would rightly (*sammā*) speak (*vadamānā vadeyyuṃ*)?"
commentary_pali: 28. Evaṃ brahmadattena vuttavaṇṇassa anusandhivasena tividhaṃ sīlaṃ vitthāretvā idāni bhikkhusaṅghena vuttavaṇṇassa  anusandhivasena – ‘‘atthi, bhikkhave, aññeva dhammā gambhīrā duddasā’’tiādinā nayena suññatāpakāsanaṃ ārabhi. Tattha dhammāti guṇe, desanāyaṃ, pariyattiyaṃ, nissatteti evamādīsu dhammasaddo vattati. Ādīsu hi guṇe dhammasaddo. ‘‘Dhammaṃ, vo bhikkhave, desessāmi ādikalyāṇa’’ntiādīsu (ma. ni. 3.420) desanāyaṃ. ‘‘Idha bhikkhu dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇāti suttaṃ , geyya’’ntiādīsu (a. ni. 5.73) pariyattiyaṃ. ‘‘Tasmiṃ kho pana samaye dhammā honti, khandhā hontī’’tiādīsu (dha. sa. 121) nissatte. Idha pana guṇe vattati. Tasmā atthi, bhikkhave, aññeva tathāgatassa guṇāti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Gambhīrāti mahāsamuddo viya makasatuṇḍasūciyā aññatra tathāgatā aññesaṃ ñāṇena alabbhaneyyapatiṭṭhā, gambhīrattāyeva duddasā. Duddasattāyeva duranubodhā. Nibbutasabbapariḷāhattā santā, santārammaṇesu pavattanatopi santā. Atittikaraṇaṭṭhena paṇītā, sādurasabhojanaṃ viya. Uttamañāṇavisayattā na takkena avacaritabbāti atakkāvacarā. Nipuṇāti saṇhasukhumasabhāvattā. Bālānaṃ avisayattā, paṇḍitehiyeva veditabbāti paṇḍitavedanīyā. Ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedetīti ye dhamme tathāgato anaññaneyyo hutvā sayameva abhivisiṭṭhena ñāṇena paccakkhaṃ katvā pavedeti, dīpeti, katheti, pakāsetīti attho. Yehīti yehi guṇadhammehi. Yathābhuccanti yathābhūtaṃ. Vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyunti tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vattukāmā sammā vadeyyuṃ, ahāpetvā vattuṃ sakkuṇeyyunti attho. Katame ca pana te dhammā bhagavatā evaṃ thomitāti? Sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ. Yadi evaṃ, kasmā bahuvacananiddeso  katoti? Puthucittasamāyogato ceva, puthuārammaṇato ca. Tañhi catūsu ñāṇasampayuttamahākiriyacittesu labbhati, na cassa koci dhammo ārammaṇaṃ nāma na hoti. Yathāha – ‘‘atītaṃ sabbaṃ jānātīti sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ, tattha āvaraṇaṃ natthīti anāvaraṇañāṇa’’ntiādi (paṭi. ma. 1.120). Iti puthucittasamāyogato punappunaṃ uppattivasena puthuārammaṇato ca bahuvacananiddeso katoti. ‘‘Aññevā’’ti idaṃ panettha vavatthāpanavacanaṃ, ‘‘aññeva, na pāṇātipātā veramaṇiādayo. Gambhīrāva na uttānā’’ti evaṃ sabbapadehi yojetabbaṃ. Sāvakapāramīñāṇañhi gambhīraṃ, paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ pana tato gambhīrataranti tattha vavatthānaṃ natthi, sabbaññutaññāṇañca tatopi gambhīrataranti tatthāpi vavatthānaṃ natthi, ito panaññaṃ gambhīrataraṃ natthi; tasmā gambhīrā vāti vavatthānaṃ labbhati. Tathā duddasāva duranubodhā vāti sabbaṃ veditabbaṃ. Katameca te bhikkhaveti ayaṃ pana tesaṃ dhammānaṃ kathetukamyatā pucchā. Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇātiādi pucchāvissajjanaṃ. Kasmā panetaṃ evaṃ āraddhanti ce? Buddhānañhi cattāri ṭhānāni patvā gajjitaṃ mahantaṃ hoti, ñāṇaṃ anupavisati, buddhañāṇassa mahantabhāvo  paññāyati, desanā gambhīrā hoti, tilakkhaṇāhatā, suññatāpaṭisaṃyuttā. Katamāni cattāri? Vinayapaññattiṃ, bhūmantaraṃ, paccayākāraṃ, samayantaranti. Tasmā – ‘‘idaṃ lahukaṃ, idaṃ garukaṃ, idaṃ satekicchaṃ, idaṃ atekicchaṃ, ayaṃ āpatti, ayaṃ anāpatti, ayaṃ chejjagāminī, ayaṃ vuṭṭhānagāminī, ayaṃ desanāgāminī, ayaṃ lokavajjā, ayaṃ paṇṇattivajjā, imasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ idaṃ paññapetabba’’nti yaṃ evaṃ otiṇṇe vatthusmiṃ  sikkhāpadapaññāpanaṃ nāma, tattha aññesaṃ thāmo vā balaṃ vā natthi; avisayo esa aññesaṃ, tathāgatasseva visayo. Iti vinayapaññattiṃ patvā buddhānaṃ gajjitaṃ mahantaṃ hoti, ñāṇaṃ anupavisati…pe… suññatāpaṭisaṃyuttāti. Tathā ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā nāma…pe… ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo nāma, pañca khandhā nāma, dvādasa āyatanāni nāma, aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo nāma, cattāri ariyasaccāni nāma, bāvīsatindriyāni nāma, nava hetū nāma, cattāro āhārā nāma, satta phassā nāma, satta vedanā nāma, satta saññā nāma, satta cetanā nāma, satta cittāni nāma. Etesu ettakā kāmāvacarā dhammā nāma, ettakā rūpāvacaraarūpāvacarapariyāpannā dhammā nāma, ettakā lokiyā dhammā nāma, ettakā lokuttarā dhammā nāmāti catuvīsatisamantapaṭṭhānaṃ anantanayaṃ abhidhammapiṭakaṃ vibhajitvā kathetuṃ aññesaṃ thāmo vā balaṃ vā natthi, avisayo esa aññesaṃ, tathāgatasseva visayo. Iti bhūmantaraparicchedaṃ patvā buddhānaṃ gajjitaṃ mahantaṃ hoti, ñāṇaṃ anupavisati…pe… suññatāpaṭisaṃyuttāti. Tathā ayaṃ avijjā saṅkhārānaṃ navahākārehi paccayo hoti, uppādo hutvā paccayo hoti, pavattaṃ hutvā, nimittaṃ, āyūhanaṃ, saṃyogo, palibodho, samudayo, hetu, paccayo hutvā paccayo hoti, tathā saṅkhārādayo viññāṇādīnaṃ. Yathāha – ‘‘kathaṃ paccayapariggahe paññā dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇaṃ? Avijjā saṅkhārānaṃ uppādaṭṭhiti ca pavattaṭṭhiti ca, nimittaṭṭhiti  ca, āyūhanaṭṭhiti ca, saṃyogaṭṭhiti ca, palibodhaṭṭhiti ca, samudayaṭṭhiti ca, hetuṭṭhiti ca, paccayaṭṭhiti ca, imehi navahākārehi avijjā paccayo, saṅkhārā paccayasamuppannā, ubhopete dhammā paccayasamuppannāti paccayapariggahe paññā dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇaṃ. Atītampi addhānaṃ, anāgatampi addhānaṃ avijjā saṅkhārānaṃ uppādaṭṭhiti ca…pe…  jāti jarāmaraṇassa uppādaṭṭhiti ca…pe… paccayaṭṭhiti ca, imehi navahākārehi jāti paccayo, jarāmaraṇaṃ paccayasamuppannaṃ, ubhopete dhammā paccayasamuppannāti paccayapariggahe paññā dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇa’’nti (paṭi. ma. 1.45). Evamimaṃ tassa tassa dhammassa tathā tathā paccayabhāvena pavattaṃ tivaṭṭaṃ tiyaddhaṃ  tisandhiṃ catusaṅkhepaṃ vīsatākāraṃ paṭiccasamuppādaṃ vibhajitvā kathetuṃ aññesaṃ thāmo vā balaṃ vā natthi, avisayo esa aññesaṃ, tathāgatasseva visayo, iti paccayākāraṃ patvā buddhānaṃ gajjitaṃ mahantaṃ hoti, ñāṇaṃ anupavisati…pe… suññatāpaṭisaṃyuttāti. Tathā cattāro janā sassatavādā nāma, cattāro ekaccasassatavādā, cattāro antānantikā, cattāro amarāvikkhepikā, dve adhiccasamuppannikā, soḷasa saññīvādā, aṭṭha asaññīvādā, aṭṭha nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā, satta ucchedavādā, pañca diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā nāma. Te idaṃ nissāya idaṃ gaṇhantīti dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni bhinditvā nijjaṭaṃ niggumbaṃ katvā kathetuṃ aññesaṃ thāmo vā balaṃ vā natthi, avisayo esa aññesaṃ, tathāgatasseva visayo. Iti samayantaraṃ patvā buddhānaṃ gajjitaṃ mahantaṃ hoti, ñāṇaṃ anupavisati, buddhañāṇassa mahantatā paññāyati, desanā gambhīrā hoti, tilakkhaṇāhatā, suññatāpaṭisaṃyuttāti. Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne samayantaraṃ labbhati, tasmā sabbaññutaññāṇassa mahantabhāvadassanatthaṃ desanāya ca suññatāpakāsanavibhāvanatthaṃ samayantaraṃ anupavisanto dhammarājā – ‘‘santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā’’ti evaṃ pucchāvissajjanaṃ ārabhi.
commentary_english:
28. Having explained in detail the three classes of moral virtue as the sequel to the praise spoken by Brahmadatta, now, as the sequel to the praise spoken by the company of *bhikkhus*, the Exalted One begins the elucidation of emptiness with the words: “There are, *bhikkhus*, other *dharmas* deep, difficult to see,” and so forth.

There, "*dhamma*" means noble quality (*guṇa*), the teaching (*desanā*), the scriptures (*pariyatti*), impersonal states (*nissatta*), etc.; thus, the word *dhamma* is used.

In the passage, "I will teach you the *Dhamma*, *bhikkhus*, good in the beginning," etc., it means the teaching.

In the passage, "Herein, a *bhikkhu* masters the *Dhamma*—the *suttas*, songs," etc., it means the scriptures.

And in the passage, “On that occasion there are *dharmas*, there are aggregates," etc., it means impersonal states.

Here, it has the meaning of noble quality (*guṇa*).

Thus, the sentence means: “There are other noble qualities (*guṇa*) of the *Tathāgata*."

"*Gambhīrā*" (deep): like the great ocean, where, with the needle-point beak of a mosquito, there is no place to get a footing for the knowledge of others except for the *Tathāgatas*; they are "*duddasā*" (difficult to see) because of their depth.

They are "*duranubodhā*" (difficult to understand) because they are "*duddasattāyeva*" (difficult to see).

They are "*santā*" (peaceful) because all the fevers of passion become pacified, or because they occur in regard to peaceful objects; "*santārammaṇesu pavattanatopi santā*."

They are "*paṇītā*" (sublime) because one cannot be satiated with them, as with delicious food; "*atittikaraṇaṭṭhena*."

They are "*atakkāvacarā*" (beyond the sphere of reasoning) because the objective domain of the uttermost knowledge cannot be encompassed by reasoning; "*uttamañāṇavisayattā na takkena avacaritabbāti*."

"*Nipuṇāti*" (subtle) because they are abstruse and recondite in nature; "*saṇhasukhumasabhāvattā*."

And they are "*paṇḍitavedanīyā*" (comprehensible only to the wise), that is, they must be understood by the wise, for they are not the objective domain of fools; "*bālānaṃ avisayattā, paṇḍitehiyeva veditabbāti*."

"*Ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedetīti ye dhamme tathāgato anaññaneyyo hutvā selama abhivisiṭṭhena ñāṇena paccakkhaṃ katvā pavedeti, dīpeti, katheti, pakāsetīti attho*" (those things which the *Tathāgata* himself makes known, having directly experienced them with higher knowledge, means those *dharmas* which the *Tathāgata*, being unguided by another, himself directly makes known with outstanding knowledge, explains, declares, reveals); this is the meaning.

"*Yehīti yehi guṇadhammehi*" (with which): with which noble qualities (*guṇadhamma*).

"*Yathābhuccanti yathābhūtaṃ*" (as it really is): in accordance with reality.

"*Vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyunti tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vattukāmā sammā vadeyyuṃ, ahāpetvā vattuṃ sakkuṇeyyunti attho*" (speaking praise rightly, they should speak): those who desire to speak the praise of the *Tathāgata* should speak rightly, and they should be able to speak without depreciation; this is the meaning.

What are these *dharmas* extolled in this way by the Blessed One (*bhagavatā*)? All-knowing knowledge (*sabbaññutañāṇaṃ*).

If so, why is it described in the plural? Because it is associated with multiple classes of consciousness and because it takes a multiplicity of objects on the successive occasions of its arising; "*puthucittasamāyogato ceva, puthuārammaṇato ca*."

For the knowledge of omniscience is found in the four great functional classes of consciousness associated with knowledge, and there is no *dhamma* that is not an object of it; "*tañhi catūsu ñāṇasampayuttamahākiriyacittesu labbhati, na cassa koci dhammo ārammaṇaṃ nāma na hoti*."

As it is said: “It knows the entire past, thus it is the knowledge of omniscience. It knows everything therein without obstruction, thus it is unobstructed knowledge” (*atītaṃ sabbaṃ jānātīti sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ, tattha āvaraṇaṃ natthīti anāvaraṇañāṇa*).

Thus, because it is associated with multiple classes of consciousness and because it takes a multiplicity of objects on the successive occasions of its arising, it is described in the plural; "*iti puthucittasamāyogato punappunaṃ uppattivasena puthuārammaṇato ca bahuvacananiddeso katoti*."

“*Aññevā*”: this is a term for distinguishing there: “different indeed, not abstaining from killing living beings, etc. (*na pāṇātipātā veramaṇiādayo*)."

"*Gambhīrāva na uttānā*": in this way, it should be connected with all the terms.

Indeed, the knowledge consisting of the perfections of a disciple (*sāvakapāramīñāṇa*) is deep (*gambhīraṃ*), but the knowledge of a solitary Buddha (*paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ*) is deeper than that, but there is no distinction there; and all-knowing knowledge (*sabbaññutañāṇa*) is deeper than that, and there is no distinction even there; but there is nothing deeper than this; therefore, the distinction is obtained that they are deep.

Likewise, everything should be understood as difficult to see and difficult to understand; "*tathā duddasāva duranubodhā vāti sabbaṃ veditabbaṃ*."
What are these factors, monks? This question expresses their desire to speak about these factors (dharma).

There are, monks, some recluses and brahmins, and so forth, a question and answer.

Why, then, has this been commenced in this way? Because on four occasions the thundering of the Buddhas becomes truly great, their knowledge enters its proper field, the greatness of the Buddha knowledge becomes manifest and their teaching becomes deep, stamped with the three characteristics, connected with emptiness.

What are the four? The promulgation of the Vinaya (vinayapaññattiṃ), the classification of the diversity of planes (bhūmantaraṃ), the exposition of conditionality (paccayākāraṃ), and the classification of the diversity of creeds (samayantaranti).

Therefore: “This is a light offense, this a heavy offense. This is curable, this incurable. This is an offense, this not an offense. This leads to expulsion, this to rehabilitation, this to confession. This is a fault according to the world, this according to the rules of the Order. In such a case, such should be promulgated." The “promulgation of the Discipline” is the promulgation of a training rule in a particular case which has arisen. In this matter others have neither the capacity nor the power; this is not the domain of others, it is the domain only of the Tathāgata.

Thus, in the promulgation of the Discipline (vinayapaññattiṃ), the thundering of the Buddhas becomes truly great, their knowledge enters its proper field, and so on, connected with emptiness.

Likewise, these are the four foundations of mindfulness (satipaṭṭhānā nāma)... and so on... the Noble Eightfold Path (ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo nāma), the five aggregates (pañca khandhā nāma), the twelve sense bases (dvādasa āyatanāni nāma), the eighteen elements (aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo nāma), the four noble truths (cattāri ariyasaccāni nāma), the twenty-two faculties (bāvīsatindriyāni nāma), the nine causes (nava hetū nāma), the four kinds of nutriment (cattāro āhārā nāma), the seven contacts (satta phassā nāma), the seven feelings (satta vedanā nāma), the seven perceptions (satta saññā nāma), the seven volitions (satta cetanā nāma), the seven types of consciousness (satta cittāni nāma).

Among these, so many factors (dharma) pertain to the sense sphere (kāmāvacarā dhammā nāma), so many factors pertain to the fine-material and immaterial spheres (rūpāvacaraarūpāvacarapariyāpannā dhammā nāma), so many factors are mundane (lokiyā dhammā nāma), so many factors are supramundane (lokuttarā dhammā nāmāti). Others have neither the capacity nor the power to explain this matter, for this is not the domain of others; it is the domain only of the Tathāgata in the twenty-four fold universal pattern (catuvīsatisamantapaṭṭhānaṃ) of the Abhidhamma Piṭaka (abhidhammapiṭakaṃ) with its infinite methods (anantanayaṃ).

Thus, in the classification of the diversity of planes (bhūmantaraparicchedaṃ), the thundering of the Buddhas becomes truly great, their knowledge enters its proper field, and so on, connected with emptiness.

Likewise, this ignorance (avijjā) is a condition (paccayo) for the formations (saṅkhārānaṃ) in nine ways (navahākārehi): being a condition as arising (uppādo hutvā paccayo hoti), being a condition as occurrence (pavattaṃ hutvā), sign (nimittaṃ), accumulation (āyūhanaṃ), conjunction (saṃyogo), impediment (palibodho), origination (samudayo), cause (hetu), and condition (paccayo hutvā paccayo hoti). Likewise, the formations (saṅkhārādayo) are conditions for consciousness (viññāṇādīnaṃ).

As it was said: “How is wisdom (paññā) in the discernment of conditions (paccayapariggahe) the knowledge of the structure of dhammas (dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇaṃ)? Ignorance (avijjā) is the basis for kamma-formations (saṅkhārānaṃ), as the arising (uppādaṭṭhiti ca), occurrence (pavattaṭṭhiti ca), sign (nimittaṭṭhiti  ca), accumulation (āyūhanaṭṭhiti ca), conjunction (saṃyogaṭṭhiti ca), impediment (palibodhaṭṭhiti ca), origination (samudayaṭṭhiti ca), cause (hetuṭṭhiti ca), and condition (paccayaṭṭhiti ca) for kamma-formations. Ignorance (avijjā) is a condition (paccayo) in these nine modes (imehi navahākārehi), the kamma-formations (saṅkhārā) are conditionally arisen (paccayasamuppannā), both these dhammas (ubhopete dhammā) are conditionally arisen (paccayasamuppannāti). This is wisdom (paññā) in the discernment of conditions (paccayapariggahe), the knowledge of the structure of dhammas (dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇaṃ).

In the past (atītampi addhānaṃ), and also in the future (anāgatampi addhānaṃ), ignorance (avijjā) is the condition for kamma formations (saṅkhārānaṃ) as arising... and so on... birth (jāti) is the condition for aging and death (jarāmaraṇassa) as arising ...and so on... and condition. Birth (jāti) is a condition (paccayo) in these nine modes (imehi navahākārehi), aging and death (jarāmaraṇaṃ) are conditionally arisen (paccayasamuppannaṃ), both these dhammas (ubhopete dhammā) are conditionally arisen (paccayasamuppannāti). This is wisdom (paññā) in the discernment of conditions (paccayapariggahe), the knowledge of the structure of dhammas (dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇaṃ)." (Paṭi., Ma., 1.45).

In this way, others have neither the capacity nor the power to explain this matter, for this is not the domain of others; it is the domain only of the Tathāgata, for this arising of this and that dhamma (evamimaṃ tassa tassa dhammassa), in such and such a condition (tathā tathā paccayabhāvena), the continuity (pavattaṃ), threefold round (tivaṭṭaṃ), threefold duration (tiyaddhaṃ), threefold connection (tisandhiṃ), fourfold section (catusaṅkhepaṃ), twentyfold mode (vīsatākāraṃ) of dependent origination (paṭiccasamuppādaṃ). Thus, in the exposition of conditionality (paccayākāraṃ), the thundering of the Buddhas becomes truly great, their knowledge enters its proper field, and so on, connected with emptiness.

Likewise, there are four kinds of eternalists (sassatavādā nāma), four kinds of partial eternalists (ekaccasassatavādā), four kinds of extensionists (antānantikā), four kinds of endless equivocators (amarāvikkhepikā), two kinds of fortuitous originationists (adhiccasamuppannikā), sixteen who hold doctrines of percipient immortality (saññīvādā), eight who hold doctrines of non-percipient immortality (asaññīvādā), eight who hold doctrines of neither percipient nor non-percipient immortality (nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā), seven kinds of annihilationists (ucchedavādā), and five kinds of present-life Nibbāna-ists (diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā nāma).

Depending on this, they assume this. Others have neither the capacity nor the power to explain these sixty-two speculative views (dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni), breaking them down (bhinditvā) into a state free from entanglement (nijjaṭaṃ) and free from thickets (niggumbaṃ), for this is not the domain of others; it is the domain only of the Tathāgata.

Thus, in the classification of the diversity of creeds (samayantaraṃ), the thundering of the Buddhas becomes truly great, their knowledge enters its proper field, the greatness of the Buddha-knowledge is discerned, and their teaching becomes deep, stamped with the three characteristics, connected with emptiness.

In this place (imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne), the classification of the diversity of creeds (samayantaraṃ) is found (labbhati). Therefore, in order to show the greatness of his knowledge of omniscience (sabbaññutaññāṇassa mahantabhāvadassanatthaṃ), and in order to give, through the discourse (desanāya ca), an explication and elucidation of emptiness (suññatāpakāsanavibhāvanatthaṃ), the King of the Dhamma (dhammarājā), entering into the diversity of creeds (samayantaraṃ anupavisanto), begins his answer to the question with the words: "There are, monks, some recluses and brahmins (santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā)," and so forth, a question and answer (evaṃ pucchāvissajjanaṃ ārabhi).

mula_pali: 29. ‘‘Santi , bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino, pubbantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni adhivuttipadāni (sī. pī.) abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi. Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni  adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi?
mula_english:
29. "Bhikkhus, there are some ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the past ( *pubbantakappikā*), holding fixed views about the past (*pubbantānudiṭṭhino*), and who, with reference to the past (*pubbantaṃ ārabbha*), assert various conceptual theorems (*anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni*) and doctrinal propositions (*adhivuttipadāni*) in eighteen ways (*aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi*).

And on what grounds, with reference to what, do these venerable ascetics and Brahmins, being speculators about the past (*pubbantakappikā*) and holding fixed views about the past (*pubbantānudiṭṭhino*), assert various conceptual theorems (*anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni*) in reference to the past (*pubbantaṃ ārabbha*) in eighteen ways (*aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi*)?
commentary_pali: 29. Tattha santīti atthi saṃvijjanti upalabbhanti. Bhikkhaveti ālapanavacanaṃ. Eketi ekacce. Samaṇabrāhmaṇāti pabbajjūpagatabhāvena samaṇā, jātiyā brāhmaṇā. Lokena vā samaṇāti ca brāhmaṇāti ca evaṃ sammatā. Pubbantaṃ  kappetvā vikappetvā gaṇhantīti pubbantakappikā. Pubbantakappo vā  etesaṃ atthīti pubbantakappikā. Tattha antoti ayaṃ saddo antaabbhantaramariyādalāmakaparabhāgakoṭṭhāsesu dissati. ‘‘Antapūro udarapūro’’tiādīsu hi ante antasaddo. ‘‘Caranti loke parivārachannā anto asuddhā bahi sobhamānā’’tiādīsu (saṃ. ni. 1.122) abbhantare. ‘‘Kāyabandhanassa anto jīrati (cūḷava. 278). ‘‘Sā haritantaṃ vā panthantaṃ vā selantaṃ vā udakantaṃ vā’’tiādīsu (ma. ni. 1.304) mariyādāyaṃ. ‘‘Antamidaṃ, bhikkhave, jīvikānaṃ yadidaṃ piṇḍolya’’ntiādīsu (saṃ. ni. 3.80) lāmake. ‘‘Esevanto dukkhassā’’tiādīsu (saṃ. ni. 2.51) parabhāge. Sabbapaccayasaṅkhayo hi dukkhassa parabhāgo koṭīti vuccati. ‘‘Sakkāyo kho, āvuso, eko anto’’tiādīsu (a. ni. 6.61) koṭṭhāse. Svāyaṃ idhāpi koṭṭhāse vattati. Kappasaddopi –  ‘‘tiṭṭhatu, bhante bhagavā kappaṃ’’ (dī. ni. 2.167), ‘‘atthi kappo nipajjituṃ’’ (a. ni. 8.80), ‘‘kappakatena akappakataṃ saṃsibbitaṃ hotī’’ti, (pāci. 371) evaṃ āyukappalesakappavinayakappādīsu sambahulesu atthesu vattati. Idha taṇhādiṭṭhīsu vattatīti veditabbo. Vuttampi cetaṃ – ‘‘kappāti dve kappā, taṇhākappo ca diṭṭhikappo cā’’ti (mahāni. 28). Tasmā taṇhādiṭṭhivasena atītaṃ khandhakoṭṭhāsaṃ kappetvā pakappetvā ṭhitāti pubbantakappikāti evamettha attho veditabbo. Tesaṃ evaṃ pubbantaṃ kappetvā ṭhitānaṃ punappunaṃ uppajjanavasena pubbantameva anugatā diṭṭhīti pubbantānudiṭṭhino. Te evaṃdiṭṭhino taṃ pubbantaṃ ārabbha āgamma paṭicca aññampi janaṃ diṭṭhigatikaṃ karontā anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi. Tattha anekavihitānīti anekavidhāni. Adhimuttipadānīti adhivacanapadāni. Atha vā bhūtaṃ atthaṃ  abhibhavitvā yathāsabhāvato aggahetvā pavattanato adhimuttiyoti diṭṭhiyo vuccanti. Adhimuttīnaṃ padāni adhimuttipadāni, diṭṭhidīpakāni vacanānīti attho. Aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhīti aṭṭhārasahi kāraṇehi.
commentary_english:
29. Herein, there are means, there are found, there are perceived.
Bhikkhave = "Bhikkhus." This is a term of address.
"One" [means] one.
*Śramaṇa* and *brāhmaṇa* mean *śramaṇas* due to having undertaken the homeless life, and *brāhmaṇas* by birth.
Or, they are thus regarded by the world as *śramaṇas* and as *brāhmaṇas*.
“Speculators about the past”: they apprehend after thinking and speculating about the past.
Or, because they have speculations about the past, therefore, [they are called] speculators about the past.
There, *anta* thus, this term is seen in inner, limit, bad, superior, portion, and compartment.
Indeed, in “full of entrails, full of belly,” etc., the term *anta* is [used].
In “they wander in the world, covered by a retinue, inwardly impure, outwardly beautiful,” etc.
Ni.

122) In the inner part.
“The end of the belts wore away (Cūḷava.
278)."
"It comes to green grass, or to a road, or to a rock, or to water," etc. (Ma.
Ni.

304) In limit.
"This is the end, monks, of the means of livelihood, namely, what is begged," etc. (Saṃ.
Ni.

80) In badness.
"This is the cessation of suffering," etc. (Saṃ.
Ni.

Indeed, the destruction of all conditions is called the supreme portion, the extremity of suffering.
"Personal existence, friends, is one end," etc. (A.
Ni.

Moreover, this also applies here, in [the sense of] portion.
The term *kappa* also— "May the Blessed One remain, *bhante*, for an *aeon* (dī.

371) Thus, it occurs in many senses, such as lifespan-construction, trace-construction, discipline-construction, and so on.
Kappa here signifies craving (*taṇhā*) and views (*diṭṭhi*).
As it is said: “There are two thought constructions (*kappā*): the thought construction governed by craving (*taṇhā*) and the thought construction governed by views (*diṭṭhi*)” (Mahāni. 28).
Therefore, the meaning of "speculators about the past" (*pubbantakappika*) should be understood as follows: they persistently think and speculate about the past portion of the aggregates (*atītaṃ khandhakoṭṭhāsaṃ*) by way of craving (*taṇhā*) and views (*diṭṭhi*).
As they thus persistently speculate about the past (*pubbantaṃ kappetvā ṭhitānaṃ*), their views (*diṭṭhi*), by arising repeatedly (*punappunaṃ uppajjanavasena*), become settled on the past; thus they "hold settled views about the past" (*pubbantānudiṭṭhino*).
Holding such views (*evaṃdiṭṭhino*), they try to convert other people (*aññampi janaṃ*) to their views (*diṭṭhigatikaṃ karontā*) by asserting on eighteen grounds (*aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi*) various conceptual theorems (*anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni*) referring to the past (*taṃ pubbantaṃ ārabbha āgamma paṭicca*).
There, *anekavihitāni* means *anekavidhāni* (of many kinds).
The word “conceptual theorems” (*adhimuttipadāni*) means “designational terms” (*adhivacana-padāni*).
Or else, views (*diṭṭhiyo*) are called *adhimutti* because they do violence to the real meaning (*bhūtaṃ atthaṃ abhibhavitvā*) and do not apprehend things according to their true nature (*yathāsabhāvato aggahetvā pavattanato*).
*Adhimuttīnaṃ padāni* means *adhimuttipadāni*, terms signifying views (*diṭṭhidīpakāni vacanāni*).
*Aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi* means *aṭṭhārasahi kāraṇehi* (on eighteen grounds).

mula_pali: 30. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā, sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi. Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi?
mula_english:
30. "There are, monks (bhikkhave), some ascetics and Brahmins (samaṇabrāhmaṇā) who are eternalists (sassatavādā), and who proclaim the self (ātmānam) and the world (lokam) to be eternal (śāśvataṃ) on four grounds (catūhi vatthūhi).
And owing to what, with reference to what, do these honourable (bhonto) recluses and brahmins (samaṇabrāhmaṇā) proclaim their views, being eternalists (sassatavādā), proclaiming the self (ātmānam) and the world (lokam) to be eternal (śāśvataṃ) on four grounds (catūhi vatthūhi)?
commentary_pali: 30. Idāni  yehi aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi abhivadanti, tesaṃ kathetukamyatāya pucchāya ‘‘te ca kho bhonto’’tiādinā nayena pucchitvā tāni vatthūni vibhajitvā dassetuṃ ‘‘santi, bhikkhave’’tiādimāha. Tattha vadanti etenāti vādo, diṭṭhigatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Sassato vādo etesanti sassatavādā, sassatadiṭṭhinoti attho. Eteneva nayena ito paresampi evarūpānaṃ padānaṃ attho veditabbo. Sassataṃ attānañca lokañcāti rūpādīsu aññataraṃ attāti ca lokoti ca gahetvā taṃ sassataṃ amaraṃ niccaṃ dhuvaṃ paññapenti. Yathāha – ‘‘rūpaṃ attā ceva loko ca sassato cāti attānañca lokañca paññapenti tathā vedanaṃ, saññaṃ, saṅkhāre, viññāṇaṃ attā ceva loko ca sassato cāti attānañca lokañca paññapentī’’ti.
commentary_english:
30. Now, in order to explain those eighteen things (aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi) that they assert, he asks a question to express his desire to speak, "But those venerable ones (te ca kho bhonto)," and after asking in this way, to show those things by dividing them, he says, "There are, monks (santi, bhikkhave)."
There, *vāda* is what they speak with; this is a designation for a view (diṭṭhigatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ).
Those who hold the doctrine of permanence are called eternalists (sassatavādā), this is the meaning of eternalist view (sassatadiṭṭhi).
By this same method, the meaning of similar terms should be understood.
They postulate the self (attā) and the world (loka) as eternal (sassataṃ), by grasping one of the aggregates such as form (rūpādīsu), as "the self (attā) and the world (loko)," they declare it to be eternal (sassataṃ), immortal (amaraṃ), permanent (niccaṃ), and stable (dhruvaṃ).
As it is said: "Form (rūpaṃ) is the self (attā), and the world (loko) is eternal (sassato)," thus they postulate the self (attānaṃ) and the world (lokaṃ). Likewise, feeling (vedanaṃ), perception (saññaṃ), mental formations (saṅkhāre), consciousness (viññāṇaṃ) are the self (attā), and the world (loko) is eternal (sassato)," thus they postulate the self (attānaṃ) and the world (lokaṃ).

mula_pali: 31. ‘‘Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte ( ) (parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpattilese) (syā. ka.) anekavihitaṃ  pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati. Seyyathidaṃ – ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekānipi jātisatāni anekānipi jātisahassāni anekānipi jātisatasahassāni – ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ  anussarati. ‘‘So  evamāha – ‘sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito; te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisamaṃ. Taṃ kissa hetu? Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya  anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi, yathāsamāhite citte anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi seyyathidaṃ – ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi  jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekānipi jātisatāni anekānipi jātisahassāni anekānipi jātisatasahassāni – amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapannoti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi. Imināmahaṃ etaṃ jānāmi ‘‘yathā sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito; te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisama’’nti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
mula_english:
31.

“Here, monks, a certain ascetic or *brāhmana*, by means of ardour (*ātappa*), endeavour (*padhāna*), application (*anuyoga*), diligence (*appamāda*), and right reflection (*sammāmanasikāra*), attains to such a state of mental concentration (*cetosamādhi*) that with his mind thus concentrated, he recollects his numerous past lives (*anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati*).

That is, one birth, two births, three, four, or five births; ten, twenty, thirty, forty, or fifty births; a hundred, a thousand, or a hundred thousand births; many hundreds of births, many thousands of births, many hundreds of thousands of births. ‘There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my span of life. Passing away thence, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my span of life. Passing away thence, I re-arose here.’

Thus he recollects his numerous past lives in their modes and their details (*iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati*).

“He speaks thus: ‘The *ātman* (self) and the world are eternal (*sassato attā ca loko ca*), barren, steadfast as a mountain peak (*kūṭaṭṭho*), standing firm like a pillar (*esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito*). And though these beings roam and wander (*sandhāvanti saṃsaranti*), pass away and re-arise (*cavanti upapajjanti*), yet the self and the world remain the same just like eternity itself (*atthitveva sassatisamaṃ*.’

Why is that? Because I, by means of ardour (*ātappa*), endeavour (*padhāna*), application (*anuyoga*), diligence (*appamāda*), and right reflection (*sammāmanasikāra*), attain to such a degree of mental concentration (*cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi*) that with my mind thus concentrated, I recollect my numerous past lives (*anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi*): that is, one birth, two births, three, four, or five births; ten, twenty, thirty, forty, or fifty births; a hundred, a thousand, or a hundred thousand births; many hundreds of births, many thousands of births, many hundreds of thousands of births. ‘There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my span of life. Passing away thence, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my span of life. Passing away thence, I re-arose here.’

Thus with their aspects and particulars I recollected my manifold past lives (*iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi*).

For this reason I know this: the *ātman* (self) and the world are eternal (*sassato attā ca loko ca*), barren, steadfast as a mountain peak (*kūṭaṭṭho*), standing firm like a pillar (*esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito*). And though these beings roam and wander (*sandhāvanti saṃsaranti*), pass away and re-arise (*cavanti upapajjanti*), yet the self and the world remain the same just like eternity itself (*atthitveva sassatisamaṃ*.’

That is the first way in which some ascetics and *brāhmanas* proclaim the eternity (*sassatavādā*) of the *ātman* (self) and the world (*sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti*).
commentary_pali: 31.Ātappamanvāyātiādīsu vīriyaṃ kilesānaṃ ātāpanabhāvena ātappanti vuttaṃ. Tadeva padahanavasena padhānaṃ. Punappunaṃ yuttavasena anuyogoti. Evaṃ tippabhedaṃ vīriyaṃ anvāya āgamma paṭiccāti attho. Appamādo vuccati satiyā avippavāso. Sammā manasikāroti upāyamanasikāro, pathamanasikāro, atthato ñāṇanti vuttaṃ hoti. Yasmiñhi manasikāre ṭhitassa pubbenivāsānussati ñāṇaṃ ijjhati, ayaṃ imasmiṃ ṭhāne manasikāroti adhippeto. Tasmā vīriyañca satiñca ñāṇañca āgammāti ayamettha saṅkhepattho. Tathārūpanti tathājātikaṃ. Cetosamādhinti  cittasamādhiṃ. Phusatīti vindati paṭilabhati. Yathā samāhite citteti yena samādhinā sammā āhite suṭṭhu ṭhapite cittamhi anekavihitaṃpubbenivāsantiādīnaṃ attho visuddhimagge vutto. So evamāhāti so evaṃ jhānānubhāvasampanno hutvā diṭṭhigatiko evaṃ vadati. Vañjhoti vañjhapasuvañjhatālādayo viya aphalo kassaci ajanakoti. Etena ‘‘attā’’ti ca ‘‘loko’’ti ca gahitānaṃ jhānādīnaṃ rūpādijanakabhāvaṃ paṭikkhipati. Pabbatakūṭaṃ viya ṭhitoti kūṭaṭṭho. Esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitoti esikaṭṭhāyī viya hutvā ṭhitoti esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito. Yathā sunikhāto esikatthambho niccalo tiṭṭhati, evaṃ ṭhitoti attho. Ubhayenapi lokassa vināsābhāvaṃ dīpeti. Keci pana īsikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitoti pāḷiṃ vatvā muñje īsikā viya ṭhitoti vadanti . Tatrāyamadhippāyo – yadidaṃ jāyatīti vuccati, taṃ muñjato īsikā viya vijjamānameva nikkhamati. Yasmā ca īsikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito, tasmā teva sattā sandhāvanti, ito aññattha gacchantīti attho. Saṃsarantīti aparāparaṃ sañcaranti. Cavantīti evaṃ saṅkhyaṃ gacchanti. Tathā upapajjantīti. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana pubbe ‘‘sassato attā ca loko cā’’ti vatvā idāni te ca sattā sandhāvantītiādinā vacanena ayaṃ diṭṭhigatiko attanāyeva attano vādaṃ bhindati, diṭṭhigatikassa dassanaṃ nāma na nibaddhaṃ, thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇu viya cañcalaṃ, ummattakapacchiyaṃ pūvakhaṇḍagūthagomayādīni viya cettha sundarampi asundarampi hoti yevāti vuttaṃ. Atthitveva sassatisamanti ettha sassatīti niccaṃ vijjamānatāya mahāpathaviṃva maññati, tathā sinerupabbatacandimasūriye. Tato tehi samaṃ attānaṃ maññamānā atthi tveva sassatisamanti vadanti. Idāni sassato attā ca loko cātiādikāya paṭiññāya sādhanatthaṃ hetuṃ dassento ‘‘taṃ kissa hetu? Ahañhi ātappamanvāyā’’tiādimāha. Tattha imināmahaṃ etaṃ jānāmīti iminā visesādhigamena ahaṃ etaṃ paccakkhato jānāmi, na kevalaṃ saddhāmattakeneva vadāmīti dasseti, makāro panettha padasandhikaraṇatthaṃ vutto. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānanti catūhi vatthūhīti vatthusaddena vuttesu catūsu ṭhānesu idaṃ paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, idaṃ jātisatasahassamattānussaraṇaṃ paṭhamaṃ kāraṇanti attho.
commentary_english:
31. In ātappamanvāyāti, etc., *vīriya* is said to be *ātappa* because of the heating nature of the defilements.

That same is *pradhāna* because of the way of striving.

*Anuyoga* is because of the way of repeated application.

Thus, *vīriya*, with its three distinctions, is attained by following, approaching, and प्रतिच्च. Such is the meaning.

*Appamāda* is called the non-separation from mindfulness ( *smṛti*).

*Sammā manasikāra* is skillful mental application, the initial mental application; in meaning, it is said to be knowledge ( jñāna).

Because in whatever mental application ( *manasikāra*) that one abides, the knowledge of the recollection of former abodes is successful; this mental application in this place is what is intended.

Therefore, by approaching *vīriya*, *smṛti*, and *jñāna*, this is the meaning in brief here.

*Tathārūpa* means of such a kind.

*Cetosamādhi* means concentration of mind (*cittasamādhi*).

*Phusati* means finds and obtains.

As in "with the mind concentrated" ( *samāhite citteti*), the meaning of "by whatever concentration (*samādhinā*) the mind is well placed, well established, the various forms of recollection of former abodes, etc." is said in the *Visuddhimagga*.

"He says thus" means being endowed with the power of jhāna, he, the adherent to a view, speaks thus.

*Vañjha* means like a barren animal, a barren palm tree, etc., fruitless, not generating anything for anyone.

By this, he rejects the nature of producing form, etc., of the *jhānas*, etc., which are apprehended as "self" (*attā*) and "world" (*loka*).

"Standing like a mountain peak" (*pabbatakūṭaṃ viya ṭhito*) means *kūṭaṭṭho*.

*Esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito* means standing firm like a pillar (*esikaṭṭhāyī viya hutvā ṭhito*), thus *esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito*.

As a well-implanted pillar stands motionless, so it stands. Such is the meaning.

By both, he shows the indestructibility of the world ( *loka*).

But some, saying the text is *īsikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito*, say that it stands like a reed (*īsikā*) in *muñja* grass.

The meaning there is this: that which is said to be born (*jāyatīti*), emerges as something already existing, like a reed (*īsikā*) from *muñja* grass.

And because it stands like a pillar (*īsikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito*), therefore those beings wander on, from here going elsewhere. Such is the meaning.

*Saṃsarantīti* means wander about from one to another (*aparāparaṃ sañcaranti*).

*Cavantīti* means they go to reckoning (*evaṃ saṅkhyaṃ gacchanti*).

Likewise, they come to be (*tathā upapajjantīti*).

In the *Aṭṭhakathā*, however, having previously said, "The self (*attā*) and the world (*loka*) are eternal" (*sassato attā ca loko cā*), now by the statement beginning with "and those beings wander on" (*te ca sattā sandhāvantīti*), this adherent to a view, by his own self, undermines his own doctrine ( *vādaṃ bhindati*); the vision of the adherent to a view is not consistent; it is fickle like a stake implanted in a heap of chaff; in the basket of a madman, there is both beautiful and unbeautiful, like pieces of cake, excrement, cow dung, etc., thus it is said.

"*Atthitveva sassatisamanti*," here, *sassatīti* means he thinks of the great earth as being constantly present, and likewise Mount Sumeru, the moon, and the sun.

Then, conceiving the self (*attānaṃ*) to be equal to them, they say, "*Atthi tveva sassatisamanti*."

Now, showing the reason for the purpose of proving the assertion beginning with "The self (*attā*) and the world (*loka*) are eternal" (*sassato attā ca loko cāti*), he says, "What is the reason? Because I follow ātappa."

There, "By this I know this" means by this special attainment, I know this directly; he shows that he does not speak from mere faith alone. The *ma* is said here for the purpose of connecting the words.

Bhikkhus, this is the first case, and in the four cases spoken of by the word "ground" (*vatthu*), this is the first case; this recollection of hundreds of thousands of births is the first cause. Such is the meaning.

mula_pali: 32. ‘‘Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati. Seyyathidaṃ – ekampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ dvepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni tīṇipi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni cattāripi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni pañcapi  saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni dasapi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni – ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī  evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati. ‘‘So  evamāha – ‘sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito; te ca  sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisamaṃ. Taṃ kissa hetu? Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi yathāsamāhite citte anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi. Seyyathidaṃ – ekampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ dvepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni tīṇipi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni cattāripi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni pañcapi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni dasapi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni. Amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapannoti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi. Imināmahaṃ etaṃ jānāmi ‘‘yathā sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito, te ca  sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisama’’nti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
mula_english:
32. "And furthermore, venerable monks and Brahmins, relying on what, depending on what, do they proclaim the eternalist doctrine, the self and the world are eternal?"

"Here, monks, a certain ascetic or Brahmin, through ardour (*ātappa*), through striving (*padhāna*), through application (*anuyoga*), through diligence (*appamāda*), through proper attention (*sammāmanasikāra*), attains such a mental concentration (*cetosamādhi*) that, with his mind thus concentrated, he recollects many kinds of past lives (*anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati*).

That is to say, one cycle of world-contraction and expansion (*saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭa*), two cycles of world-contraction and expansion, three, four, five, or ten cycles of world-contraction and expansion: 'There I was so-and-so by name, of such-and-such a clan, of such-and-such appearance, such was my food, such was my experience of pleasure and pain, such was the extent of my life. Passing away from there, I was reborn there. There too I was so-and-so by name, of such-and-such a clan, of such-and-such appearance, such was my food, such was my experience of pleasure and pain, such was the extent of my life. Passing away from there, I was reborn here.'

Thus he recollects his past abodes with their modes and details (*sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati*).

"He says thus: 'The self (*attā*) and the world (*loka*) are eternal (*sassato*), barren (*vañjha*), steadfast as a mountain peak (*kūṭaṭṭha*), standing firm like a pillar (*esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhita*). And though these beings (*sattā*) roam and wander (*sandhāvanti saṃsaranti*), pass away (*cavanti*) and re-arise (*upapajjanti*), yet the self and the world remain the same just like eternity itself (*atthitveva sassatisamaṃ*.'

What is the reason for that? Because I, by means of ardour (*ātappa*), by means of striving (*padhāna*), by means of application (*anuyoga*), by means of diligence (*appamāda*), and by means of right reflection (*sammāmanasikāra*), attain to such a degree of mental concentration (*cetosamādhi*) that with my mind thus concentrated, I recollect my numerous past lives (*anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi*).

That is to say, one cycle of world-contraction and expansion (*saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭa*), two cycles of world-contraction and expansion, three, four, five, or ten cycles of world-contraction and expansion.

There I was so named, of such a clan, with such an appearance, such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my life-span. Passing away from there, I arose there. There too I was so named, of such a clan, with such an appearance, such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my life-span. Passing away from there, I was reborn here.

Thus I recollect my manifold past lives in their modes and details (*sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi*).

For this reason, I know this: 'The self (*attā*) and the world (*loka*) are eternal (*sassato*), barren (*vañjha*), steadfast as a mountain peak (*kūṭaṭṭha*), standing firm like a pillar (*esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhita*). And though these beings (*sattā*) roam and wander (*sandhāvanti saṃsaranti*), pass away (*cavanti*) and re-arise (*upapajjanti*), yet the self and the world remain the same just like eternity itself (*atthitveva sassatisamaṃ*.'

This, monks, is the second reason, relying on which, depending on which, some ascetics and Brahmins proclaim the eternalist doctrine, the self and the world are eternal (*sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti*)."
commentary_pali: 32-33. Upari  vāradvayepi eseva nayo. Kevalañhi ayaṃ vāro anekajātisatasahassānussaraṇavasena vutto. Itare dasacattālīsasaṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappānussaraṇavasena. Mandapañño hi titthiyo anekajātisatasahassamattaṃ anussarati, majjhimapañño dasasaṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappāni, tikkhapañño cattālīsaṃ, na tato uddhaṃ.
commentary_english:
32-33. The same method of explanation applies to the following two sections.

Indeed, this section (vāra) is stated in terms of the recollection of many hundreds of thousands of past births (anekajātisatasahassānussaraṇavasena).

The others speak in terms of the recollection of ten and forty aeons of world contraction and expansion (dasa-cattālīsa-saṃvaṭṭa-vivaṭṭa-kappa-anussaraṇa-vasena).

For a sectarian (titthiyo) with dull intelligence (mandapañño) can recollect several hundred thousand past births; one with medium intelligence (majjhimapañño) can recollect ten aeons of world contraction and expansion (dasa-saṃvaṭṭa-vivaṭṭa-kappāni); and one with keen intelligence (tikkhapañño) can recollect forty, but not more than that.

Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya  tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati. Seyyathidaṃ – dasapi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni vīsampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni tiṃsampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni cattālīsampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni – ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati. ‘‘So  evamāha – ‘sassato attā ca loko  ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito; te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisamaṃ.
