Seyyathidaṃ – dasapi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni vīsampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni tiṃsampi  saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni cattālīsampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni – ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapannoti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi. Imināmahaṃ etaṃ jānāmi ‘‘yathā sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito, te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisama’’nti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
mula_english:
33. Furthermore, on what grounds, relying on what, do some ascetics and Brahmins proclaim the doctrine of eternalism, that the self (ātman) and the world are eternal? Here, monks, some ascetic or Brahmin, through ardour (*ātappa*), endeavour (*padhāna*), application (*anuyoga*), diligence (*appamāda*), and right reflection (*sammāmanasikāra*), attains to such a degree of mental concentration (*cetosamādhi*) that with his mind thus concentrated, he recollects his numerous past lives (*pubbenivāsa*) in their modes and their details.

That is, he recalls ten, twenty, thirty, forty periods of contraction and expansion (*saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭa*). “There my name was so-and-so, my clan was so-and-so, my appearance was so-and-so, such was my food, such was my experience of pleasure and pain, such was my life span. Passing away from there, I was reborn there. There too my name was so-and-so, my clan was so-and-so, my appearance was so-and-so, such was my food, such was my experience of pleasure and pain, such was my life span. Passing away from there, I was reborn here.”

In this way, he remembers the details of his various past lives (*pubbenivāsa*).

He says: “The self ( *attā*) and the world are eternal, barren, steadfast as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar. And though these beings roam and wander, pass away and re-arise, yet existence itself is just like eternity.”

What is the reason for this? Because I, through ardour (*ātappa*), endeavour (*padhāna*), application (*anuyoga*), diligence (*appamāda*), and right reflection (*sammāmanasikāra*), attain to such a degree of mental concentration (*cetosamādhi*) that with my mind thus concentrated, I recollect my numerous past lives (*pubbenivāsa*).

That is, he recalls ten, twenty, thirty, forty periods of contraction and expansion (*saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭa*). “There my name was so-and-so, my clan was so-and-so, my appearance was so-and-so, such was my food, such was my experience of pleasure and pain, such was my life span. Passing away from there, I was reborn there. There too my name was so-and-so, my clan was so-and-so, my appearance was so-and-so, such was my food, such was my experience of pleasure and pain, such was my life span. Passing away from there, I was reborn here.”

In this way, I remember the details of my various past lives (*pubbenivāsa*).

For this reason, I know this: the self ( *attā*) and the world are eternal, barren, steadfast as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar. And though these beings roam and wander, pass away and re-arise, yet existence itself is just like eternity.’

This, monks, is the third basis (*ṭhāna*) on which, relying on which, some ascetics (*samaṇa*) and Brahmins (*brāhmaṇa*) are eternalists (*sassatavādā*) and proclaim the self (*attā*) and the world to be eternal (*sassataṃ*).
commentary_pali: 32-33. Upari  vāradvayepi eseva nayo. Kevalañhi ayaṃ vāro anekajātisatasahassānussaraṇavasena vutto. Itare dasacattālīsasaṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappānussaraṇavasena. Mandapañño hi titthiyo anekajātisatasahassamattaṃ anussarati, majjhimapañño dasasaṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappāni, tikkhapañño cattālīsaṃ, na tato uddhaṃ.
commentary_english:
32-33. The same method of explanation applies to the following two sections only.
Indeed, this section speaks in terms of the recollection of many hundred thousands of past births.
The following two speak in terms of the recollection of ten and forty aeons of world contraction and expansion, respectively.
For a sectarian with dull intelligence (manda-pañño) can recollect approximately several hundred thousand past births; one with medium intelligence (majjhima-pañño) can recollect ten aeons of world contraction and expansion; and one with keen intelligence (tikkha-pañño) can recollect forty, but not more than that.

mula_pali: 34. ‘‘Catutthe ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā takkī hoti vīmaṃsī, so takkapariyāhataṃ vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayaṃ paṭibhānaṃ evamāha – ‘sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito; te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisama’nti . Idaṃ, bhikkhave, catutthaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
mula_english:
34. “And furthermore, venerable bhikkhus, relying on what, depending on what, do some ascetics and Brahmins proclaim the eternalist doctrine (sassatavāda), asserting the self (attā) and the world (loka) are eternal (sassataṃ)? Here, bhikkhus, some recluse or Brahmin is a rationalist (takkī), an investigator (vīmaṃsī). He declares his view—hammered out by reason, deduced from his investigations, following his own flight of thought—thus: ‘The self (attā) and the world (loka) are eternal (sassato), barren (vañjho), steadfast as a mountain peak (kūṭaṭṭho), standing firm like a pillar (esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito). And though these beings (sattā) roam (sandhāvanti) and wander (saṃsaranti), pass away (cavanti) and re-arise (upapajjanti), yet the self and the world remain the same just like eternity itself (atthitveva sassatisama).’

This, bhikkhus, is the fourth case, relying on which, depending on which, some ascetics and Brahmins proclaim the eternalist doctrine (sassatavādā), asserting the self (attānaṃ) and the world (lokaṃ) are eternal (sassataṃ).
commentary_pali: 34. Catutthavāre takkayatīti takkī, takko vā assa atthīti takkī. Takketvā vitakketvā diṭṭhigāhino etaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Vīmaṃsāya samannāgatoti vīmaṃsī. Vīmaṃsā nāma tulanā ruccanā khamanā. Yathā hi puriso yaṭṭhiyā udakaṃ vīmaṃsitvā otarati, evameva yo tulayitvā ruccitvā  khamāpetvā diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti, so ‘‘vīmaṃsī’’ti veditabbo. Takkapariyāhatanti takkena pariyāhataṃ, tena tena pariyāyena takketvāti attho. Vīmaṃsānucaritanti tāya vuttappakārāya vīmaṃsāya anucaritaṃ. Sayaṃpaṭibhānanti attano paṭibhānamattasañjātaṃ. Evamāhāti sassatadiṭṭhiṃ gahetvā evaṃ vadati. Tattha catubbidho takkī – anussutiko, jātissaro, lābhī, suddhatakkikoti. Tattha yo ‘‘vessantaro nāma rājā ahosī’’tiādīni sutvā ‘‘tena hi yadi vessantarova bhagavā, sassato  attā’’ti takkayanto diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti, ayaṃ anussutiko nāma. Dve tisso jātiyo saritvā – ‘‘ahameva pubbe asukasmiṃ nāma ahosiṃ, tasmā sassato attā’’ti takkayanto jātissaratakkiko nāma. Yo pana lābhitāya ‘‘yathā me idāni attā sukhī hoti, atītepi evaṃ ahosi, anāgatepi bhavissatī’’ti takkayitvā diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti, ayaṃ lābhītakkiko nāma. ‘‘Evaṃ sati idaṃ hotī’’ti takkamatteneva gaṇhanto pana suddhatakkiko nāma.
commentary_english:
34. Because one reasons (*takkayati*), he is a rationalist (*takkī*); or because he has reasoning (*takka*), he is a rationalist (*takkī*).
This is a designation for a theorist (*diṭṭhigāhino*) who assumes his views via reasoning (*takketvā*) and initial thought (*vitakketvā*).
Because he is endowed with investigation (*vīmaṃsā*), he is an investigator (*vīmaṃsī*).
“Investigation” (*vīmaṃsā*) is pondering (*tulanā*), preferring (*ruccanā*), acquiescing (*khamanā*).
Just as a man descends into water after investigating its depth with a stick (*yaṭṭhiyā*), the investigator (*vīmaṃsī*) ponders (*tulayitvā*), forms a preference (*ruccitvā*), acquiesces (*khamāpetvā*), and assumes his view (*diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti*); he is to be understood as an investigator (*vīmaṃsī*).
"Affected by reasoning" (*takkapariyāhata*) means affected by reasoning (*takkena pariyāhataṃ*), meaning he reasons through this and that method (*pariyāyena takketvā*).
"Accompanied by investigation" (*vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ*) means accompanied by investigation (*vīmaṃsāya anucaritaṃ*) of the type that has been described (*vuttappakārāya*).
"Self-intuition" (*sayaṃpaṭibhāna*) means arisen merely from one's own intuition (*attano paṭibhānamattasañjātaṃ*).
Thus he speaks, meaning he takes up the eternalist view (*sassatadiṭṭhiṃ gahetvā*) and speaks thus (*evaṃ vadati*).
There are four kinds of rationalists (*takkī*): one who reasons from hearsay (*anussutiko*), one who remembers past lives (*jātissaro*), one who reasons from fortune (*lābhī*), and one who follows pure reason (*suddhatakkiko*).
There, one who, having heard things such as, “There was a king named Vessantara (*vessantaro nāma rājā ahosī*)” and so on, reasons, “Therefore, if the Blessed One was Vessantara (*vessantarova bhagavā*), there must be an eternal self (*sassato attā*)” and assumes a view, this is called one who reasons from hearsay (*anussutiko nāma*).
Having remembered two or three births (*dve tisso jātiyo saritvā*)—"I myself was so-and-so in the past (*ahameva pubbe asukasmiṃ nāma ahosiṃ*), therefore there is an eternal self (*sassato attā*)"—one who reasons thus is called one who remembers past lives (*jātissaratakkiko nāma*).
But one who, on account of gain (*lābhitāya*), reasons, "As my self is happy now (*yathā me idāni attā sukhī hoti*), so it was in the past (*atītepi evaṃ ahosi*), and so it will be in the future (*anāgatepi bhavissatī*)," and assumes a view, this is called one who reasons from fortune (*lābhītakkiko nāma*).
But one who, grasping (*gaṇhanto*) at mere reasoning (*takkamattena*), thinks, "If this exists (*evaṃ sati*), that exists (*idaṃ hoti*)," is called one who follows pure reason (*suddhatakkiko nāma*).

mula_pali: 35. ‘‘Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi. Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva catūhi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena; natthi ito bahiddhā.
mula_english:
35. "It is on these four grounds, *bhikkhus*, that those *samaṇa* and *brāhmaṇa* who are proponents of eternalism (*śāśvatavāda*) propound the self (*ātman*) and the world to be eternal.

Whatever *samaṇa*s or *brāhmaṇa*s there may be, *bhikkhus*, who are proponents of eternalism (*śāśvatavāda*) and propound the self (*ātman*) and the world to be eternal, all of them do so on these four grounds or on one or another of them. There is nothing outside of these.
commentary_pali: 35.Etesaṃ vā aññatarenāti etesaṃyeva catunnaṃ vatthūnaṃ aññatarena ekena vā dvīhi vā tīhi vā. Natthi ito bahiddhāti imehi pana vatthūhi bahi aññaṃ ekaṃ kāraṇampi sassatapaññattiyā natthīti appaṭivattiyaṃ sīhanādaṃ nadati.
commentary_english:
35. "Or by any one of these": indeed, by any one of these four grounds, by one, or by two, or by three.
"Outside of these there is none": Outside of these grounds, there is not even one cause for the proclaiming of eternalism. ( *sassatapaññattiyā natthi* ) The Buddha roars his irreversible lion’s roar ( *appaṭivattiyaṃ sīhanādaṃ nadati* ).

mula_pali: 36. ‘‘Tayidaṃ , bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānāti – ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṃgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṃgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā’ti, tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti; tañca pajānanaṃ pajānaṃ (?) dī. ni. 3.36 pāḷiaṭṭhakathā passitabbaṃ na  parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā. Vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
mula_english:
36.

"This, monks, the *Tathāgata* knows: 'These bases for views, thus grasped, thus clung to, lead to such destinies, to such a state in the world beyond.' And the *Tathāgata* knows that, and even further beyond; and that knowing...

...

3.

36. The *Pāḷi* commentary should be seen. He does not misapprehend, and because he is free from misapprehension, he has realized perfect peace for himself.

Having understood as they really are the arising and the passing away of feelings (*vedanā*), their satisfaction, their unsatisfactoriness, and the escape from them, the *Tathāgata*, monks, is liberated through non-clinging (*anupādāvimutto*).
commentary_pali: 36.Tayidaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānātīti bhikkhave, taṃ idaṃ catubbidhampi diṭṭhigataṃ tathāgato nānappakārato jānāti. Tato taṃ pajānanākāraṃ dassento ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānātiādimāha. Tattha diṭṭhiyova diṭṭhiṭṭhānā nāma. Api ca diṭṭhīnaṃ kāraṇampi diṭṭhiṭṭhānameva. Yathāha ‘‘katamāni aṭṭha diṭṭhiṭṭhānāni? Khandhāpi diṭṭhiṭṭhānaṃ, avijjāpi, phassopi , saññāpi, vitakkopi, ayonisomanasikāropi, pāpamittopi, paratoghosopi diṭṭhiṭṭhāna’’nti. ‘‘Khandhā hetu, khandhā paccayo diṭṭhiṭṭhānaṃ upādāya samuṭṭhānaṭṭhena, evaṃ khandhāpi diṭṭhiṭṭhānaṃ. Avijjā hetu…pe… pāpamitto hetu. Paratoghoso hetu, paratoghoso paccayo diṭṭhiṭṭhānaṃ upādāya samuṭṭhānaṭṭhena, evaṃ paratoghosopi diṭṭhiṭṭhāna’’nti (paṭi. ma. 1.124). Evaṃgahitāti diṭṭhisaṅkhātā tāva  diṭṭhiṭṭhānā – ‘‘sassato attā ca loko cā’’ti evaṃgahitā ādinnā, pavattitāti attho. Evaṃparāmaṭṭhāti nirāsaṅkacittatāya punappunaṃ āmaṭṭhā parāmaṭṭhā, ‘idameva saccaṃ, moghamañña’nti pariniṭṭhāpitā . Kāraṇasaṅkhātā pana diṭṭhiṭṭhānā yathā gayhamānā diṭṭhiyo samuṭṭhāpenti, evaṃ ārammaṇavasena ca pavattanavasena ca āsevanavasena ca gahitā. Anādīnavadassitāya punappunaṃ gahaṇavasena parāmaṭṭhā. Evaṃgatikāti evaṃ nirayatiracchānapettivisayagatikānaṃ aññataragatikā. Evaṃ abhisamparāyāti idaṃ purimapadasseva vevacanaṃ, evaṃvidhaparalokāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tañca tathāgato pajānātīti na kevalañca tathāgato sakāraṇaṃ sagatikaṃ diṭṭhigatameva pajānāti, atha kho tañca sabbaṃ pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ sīlañceva samādhiñca sabbaññutaññāṇañca pajānāti. Tañca pajānanaṃ na parāmasatīti tañca evaṃvidhaṃ anuttaraṃ visesaṃ pajānantopi ahaṃ pajānāmīti taṇhādiṭṭhimānaparāmāsavasena tañca na parāmasati. Aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditāti evaṃ aparāmasato cassa aparāmāsapaccayā sayameva attanāyeva tesaṃ parāmāsakilesānaṃ nibbuti viditā. Pākaṭaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa nibbānanti dasseti. Idāni yathāpaṭipannena tathāgatena sā nibbuti adhigatā, taṃ paṭipattiṃ dassetuṃ yāsu vedanāsu rattā titthiyā ‘‘idha sukhino bhavissāma, ettha sukhino bhavissāmā’’ti diṭṭhigahanaṃ pavisanti, tāsaṃyeva vedanānaṃ vasena kammaṭṭhānaṃ ācikkhanto vedanānaṃ samudayañcātiādimāha. Tattha yathābhūtaṃ viditvāti ‘‘avijjāsamudayā vedanāsamudayoti paccayasamudayaṭṭhena vedanākkhandhassa udayaṃ passati, taṇhāsamudayā vedanāsamudayoti paccayasamudayaṭṭhena vedanākkhandhassa udayaṃ passati, kammasamudayā vedanāsamudayoti paccayasamudayaṭṭhena vedanākkhandhassa udayaṃ passati, phassasamudayā vedanāsamudayoti paccayasamudayaṭṭhena vedanākkhandhassa udayaṃ passati (paṭi. ma. 1.50). Nibbattilakkhaṇaṃ passantopi vedanākkhandhassa udayaṃ passatī’’ti imesaṃ pañcannaṃ lakkhaṇānaṃ vasena vedanānaṃ samudayaṃ yathābhūtaṃ viditvā; ‘‘avijjānirodhā vedanānirodhoti paccayanirodhaṭṭhena vedanākkhandhassa  vayaṃ passati, taṇhānirodhā  vedanānirodhoti paccayanirodhaṭṭhena vedanākkhandhassa vayaṃ passati , kammanirodhā vedanānirodhoti paccayanirodhaṭṭhena vedanākkhandhassa vayaṃ passati, phassanirodhā vedanānirodhoti paccayanirodhaṭṭhena vedanākkhandhassa vayaṃ passati. Vipariṇāmalakkhaṇaṃ passantopi vedanākkhandhassa vayaṃ passatī’’ti (paṭi. ma. 1.50) imesaṃ pañcannaṃ lakkhaṇānaṃ vasena vedanānaṃ atthaṅgamaṃ yathābhūtaṃ viditvā, ‘‘yaṃ vedanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ vedanāya assādo’’ti (saṃ. ni. 3.26) evaṃ assādañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā, ‘‘yaṃ vedanā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, ayaṃ vedanāya ādīnavo’’ti evaṃ ādīnavañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā, ‘‘yo vedanāya chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ vedanāya nissaraṇa’’nti evaṃ nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā vigatachandarāgatāya anupādāno anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato; yasmiṃ upādāne sati kiñci upādiyeyya, upādinnattā ca khandho bhaveyya, tassa abhāvā kiñci dhammaṃ anupādiyitvāva vimutto bhikkhave tathāgatoti.
commentary_english:
36. Now, monks, the *Tathāgata* understands this. Monks, the *Tathāgata* understands in its diverse aspects this fourfold speculative view.
Showing how he understands it, he begins by saying, "These are the grounds for views (*dṛṣṭhi-sthāna*)," and so forth.
There, views themselves are called grounds for views (*dṛṣṭhi-sthāna*).
Moreover, the cause of views is also a ground for views (*dṛṣṭhi-sthāna*).
As he said: "What are the eight grounds for views (*dṛṣṭhi-sthāna*)? The aggregates (*skandha*) are also a ground for views (*dṛṣṭhi-sthāna*), ignorance (*avidyā*) also, contact (*sparśa*) also, perception (*saṃjñā*) also, thought (*vitarka*) also, improper attention (*ayoniso-manasikāra*) also, bad friends (*pāpa-mitta*) also, the voice of another (*paratoghosa*) is also a ground for views (*dṛṣṭhi-sthāna*)."

"The aggregates (*skandha*) are a cause, the aggregates (*skandha*) are a condition, in the sense of an origin for a standpoint; thus the aggregates (*skandha*) are also a ground for views (*dṛṣṭhi-sthāna*).
Ignorance (*avidyā*) is a cause... and so on... bad friends (*pāpa-mitta*) are a cause.
The voice of another (*paratoghosa*) is a cause, the voice of another (*paratoghosa*) is a condition, in the sense of an origin for a standpoint; thus the voice of another (*paratoghosa*) is also a ground for views (*dṛṣṭhi-sthāna*)."
(Paṭisambhidāmagga.
Mahāvagga.
1.
124)

"Thus assumed." Firstly, the grounds for views (*dṛṣṭhi-sthāna*) consisting in the views that hold the self (*ātman*) and the world (*loka*) to be eternal (*śāśvata*) are "thus assumed," that is, taken up and made to occur. This is the meaning.

They are "thus misapprehended," i.e., apprehended again and again with an unquestioning mind and consummated with the conclusion: "This alone is the truth, any other view is false."

Secondly, since the grounds for views (*dṛṣṭhi-sthāna*) consisting in causes give rise to views when they are assumed, they are assumed by way of object, by way of occurrence, and by way of cultivation.

They are misapprehended by assuming them again and again as long as the danger inherent in them is not perceived.

They "lead to such a future destination," that is, they lead to the hells (*niraya*), the animal kingdom (*tiracchāna*), or the realm of ghosts (*preta-viṣaya*).

"Thus, with regard to the future": this is synonymous with the previous expression; it is said to be "of such a kind in the next world."

The *Tathāgata* understands this. The *Tathāgata* does not understand only this fourfold speculative view together with its grounds and destinations, but he understands all that, and he understands what transcends it; that is, virtue (*śīla*), concentration (*samādhi*), and the knowledge of omniscience (*sarvajñuta-jñāna*).

Yet even that understanding he does not misapprehend. Although he understands such incomparable states of distinction, he does not think, "I understand this," etc., misapprehending it by way of craving (*tṛṣṇā*), views (*dṛṣṭi*), and conceit (*māna*).

"And because he is free from misapprehension, he has realized within himself the state of perfect peace (*nirvṛti*)." With non-misapprehension as a condition, he has realized within himself the state of perfect peace (*nirvṛti*), the pacification of the defilements (*kleśa*) of misapprehension.

He shows: "Monks, *Nirvāṇa* is evident to the *Tathāgata*."

Now, in order to show the practice by means of which he, the *Tathāgata*, achieved that perfect peace (*nirvṛti*), the *Tathāgata*, explaining the meditation subject in terms of those very feelings enamored with which the sectarians (*tīrthika*) enter the jungle of views, thinking, "Here we shall be happy! We shall be happy here!" begins by saying, "The arising of feelings," and so forth.

"Having understood as they really are…": "With the arising of ignorance (*avidyā*), there is the arising of feelings (*vedanā*)"—he sees the rise of the aggregate of feelings (*vedanā-skandha*) in the sense of its conditioned origination; "with the arising of craving (*tṛṣṇā*), there is the arising of feelings (*vedanā*)"—he sees the rise of the aggregate of feelings (*vedanā-skandha*) in the sense of its conditioned origination; "with the arising of *karma*, there is the arising of feelings (*vedanā*)"—he sees the rise of the aggregate of feelings (*vedanā-skandha*) in the sense of its conditioned origination; "with the arising of contact (*sparśa*), there is the arising of feelings (*vedanā*)"—he sees the rise of the aggregate of feelings (*vedanā-skandha*) in the sense of its conditioned origination.
(Paṭisambhidāmagga.
Mahāvagga.
1.
50)

"Seeing as well the characteristic of production, he sees the rise of the aggregate of feelings (*vedanā-skandha*)." Having understood as it really is the origin of feelings (*vedanā*) by way of these five characteristics: "With the cessation of ignorance (*avidyā*), there is the cessation of feelings (*vedanā*)"—he sees the fall of the aggregate of feelings (*vedanā-skandha*) in the sense of its conditioned cessation; "with the cessation of craving (*tṛṣṇā*), there is the cessation of feelings (*vedanā*)"—he sees the fall of the aggregate of feelings (*vedanā-skandha*) in the sense of its conditioned cessation; "with the cessation of *karma*, there is the cessation of feelings (*vedanā*)"—he sees the fall of the aggregate of feelings (*vedanā-skandha*) in the sense of its conditioned cessation; "with the cessation of contact (*sparśa*), there is the cessation of feelings (*vedanā*)"—he sees the fall of the aggregate of feelings (*vedanā-skandha*) in the sense of its conditioned cessation.

"Seeing as well the characteristic of change, he sees the fall of the aggregate of feelings (*vedanā-skandha*)."
(Paṭisambhidāmagga.
Mahāvagga.
1.
50) Having understood as it really is the passing away of feelings (*vedanā*) by way of these five characteristics, [he further understands]: "The pleasure (*sukha*) and joy (*saumanasya*) that arise in dependence on feelings (*vedanā*), this is the satisfaction (*āsvāda*) in feelings (*vedanā*)."
(Saṃyutta Nikāya.
Nidāna Vagga.
3.
26) Thus, having understood as it really is the satisfaction (*āsvāda*), [he further understands]: "That feelings (*vedanā*) are impermanent (*anitya*), suffering (*duḥkha*), subject to change (*vipariṇāma-dharma*), this is the unsatisfactoriness (*ādīnava*) in feelings (*vedanā*)." Thus, having understood as it really is the unsatisfactoriness (*ādīnava*), [he further understands]: "The abandonment of desire (*chanda*) and passion (*rāga*) with regard to feelings (*vedanā*), the giving up of desire (*chanda*) and passion (*rāga*), this is the escape (*niḥsaraṇa*) from feelings (*vedanā*)." Thus, having understood as it really is the escape (*niḥsaraṇa*), because of the absence of desire (*chanda*) and passion (*rāga*), the *Tathāgata*, monks, is without grasping (*anupādāna*), liberated through non-grasping (*anupādā-vimutta*); if there were any grasping (*upādāna*), he would grasp at something, and because of grasping there would be an aggregate (*skandha*); because of the absence of that, without grasping at any *dharma* (*dharma*), the *Tathāgata*, monks, is liberated.

mula_pali: 37. ‘‘Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā  nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
mula_english: 37. "These *dharmas*, *bhikkhus*, are profound, difficult to see, difficult to understand, peaceful, excellent, beyond the sphere of reasoning, subtle, to be experienced by the wise, which the *Tathāgata* having realized for himself with direct knowledge (*abhiññā sacchikatvā*) propounds to others; and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *Tathāgata* in accordance with reality would speak.
commentary_pali: 37.Ime kho te, bhikkhaveti ye te ahaṃ – ‘‘katame, ca te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā’’ti apucchiṃ, ‘‘ime kho te, bhikkhave, tañca tathāgato pajānāti tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānātī’’ti evaṃ niddiṭṭhā sabbaññutaññāṇadhammā gambhīrā duddasā…pe… paṇḍitavedanīyāti veditabbā. Yehi tathāgatassa neva puthujjano, na sotāpannādīsu aññataro vaṇṇaṃ yathābhūtaṃ vattuṃ sakkoti, atha kho tathāgatova yathābhūtaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamāno vadeyyāti evaṃ pucchamānenāpi sabbaññutaññāṇameva puṭṭhaṃ, niyyātentenāpi tadeva niyyātitaṃ, antarā pana diṭṭhiyo vibhattāti.
commentary_english:
37. Bhikkhus, these are those ( *ime kho te, bhikkhave*)… I asked: "What, bhikkhus, are those *dharmas* that are profound ( *dhammā gambhīrā*)?" "It is these *dharmas*, bhikkhus, that the *Tathāgata* understands, and understands even further" (*tañca tathāgato pajānāti tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti*), thus, these *dharmas* pertaining to the knowledge of omniscience (*sabbaññutaññāṇadhammā*), that are pointed out, are profound, difficult to see, comprehensible only to the wise.

Concerning these, neither the worldling (*puthujjano*) nor the stream-enterer (*sotāpanna*), nor anyone else can speak in praise of the *Tathāgata* in accordance with reality (*yathābhūtaṃ*). The *Tathāgata* alone can do so (*tathāgatova*). Asking thus, he asked only in reference to the knowledge of omniscience (*sabbaññutaññāṇa*), and answering, he answered by reference to the same. But other views (*diṭṭhiyo*) remain to be analyzed.

mula_pali: 38. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca  paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi. Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi?
mula_english:
39. “There are, monks, some ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists in regard to some things and non-eternalists in regard to other things, and who on four grounds proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world to be partly eternal and partly non-eternal.

And on what grounds, with reference to what, do those honorable ascetics and Brahmins, being partly eternalists and partly non-eternalists, proclaim the self and the world to be partly eternal and partly non-eternal?
commentary_pali: 38.Ekaccasassatikāti ekaccasassatavādā. Te duvidhā honti – sattekaccasassatikā, saṅkhārekaccasassatikāti. Duvidhāpi idha gahitāyeva.
commentary_english:
38. *Ekaccasassatikāti ekaccasassatavādā.*

They are partial-eternalists.
They are of two kinds: partial-eternalists in regard to beings (*sattekaccasassatikā*), and partial-eternalists in regard to formations (*saṅkhārekaccasassatikāti*).
Both kinds are included here (*duvidhāpi idha gahitāyeva*).

mula_pali: 39. ‘‘Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo, yaṃ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṃ loko saṃvaṭṭati. Saṃvaṭṭamāne loke yebhuyyena sattā ābhassarasaṃvattanikā honti. Te tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṃpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino, ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhanti.
mula_english: 39. "There comes a time, monks, when, after the lapse of a long period, this world contracts. While the world is contracting, beings for the most part are reborn in the Ābhassara Brahma-world. And there they dwell, mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, moving through the air, abiding in glory. And they continue thus for a long, long period of time.
commentary_pali: 39.Yanti  nipātamattaṃ. Kadācīti kismiñci kāle. Karahacīti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Dīghassaaddhunoti dīghassa kālassa. Accayenāti atikkamena . Saṃvaṭṭatīti vinassati. Yebhuyyenāti ye uparibrahmalokesu vā arūpesu vā nibbattanti, tadavasese sandhāya vuttaṃ. Jhānamanena nibbattattā manomayā. Pīti tesaṃ bhakkho āhāroti pītibhakkhā. Attanova tesaṃ pabhāti sayaṃpabhā. Antalikkhe carantīti antalikkhacarā. Subhesu uyyānavimānakapparukkhādīsu tiṭṭhantīti, subhaṭṭhāyino subhā vā manorammavatthābharaṇā hutvā tiṭṭhantīti subhaṭṭhāyino. Ciraṃ dīghamaddhānanti ukkaṃsena aṭṭha kappe.
commentary_english:
39. Yanti is simply a particle.
"Sometimes" means at some time.
Karahacīti is a synonym for that.
Dīghassaaddhunoti means for a long time.
accayenāti means by transgression.
Saṃvaṭṭatīti means it perishes.
Yebhuyyenāti means beings for the most part are reborn in the upper Brahma-worlds or in the immaterial realms, referring to the remainder of those.
Jhānamanena nibbattattā manomayā means mind-made, because they have been reborn through the *jhāna*-mind.
Pīti tesaṃ bhakkho āhāroti pītibhakkhā means joy is their food and nourishment, therefore they are nourished by joy.
Attanova tesaṃ pabhāti sayaṃpabhā means they shine with their own light.
Antalikkhe carantīti antalikkhacarā means those who wander in the sky.
Subhesu uyyānavimānakapparukkhādīsu tiṭṭhantīti, subhaṭṭhāyino subhā vā manorammavatthābharaṇā hutvā tiṭṭhantīti subhaṭṭhāyino means they dwell in auspicious gardens, celestial mansions, wish-fulfilling trees, etc., therefore they are auspicious dwellers; or, having become auspicious, delightful in garments and ornaments, they dwell, therefore they are auspicious dwellers.
Ciraṃ dīghamaddhānanti ukkaṃsena aṭṭha kappe means for a long time, at most eight aeons.

mula_pali: 40. ‘‘Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo, yaṃ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṃ loko vivaṭṭati. Vivaṭṭamāne loke suññaṃ brahmavimānaṃ pātubhavati. Atha kho aññataro satto āyukkhayā  vā puññakkhayā vā ābhassarakāyā cavitvā suññaṃ brahmavimānaṃ upapajjati. So  tattha hoti manomayo pītibhakkho sayaṃpabho antalikkhacaro subhaṭṭhāyī, ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhati.
mula_english:
40. "There comes a time, monks, sooner or later, after a long period, when this world begins to expand again.

While the world is expanding, an empty Brahmā's palace appears.

Then a certain being, due to the exhaustion of their life-span or the exhaustion of their merit, passes away from the Ābhassara realm and is reborn in the empty Brahmā's palace.

There he dwells, mind-made (manomayo), feeding on joy (pītibhakkho), self-luminous (sayaṃpabho), moving through the sky (antalikkhacaro), abiding in glory (subhaṭṭhāyī), for a long, long time (ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ)."
commentary_pali: 40.Vivaṭṭatīti saṇṭhāti. Suññaṃ brahmavimānanti pakatiyā nibbattasattānaṃ natthitāya suññaṃ, brahmakāyikabhūmi nibbattatīti attho. Tassa kattā vā kāretā vā natthi, visuddhimagge vuttanayena pana kammapaccayautusamuṭṭhānā ratanabhūmi nibbattati. Pakatinibbattiṭṭhānesuyeva cettha uyyānakapparukkhādayo nibbattanti. Atha sattānaṃ pakatiyā vasitaṭṭhāne nikanti uppajjati, te paṭhamajjhānaṃ bhāvetvā tato otaranti, tasmā atha kho aññataro sattotiādimāha. Āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vāti ye uḷāraṃ puññakammaṃ katvā yattha katthaci appāyuke devaloke nibbattanti, te attano puññabalena ṭhātuṃ  na sakkonti, tassa pana devalokassa āyuppamāṇeneva cavantīti āyukkhayā cavantīti vuccanti. Ye pana parittaṃ puññakammaṃ katvā dīghāyukadevaloke nibbattanti, te yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhātuṃ na sakkonti, antarāva cavantīti puññakkhayā cavantīti vuccanti. Dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhatīti kappaṃ vā upaḍḍhakappaṃ vā.
commentary_english:
40. It stands and continues.
An empty palace of Brahmā, because it was originally empty, since no beings were as yet reborn there; the plane of Brahmā's company is produced, this is the meaning.
It has no maker or creator, but is a gem-studded plane produced through *karma* as condition and temperature as the mode of origin, in the way described in the *Visuddhimagga*.
Gardens, celestial wishing trees, etc., are produced here in the natural places for their production.
Then an attachment to their dwelling place spontaneously arises in those beings. Having developed the first *jhāna*, they descend from there, therefore, he said, "Then a certain being..." etc.
“Due to the exhaustion of his life span” or “due to the exhaustion of his merit”: those beings who have done lofty deeds of merit (*puṇyakarma*) and are reborn in a celestial world (*devaloka*) with a short life span (*appāyuka*) cannot remain there solely by the power of their merit, but pass away because of the length of the life span in that world. These beings are said to pass away due to the exhaustion of their life span (*āyukkhayā cavantīti vuccanti*).
Those beings who have done inferior deeds of merit (*puṇyakarma*) and are reborn in a celestial world (*devaloka*) with a long life span (*dīghāyuka*) cannot remain for the full life span of that world, but pass away in the middle of their life. These are said to pass away due to the exhaustion of their merit (*puṇyakkkhayā cavantīti vuccanti*).
It lasts for a long time, either a *kappa* or half a *kappa*.

mula_pali: 41. ‘‘Tassa tattha ekakassa dīgharattaṃ nivusitattā anabhirati paritassanā upapajjati – ‘aho vata aññepi sattā itthattaṃ āgaccheyyu’nti. Atha aññepi sattā āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vā ābhassarakāyā cavitvā brahmavimānaṃ upapajjanti tassa sattassa sahabyataṃ. Tepi tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṃpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino, ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhanti.
mula_english:
41. “Then, as a result of dwelling there all alone for so long a time, there arises in him dissatisfaction and agitation, thinking: ‘Oh, that other beings might come to this place!’

And other beings, from exhaustion of their life-span (āyukkhayā) or of their merit (puññakkhayā), fall from the Ābhassara world and arise in the Brahma-palace as companions for that being.

And there they dwell, mind-made (manomayā), feeding on delight (pītibhakkhā), self-luminous (sayaṃpabhā), moving through the air (antalikkhacarā), abiding in glory (subhaṭṭhāyino), and they stay like that for a very long time (ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhanti).
commentary_pali: 41.Anabhiratīti aparassāpi sattassa āgamanapatthanā. Yā pana paṭighasampayuttā ukkaṇṭhitā, sā brahmaloke natthi. Paritassanāti ubbijjanā phandanā, sā panesā tāsatassanā, taṇhātassanā, diṭṭhitassanā, ñāṇatassanāti catubbidhā hoti. Tattha ‘‘jātiṃ paṭicca bhayaṃ bhayānakaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso cetaso utrāso. Jaraṃ… byādhiṃ… maraṇaṃ paṭicca…pe… utrāso’’ti (vibha. 921) ayaṃ tāsatassanā nāma. ‘‘Aho vata aññepi sattā itthattaṃ āgaccheyyu’’nti (dī. ni. 3.38) ayaṃ taṇhātassanā nāma. ‘‘Paritassitavipphanditamevā’’ti ayaṃ diṭṭhitassanā nāma. ‘‘Tepi tathāgatassa dhammadesanaṃ  sutvā yebhuyyena bhayaṃ saṃvegaṃ santāsaṃ āpajjantī’’ti (a. ni. 4.33) ayaṃ ñāṇatassanā nāma. Idha pana taṇhātassanāpi diṭṭhitassanāpi vaṭṭati. Brahmavimānanti idha pana paṭhamābhinibbattassa atthitāya suññanti na vuttaṃ. Upapajjantīti upapattivasena upagacchanti. Sahabyatanti sahabhāvaṃ.
commentary_english:
41. "Anabhirati" means the wish for the arrival of another being.

But dissatisfaction associated with aversion does not exist in the Brahma-world.

“Paritassanā” means agitation, trembling. This is fourfold: agitation through fear (*tāsatassanā*), agitation through craving (*taṇhātassanā*), agitation through views (*diṭṭhitassanā*), and agitation through knowledge (*ñāṇatassanā*).

Therein, “the fear, fright, consternation, horripilation, and mental disquietude that arise on account of birth (*jāti*), aging (*jarā*), disease (*byādhi*), and death (*maraṇa*)…"- this is called agitation through fear (*tāsatassanā*).

“Oh, that other beings might come to this place!” - this is called agitation through craving (*taṇhātassanā*).

“Agitation and vacillation” - this is called agitation through views (*diṭṭhitassanā*).

“Those gods, on hearing the *tathāgata’s* discourse on *dharma*, generally feel fear, a sense of urgency, and terror” - this is called agitation through knowledge (*ñāṇatassanā*).

In the above passage, both agitation through craving (*taṇhātassanā*) and agitation through views (*diṭṭhitassanā*) apply.

"Brahmavimāna" means that here it is not said that the first newly born has the existence of emptiness.

*Upapajjanti* means they approach by way of arising (*upapattivasena upagacchanti*).

*Sahabyata* means companionship (*sahabhāvaṃ*).

mula_pali: 42. ‘‘Tatra , bhikkhave, yo so satto paṭhamaṃ upapanno tassa evaṃ hoti – ‘ahamasmi brahmā mahābrahmā  abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā sajjitā (syā. kaṃ.) vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ. Mayā ime sattā nimmitā. Taṃ kissa hetu? Mamañhi pubbe etadahosi – ‘‘aho vata aññepi sattā itthattaṃ āgaccheyyu’’nti. Iti mama ca manopaṇidhi, ime ca sattā itthattaṃ āgatā’ti. ‘‘Yepi te sattā pacchā upapannā, tesampi evaṃ hoti – ‘ayaṃ kho bhavaṃ brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ. Iminā mayaṃ bhotā brahmunā nimmitā. Taṃ kissa hetu? Imañhi mayaṃ addasāma idha paṭhamaṃ upapannaṃ, mayaṃ panamha pacchā upapannā’ti.
mula_english:
42. Monks, when that being first arises there, he thinks: 'I am Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the Conqueror, the Unconquered, the All-Seeing, the Wielder of Power ( *vasavattī*), the Lord (*īśvara*), the Maker (*kartā*), the Creator (*nirmātā*), the Best (*śreṣṭha*), the Ordainer, the Controller, the Father of all beings that have been and will be (*bhūtabhavyānām*). These beings were created by me (*mayā ime sattā nimmitā*). What is the reason for this? Formerly, I thought, "Oh, that other beings might come into this state!" Thus, according to my aspiration and mental resolution (*manopaṇidhi*), these beings have now come into this state.'

"And those beings who arose later also think: 'This, surely, is Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the Conqueror, the Unconquered, the All-Seeing, the Wielder of Power, the Lord, the Maker, the Creator, the Best, the Ordainer, the Controller, the Father of all beings that have been and will be. We were created by this Brahmā (*iminā mayaṃ brahmunā nimmitā*). What is the reason for this? We saw him arise here first; we arose after him (*pacchā upapannā*).'"
commentary_pali: 42.Abhibhūti  abhibhavitvā ṭhito jeṭṭhakohamasmīti. Anabhibhūtoti aññehi anabhibhūto. Aññadatthūti ekaṃsavacane nipāto. Dassanavasena daso, sabbaṃ passāmīti attho. Vasavattīti sabbaṃ janaṃ vase vattemi. Issaro kattā nimmātāti ahaṃ loke issaro, ahaṃ lokassa kattā ca nimmātā ca, pathavī – himavanta-sineru-cakkavāḷa-mahāsamudda-candima-sūriyā mayā nimmitāti. Seṭṭho sajitāti ahaṃ lokassa uttamo ca sajitā ca, ‘‘tvaṃ khattiyo nāma hohi, tvaṃ brāhmaṇo, vesso, suddo, gahaṭṭho, pabbajito nāma. Antamaso  tvaṃ oṭṭho hohi, goṇo hohī’’ti ‘‘evaṃ sattānaṃ saṃvisajetā aha’’nti maññati. Vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānanti (dī. ni. 1.17) ahamasmi ciṇṇavasitāya vasī, ahaṃ pitā bhūtānañca bhabyānañcāti maññati. Tattha aṇḍajajalābujā sattā antoaṇḍakose ceva antovatthimhi ca bhabyā nāma, bahi nikkhantakālato paṭṭhāya bhūtā nāma. Saṃsedajā paṭhamacittakkhaṇe bhabyā, dutiyato paṭṭhāya bhūtā. Opapātikā paṭhamairiyāpathe bhabyā, dutiyato paṭṭhāya bhūtāti veditabbā. Te sabbepi mayhaṃ puttāti saññāya ‘‘ahaṃ pitā bhūtabhabyāna’’nti maññati. Idāni kāraṇato sādhetukāmo – ‘‘mayā ime sattā nimmitā’’ti paṭiññaṃ katvā ‘‘taṃ kissa hetū’’tiādimāha. Itthattanti itthabhāvaṃ, brahmabhāvanti attho. Iminā mayanti attano kammavasena cutāpi upapannāpi ca kevalaṃ maññanāmatteneva ‘‘iminā mayaṃ nimmitā’’ti maññamānā vaṅkacchidde vaṅkaāṇī viya onamitvā tasseva pādamūlaṃ gacchantīti.
commentary_english:
42. "I am the chief, having overcome and remained in a superior position."
"Unsubdued" means unsubdued by others.
"Aññadatthūti" is a particle in a single-meaning expression.
"Dassanavasena daso" means "a seer by way of seeing, I see everything."
"Vasavattīti" means "I cause all people to behave as I wish."
“I am the lord, the maker, the creator” means, "I am the lord in the world, I am the maker and creator of the world; the earth *pathavī*, the Himalayas *himavanta*, Mount Sineru *sineru*, the world-spheres *cakkavāḷa*, the great ocean *mahāsamudda*, the moon *candima*, and the sun *sūriya* have been created by me."
“The best, the victorious” means, "I am the highest and the most victorious in the world. ‘You be a *khattiya* (warrior), you a *brāhmaṇa* (priest), *vessa* (merchant), *sudda* (worker), *gahaṭṭha* (householder), *pabbajita* (renunciate)."
"At the very least, may you be a camel, may you be a cow," he thinks, "Thus I will send forth beings."
"The father who has power over things past and things to come" (Dīgha Nikāya).
Niyama.
1.
17) "I am the powerful one, disciplined by long-standing habit, I am the father of beings that have been and will be," he thinks.
There, beings born from eggs *aṇḍaja*, born from wombs *jalābuja*, are reckoned as "liable to become" while still inside the egg-shell *aṇḍakose* or in the womb *antovatthimhi*; from the time they emerge, they are reckoned as "having become."
Beings born from moisture *saṃsedajā* are "liable to become" in the first moment of consciousness *paṭhamacittakkhaṇe*; from the second onwards, they "have become."
Beings with spontaneous birth *opapātikā* are "liable to become" in their first posture *paṭhamairiyāpathe*; from the second onwards, they "have become," so it should be understood.
Thinking of all of them as "my sons," he thinks, "I am the father of beings that have been and will be."
Now, wishing to substantiate this with a reason, after making the claim, "These beings have been created by me," he says, "What is the reason for that?" etc.
"Itthattanti" means "suchness" *itthabhāvaṃ*, "brahmabhāvanti" means "the state of Brahmā".
"By this we..." Although they passed away and re-arose by reason of their own karma *kamma*, through sheer imagination alone they imagined that they had been created by him, and bowing before him like crooked pegs being inserted into crooked holes, they went to his feet.

mula_pali: 43. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, yo so satto paṭhamaṃ upapanno, so dīghāyukataro ca hoti vaṇṇavantataro ca mahesakkhataro ca. Ye pana te sattā pacchā upapannā, te appāyukatarā ca honti dubbaṇṇatarā ca appesakkhatarā ca.
mula_english: 43. "And herein, monks, that being who first arose there is longer-lived, more beautiful, and more powerful. But those beings who arose later are shorter-lived, less beautiful, and less influential."
commentary_pali: 43.Vaṇṇavantataro cāti vaṇṇavantataro, abhirūpo pāsādikoti attho. Mahesakkhataroti issariyaparivāravasena mahāyasataro.
commentary_english:
43. He is even more beautiful and very beautiful, meaning he is pleasing and delightful.
He is mightier, meaning he is more glorious because of the power of his retinue.

mula_pali: 44. ‘‘Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati, yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati. Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati. Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno  ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati , tato paraṃ nānussarati. ‘‘So evamāha – ‘yo kho so bhavaṃ brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ, yena mayaṃ bhotā brahmunā nimmitā, so nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassati. Ye pana mayaṃ ahumhā tena bhotā brahmunā  nimmitā, te mayaṃ aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṃ āgatā’ti. Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
mula_english:
44. "Now, *bhikkhus*, it is possible that a certain being, after passing away from that body, comes to this world (*itthattaṃ āgacchati*).

Having come to this world, he goes forth from the householder's life to homelessness (*agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati*).

Having gone forth from the householder's life to homelessness, by means of zeal (*ātappa*), striving (*padhāna*), application (*anuyoga*), diligence (*appamāda*), and right attention (*sammāmanasikāra*), he attains to such a state of concentration of mind (*cetosamādhi*) that, with his mind thus concentrated, he remembers his past life (*pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati*), but he does not remember beyond that.

"He speaks thus: 'That venerable Brahmā, the Great Brahmā (*mahābrahmā*), the Conqueror, the Unconquered, the All-Seeing, the Wielder of Power (*vasavattī*), the Lord (*issaro*), the Maker (*kattā*) and Creator (*nimmātā*), the Chief (*seṭṭho*), the Ordainer (*sajitā*), the Master (*vasī*), the Father of all beings who have been and are to be—by him were we created, and he is permanent (*nicco*), stable (*dhruvo*), eternal (*sassato*), not subject to change (*avipariṇāmadhammo*), and he will remain the same just like eternity itself.

But we, who have been created by that venerable Brahmā, are impermanent (*aniccā*), unstable (*addhuvā*), short-lived (*appāyukā*), subject to falling away (*cavanadhammā*), and we have come to this world (*itthattaṃ āgatā*)’ti.

This, *bhikkhus*, is the first basis (*ṭhānaṃ*), resorting to which, depending on which, some ascetics and Brahmins proclaim the self and the world to be partly eternalists (*ekaccasassatikā*), partly non-eternalists (*ekaccaasassatikā*), partly eternal (*ekaccaṃ sassataṃ*), and partly non-eternal (*ekaccaṃ asassataṃ*).
commentary_pali: 44.Ṭhānaṃkho panetanti kāraṇaṃ kho panetaṃ. So tato cavitvā aññatra na gacchati, idheva āgacchati, taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Agārasmāti gehā. Anagāriyanti pabbajjaṃ. Pabbajjā hi yasmā agārassa hi taṃ kasigorakkhādikammaṃ tattha natthi, tasmā anagāriyanti vuccati. Pabbajatīti upagacchati. Tato paraṃ nānussaratīti tato pubbenivāsā paraṃ na sarati, sarituṃ asakkonto tattha ṭhatvā diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti. Niccotiādīsu tassa upapattiṃ apassanto niccoti vadati, maraṇaṃ apassanto dhuvoti, sadābhāvato sassatoti, jarāvasenāpi  vipariṇāmassa abhāvato avipariṇāmadhammoti. Sesamettha paṭhamavāre uttānamevāti.
commentary_english:
44. ṭhānaṃkho panetanti kāraṇaṃ kho panetaṃ.
so tato cavitvā aññatra na gacchati, idheva āgacchati, taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.
agārasmā means gehā. (Agārasmāti gehā)
anagāriya means pabbajjā. (Anagāriyanti pabbajjaṃ)
pabbajjā hi yasmā agārassa hi taṃ kasigorakkhādikammaṃ tattha natthi, tasmā anagāriyanti vuccati.
pabbajati means upagacchati. (Pabbajatīti upagacchati)
tato paraṃ nānussaratīti tato pubbenivāsā paraṃ na sarati, sarituṃ asakkonto tattha ṭhatvā diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti.
niccotiādīsu tassa upapattiṃ apassanto niccoti vadati, maraṇaṃ apassanto dhuvoti, sadābhāvato sassatoti, jarāvasenāpi vipariṇāmassa abhāvato avipariṇāmadhammoti.
sesamettha paṭhamavāre uttānamevāti.

mula_pali: 45. ‘‘Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā  ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti? Santi, bhikkhave, khiḍḍāpadosikā nāma devā, te ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā hasakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā (ka.) viharanti. Tesaṃ ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati sammussati pamussati (sī. syā.). Satiyā sammosā te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
mula_english: 45. Furthermore, venerable monks, what is the basis and origin for some ascetics and Brahmins to proclaim the self and the world as partly eternal (śāśvata) and partly non-eternal (aśāśvata)? There are, monks, gods called those corrupted by play (khiḍḍāpadosikā); they excessively indulge in the delight of laughter, play, and sensual pleasures. While they excessively indulge in the delight of laughter, play, and sensual pleasures, their mindfulness is impaired; because of the impairment of mindfulness, those gods pass away from that realm.
commentary_pali: 45-46. Dutiyavāre  khiḍḍāya padussanti vinassantīti khiḍḍāpadosikā, padūsikātipi pāḷiṃ likhanti, sā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ natthi. Ativelanti atikālaṃ, aticiranti attho. Hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannāti hassarati dhammañceva khiḍḍāratidhammañca samāpannā anuyuttā, keḷihassasukhañceva kāyikavācasikakīḷāsukhañca anuyuttā, vuttappakāraratidhammasamaṅgino hutvā viharantīti attho. Sati sammussatīti khādanīyabhojanīyesu sati sammussati. Te kira puññavisesādhigatena mahantena attano sirivibhavena nakkhattaṃ kīḷantā tāya sampattimahantatāya – ‘‘āhāraṃ paribhuñjimha, na paribhuñjimhā’’tipi na jānanti. Atha ekāhārātikkamanato paṭṭhāya nirantaraṃ khādantāpi pivantāpi cavantiyeva, na tiṭṭhanti. Kasmā? Kammajatejassa balavatāya, karajakāyassa mandatāya, manussānañhi kammajatejo mando, karajakāyo balavā. Tesaṃ tejassa mandatāya karajakāyassa balavatāya sattāhampi atikkamitvā uṇhodakaacchayāguādīhi sakkā vatthuṃ upatthambhetuṃ. Devānaṃ pana tejo balavā hoti, karajaṃ mandaṃ. Te ekaṃ āhāravelaṃ atikkamitvāva saṇṭhātuṃ na sakkonti. Yathā nāma gimhānaṃ majjhanhike tattapāsāṇe ṭhapitaṃ padumaṃ vā uppalaṃ vā sāyanhasamaye ghaṭasatenāpi siñciyamānaṃ pākatikaṃ na hoti, vinassatiyeva. Evameva pacchā nirantaraṃ khādantāpi pivantāpi cavantiyeva, na  tiṭṭhanti. Tenāha ‘‘satiyā sammosā te devā tamhā kāyā cavantī’’ti. Katame  pana te devāti? Ime devāti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vicāraṇā natthi, ‘‘devānaṃ kammajatejo balavā hoti, karajaṃ manda’’nti avisesena vuttattā pana ye keci kabaḷīkārāhārūpajīvino devā evaṃ karonti, teyeva cavantīti veditabbā. Keci panāhu – ‘‘nimmānaratiparanimmitavasavattino te devā’’ti. Khiḍḍāpadussanamatteneva hete khiḍḍāpadosikāti vuttā. Sesamettha purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
45-46. Because they are corrupted and ruined by amusement a second time, they are called *khiḍḍāpadosikā* (corrupted by amusement). Some write the Pali word as *padūsikā* as well, but that (form) is not in the commentary (*aṭṭhakathā*).

"Excessively" means "at an improper time," that is, "too long".

"Endowed with laughter, amusement, delight, and the law (of righteousness)" means they are endowed with and devoted to laughter, delight in the Dhamma, amusement, and delight in the Dhamma. They are attached to playfulness, laughter, happiness, physical and verbal enjoyment of sport. It means they live having qualities of delight and the Dhamma of the type described previously.

"Mindful, he is confused" means in the case of what is suitable for eating and consuming, he is confused in mind.

These gods, it is said, celebrate a festival (*nakkhattaṃ*) in honor of their own great beauty and splendor (*sirivibhava*), attained through their distinguished merit (*puññavisesādhigatena*). They then become so absorbed in their great enjoyment (*sampattimahantatāya*) that they do not even know whether or not they have eaten, thinking "We have eaten food (*āhāraṃ paribhuñjimha*), we have not eaten food (*na paribhuñjimhā*)."

But when they have passed up the time even for a single meal, though they eat and drink immediately afterwards, they pass away and cannot remain.

Why? Because of the strength of their karma-born heat element (*kammajatejassa balavatāya*) and the delicacy of their material body (*karajakāyassa mandatāya*). For humans, indeed, the karma-born heat is delicate and the material body is strong.

Because of the weakness of their heat element and the strength of their material body, they can subsist for even seven days on warm water, clear gruel (*acchayāgu*), etc., and it is possible to support existence.

But in the case of gods (*devānaṃ*), the heat element is strong (*tejo balavā hoti*), and the material (body) is delicate (*karajaṃ mandaṃ*).

If they pass up the time even for a single meal (*āhāravelaṃ*), they cannot endure (*saṇṭhātuṃ na sakkonti*).

Just as a red lotus (*padumaṃ*) or blue lotus (*uppalaṃ*) placed on a heated rock (*tattapāsāṇe*) at midday (*majjhanhike*) in the hot season (*gimhānaṃ*) would not be able to resume its original condition (*pākatikaṃ na hoti*) in the evening (*sāyanhasamaye*) even if one were to pour a hundred jars (*ghaṭasatenāpi siñciyamānaṃ*) of water over it, but would only perish (*vinassatiyeva*),

in the same way, though they eat and drink immediately after, these gods pass away and cannot remain (*na tiṭṭhanti*).

Therefore, he said, "When mindfulness is confused (*satiyā sammosā*), those gods (*te devā*) pass away (*cavanti*) from that body (*tamhā kāyā*)."

Which are those gods (*katame pana te devāti*)? There is no investigation in the commentary (*aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vicāraṇā natthi*) as to whether these are the gods (*ime devāti*). But since it is said without making any distinctions, "In the case of gods (*devānaṃ*), the karma-born heat is strong (*kammajatejo balavā hoti*), and the material (body) is delicate (*karajaṃ mandaṃ*)," we can understand that all gods who live on solid food (*kabaḷīkārāhārūpajīvino devā*) who act thus pass away (*cavanti*).

Some, however, say, "Those gods (*te devā*) are the gods of the Nirmāṇarati and Paranirmitavaśavartin heavens (*nimmānaratiparanimmitavasavattino*)."

They are called *khiḍḍāpadosikā* because they are corrupted by nothing more than amusement (*khiḍḍāpadussanamatteneva*).

The rest should be understood here in the same way as before (*sesamettha purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ*).

mula_pali: 46. ‘‘Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati. Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati. Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya  anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ nānussarati. ‘‘So evamāha – ‘ye kho te bhonto devā na khiḍḍāpadosikā, te na ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharanti. Tesaṃ na ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati na sammussati. Satiyā  asammosā te devā tamhā kāyā na cavanti; niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassanti . Ye pana mayaṃ ahumhā khiḍḍāpadosikā, te mayaṃ ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharimhā. Tesaṃ no ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati sammussati. Satiyā sammosā evaṃ mayaṃ tamhā kāyā cutā aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṃ āgatā’ti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
mula_english:
46. “Now, mendicants, it is possible that a certain being, passing away from that group of beings, will come to this world ( *itthattaṃ āgacchati*).

Having come to this world ( *itthattaṃ āgato samāno*), he goes forth from the household life into homelessness (*agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati*).

Having gone forth from the household life into homelessness (*agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno*), by means of ardour ( *ātappamanvāya*), exertion (*padhānamanvāya*), application (*anuyogamanvāya*), diligence (*appamādamanvāya*), and right reflection (*sammāmanasikāramanvāya*), he attains to such a degree of mental concentration (*tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati*) that with his mind thus concentrated (*yathāsamāhite citte*) he recollects his immediately preceding life (*taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati*), but none previous to that (*tato paraṃ nānussarati*).

‘He speaks thus: “Those venerable gods who are not corrupted by play (*khiḍḍāpadosikā*) do not spend an excessive amount of time addicted to merriment, play and enjoyment (*hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharanti*).

As a consequence, their mindfulness is not dissipated (*tesaṃ na ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati na sammussati*).

Because of the non-dissipation of mindfulness (*satiyā asammosā*), those gods do not fall from that state (*te devā tamhā kāyā na cavanti*); they are permanent (*niccā*), stable (*dhuvā*), eternal (*sassatā*), not subject to change (*avipariṇāmadhammā*), and they will remain the same just like eternity itself (*sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassanti*).

But we, who were corrupted by play (*khiḍḍāpadosikā*), spent an excessive amount of time addicted to merriment, play and enjoyment (*te mayaṃ ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharimhā*).

They spend an excessive amount of time addicted to merriment, play and enjoyment, so that their mindfulness is dissipated (*tesaṃ no ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati sammussati*).

When our mindfulness was dissipated (*satiyā sammosā*), we passed away from that group of beings (*evaṃ mayaṃ tamhā kāyā cutā*). Coming to this world (*itthattaṃ āgatā’ti*), now we are impermanent (*aniccā*), unstable (*addhuvā*), short-lived (*appāyukā*), and doomed to perish (*cavanadhammā*).”’

This, mendicants, is the second basis (*idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ*) on which some ascetics and Brahmins (*samaṇabrāhmaṇā*) proclaim that the self and the world are partly eternalists (*ekaccasassatikā*) and partly non-eternalists (*ekaccaasassatikā*), partly eternal (*ekaccaṃ sassataṃ*) and partly non-eternal (*ekaccaṃ asassataṃ*).
