mula_pali: 73. ‘‘Ime  kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti , yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
mula_english: 73. "These, monks, are those *dharmas* that are profound (*gambhīrā*), difficult to see (*duddasā*), difficult to understand (*duranubodhā*), peaceful (*santā*), excellent (*paṇītā*), beyond the sphere of reasoning (*atakkāvacarā*), subtle (*nipuṇā*), comprehensible only to the wise (*paṇḍitavedanīyā*), which the *Tathāgata*, having realized for himself with direct knowledge (*abhiññā sacchikatvā*), propounds to others; and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *Tathāgata* in accordance with reality would speak.
commentary_pali: 68-73.Asaññasattāti desanāsīsametaṃ, acittuppādā rūpamattakaattabhāvāti attho. Tesaṃ evaṃ uppatti veditabbā – ekacco hi titthāyatane pabbajitvā vāyokasiṇe parikammaṃ katvā  catutthajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā jhānā vuṭṭhāya – ‘‘citte dosaṃ passati, citte sati hatthacchedādidukkhañceva  sabbabhayāni ca honti, alaṃ iminā cittena, acittakabhāvova santo’’ti, evaṃ citte dosaṃ passitvā aparihīnajjhāno kālaṃ katvā asaññasattesu nibbattati, cittamassa cuticittanirodhena idheva nivattati, rūpakkhandhamattameva tattha pātubhavati. Te tattha yathā nāma jiyāvegakkhitto saro yattako jiyāvego, tattakameva ākāse gacchati. Evameva jhānavegakkhittā upapajjitvā yattako jhānavego, tattakameva kālaṃ tiṭṭhanti, jhānavege pana parihīne tattha rūpakkhandho antaradhāyati, idha pana paṭisandhisaññā uppajjati. Yasmā pana tāya idha uppannasaññāya tesaṃ tattha cuti paññāyati, tasmā ‘‘saññuppādā ca pana te devā tamhā kāyā cavantī’’ti vuttaṃ. Santatāyāti santabhāvāya. Sesamettha uttānameva. Takkīvādopi vuttanayeneva veditabboti.
commentary_english:
68-73.

“Non-percipient beings”: this is the heading of the teaching. Because they arise without mind, their individual forms consist of mere materiality; this is the meaning.

Their origin is explained as follows. Someone who has gone forth into a sectarian order practices the preliminary work of meditation on the wind *kasiṇa* and develops the fourth *jhāna*. After emerging from the *jhāna* he sees the fault in mind thus: “When there is mind, one is exposed to the suffering of having one’s hands mutilated, etc., and to all kinds of perils. Enough with mind! The unconscious state alone is peaceful.” Having thus seen the fault in mind, if he passes away without having fallen away from the *jhāna*, he is reborn in the non-percipient realm. His mind ceases there with the cessation of the death-consciousness, and only the aggregate of material form manifests there.

Just as an arrow driven by the propulsive force of the bowstring travels through space to a distance exactly proportional to the propulsive force of the string,

in the same way this being, taking rebirth through the propulsive force of the *jhāna*, remains in that realm for a time exactly proportional to the propulsive force of the *jhāna*. When the force of the *jhāna* is exhausted, the aggregate of material form disappears there and a rebirth-linking perception (*pratisaṃdhi-saṃjñā*) arises here.

Because their passing away from the non-percipient realm is discerned through the arising of perception here, it is said: “When perception arises in them, those gods pass away from that plane.”

*Santatāyāti* means to the state of continuousness.

The rest is evident.

The argument based on reasoning ( *takkīvāda* ) should be understood just as has been said.

mula_pali: 74. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino, aparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya catucattālīsāya (syā. kaṃ.) vatthūhi. Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi?
mula_english:
74. "There are, monks, some ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the future, who hold settled views about the future, and who, with reference to the future, assert various conceptual theorems in forty-four ways, on forty-four grounds.

And owing to what, with reference to what, do these honorable ascetics and Brahmins frame their speculations about the future, holding fixed views about the future, and assert various conceptual theorems concerning the future in forty-four ways?
commentary_pali: 74. Evaṃ aṭṭhārasa pubbantakappike dassetvā idāni catucattārīsaṃ aparantakappike dassetuṃ – ‘‘santi, bhikkhave’’tiādimāha. Tattha anāgatakoṭṭhāsasaṅkhātaṃ aparantaṃ kappetvā gaṇhantīti aparantakappikā, aparantakappo vā etesaṃ  atthīti aparantakappikā. Evaṃ sesampi pubbe vuttappakāranayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
74. Having shown the eighteen kinds of speculation about the past ( *pubbantakappike* ) in this way, now, in order to show the forty-four kinds of speculation about the future ( *aparantakappike* ), he said, "There are, monks," etc.

There, those who speculate and grasp the future, which is reckoned as the future portion, are *aparantakappikā*, or these have speculation about the future, therefore, *aparantakappikā*.

Thus, the rest should also be understood in the same way as previously stated.

mula_pali: 75. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā  saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ saññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi. Te  ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ saññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti soḷasahi  vatthūhi?
mula_english:
75. "Monks, there are some ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of the doctrine of conscious survival after death. They propound that the self is conscious after death based on sixteen grounds.

And upon what grounds, based on what, do these venerable ascetics and Brahmins, who are proponents of the doctrine of conscious survival after death, propound that the self is conscious after death based on sixteen grounds?
commentary_pali: 75.Uddhamāghātanikāti āghātanaṃ vuccati maraṇaṃ, uddhamāghātanā attānaṃ vadantīti uddhamāghātanikā. Saññīti pavatto vādo, saññīvādo, so etesaṃ atthīti saññīvādā.
commentary_english:
75. *Uddhamāghātanikā*: *āghātanaṃ* is said to be death (*maraṇaṃ*); those who speak of self-destruction (*attānaṃ vadanti*) are *uddhamāghātanikā*.

*Saññīti pavatto vādo, saññīvādo*: a discourse (*vādo*) that proceeds with perception (*saññī*), is *saññīvādo*; those who have that are *saññīvādā*.

mula_pali: 76. ‘‘‘Rūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī’ti naṃ paññapenti. ‘Arūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī’ti naṃ paññapenti. ‘Rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti…pe… nevarūpī nārūpī attā hoti… antavā attā hoti… anantavā attā hoti… antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti… nevantavā nānantavā attā hoti… ekattasaññī attā hoti… nānattasaññī attā hoti… parittasaññī attā hoti… appamāṇasaññī attā hoti… ekantasukhī attā hoti… ekantadukkhī attā hoti. Sukhadukkhī attā hoti. Adukkhamasukhī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī’ti naṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
76. They declare that the self after death is healthy, conscious, and: material (*rūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī*).
They declare that the self after death is healthy, conscious, and: immaterial (*arūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī*).
The self is both material and immaterial, neither material nor immaterial, finite, infinite, both finite and infinite, neither finite nor infinite, of uniform perception, of diversified perception, of limited perception, of boundless perception, exclusively happy, exclusively miserable.
The self is both happy and miserable (*sukhadukkhī attā hoti*).
They declare that the self after death is healthy, conscious, and: neither happy nor miserable (*adukkhamasukhī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī*).
commentary_pali: 76-77.Rūpī attātiādīsu kasiṇarūpaṃ ‘‘attā’’ti tattha pavattasaññañcassa ‘‘saññā’’ti gahetvā vā ājīvakādayo viya takkamatteneva vā ‘‘rūpī attā hoti, arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī’’ti naṃ paññapenti. Tattha arogoti nicco. Arūpasamāpattinimittaṃ pana ‘‘attā’’ti samāpattisaññañcassa ‘‘saññā’’ti gahetvā vā nigaṇṭhādayo viya takkamatteneva vā ‘‘arūpī attā hoti, arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī’’ti naṃ paññapenti. Tatiyā pana missakagāhavasena pavattā diṭṭhi. Catutthā takkagāheneva. Dutiyacatukkaṃ  antānantikavāde vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Tatiyacatukke samāpannakavasena ekattasaññī , asamāpannakavasena nānattasaññī, parittakasiṇavasena parittasaññī, vipulakasiṇavasena appamāṇasaññīti veditabbā. Catutthacatukke pana dibbena cakkhunā tikacatukkajjhānabhūmiyaṃ nibbattamānaṃ disvā ‘‘ekantasukhī’’ti gaṇhāti. Niraye nibbattamānaṃ disvā ‘‘ekantadukkhī’’ti. Manussesu nibbattamānaṃ disvā ‘‘sukhadukkhī’’ti. Vehapphaladevesu nibbattamānaṃ disvā ‘‘adukkhamasukhī’’ti gaṇhāti. Visesato hi pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇalābhino pubbantakappikā honti, dibbacakkhukā aparantakappikāti.
commentary_english:
76-77. Regarding "the self is material" etc., they proclaim, "The self is material, healthy (aroga), and percipient (saññī) after death," either by taking the material form (rūpa) of the *kasiṇa* object as the self (*attā*), and its perception (saññā) as the self's perception, or by mere reasoning, as in the case of the Ājīvakas etc. Here, *aroga* means eternal (nicca).

Moreover, regarding the signs of the immaterial attainments (*arūpasamāpatti*) as the self (*attā*), and the perception (*saññā*) occurring in the attainment as the self's perception, or by mere reasoning as in the case of the Nigaṇṭhas, they proclaim: “The self is immaterial (*arūpī*), healthy (*aroga*), and percipient (*saññī*) after death.”

The third view (*diṭṭhi*) arises by combining the views.

The fourth [arises] through reasoning (*takka*) alone.

The second tetrad should be understood in the same way as stated in the discussion of extensionism (*antānantikavāda*).

In the third tetrad: one should understand that the perception of uniformity (*ekattasaññī*) is due to attainment (*samāpannakavasena*); the perception of diversity (*nānattasaññī*) is due to non-attainment (*asamāpannakavasena*); the perception of limitation (*parittasaññī*) is due to a limited *kasiṇa* (*parittakasiṇavasena*); and the perception of boundlessness (*appamāṇasaññī*) is due to an expanded *kasiṇa* (*vipulakasiṇavasena*).

In the fourth tetrad, having seen with the divine eye (*dibbena cakkhunā*) a being taking rebirth on the plane of the first three or four *jhānas*, one holds that the self is "exclusively happy" (*ekantasukhī*).

Having seen a being reborn in hell (*niraya*), he holds that the self is "exclusively miserable" (*ekantadukkhī*).

Having seen a being reborn in the human world (*manussesu*), he holds that the self is "both happy and miserable" (*sukhadukkhī*).

Having seen a being reborn among the Vehapphala gods, he holds that the self is "neither happy nor miserable" (*adukkhamasukhī*).

Specifically, those who have gained the recollection of past lives (*pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇa*) speculate about the past (*pubbantakappikā*), while those who have the divine eye (*dibbacakkhukā*) speculate about the future (*aparantakappikā*).

mula_pali: 77. ‘‘Imehi  kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ saññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi. Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ saññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva soḷasahi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena, natthi ito bahiddhā…pe… yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
mula_english:
77. "It is on these sixteen grounds, monks, that those ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of percipient immortality proclaim the self to survive percipient after death.

Whatever ascetics or Brahmins maintain a doctrine of percipient immortality, all of them do so on these sixteen grounds or on a certain one of them. Outside of these there is none… and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *Tathāgata* in accordance with reality would speak."
commentary_pali: 76-77.Rūpī attātiādīsu kasiṇarūpaṃ ‘‘attā’’ti tattha pavattasaññañcassa ‘‘saññā’’ti gahetvā vā ājīvakādayo viya takkamatteneva vā ‘‘rūpī attā hoti, arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī’’ti naṃ paññapenti. Tattha arogoti nicco. Arūpasamāpattinimittaṃ pana ‘‘attā’’ti samāpattisaññañcassa ‘‘saññā’’ti gahetvā vā nigaṇṭhādayo viya takkamatteneva vā ‘‘arūpī attā hoti, arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī’’ti naṃ paññapenti. Tatiyā pana missakagāhavasena pavattā diṭṭhi. Catutthā takkagāheneva. Dutiyacatukkaṃ  antānantikavāde vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Tatiyacatukke samāpannakavasena ekattasaññī , asamāpannakavasena nānattasaññī, parittakasiṇavasena parittasaññī, vipulakasiṇavasena appamāṇasaññīti veditabbā. Catutthacatukke pana dibbena cakkhunā tikacatukkajjhānabhūmiyaṃ nibbattamānaṃ disvā ‘‘ekantasukhī’’ti gaṇhāti. Niraye nibbattamānaṃ disvā ‘‘ekantadukkhī’’ti. Manussesu nibbattamānaṃ disvā ‘‘sukhadukkhī’’ti. Vehapphaladevesu nibbattamānaṃ disvā ‘‘adukkhamasukhī’’ti gaṇhāti. Visesato hi pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇalābhino pubbantakappikā honti, dibbacakkhukā aparantakappikāti.
commentary_english:
76-77. Regarding views beginning with "The self is material ( *rūpī attā*)," some, like the Ājīvakas, proclaim: "The self is material (*rūpī attā hoti*), immutable after death (*arogo paraṃ maraṇā*), and percipient (*saññī*)," either by apprehending the material form (*kasiṇarūpaṃ*) as the self (*attā*), and the perception that occurs in that context as "perception" (*saññā*), or simply through reasoning (*takkamattena eva*).

Here, "immutable (*arogo*)" means eternal (*nicco*).

Regarding the signs (*nimittaṃ*) of the immaterial attainments (*arūpasamāpatti*), some, like the Nigaṇṭhas, proclaim: "The self is immaterial (*arūpī attā hoti*), immutable after death (*arogo paraṃ maraṇā*), and percipient (*saññī*)," either by apprehending the signs of the attainment as the self (*attā*), and the perception that occurs in the attainment as "perception" (*saññā*), or simply through reasoning (*takkamattena eva*).

The third view (*tatiyā diṭṭhi*) arises by way of combining (*missakagāhavasena pavattā*).

The fourth (*catutthā*) arises simply through reasoning (*takkagāhena eva*).

The second tetrad (*dutiyacatukkaṃ*) should be understood in the manner described in the discussion on extensionism (*antānantikavāde*).

In the third tetrad (*tatiyacatukke*): the doctrine that the self is of uniform perception (*ekattasaññī*) pertains to one who attains the meditative attainments (*samāpannakavasena*); the doctrine that the self is of diversified perception (*nānattasaññī*) pertains to the non-attainer (*asamāpannakavasena*); the doctrine that the self is of limited perception (*parittasaññī*) pertains to one who employs a limited *kasiṇa* (*parittakasiṇavasena*); and the doctrine that the self is of boundless perception (*appamāṇasaññī*) pertains to one who employs an expanded *kasiṇa* (*vipulakasiṇavasena*).

With the fourth tetrad (*catutthacatukke*), having seen with the divine eye (*dibbena cakkhunā*) a being taking rebirth on the plane of the first three or four *jhānas* (*tikacatukkajjhānabhūmiyaṃ nibbattamānaṃ disvā*), he holds that the self is "exclusively happy" (*ekantasukhī*).

Having seen a being reborn in hell (*niraye nibbattamānaṃ disvā*), he [holds that the self is] "exclusively miserable" (*ekantadukkhī*).

Having seen a being reborn in the human world (*manussesu nibbattamānaṃ disvā*), he [holds that the self is] "both happy and miserable" (*sukhadukkhī*).

Having seen a being reborn among the Vehapphala gods (*vehapphaladevesu nibbattamānaṃ disvā*), he [holds that the self is] "neither happy nor miserable" (*adukkhamasukhī*).

Generally (*visesato hi*), those who gain the recollection of past lives (*pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇalābhino*) speculate about the past (*pubbantakappikā honti*), [and] those who gain the divine eye (*dibbacakkhukā*) speculate about the future (*aparantakappikā*).

mula_pali: 78. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ asaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi. Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha uddhamāghātanikā  asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ asaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi?
mula_english:
78. “There are, monks, some ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of unconscious survival after death, and they propound that the self survives unconscious after death on eight grounds.

On what grounds, based on what, do those ascetics and Brahmins, maintaining a doctrine of unconscious survival after death, propound that the self survives unconscious after death on eight grounds?
commentary_pali: 78-83. Asaññīvādo saññīvāde ādimhi vuttānaṃ dvinnaṃ catukkānaṃ vasena veditabbo. Tathā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādo. Kevalañhi tattha ‘‘saññī attā’’ti gaṇhantānaṃ tā diṭṭhiyo, idha ‘‘asaññī’’ti ca ‘‘nevasaññīnāsaññī’’ti ca. Tattha na ekantena kāraṇaṃ pariyesitabbaṃ. Diṭṭhigatikassa hi gāho ummattakapacchisadisoti vuttametaṃ.
commentary_english:
78-83. The doctrine of non-percipient immortality (*asaññī-vāda*) should be understood in terms of the first two tetrads of the doctrine of percipient immortality (*saññī-vāda*).
Likewise, the doctrine of neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient immortality (*nevasaññīnāsaññī-vāda*).
Only those theorists held the view there that the self (*attā*) is percipient (*saññī*), while these respectively hold that it is non-percipient (*asaññī*) and neither percipient nor non-percipient (*nevasaññīnāsaññī*).
No special reason need be sought for this.
For the theorists’ assumptions (*diṭṭhi-gatika*) are said to be like the basket of a madman (*ummattaka-pacchi*).

mula_pali: 79. ‘‘‘Rūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā asaññī’ti naṃ paññapenti. ‘Arūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā asaññī’ti naṃ paññapenti. ‘Rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti…pe… nevarūpī nārūpī attā hoti… antavā attā hoti… anantavā attā hoti… antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti… nevantavā nānantavā attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā asaññī’ti naṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
79. “They declare: ‘The self is material (rūpī attā) after death, healthy (aroga) and non-percipient (asaññī).’
‘The self is immaterial (arūpī attā) after death, healthy (aroga) and non-percipient (asaññī).’
‘The self is both material and immaterial (rūpī ca arūpī ca attā)…pe…neither material nor immaterial (nevarūpī nārūpī attā)…finite (antavā attā)…infinite (anantavā attā)…both finite and infinite (antavā ca anantavā ca attā)…neither finite nor infinite (nevantavā nānantavā attā) after death, healthy (aroga) and non-percipient (asaññī).”
commentary_pali: 78-83. Asaññīvādo saññīvāde ādimhi vuttānaṃ dvinnaṃ catukkānaṃ vasena veditabbo. Tathā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādo. Kevalañhi tattha ‘‘saññī attā’’ti gaṇhantānaṃ tā diṭṭhiyo, idha ‘‘asaññī’’ti ca ‘‘nevasaññīnāsaññī’’ti ca. Tattha na ekantena kāraṇaṃ pariyesitabbaṃ. Diṭṭhigatikassa hi gāho ummattakapacchisadisoti vuttametaṃ.
commentary_english: 78-83. The doctrine of non-percipient immortality ( *asaññī-vāda*) should be understood in terms of the first two tetrads of the doctrine of percipient immortality (*saññī-vāda*). Similarly, so should the doctrine of neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient immortality (*nevasaññīnāsaññī-vāda*). Only those theorists held the view that the self (*attā*) is percipient (*saññī*), while these respectively hold that it is non-percipient (*asaññī*) and neither percipient nor non-percipient (*nevasaññīnāsaññī*). No special reason (*kāraṇa*) need be sought for this. For the theorists’ assumptions are like the basket of a madman.

mula_pali: 80. ‘‘Imehi  kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ asaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi. Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ asaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena, natthi ito bahiddhā…pe…  yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
mula_english:
80. "It is on these eight grounds, monks, that those ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of non-percipient immortality proclaim the self to survive non-percipient after death.

Whatever ascetics or Brahmins maintain a doctrine of non-percipient immortality, all of them do so on these eight grounds or on a certain one of them. Outside of these there is none... and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *Tathāgata* in accordance with reality would speak.
commentary_pali: 78-83. Asaññīvādo saññīvāde ādimhi vuttānaṃ dvinnaṃ catukkānaṃ vasena veditabbo. Tathā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādo. Kevalañhi tattha ‘‘saññī attā’’ti gaṇhantānaṃ tā diṭṭhiyo, idha ‘‘asaññī’’ti ca ‘‘nevasaññīnāsaññī’’ti ca. Tattha na ekantena kāraṇaṃ pariyesitabbaṃ. Diṭṭhigatikassa hi gāho ummattakapacchisadisoti vuttametaṃ.
commentary_english: 78-83. The doctrine of non-percipient immortality ( *asaññīvādo*) should be understood in terms of the first two tetrads of the doctrine of percipient immortality ( *saññīvāde*). And also that of neither percipient nor non-percipient immortality (*nevasaññīnāsaññīvādo*). Only those theorists held the view that the self (*attā*) is percipient (*saññī*), while these respectively hold that it is non-percipient (*asaññī*) and neither percipient nor non-percipient (*nevasaññīnāsaññī*). No special reason (*kāraṇaṃ*) need be sought for this. For the theorists’ assumptions are said to be like the basket of a madman.

mula_pali: 81. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā, uddhamāghātanaṃ nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi. Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi?
mula_english:
81. “There are, monks, some ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient post-mortem survival (*uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā*), and they propound the self as neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient after death on eight grounds.

And upon what, based on what, do those esteemed ascetics and Brahmins, who are proponents of neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient post-mortem survival, propound the self as neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient after death on eight grounds?
commentary_pali: 78-83. Asaññīvādo saññīvāde ādimhi vuttānaṃ dvinnaṃ catukkānaṃ vasena veditabbo. Tathā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādo. Kevalañhi tattha ‘‘saññī attā’’ti gaṇhantānaṃ tā diṭṭhiyo, idha ‘‘asaññī’’ti ca ‘‘nevasaññīnāsaññī’’ti ca. Tattha na ekantena kāraṇaṃ pariyesitabbaṃ. Diṭṭhigatikassa hi gāho ummattakapacchisadisoti vuttametaṃ.
commentary_english: 78-83. The doctrine of non-percipient immortality ( *asaññī-vāda*) should be understood in terms of the first two tetrads of the doctrine of percipient immortality (*saññī-vāda*). Likewise, the doctrine of neither percipient nor non-percipient immortality (*nevasaññīnāsaññī-vāda*). Indeed, only those theorists held the view that the self (*attā*) is percipient (*saññī*), while these respectively hold that it is non-percipient (*asaññī*) and neither percipient nor non-percipient (*nevasaññīnāsaññī*). No special reason (*kāraṇa*) need be sought for this. For the theorists’ assumptions (*gāho*) are said to be like the basket of a madman (*ummattaka-pacchi-sadiso*).

mula_pali: 82. ‘‘‘Rūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā nevasaññīnāsaññī’ti naṃ paññapenti ‘arūpī  attā hoti…pe… rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti… nevarūpī nārūpī attā hoti… antavā attā hoti… anantavā attā hoti… antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti… nevantavā nānantavā attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā nevasaññīnāsaññī’ti naṃ paññapenti.
mula_english: 82. They propound: 'The self (*ātman*) is with form (*rūpī*), healthy (*aroga*), after death (*paraṃ maraṇā*), neither conscious nor unconscious (*nevasaññīnāsaññī*)'. They propound: 'The self is without form (*arūpī*)…and so on… The self is both with and without form (*rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti*)… The self is neither with nor without form (*nevarūpī nārūpī attā hoti*)… The self is finite (*antavā attā hoti*)… The self is infinite (*anantavā attā hoti*)… The self is both finite and infinite (*antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti*)… The self is neither finite nor infinite (*nevantavā nānantavā attā hoti*), healthy (*aroga*), after death (*paraṃ maraṇā*), neither conscious nor unconscious (*nevasaññīnāsaññī*)'.
commentary_pali: 78-83. Asaññīvādo saññīvāde ādimhi vuttānaṃ dvinnaṃ catukkānaṃ vasena veditabbo. Tathā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādo. Kevalañhi tattha ‘‘saññī attā’’ti gaṇhantānaṃ tā diṭṭhiyo, idha ‘‘asaññī’’ti ca ‘‘nevasaññīnāsaññī’’ti ca. Tattha na ekantena kāraṇaṃ pariyesitabbaṃ. Diṭṭhigatikassa hi gāho ummattakapacchisadisoti vuttametaṃ.
commentary_english:
78-83. The doctrine of non-percipient immortality (*asaññī-vāda*) should be understood in terms of the first two tetrads of the doctrine of percipient immortality (*saññī-vāda*).
Likewise, the doctrine of neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient immortality (*nevasaññī-nāsaññī-vāda*).
Only those theorists hold the view that the self (*attā*) is percipient (*saññī*); here, however, it is respectively non-percipient (*asaññī*), and neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient (*nevasaññī-nāsaññī*).
No special reason need be sought for this.
For the theorists’ assumptions (*diṭṭhi-gatika*) are said to be like the basket of a madman (*ummattaka-pacchi-sadisa*).

mula_pali: 83. ‘‘Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi. Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva aṭṭhahi vatthūhi…pe…  yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
mula_english:
83. "It is on these eight grounds, monks, that those ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient survival proclaim the self to survive neither percipient nor non-percipient after death.

Whatever ascetics or Brahmins maintain a doctrine of neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient survival, all of them do so on these eight grounds…and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *Tathāgata* (Tathāgata) in accordance with reality would speak.
commentary_pali: 78-83. Asaññīvādo saññīvāde ādimhi vuttānaṃ dvinnaṃ catukkānaṃ vasena veditabbo. Tathā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādo. Kevalañhi tattha ‘‘saññī attā’’ti gaṇhantānaṃ tā diṭṭhiyo, idha ‘‘asaññī’’ti ca ‘‘nevasaññīnāsaññī’’ti ca. Tattha na ekantena kāraṇaṃ pariyesitabbaṃ. Diṭṭhigatikassa hi gāho ummattakapacchisadisoti vuttametaṃ.
commentary_english:
78-83. The doctrine of non-percipient immortality (asaññīvādo) should be understood in terms of the first two tetrads of the doctrine of percipient immortality (saññīvāde).

And also that of neither percipient nor non-percipient immortality (nevasaññīnāsaññīvādo).

Only those theorists held the view that the self (attā) is percipient (saññī), while these respectively hold that it is non-percipient (asaññī) and neither percipient nor non-percipient (nevasaññīnāsaññī).

No special reason (kāraṇaṃ) need be sought for this.

For the theorists’ assumptions (gāho) are said to be like the basket of a madman (ummattakapacchisadiso).

mula_pali: 84. ‘‘Santi , bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi. Te ca bhonto  samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi?
mula_english:
84. "There are, monks, some ascetics and Brahmins who are annihilationists (*ucchedavāda*) and who, on seven grounds, proclaim the annihilation (*uccheda*), destruction (*vināsa*), and extermination (*vibhava*) of an existent being (*sato sattassa*).

And upon what grounds do those ascetics and Brahmins, being annihilationists (*ucchedavāda*), proclaim the annihilation (*uccheda*), destruction (*vināsa*), and extermination (*vibhava*) of an existent being (*sato sattassa*) on seven grounds (*sattahi vatthūhi*)?
commentary_pali: 84. Ucchedavāde satoti vijjamānassa. Ucchedanti upacchedaṃ . Vināsanti adassanaṃ. Vibhavanti bhāvavigamaṃ. Sabbānetāni aññamaññavevacanāneva. Tattha dve janā ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhanti, lābhī ca alābhī ca. Lābhī arahato dibbena cakkhunā cutiṃ disvā upapattiṃ apassanto, yo vā cutimattameva daṭṭhuṃ sakkoti, na upapātaṃ; so ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti. Alābhī ca ‘‘ko paralokaṃ na jānātī’’ti kāmasukhagiddhatāya vā. ‘‘Yathā rukkhato paṇṇāni patitāni na puna viruhanti, evameva sattā’’tiādinā takkena vā ucchedaṃ gaṇhāti. Idha pana taṇhādiṭṭhīnaṃ vasena tathā ca aññathā ca vikappetvāva imā satta diṭṭhiyo uppannāti veditabbā.
commentary_english:
84. In the annihilationist doctrine, "being" means existing.
"Cutting off" means interruption.
"Destruction" means non-seeing ( *adassanaṃ*).
"Disappearance" means the passing away of being.
All these are synonyms for one another.
There, two types of people hold the annihilationist view ( *ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhanti*), the possessor ( *lābhī*) and the non-possessor ( *alābhī*).
The possessor ( *lābhī*) adopts the annihilationist view ( *ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti*) when, with the divine eye ( *dibbena cakkhunā*), he sees the passing away ( *cutiṃ disvā*) of an *arhat* without seeing any rebirth ( *upapattiṃ apassanto*), or when he is only able to perceive the mere passing away ( *cutimattameva daṭṭhuṃ sakkoti*), and not the rebirth ( *na upapātaṃ*).
The non-possessor ( *alābhī ca*) adopts the annihilationist view because he thinks, "Who knows about the next world ( *ko paralokaṃ na jānātī*)?", or due to his greed for sensual pleasures ( *kāmasukhagiddhatāya vā*).
Or by way of reasoning, e.g., as follows: “Just as leaves ( *paṇṇāni*) which fall from a tree ( *rukkhato*) never grow again ( *na puna viruhanti*), even so are beings ( *evameva sattā*)," he grasps at annihilation ( *ucchedaṃ gaṇhāti*).
Here, however, it should be understood ( *veditabbā*) that these seven views ( *imā satta diṭṭhiyo uppannāti*) have arisen on account of craving ( *taṇhā*) and views ( *diṭṭhīnaṃ*), in one way ( *tathā*) or another ( *aññathā*), or by proceeding eclectically ( *vikappetvāva*).

mula_pali: 85. ‘‘Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃvādī hoti evaṃdiṭṭhi evaṃdiṭṭhī (ka. pī.) – ‘yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti. Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
85. "Here, monks, some renunciate (*śramaṇa*) or Brahmin asserts the following view and opinion: 'When this self (*ātmā*), good sir, is material (*rūpī*), composed of the four great elements (*cātumahābhūtika*), originating from mother and father (*mātāpettikasambhava*), at the breaking up (*bhedā*) of the body (*kāya*) it is annihilated (*ucchijjati*) and perishes (*vinassati*), and does not exist after death (*maraṇā*). At this point, good sir, the self (*ātmā*) is completely annihilated (*sammā samucchinno*)'.
In this way, some proclaim the annihilation (*uccheda*), destruction (*vināśa*), and extermination (*vibhava*) of an existent being (*sattva*)."
commentary_pali: 85. Tattha rūpīti rūpavā. Cātumahābhūtikoti catumahābhūtamayo. Mātāpitūnaṃ etanti mātāpettikaṃ. Kiṃ taṃ? Sukkasoṇitaṃ. Mātāpettike  sambhūto jātoti mātāpettikasambhavo. Iti rūpakāyasīsena manussattabhāvaṃ ‘‘attā’’ti vadati. Ittheketi itthaṃ eke evameketi attho.
commentary_english:
85. There, *rūpī* means possessing *rūpa* (form).
*Cātumahābhūtika* means consisting of the four great elements (*catumahābhūta*).
*Mātāpitūnaṃ etanti mātāpettikaṃ* means originating from mother and father, hence *mātāpettikaṃ*.
What is that? Semen and blood (*śukraśoṇita*).
Born and produced from mother and father, hence *mātāpettikasambhava*.
Thus, the first theorist asserts the human form under the heading of the material body, to be the self (*ātmā*).
*Itthā* means thus, some [say] thus, some [say] like this, such is the meaning.

mula_pali: 86. ‘‘Tamañño evamāha – ‘atthi  kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi; no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā sammā samucchinno hoti. Atthi kho, bho, añño attā dibbo rūpī kāmāvacaro kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho. Taṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi na passasi. Tamahaṃ jānāmi passāmi. So kho, bho, attā yato kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti. Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
86. "To him another says: 'There is, good sir, such a self (*ātman*) as you assert. I do not deny it. But it is not at that point that the self is completely annihilated.
For there is another self—divine (*divya*), having material form (*rūpin*), pertaining to the sense sphere (*kāmāvacara*), feeding on edible nutriment.
That you neither know nor see.
But I know it and see it.
Since this self, good sir, is annihilated and destroyed with the breakup of the body and does not exist after death, at this point the self is completely annihilated.'
That is how some proclaim the annihilation (*uccheda*), destruction (*vināśa*), and nonexistence (*vibhava*) of beings.
commentary_pali: 86. Dutiyo  taṃ paṭikkhipitvā dibbattabhāvaṃ vadati. Dibboti devaloke sambhūto. Kāmāvacaroti cha kāmāvacaradevapariyāpanno. Kabaḷīkāraṃ āhāraṃ bhakkhatīti kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho.
commentary_english:
86. The second, rejecting this, asserts the state of being divine (*dibbattabhāvaṃ*).

"Divine" (*dibbo*) means originating (*sambhūto*) in the world of the gods (*devaloke*).

"Pertaining to the sense sphere" (*kāmāvacaro*) means included among the six classes of sense-sphere gods (*cha kāmāvacaradevapariyāpanno*).

Because one consumes (*bhakkhati*) solid food (*kabaḷīkāraṃ āhāraṃ*), therefore one is an eater of solid food (*kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho*).

mula_pali: 87. ‘‘Tamañño evamāha – ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi; no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā sammā samucchinno hoti. Atthi kho, bho, añño attā dibbo rūpī manomayo sabbaṅgapaccaṅgī ahīnindriyo. Taṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi na passasi. Tamahaṃ jānāmi passāmi. So kho, bho, attā yato kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti. Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
87. Another says to him: "Sir, there is such a self (*ātman*) as you say; I do not deny its existence. But that self is not wholly annihilated at that point.
For there is, good sir, another self—divine (*divya*), having material form (*rūpin*), mind-made (*manomaya*), complete in all its limbs and organs (*sabvaṅgapaccaṅgin*), not destitute of any faculties (*ahīnindriya*).
That you neither know nor see.
But I know it and see it.
Since this self, good sir, is annihilated and destroyed with the breakup of the body and does not exist after death, at this point the self is completely annihilated."
That is how some proclaim the annihilation (*uccheda*), destruction (*vināsa*), and non-existence (*vibhava*) of beings.
commentary_pali: 87.Manomayoti jhānamanena nibbatto. Sabbaṅgapaccaṅgīti sabbaṅgapaccaṅgayutto. Ahīnindriyoti paripuṇṇindriyo. Yāni brahmaloke atthi, tesaṃ vasena itaresañca saṇṭhānavasenetaṃ vuttaṃ.
commentary_english:
87. "Mind-made" (*manomaya*) means produced through this jhāna mind.
"Possessing all limbs and secondary limbs" (*sabbaṅgapaccaṅgī*) means endowed with all limbs and secondary limbs.
“Not destitute of any faculties” (*ahīnindriya*) means complete in its faculties (*paripuṇṇindriya*).
This is said by way of the faculties that exist in the Brahma-world and by way of the figures of the others.

mula_pali: 88. ‘‘Tamañño evamāha – ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi; no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā  sammā samucchinno hoti. Atthi kho , bho, añño attā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ  amanasikārā ‘‘ananto ākāso’’ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpago. Taṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi  na passasi. Tamahaṃ jānāmi passāmi. So kho, bho, attā yato kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti. Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
88. Another says to him: ‘Good sir, there is a self (ātman) such as you describe, I do not deny that it exists; however, it is not at this point that the self is completely annihilated (sammā samucchinno hoti).

For there is, good sir, another self (ātman) belonging to the base of infinite space, through the complete surmounting of perceptions of form (rūpasaññānaṃ), by the disappearance of perceptions of resistance (paṭighasaññānaṃ), by non-attention to perceptions of diversity (nānattasaññānaṃ), thinking "space is infinite" (ananto ākāso), one attains to the sphere of infinite space (ākāsānañcāyatanūpago).

You neither know nor see that.

But I know and see it.

It is this self (ātman) that at the breaking-up of the body (kāyassa bhedā) is annihilated (ucchijjati) and perishes (vinassati), and does not exist after death (paraṃ maraṇā). It is in this way that the self (ātman) is completely annihilated (sammā samucchinno hoti.’

In this way some proclaim the annihilation (ucchedaṃ), destruction (vināsaṃ), and extermination (vibhavaṃ) of an existent being (sato sattassa).
commentary_pali: 88-92.Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamātiādīnaṃ attho visuddhimagge vutto. Ākāsānañcāyatanūpagotiādīsu pana ākāsānañcāyatanabhavaṃ upagatoti, evamattho veditabbo. Sesamettha uttānamevāti.
commentary_english:
88-92. The meaning of "utterly transcending all perceptions of form," and so on, is explained in the *Visuddhimagga*.

Furthermore, regarding "having attained the sphere of infinite space," and so on, the meaning should be understood thus: "he has attained the state of the sphere of infinite space."

The rest, here, is but clear.

mula_pali: 89. ‘‘Tamañño evamāha – ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi; no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā sammā samucchinno hoti. Atthi kho, bho, añño attā sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘‘anantaṃ viññāṇa’’nti viññāṇañcāyatanūpago. Taṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi na passasi. Tamahaṃ jānāmi passāmi. So kho, bho, attā yato kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti. Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
89. Another one says to him: 'Good sir, there is a self (*ātmā*) as you say. I do not deny it. However, that self is not completely annihilated at that point.
There is another self (*ātmā*) which, by entirely surpassing the sphere of infinite space (*ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ*), and [realizing] that "consciousness (*vijñāṇa*) is infinite" has attained the sphere of infinite consciousness (*viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ*).
That you neither know nor see.
But I know it and see it.
It is this self (*ātmā*), good sir, that is annihilated and destroyed with the breakup of the body (*kāyassa bhedā*) and does not exist after death (*maraṇā*). At this point, the self (*ātmā*) is completely annihilated.'
In this way, some proclaim the annihilation (*ucchedaṃ*), destruction (*vināsaṃ*), and non-existence (*vibhavaṃ*) of an existent being.
commentary_pali: 88-92.Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamātiādīnaṃ attho visuddhimagge vutto. Ākāsānañcāyatanūpagotiādīsu pana ākāsānañcāyatanabhavaṃ upagatoti, evamattho veditabbo. Sesamettha uttānamevāti.
commentary_english:
88-92. The meaning of "utterly transcending all perceptions of form," and so on, is explained in the *Visuddhimagga*.

Furthermore, in the section beginning with, "having attained the sphere of infinite space (ākāsānañcāyatana)," the meaning should be understood thus: "having attained the state of the sphere of infinite space."

The rest is evident.

mula_pali: 90. ‘‘Tamañño evamāha – ‘atthi kho, bho, so attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi; no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā sammā samucchinno hoti. Atthi kho, bho, añño attā sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘‘natthi kiñcī’’ti ākiñcaññāyatanūpago. Taṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi na passasi. Tamahaṃ jānāmi passāmi. So kho, bho, attā yato kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho , bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’’ti. Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
90.
“To him another says: ‘Indeed, sir, there is such a self (*ātman*) as you assert. I do not deny that it doesn't exist; but that self is not completely annihilated merely by that.
For there is, good sir, another self belonging to the base of nothingness, completely surmounting the base of infinite consciousness: “There is nothing” (*natthi kiñcī*).
You do not know it or see it.
But I know it and see it.
Since this self, good sir, is annihilated and destroyed with the breakup of the body (kāyassa bhedā) and does not exist after death, at this point the self (*ātman*) is completely annihilated."
In this way some proclaim the annihilation (*ucchedaṃ*), destruction (*vināsaṃ*), and extermination (*vibhavaṃ*) of an existent being (*sato sattassa*).
commentary_pali: 88-92.Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamātiādīnaṃ attho visuddhimagge vutto. Ākāsānañcāyatanūpagotiādīsu pana ākāsānañcāyatanabhavaṃ upagatoti, evamattho veditabbo. Sesamettha uttānamevāti.
commentary_english:
88-92. The meaning of "completely transcending all perceptions of form ( *rūpasaññā*)," and so on, is explained in the *Visuddhimagga*.
Moreover, in the phrases beginning with "having attained the sphere of infinite space (*ākāsānañcāyatana*)," the meaning should be understood thus: "he has attained the state of the sphere of infinite space (*ākāsānañcāyatana-bhavaṃ upagato*)."
The rest here is evident.

mula_pali: 91. ‘Tamañño evamāha – ‘‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi; no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā sammā samucchinno hoti. Atthi kho, bho, añño attā  sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘‘santametaṃ paṇītameta’’nti nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpago. Taṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi na passasi. Tamahaṃ jānāmi passāmi. So kho, bho, attā yato kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti. Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
91. Another says to him: “Sir, there is such a self (*ātman*) as you say; I do not say that this self does not exist; but that self is not completely annihilated at this point.

For there is, good sir, another self (*ātman*) that, having completely transcended the sphere of nothingness (*ākiñcanyāyatana*), enters the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception (*nevasaññānāsaññāyatana*), thinking, "This is peaceful; this is sublime."

That you neither know nor see.

But I know it and see it.

It is this self (*ātman*) that, with the breakup of the body (*kāya*), is annihilated and destroyed, and does not exist after death; it is in this way that the self (*ātman*) is completely annihilated."

In this way, some proclaim the annihilation (*uccheda*), destruction (*vināsa*), and non-existence (*vibhava*) of an existing being (*satta*).
commentary_pali: 88-92.Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamātiādīnaṃ attho visuddhimagge vutto. Ākāsānañcāyatanūpagotiādīsu pana ākāsānañcāyatanabhavaṃ upagatoti, evamattho veditabbo. Sesamettha uttānamevāti.
commentary_english:
88-92. The meaning of "completely transcending all perceptions of form," and so on, is explained in the *Visuddhimagga*.

Furthermore, in "[one] has attained the sphere of the infinity of space," and so on, the meaning should be understood thus: "[one] has attained existence in the sphere of the infinity of space."

The rest is clear.

mula_pali: 92. ‘‘Imehi  kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi. Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā  vā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva sattahi vatthūhi…pe… yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
mula_english:
92. "It is on these grounds, monks, that those ascetics and Brahmins who are annihilationists ( *ucchedavādā* ) proclaim the annihilation ( *ucchedaṃ* ), destruction ( *vināsaṃ* ), and extermination ( *vibhavaṃ* ) of an existent being ( *sato sattassa* ) in seven ways.

Whatever recluses or Brahmins proclaim the annihilation ( *ucchedaṃ* ), destruction ( *vināsaṃ* ), and extermination ( *vibhavaṃ* ) of an existent being ( *sato sattassa* ), all of them do so on these seven grounds... and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *Tathāgata* in accordance with reality would speak.
commentary_pali: 88-92.Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamātiādīnaṃ attho visuddhimagge vutto. Ākāsānañcāyatanūpagotiādīsu pana ākāsānañcāyatanabhavaṃ upagatoti, evamattho veditabbo. Sesamettha uttānamevāti.
commentary_english:
88-92. The meaning of the fourth, namely, the complete transcending of perceptions of form ( *sarvaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkama*), etc., is explained in the *Visuddhimagga*.

Moreover, regarding, "one who has attained the *ākāsānañcāyatana*," etc. (*ākāsānañcāyatanūpagotiādīsu*), the meaning should be understood thus: "he has attained the state of the *ākāsānañcāyatana* (*ākāsānañcāyatanabhavaṃ upagato*)."

The rest here is evident.

mula_pali: 93. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi. Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā  sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi?
mula_english:
93. "There are, monks, some ascetics and Brahmins who are proclaimers of *dṛṣṭadharmanirvāṇa* (Nibbāna Here and Now), and who proclaim supreme *dṛṣṭadharmanirvāṇa* (Nibbāna here and now) for an existent being in five ways.

And upon what grounds, based on what, do those venerable ascetics and Brahmins, proclaimers of *dṛṣṭadharmanirvāṇa* (Nibbāna Here and Now), proclaim supreme *dṛṣṭadharmanirvāṇa* (Nibbāna here and now) for an existent being in five ways?
commentary_pali: 93. Diṭṭhadhammanibbānavāde diṭṭhadhammoti paccakkhadhammo vuccati, tattha tattha paṭiladdhattabhāvassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Diṭṭhadhamme nibbānaṃ diṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ, imasmiṃyeva attabhāve dukkhavūpasamananti attho. Taṃ vadantīti diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā.  Paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānanti paramaṃ diṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ uttamanti attho.
commentary_english: 93. In the doctrine of *diṭṭhadhammanibbāna*, *diṭṭhadhamma* is called directly experienced *dhamma*. This is a designation for the individuality obtained in this or that state of existence. *Diṭṭhadhamme nibbānaṃ*, *diṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ*, means the subsiding of suffering in this very individuality. Those who say that are the proponents of the *diṭṭhadhammanibbāna* doctrine. *Paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ* means the highest *diṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ*, the ultimate.

mula_pali: 94. ‘‘Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃvādī hoti evaṃdiṭṭhi – ‘‘yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti. Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
94.

"Here, monks, some ascetic or *brāhmaṇa* holds such a view and proclaims such a doctrine: 'When this self (*attā*), good sir, is furnished and replete with the five strands of sense pleasures (*pañcahi kāmaguṇehi*), and indulges in them, at that very point, good sir, this self (*attā*) attains the supreme *Nirvāṇa* (*paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ*) here and now!'"

In this way, some proclaim the highest *Nirvāṇa* attainable in this very life (*paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ*) for an existent being.
commentary_pali: 94.Pañcahi kāmaguṇehīti manāpiyarūpādīhi pañcahi kāmakoṭṭhāsehi bandhanehi vā. Samappitoti suṭṭhu appito allīno hutvā. Samaṅgībhūtoti samannāgato. Paricāretīti tesu kāmaguṇesu yathāsukhaṃ indriyāni cāreti sañcāreti itocito ca upaneti. Atha vā laḷati ramati kīḷati. Ettha ca duvidhā kāmaguṇā – mānusakā ceva dibbā ca. Mānusakā mandhātukāmaguṇasadisā daṭṭhabbā, dibbā paranimmitavasavattidevarājassa kāmaguṇasadisāti. Evarūpe kāme upagatānañhi te diṭṭhadhammanibbānasampattiṃ paññapenti.
commentary_english:
94. "With the five strands of sense pleasure": that is, with the five desirable sense-fields such as pleasant forms, which are like sensual attachments or bonds.

"Devoted to": being well and truly devoted, having become absorbed.

"Endowed with": being furnished with.

“Revels”: he allows his sense faculties to roam and wander among those strands of sense pleasure according to his wish, indulging in them in this way and that.

Or else: he sports, delights, and plays with them.

The strands of sense pleasure (kāmaguṇā) are twofold, the human (mānusakā) and the divine (dibbā).

The human are to be regarded as like the sense pleasures of King Mandhātu; the divine are like the sense pleasures of the king of the Paranirmita-vaśavartin gods.

The theorists proclaim the achievement of *nirvāṇa* here and now only for those who have acquired such sense pleasures (kāme).

mula_pali: 95. ‘‘Tamañño evamāha –‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi; no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hoti. Taṃ kissa hetu? Kāmā hi, bho, aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, tesaṃ vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā. Yato kho , bho, ayaṃ attā vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ  attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti. Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
95.
“Then another says to him: ‘There is, good sir, such a self (ātman) as you assert. That I do not deny. But it is not at that point that the self (ātman) attains supreme *nibbāna* here and now.

What is the reason for that? Because, good sir, sense pleasures (*kāmā*) are impermanent (*aniccā*), suffering (*dukkha*), subject to change (*vipariṇāmadhammā*), and through their change and transformation there arise sorrow (*soka*), lamentation (*parideva*), pain (*dukkha*), grief (*domanassa*), and despair (*upāyāsā*).

But when this self (ātman), quite secluded from sense pleasures (*kāmehi*), secluded from unwholesome states (*akusalehi dhammehi*), enters and abides in the first *jhāna*, which is accompanied by initial thought (*savitakka*) and sustained thought (*savicāra*) and contains the rapture and happiness (*pītisukhaṃ*) born of seclusion (*vivekajaṃ*)—at this point, good sir, the self (ātman) attains supreme *nibbāna* here and now.’

In this way, some proclaim supreme *nibbāna* here and now for an existent being.
commentary_pali: 95. Dutiyavāre  hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena aniccā paṭipīḷanaṭṭhena dukkhā, pakatijahanaṭṭhena vipariṇāmadhammāti veditabbā. Tesaṃ vipariṇāmaññathābhāvāti tesaṃ kāmānaṃ vipariṇāmasaṅkhātā aññathābhāvā, yampi me ahosi, tampi me natthīti vuttanayena uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā. Tattha antonijjhāyanalakkhaṇo soko, tannissitalālappanalakkhaṇo  paridevo, kāyappaṭipīḷanalakkhaṇaṃ dukkhaṃ, manovighātalakkhaṇaṃ domanassaṃ, visādalakkhaṇo upāyāso, vivicceva kāmehītiādīnamattho visuddhimagge vutto.
commentary_english:
95. Having occurred for the second time, they should be understood as impermanent due to the characteristic of absence (abhāvaṭṭhena), as suffering (duḥkha) due to the characteristic of oppression (paṭipīḷanaṭṭhena), and as subject to transformation (vipariṇāmadhamma) due to the characteristic of abandoning their original nature (pakatijahanaṭṭhena).

Their transformation is otherness: the otherness consisting of the transformation of those desires. "What I had, that I no longer have" - in accordance with this previously stated method, sorrow (śoka), lamentation (parideva), suffering (duḥkha), displeasure (domanassa), and despair (upāyāsa) arise.

There, sorrow (śoka) has the characteristic of inward contemplation (antonijjhāyanalakkhaṇo); lamentation (paridevo) has the characteristic of compulsive talking based on that (tannissitalālappanalakkhaṇo); suffering (duḥkha) has the characteristic of bodily oppression (kāyappaṭipīḷanalakkhaṇaṃ); displeasure (daumanassaṃ) has the characteristic of mental agitation (manovighātalakkhaṇaṃ); despair (upāyāso) has the characteristic of dejection (visādalakkhaṇo). The meaning of "quite secluded from sensual pleasures" (vivicceva kāmehītiādi) and so forth is stated in the Visuddhimagga.

mula_pali: 96. ‘‘Tamañño  evamāha – ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi; no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hoti. Taṃ kissa hetu? Yadeva tattha vitakkitaṃ vicāritaṃ, etenetaṃ oḷārikaṃ akkhāyati. Yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā vitakkavicārānaṃ  vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti. Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
96. Another says to him: ‘There is, sir, such a self (*ātmā*) as you assert; I do not say that there is not. But it is not at this point that the self attains the supreme *Nirvāṇa* here and now (*paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hoti*).

Why is that? Because that *jhāna* contains initial thought (*vitakkitaṃ*) and sustained thought (*vicāritaṃ*); therefore it is declared to be gross (*oḷārikaṃ akkhāyati*).

But when, sir, the self, by the subsiding of initial and sustained thought (*vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā*), enters and abides in the second *jhāna* (*dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ*), which has inner tranquility (*ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ*) and oneness of mind (*cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ*), is without initial thought (*avitakkaṃ*) and sustained thought (*avicāraṃ*), and contains the rapture (*pīti*) and happiness (*sukhaṃ*) born of concentration (*samādhijaṃ*), that is when the self realises the supreme *Nirvāṇa* here and now (*paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hoti*)."

In this way, some proclaim the supreme *Nirvāṇa* here and now for an existent being (*satassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti*).
commentary_pali: 96.Vitakkitanti abhiniropanavasena pavatto vitakko. Vicāritanti  anumajjanavasena pavatto vicāro. Etenetanti etena vitakkitena ca vicāritena ca etaṃ paṭhamajjhānaṃ oḷārikaṃ sakaṇḍakaṃ viya khāyati.
commentary_english: 96. Thinking (vitakka) is the thought that occurs through focusing the mind. Consideration (vicāra) is the reflection that occurs through sustained application. Because of this, the first dhyāna (paṭhamajjhānaṃ), with its thinking and consideration, appears coarse (oḷārikaṃ), like something with husks (sakaṇḍakaṃ).

mula_pali: 97. ‘‘Tamañño evamāha – ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi; no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hoti. Taṃ kissa hetu? Yadeva tattha pītigataṃ cetaso uppilāvitattaṃ, etenetaṃ oḷārikaṃ akkhāyati. Yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti ‘‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’’ti, tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti. Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
97. Another says to him: ‘Sir, there is such a self ( *attā*) as you say. I don’t deny it. But that is not when the self attains the supreme *Nibbāna* here and now.

Why is that? It is declared to be gross because of the mental exhilaration (*uppilāvitattaṃ*) connected with rapture (*pīti*) that exists there.

But when the self, with the fading away of rapture (*pītiyā virāgā*), one abides in equanimity (*upekkhako*), mindful (*sato*) and clearly comprehending (*sampajāno*), and still experiencing happiness (*sukhaṃ*) with the body (*kāyena*), enters and abides in the third *jhāna*, so that the *ariyas* announce: “He abides happily (*sukhavihārī*), in equanimity (*upekkhako*) and mindfulness (*satimā*)”—at this point, good sir, the self attains supreme *Nibbāna* here and now.’

That is how some proclaim the highest *Nibbāna* here and now for an existent being.
commentary_pali: 97-98.Pītigatanti pītiyeva. Cetaso uppilāvitattanti cittassa uppilabhāvakaraṇaṃ. Cetaso ābhogoti jhānā vuṭṭhāya tasmiṃ sukhe punappunaṃ cittassa ābhogo manasikāro samannāhāroti. Sesamettha diṭṭhadhammanibbānavāde uttānameva. Ettāvatā sabbāpi dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhiyo kathitā honti. Yāsaṃ satteva ucchedadiṭṭhiyo, sesā sassatadiṭṭhiyo.
commentary_english:
97-98.
*Pīti* means just *pīti*.
The elated state of consciousness means the act of making consciousness elated.
The application of consciousness means, having arisen from *jhāna*, the application of consciousness, attention (*manasikāra*), and directing the mind (*samannāhāra*) again and again towards that bliss.
The rest is evident in the discourse on *nirvāṇa* visible in this very life (*dṛṣṭadharm નિર્વાણavāda*).
At this point, all sixty-two views have been explained.
Seven of these views belong to annihilationism (*ucchedadiṭṭhi*), the remainder to eternalism (*śāśvatadṛṣṭi*).

mula_pali: 98. ‘‘Tamañño evamāha – ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi; no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hoti. Taṃ kissa hetu? Yadeva tattha sukhamiti cetaso ābhogo, etenetaṃ oḷārikaṃ akkhāyati. Yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ  upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā  kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti. Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti.
mula_english:
98. Another says to him: “Sir, there is such a self (ātman) as you say. I do not deny it. But it is not at that point that the self (ātman) attains the supreme *Nirvāṇa* here and now.

Why is that? Because the mind contains the idea of joy there, and that state is considered gross (oḷārika).

But when, good sir, this self (ātman), with the abandonment of pleasure (sukha) and pain (duḥkha), with the disappearance of previous joy (saumanasya) and grief (daurmanasya), enters and abides in the fourth *jhāna*, which is without pleasure and pain and contains purification of mindfulness through equanimity (upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ)—at this point, good sir, this self (ātman) attains supreme *Nirvāṇa* here and now.”

In this way some proclaim the supreme *Nirvāṇa* here and now for an existent being.
commentary_pali: 97-98.Pītigatanti pītiyeva. Cetaso uppilāvitattanti cittassa uppilabhāvakaraṇaṃ. Cetaso ābhogoti jhānā vuṭṭhāya tasmiṃ sukhe punappunaṃ cittassa ābhogo manasikāro samannāhāroti. Sesamettha diṭṭhadhammanibbānavāde uttānameva. Ettāvatā sabbāpi dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhiyo kathitā honti. Yāsaṃ satteva ucchedadiṭṭhiyo, sesā sassatadiṭṭhiyo.
commentary_english:
97-98.
*pītigati* means just *pīti* (joy, rapture).
*Cetaso uppilāvitatta* means *cittassa uppilabhāvakaraṇaṃ*: making consciousness buoyant.
*Cetaso ābhogo* means, having arisen from *jhāna* (meditative absorption), the repeated application, attention (*manasikāra*), and directing (*samannāhāra*) of the mind to that happiness (*sukha*).
The rest in the explanation of the *dṛṣṭadharma nirvāṇa vāda* (the doctrine of nirvāṇa in this very life) is but clear.
At this point, all the sixty-two views (*dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhi*) have been explained.
Of these, seven are annihilationist views (*ucchedadiṭṭhi*), and the rest are eternalist views (*sassatadiṭṭhi*).

mula_pali: 99. ‘‘Imehi  kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi. Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva pañcahi vatthūhi…pe…  yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
mula_english:
"It is through these five grounds, monks, that those ascetics and Brahmins who advocate a doctrine of *dṛṣṭadharmanirvāṇa* (Nibbāna here and now) propound the supreme *dṛṣṭadharmanirvāṇa* (Nibbāna here and now) for an existing being.

Whatever ascetics or Brahmins, monks, are proponents of *dṛṣṭadharmanirvāṇa* (Nibbāna here and now), and propound the supreme *dṛṣṭadharmanirvāṇa* (Nibbāna here and now) for an existing being, all of them do so only through these five grounds…and… those who would rightly speak of the *Tathāgata's* true qualities would speak of these."

mula_pali: 100. ‘‘Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi. commentary_english:
100-104.
Now, collecting into one all the speculators about the future in the section beginning “it is on these grounds, *bhikkhus* (monks)” , he reveals his knowledge of omniscience (*sabbaññutaññāṇa*).

And again, collecting into one all the speculators about the past and the future in the section beginning “it is on these grounds, *bhikkhus* (monks)” , he again reveals this same knowledge (*ñāṇa*).

Thus, when in the beginning he asked: “And what, *bhikkhus* (monks), are those *dhammas* that are deep, etc.? ”, he asked only in reference to the knowledge of omniscience (*sabbaññutaññāṇa*). And answering this question, the Exalted One answers by means of the same knowledge of omniscience (*sabbaññutaññāṇa*), bringing forth the sixty-two speculative views (*diṭṭhigatāni*) just as if he were weighing the inclinations (*ajjhāsayaṃ*) of beings with a pair of scales or removing the sand from the foot of Mount Sineru.

Thus, this teaching (*desanā*) has come down by way of a sequence of meaning dictated by the natural structure (*yathānusandhi*) of the teaching.

For suttas have three kinds of sequence of meaning (*anusandhi*): a sequence of meaning based on a question (*pucchānusandhi*): a sequence of meaning dictated by inclination (*ajjhāsayānusandhi*); and a sequence of meaning dictated by the natural structure (*yathānusandhi*).

Herein, the “sequence of meaning based on a question” (*pucchānusandhi*) can be understood through those suttas the Exalted One pronounced in response to those who questioned him, as the following passage illustrates: “When this was said, a certain *bhikkhu* (monk) said to the Exalted One: ‘What, Lord (*bhante*), is the lower shore (*orimaṃ tīraṃ*)? What is the further shore (*pārimaṃ tīraṃ*)? What is sinking in the middle (*majjhe saṃsīdo*)? What is being thrown up on dry land (*thale ussādo*)? What is seizure by humans (*manussaggāho*), by non-humans (*amanussaggāho*) and by a whirlpool (*āvaṭṭaggāho*)? What is inner putridity (*antopūtibhāvo*)? “ (Saṃ.

Then, in the mind (*cetaso*) of a certain *bhikkhu* (monk) this thought (*parivitakko*) arose: “So, it seems, material form (*rūpaṃ*) is not self (*anattā*), feeling (*vedanā*) is not self (*anattā*), perception (*saññā*) is not self (*anattā*), formations (*saṅkhārā*) are not self (*anattā*), consciousness (*viññāṇaṃ*) is not self (*anattā*). What self (*kamattānaṃ*), then, will actions (*kammāni*) done by the not-self (*anattakatāni*) affect?”

Then the Blessed One (*bhagavā*), knowing with his mind (*cetasā*) the thought in the mind (*ceto*) of that *bhikkhu* (monk), addressed the *bhikkhus* (monks) thus: “It is possible (*ṭhānaṃ*), *bhikkhus* (monks), that some misguided man (*moghapuriso*) here, obtuse (*avidvā*) and ignorant (*avijjāgato*), with his mind (*cetasā*) dominated by craving (*taṇhādhipateyyena*) might think that he can outstrip (*atidhāvitabbaṃ maññeyya*) the Teacher’s Dispensation (*satthusāsanaṃ*) thus: ‘So, it seems, material form (*rūpaṃ*) is not self (*anattā*)… what self (*phusissantī*)?”

“What do you think (*maññatha*), *bhikkhus* (monks), is material form (*rūpaṃ*) permanent (*niccaṃ*) or impermanent (*aniccaṃ*)?” (Ma. Ni. 3. 10).

Thus, having understood the inclinations (*ajjhāsayaṃ*) of others, the “sequence of meaning dictated by inclination” (*ajjhāsayānusandhi*) can be understood through those suttas (*vuttasuttavasena*) the Exalted One pronounced (*bhagavatā*).

The “sequence of meaning dictated by the natural structure of the teaching” (*yathānusandhi*) can be understood through those suttas in which the teaching (*desanā*) progresses from its initial subject to its culmination by way of counterparts (*anurūpadhamma*), or by way of the opposites (*paṭipakkha*) of the initial subject.

For example, in the Ākaṅkheyya Sutta the teaching (*desanā*) is set up at the beginning by way of virtue (*sīlena*) and culminates in the six kinds of direct knowledge (*cha abhiññā*).

In the Vattha Sutta, the teaching (*desanā*) is set up by way of the defilements (*kilesena*) and culminates in the sublime abodes (*brahmavihārā*).

In the Kosambiya Sutta, the teaching (*desanā*) is set up by way of schism (*bhaṇḍanena*) and culminates in the principles of fraternal harmony (*sāraṇīyadhammā*).

In the Kakacūpama, the teaching (*desanā*) is set up at the beginning by way of patience (*akkhantiyā*) and culminates in the Kakacūpama.

And in this Brahmajāla Sutta, the teaching (*desanā*) is set up at the beginning by way of views (*diṭṭhivasena*) and culminates in the elucidation of emptiness (*suññatāpakāsanaṃ*).

Thus it is said: “This teaching (*desanā*) has come down by way of a sequence of meaning dictated by the natural structure (*yathānusandhivasena*) of the teaching.

Then the following line of thought arose in the mind of a certain *bhikkhu*: “It is said, sir ( *bho*), that material form ( *rūpaṃ* ) is not-self ( *anattā*), feeling ( *vedanā* ) is not-self, perception ( *saññā* ) is not-self, mental formations ( *saṅkhārā* ) are not-self, consciousness ( *viññāṇaṃ* ) is non-self ( *anattā*). What self, then, do *kammas* done without a self affect?”
Then the Exalted One, discerning with his mind this *bhikkhu*'s thought, addressed the *bhikkhus*: “It is possible, monks ( *bhikkhave*), that a certain foolish man ( *moghapuriso* ) here, confused ( *avidvā*), immersed in ignorance ( *avijjāgato* ) and dominated by craving ( *taṇhādhipateyyena* ) , may imagine in his mind that he can overshoot the dispensation of the Master (*satthusāsanaṃ* ), thus: ‘“It is said, sir ( *bho* ), that material form (*rūpaṃ*) is non-self (*anattā*)… etc. … what self will actions affect?’”
“What do you think, *bhikkhus*, is material form (*rūpaṃ*) permanent ( *niccaṃ*) or impermanent (*aniccaṃ*)?”

Thus, the “sequence of meaning dictated by inclination” (*ajjhāsayānusandhi*) can be understood through those *suttas* the Exalted One pronounced after he had understood the inclinations ( *ajjhāsaya* ) of others.
The “sequence of meaning dictated by the natural structure of the teaching” (*yathānusandhi*) can be understood through those *suttas* in which the teaching progresses from its initial subject to its culmination by way of counterparts or by way of the opposites of the initial subject, by whichever *dharma* the teaching started in the beginning.
For example, in the *Ākaṅkheyya Sutta* the teaching is set up at the beginning by way of virtue ( *sīla*) and culminates in the six kinds of direct knowledge (*abhiññā*).
In the *Vattha Sutta*, the teaching is set up by way of the defilements ( *kilesa* ) and culminates in the sublime abodes ( *brahmavihārā*).
In the *Kosambiya Sutta*, the teaching is set up by way of schism ( *bhaṇḍana*) and culminates in the principles of fraternal harmony ( *sāraṇīyadhammā*).
In the *Kakacūpama*, the teaching is set up at the beginning by way of patience ( *akkhanti*) and culminates in the *Kakacūpama*.
And in this *Brahmajāla Sutta*, the teaching is set up at the beginning by way of views (*diṭṭhi*) and culminates in the elucidation of emptiness ( *suññatāpakāsanaṃ*).
Thus it is said: “This teaching has come down by way of a sequence of meaning dictated by the natural structure of the teaching ( *yathānusandhivasena desanā āgatā* ).”

mula_pali: 103. ‘‘Tayidaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānāti – ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṃgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṃgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā’ti. Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṃ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti  viditā. Vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
mula_english:
"This, monks, the *Tathāgata* understands: 'These viewpoints, thus grasped and thus adhered to, will lead to such and such destinations in another world.' (ime *diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṃgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṃgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā*'ti).

The *Tathāgata* understands this, and even more than this, but he is not attached to that knowledge. And because he is free from misapprehension, he has realized within himself perfect peace (*nibbuti*).

Having understood as they really are the arising (*samudaya*) and passing away (*atthaṅgama*) of feelings (*vedanānaṃ*), their satisfaction (*assāda*), their unsatisfactoriness (*ādīnava*), and the escape (*nissaraṇa*) from them, the *Tathāgata*, monks, is liberated through non-clinging (*anupādāvimutto*)."
commentary_pali: 100-104. Idāni – ‘‘imehi kho te, bhikkhave’’ti iminā vārena sabbepi te aparantakappike ekajjhaṃ niyyātetvā sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ vissajjeti. Puna – ‘‘imehi, kho te bhikkhave’’tiādinā vārena sabbepi te pubbantāparantakappike ekajjhaṃ niyyātetvā tadeva ñāṇaṃ vissajjeti. Iti ‘‘katame ca te, bhikkhave, dhammā’’tiādimhi pucchamānopi sabbaññutaññāṇameva pucchitvā vissajjamānopi sattānaṃ ajjhāsayaṃ tulāya tulayanto viya sinerupādato vālukaṃ uddharanto viya dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni uddharitvā sabbaññutaññāṇameva vissajjeti. Evamayaṃ yathānusandhivasena desanā āgatā. Tayo hi suttassa anusandhī – pucchānusandhi, ajjhāsayānusandhi, yathānusandhīti. Tattha ‘‘evaṃ vutte aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – kiṃ nu  kho, bhante, orimaṃ tīraṃ, kiṃ pārimaṃ tīraṃ, ko majjhe saṃsīdo, ko thale ussādo, ko manussaggāho, ko amanussaggāho, ko āvaṭṭaggāho, ko antopūtibhāvo’’ti (saṃ. ni. 4.241) evaṃ pucchantānaṃ bhagavatā vissajjitasuttavasena pucchānusandhi veditabbo. Atha kho aññatarassa bhikkhuno evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi – ‘‘iti kira bho rūpaṃ anattā…, vedanā…, saññā…, saṅkhārā …, viññāṇaṃ anattā, anattakatāni kira kammāni  kamattānaṃ phusissantī’’ti. Atha kho bhagavā tassa bhikkhuno cetasā ceto parivitakkamaññāya bhikkhū āmantesi – ‘‘ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati, yaṃ idhekacco moghapuriso avidvā avijjāgato taṇhādhipateyyena cetasā satthusāsanaṃ atidhāvitabbaṃ maññeyya – ‘‘iti kira bho rūpaṃ anattā…pe… phusissantī’’ti. Yena pana dhammena ādimhi desanā uṭṭhitā, tassa dhammassa anurūpadhammavasena vā paṭipakkhavasena vā yesu suttesu upari desanā āgacchati, tesaṃ vasena yathānusandhi veditabbo. Seyyathidaṃ, ākaṅkheyyasutte heṭṭhā sīlena desanā uṭṭhitā, upari cha abhiññā āgatā. Vatthasutte heṭṭhā kilesena desanā uṭṭhitā, upari brahmavihārā āgatā. Kosambakasutte heṭṭhā bhaṇḍanena uṭṭhitā, upari sāraṇīyadhammā āgatā. Kakacūpame heṭṭhā akkhantiyā uṭṭhitā, upari kakacūpamā āgatā. Imasmimpi brahmajāle heṭṭhā diṭṭhivasena desanā uṭṭhitā, upari suññatāpakāsanaṃ āgataṃ. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘evamayaṃ yathānusandhivasena desanā āgatā’’ti.

mula_pali: 104. ‘‘Ime  kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
mula_english: “These, monks, are those *dharmas* that are profound (*gambhīra*), difficult to see (*duddasa*), difficult to understand (*duranubodha*), peaceful (*santa*), excellent (*paṇīta*), beyond the realm of logic (*atakkāvacara*), subtle (*nipuṇa*), and to be experienced by the wise (*paṇḍitavedanīya*), which the *Tathāgata* having realized them himself with direct knowledge (*abhiññā sacchikatvā*), proclaims; and it is concerning these qualities that those who would rightly praise the *Tathāgata* in accordance with reality would speak.

commentary_english:
100-104.
Now, collecting into one all those who speculate about the future in the section beginning "it is on these grounds, monks," the Exalted One reveals his knowledge of omniscience (sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ).
And again, collecting into one all those who speculate about the past and the future in the section beginning "it is on these grounds, monks," he reveals this same knowledge.
Thus, when in the beginning he asked: "And what, monks, are those *dharmas*?", he asked only in reference to the knowledge of omniscience (sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ). And answering this question, the Exalted One answers by means of the same knowledge of omniscience, bringing forth the sixty-two speculative views (dvāsatthi ditthigatāni) just as if he were weighing the inclinations (ajjhāsayam) of beings with a pair of scales or removing the sand from the foot of Mount Sineru.
Thus, this teaching (desanā) has come down by way of a sequence of meaning dictated by the natural structure of the teaching (yathānusandhivasena).
For *suttas* have three kinds of sequence of meaning: a sequence of meaning based on a question (*pucchānusandhi*), a sequence of meaning dictated by inclination (*ajjhāsayānusandhi*), and a sequence of meaning dictated by the natural structure of the teaching (*yathānusandhi*).
Herein, the "sequence of meaning based on a question" is found in those *suttas* the Exalted One pronounced in response to those who questioned him, as the following passage illustrates: "When this was said, a certain *bhikkhu* said to the Exalted One: 'What, Lord (*bhante*), is the lower shore (*orimaṃ tīraṃ*)? What is the further shore (*pārimaṃ tīraṃ*)? What is sinking in the middle (*majjhe saṃsīdo*)? What is being thrown up on dry land (*thale ussādo*)? What is seizure by humans (*manussaggāho*), by non-humans (*amanussaggāho*) and by a whirlpool (*āvaṭṭaggāho*)? What is inner putridity (*antopūtibhāvo*)?'"
Thus, when questioned, the sequence of meaning based on a question should be understood through the Blessed One's discourse in response to the question.
Then the following line of thought arose in the mind of a certain *bhikkhu*: "It is said, sir (*bho*), that form (*rūpaṃ*) is not-self (*anattā*), feeling (*vedanā*) is not-self, perception (*saññā*) is not-self, mental formations (*saṅkhārā*) are not-self, consciousness (*viññāṇaṃ*) is non-self (*anattā*). What self, then, do *kammas* done without a self affect?"
Then the Exalted One, discerning with his mind this *bhikkhu*'s thought, addressed the *bhikkhus*: "It is possible, *bhikkhus*, that a certain foolish man (*moghapuriso*) here, confused (*avidvā*), immersed in ignorance (*avijjāgato*) and dominated by craving (*taṇhādhipateyyena cetasā*), may imagine in his mind that he can overshoot the dispensation (*satthusāsanaṃ*) of the Master, thus: 'It is said, sir (*bho*), that material form (*rūpaṃ*) is non self (*anattā*)…etc… what will [actions] affect?'"
“What do you think, *bhikkhus*, is material form (*rūpaṃ*) permanent (*niccaṃ*) or impermanent (*aniccaṃ*)?”
Thus, having understood the inclinations (*ajjhāsayaṃ*) of others, the sequence of meaning dictated by inclination should be understood through those *suttas* the Exalted One pronounced.
The “sequence of meaning dictated by the natural structure of the teaching” can be understood through those *suttas* in which the teaching (desanā) progresses from its initial subject to its culmination by way of counterparts (*anurūpadhammavasena*) or by way of the opposites (*paṭipakkhavasena*) of the initial subject.
For example, in the Ākaṅkheyya Sutta the teaching (desanā) is set up at the beginning by way of virtue (*sīlena*) and culminates in the six kinds of direct knowledge (*cha abhiññā āgatā*).
In the Vattha Sutta, the teaching (desanā) is set up by way of the defilements (*kilesena*) and culminates in the sublime abodes (*brahmavihārā āgatā*).
In the Kosambiya Sutta, the teaching (desanā) is set up by way of schism (*bhaṇḍanena*) and culminates in the principles of fraternal harmony (*sāraṇīyadhammā āgatā*).
In the Kakacūpama [Sutta], the teaching (desanā) is set up at the beginning by way of patience (akkhantiyā) and culminates in the Kakacūpama.
And in this Brahmajāla Sutta, the teaching (desanā) is set up at the beginning by way of views (ditthivasena) and culminates in the elucidation of emptiness (*suññatāpakāsanaṃ āgataṃ*).

mula_pali: 105. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi , tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
mula_english: "Therein, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of the eternalist doctrine, propound the self (*ātman*) and the world as eternal based on four grounds; that is merely the feeling of those ascetics and Brahmins who do not know and do not see, and is merely the agitation and vacillation of those immersed in craving (*tṛṣṇā*)."
commentary_pali: 105-117. Idāni mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ – ‘‘tatra bhikkhave’’tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevāti yena diṭṭhiassādena  diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ kevalaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃyeva taṃ  vedayitaṃ, tañca kho panetaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva. Diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva taṇhāsaṅkhātena ca paritassitena vipphanditameva calitameva kampitameva thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇusadisaṃ, na sotāpannassa dassanamiva niccalanti dasseti. Esa nayo ekaccasassatavādādīsupi.
commentary_english:
105-117.
Now, in order to show the distinction of boundaries, the teaching beginning with “*tatra bhikkhave* (there, monks)” is undertaken.

Furthermore, that feeling of those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who do not know or see, who are attached to craving, is agitation and vacillation. Because of the satisfaction of views (*dṛṣṭi-āsvāda*), the pleasure of views (*dṛṣṭi-sukha*), and the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭi-vedayita*), they, being born of joy (*saumanasya-jātā*), proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world to be eternal (*śāśvata*) on four grounds. Furthermore, that feeling of those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who do not know or see the true nature (*sabhāva*) of phenomena (*dhamma*) as it really is (*yathābhūta*), who are attached to craving, indeed, that feeling is only of those attached to craving, and that is only agitation and vacillation.

Designated by view (*dṛṣṭi-saṅkhāta*) and designated by craving (*tṛṣṇā-saṅkhāta*), agitated and vacillating, it is only trembling, only shaking, only quivering, like a stake (*khāṇu*) planted in a heap of chaff (*thusarāśi*); it does not show unshakability like the vision (*darśana*) of a stream-enterer (*sotāpanna*).

The same method (*naya*) applies to the eternalist theories (*ekacca-śāśvata-vāda*) and so on.

mula_pali: 106. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
