mula_english: “There, monks, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are partly eternalists (*ekaccasassatikā*) and partly non-eternalists (*ekaccaasassatikā*) proclaim the self (*attānam*) and the world (*lokam*) to be partly eternal (*sassataṃ*) and partly non-eternal (*asassataṃ*) on four grounds, that too is only the feeling of those ascetics and Brahmins who do not know (*ajānataṃ*) and do not see (*apassataṃ*); that is only the agitation (*paritassita*) and vacillation (*vipphandita*) of those who are immersed in craving (*taṇhāgatānaṃ*).
commentary_pali: 105-117. Idāni mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ – ‘‘tatra bhikkhave’’tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevāti yena diṭṭhiassādena  diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ kevalaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃyeva taṃ  vedayitaṃ, tañca kho panetaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva. Diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva taṇhāsaṅkhātena ca paritassitena vipphanditameva calitameva kampitameva thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇusadisaṃ, na sotāpannassa dassanamiva niccalanti dasseti. Esa nayo ekaccasassatavādādīsupi.
commentary_english:
105-117.
Now, in order to show the distinction of boundaries, the teaching beginning with "There, monks..." is undertaken.

Even that feeling of those ascetics and Brahmins who do not know, do not see, who are attached to craving is only agitation and vacillation; the satisfaction of views ( *dṛṣṭi-āsvāda*), the pleasure of views ( *dṛṣṭi-sukha*), the feeling of views ( *dṛṣṭi-vedayita*), on account of which they, being born of joy, proclaim the self ( *ātman*) and the world ( *loka*) to be eternal ( *śāśvata*) on four grounds; even that is only the feeling of those ascetics and Brahmins who do not know and do not see the true nature ( *svabhāva*) of phenomena ( *dhamma*) as it really is ( *yathābhūta*); it is only the feeling of those who are entirely immersed in craving, and that is only agitation and vacillation.

Designated by view ( *dṛṣṭi-saṃkhāta*) and also designated by craving ( *tṛṣṇā-saṃkhāta*), agitated by craving, it is only agitation and vacillation, it is only trembling, it is only shaking, like a stake planted in a heap of chaff; it does not show the unshakable vision like that of a stream-enterer (*sotāpanna*).

The same method ( *naya*) applies to the eternalist views ( *ekacca-śāśvata-vāda*) and so on.

mula_pali: 107. ‘‘Tatra , bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
mula_english: 107. "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are Finitists and Infinitists, propounding the finitude and infinitude of the world (lokassa) on four grounds, that is merely the feeling of those ascetics and Brahmins who do not know (ajānataṃ) and do not see (apassataṃ), the agitation and vacillation of those who are immersed in craving (taṇhāgatānaṃ)."
commentary_pali: 105-117. Idāni mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ – ‘‘tatra bhikkhave’’tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevāti yena diṭṭhiassādena  diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ kevalaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃyeva taṃ  vedayitaṃ, tañca kho panetaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva. Diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva taṇhāsaṅkhātena ca paritassitena vipphanditameva calitameva kampitameva thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇusadisaṃ, na sotāpannassa dassanamiva niccalanti dasseti. Esa nayo ekaccasassatavādādīsupi.
commentary_english:
105-117. Now, in order to show the demarcation of boundaries, the teaching beginning with "Tatra Bhikkhave (there, monks)" is undertaken.

Even that feeling of those esteemed ascetics and Brahmins who do not know, do not see, and are immersed in craving, that agitation and vacillation by which, through the satisfaction of views (*dṛṣṭi-āsvāda*), the pleasure of views (*dṛṣṭi-sukha*), and the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭi-vedayita*), they, being filled with joy, proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world to be eternal (*śāśvata*) on four grounds; even that is only the feeling of those esteemed ascetics and Brahmins who do not know and do not see the true nature (*sabhāva*) of phenomena (*dhamma*) as it really is (*yathābhūta*); it is only the feeling of those who are entirely immersed in craving. And that is only agitation and vacillation.

Agitation and vacillation, caused by what is reckoned as views (*dṛṣṭi-saṅkhāta*) and what is reckoned as craving (*taṇhā-saṅkhāta*) and is agitated, is just wavering, just shaking, just trembling, like a stake planted in a heap of chaff; it is not unshakable like the vision (*darśana*) of a stream-enterer (*sotāpanna*).

The same method applies to the eternalist theory (*ekaccasassatavāda*) and so on.

mula_pali: 108. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
mula_english:
108.
"And furthermore, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who are endless equivocators, when questioned on this and that point, resort to evasive statements and endless equivocation on four grounds; that is merely the agitated trembling of those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who do not know, do not see, are subject to feeling, and are driven by craving (*tṛṣṇā*)."
commentary_pali: 105-117. Idāni mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ – ‘‘tatra bhikkhave’’tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevāti yena diṭṭhiassādena  diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ kevalaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃyeva taṃ  vedayitaṃ, tañca kho panetaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva. Diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva taṇhāsaṅkhātena ca paritassitena vipphanditameva calitameva kampitameva thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇusadisaṃ, na sotāpannassa dassanamiva niccalanti dasseti. Esa nayo ekaccasassatavādādīsupi.
commentary_english:
105-117. Now, in order to show the demarcation of boundaries, the teaching beginning with "There, monks..." is undertaken.

Furthermore, that which is felt by those ascetics and Brahmins who do not know or see, who are driven by craving, is merely agitation and vacillation. Through the satisfaction of views (*dṛṣṭi-āsvāda*), the pleasure of views (*dṛṣṭi-sukha*), and the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭi-vedayita*), they, being born of joy, proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world to be eternal (*śāśvata*) on four grounds. But that is only the feeling of those ascetics and Brahmins who do not know or see the true nature (*svabhāva*) of phenomena (*dharma*) as it really is (*yathābhūta*); it is only the feeling of those who are entirely driven by craving. And that is merely agitation and vacillation.

Designated by views (*dṛṣṭi-saṃkhāta*) and designated by craving (*tṛṣṇā-saṃkhāta*), agitated and vacillating, it is merely moving, merely shaking, like a stake planted in a heap of chaff. It does not show unwavering like the vision of a stream-enterer (*sotāpanna*).

The same method (*naya*) applies to the eternalist views (*ekacca-śāśvata-vāda*) and so on.

mula_pali: 109. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
mula_english: Monks, when those ascetics and Brahmins, the proponents of fortuitous origination (adhiccasamuppannikā), assert on two grounds that the self (ātmā) and the world (loka) arise by chance (adhiccasamuppannaṃ)—that is merely the feeling of those ascetics and Brahmins who do not know and do not see; that is only the agitation and vacillation of those who are immersed in craving (taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva).
commentary_pali: 105-117. Idāni mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ – ‘‘tatra bhikkhave’’tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevāti yena diṭṭhiassādena  diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ kevalaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃyeva taṃ  vedayitaṃ, tañca kho panetaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva. Diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva taṇhāsaṅkhātena ca paritassitena vipphanditameva calitameva kampitameva thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇusadisaṃ, na sotāpannassa dassanamiva niccalanti dasseti. Esa nayo ekaccasassatavādādīsupi.
commentary_english:
105-117. Now, in order to show the distinction of the boundaries, the teaching beginning with "Tatra Bhikkhave (there, monks)" is undertaken.

“The satisfaction of views ( *dṛṣṭi-āsvāda*), the pleasure of views (*dṛṣṭi-sukha*), the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭi-vedayita*), on account of which those recluses and *brāhmaṇas* joyfully proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world (*loka*) to be eternal (*śāśvata*) on four grounds— that is only the feeling of those who do not know and do not see the true nature (*yathābhūtaṃ sabhāvaṃ*) of *dharmas* as it really is; it is only the feeling of those who are entirely immersed in craving (*taṇhā*)." And “it is only the agitation and vacillation ( *paritassita-vipphandita*)".

Designated by views (*dṛṣṭi-saṅkhāta*) and designated by craving (*taṇhā-saṅkhāta*), it is only agitation and vacillation (*paritassita-vipphandita*), only trembling, only shaking, like a stake (*khāṇu*) planted in a heap of chaff (*thusarāśi*); it is not unshakable like the vision (*darśana*) of a stream-enterer (*sotāpanna*).

The same method applies to all the views of the eternalists and so on (*ekaccasassatavādādīsupi*).

mula_pali: 110. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantaṃ  ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi  vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
mula_english: Monks, those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who speculate about the past (*pūrvānta*), who adhere to fixed views about the past, and who, concerning the past, propound various kinds of dogmatic views based on eighteen grounds; all that is merely the feeling of those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who do not know, do not see, are immersed in craving (*tṛṣṇā*), and are subject to agitation and vacillation.
commentary_pali: 105-117. Idāni mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ – ‘‘tatra bhikkhave’’tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevāti yena diṭṭhiassādena  diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ kevalaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃyeva taṃ  vedayitaṃ, tañca kho panetaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva. Diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva taṇhāsaṅkhātena ca paritassitena vipphanditameva calitameva kampitameva thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇusadisaṃ, na sotāpannassa dassanamiva niccalanti dasseti. Esa nayo ekaccasassatavādādīsupi.
commentary_english:
105-117. Now, in order to show the demarcation of boundaries, the teaching beginning with "There, mendicants ( *bhikkhave* )" is undertaken.

“The satisfaction of views (*dṛṣṭi-āsvāda*), the pleasure of views (*dṛṣṭi-sukha*), the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭi-vedayita*), on account of which those recluses (*śramaṇa*) and Brahmins (*brāhmaṇa*) joyfully proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world (*loka*) to be eternal (*śāśvata*) on four grounds— that is only the feeling of those who do not know and do not see the true nature (*yathābhūtaṃ sabhāvaṃ*) of phenomena (*dhamma*) as it really is; it is only the feeling of those who are entirely immersed in craving (*taṇhā*)." And that is only agitation and vacillation (*paritassita-vipphandita*).

Through agitation and vacillation (*paritassita-vipphandita*) consisting of views (*dṛṣṭi*) and craving (*taṇhā*), it is only wavering, only shaking, only trembling, like a stake (*khāṇu*) planted in a heap of chaff (*thusarāśi*). It does not show immovability like the vision (*darśana*) of a stream-enterer (*srotāpanna*).

The same method applies to those holding to a partial eternalism (*ekaccasassatavāda*) and so on.

mula_pali: 111. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ saññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
mula_english: Monks, when those ascetics and Brahmins, proponents of post-mortem consciousness (uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā), propound a conscious self (saññiṃ attānaṃ) persisting after death on sixteen grounds, that is merely the agitated vacillation of those ascetics and Brahmins who do not know, do not see, are driven by craving (taṇhāgatānaṃ), and are attached to feeling (vedayitaṃ).
commentary_pali: 105-117. Idāni mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ – ‘‘tatra bhikkhave’’tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevāti yena diṭṭhiassādena  diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ kevalaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃyeva taṃ  vedayitaṃ, tañca kho panetaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva. Diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva taṇhāsaṅkhātena ca paritassitena vipphanditameva calitameva kampitameva thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇusadisaṃ, na sotāpannassa dassanamiva niccalanti dasseti. Esa nayo ekaccasassatavādādīsupi.
commentary_english:
105-117. Now, in order to show the demarcation of boundaries, the discourse beginning with "Tatra Bhikkhave (There, monks)" is undertaken.

“The satisfaction of views ( *dṛṣṭi-āsvāda*), the pleasure of views (*dṛṣṭi-sukha*), the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭi-vedayita*), on account of which those recluses and Brahmins, being joyful, proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world to be eternal (*śāśvata*) on four grounds— that is only the feeling of those who do not know and do not see the true nature (*sabhāva*) of the *dharmas* as it really is (*yathābhūta*); it is only the feeling of those who are entirely immersed in craving (*tṛṣṇā*).” And “it is only the agitation and vacillation.”

It is only vacillation, shaking, and wavering, caused by the agitation of views (*dṛṣṭi*) and craving (*tṛṣṇā*), like a stake planted in a heap of chaff, it is not unshakable like the vision (*darśana*) of a stream-enterer (*sotāpanna*).

The same method applies to all the views of eternalism and so on (*ekaccasassatavāda*).

mula_pali: 112. ‘‘Tatra , bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ asaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
mula_english: “And furthermore, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of unconscious survival after death (*uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā*) and who propound an unconscious self after death in eight ways, that is merely the feeling, the worry and vacillation of those immersed in craving, of those ascetics and Brahmins who do not know and see.
commentary_pali: 105-117. Idāni mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ – ‘‘tatra bhikkhave’’tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevāti yena diṭṭhiassādena  diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ kevalaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃyeva taṃ  vedayitaṃ, tañca kho panetaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva. Diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva taṇhāsaṅkhātena ca paritassitena vipphanditameva calitameva kampitameva thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇusadisaṃ, na sotāpannassa dassanamiva niccalanti dasseti. Esa nayo ekaccasassatavādādīsupi.
commentary_english:
105-117. Now, in order to show the demarcation of boundaries, the teaching beginning with “*tatra bhikkhave* (there, monks)” is undertaken.

Furthermore, that feeling of those esteemed ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who do not know, do not see, are immersed in craving, is agitation and vacillation, on account of which, through the satisfaction of views (*dṛṣṭi-assāda*), the pleasure of views (*dṛṣṭi-sukha*), and the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭi-vedayita*), they, being born of joy (*somanassa-jātā*), proclaim the self (*ātmā*) and the world to be eternal (*śāśvata*) on four grounds. Furthermore, that is only the feeling of those esteemed ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who do not know and do not see the true nature (*sabhāva*) of phenomena (*dhamma*) as it really is (*yathābhūta*); it is only the feeling of those who are entirely immersed in craving. And that is only agitation and vacillation.

Caused by agitation associated with views (*dṛṣṭi-saṅkhāta*) and also with craving (*taṇhā-saṅkhāta*), it is only agitation and vacillation, only trembling, only shaking, like a stake (*khāṇu*) planted in a heap of chaff (*thusarāsi*); it does not demonstrate unshakability like the vision (*darśana*) of a stream-enterer (*sotāpanna*).

The same method applies to those holding to partial eternalism (*ekaccasassatavāda*) and so on.

mula_pali: 113. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
mula_english: “And furthermore, monks, when those ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient survival ( *nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā*) proclaim on eight grounds the self to survive neither percipient nor non-percipient (*nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ*) after death (*uddhamāghātanaṃ*), that too is merely the feeling, the worry and vacillation, of those venerable ascetics and Brahmins who do not know and do not see, who are immersed in craving ( *taṇhāgatānaṃ*).
commentary_pali: 105-117. Idāni mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ – ‘‘tatra bhikkhave’’tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevāti yena diṭṭhiassādena  diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ kevalaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃyeva taṃ  vedayitaṃ, tañca kho panetaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva. Diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva taṇhāsaṅkhātena ca paritassitena vipphanditameva calitameva kampitameva thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇusadisaṃ, na sotāpannassa dassanamiva niccalanti dasseti. Esa nayo ekaccasassatavādādīsupi.
commentary_english:
105-117. Now, in order to show the demarcation of boundaries, the teaching beginning with "Tatra Bhikkhave (there, monks)" is undertaken.

And that feeling of those esteemed ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who do not know and do not see, who are immersed in craving, is only agitation and vacillation, because those who are born of joy, with the satisfaction of views (*dṛṣṭi-āsvāda*), the pleasure of views (*dṛṣṭi-sukha*), and the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭi-vedayita*), proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world to be eternal (*śāśvata*) on four grounds. That is only the feeling of those esteemed ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who do not know and do not see the true nature (*svabhāva*) of phenomena (*dharmas*) as it really is; it is only the feeling of those who are entirely immersed in craving, and that is only agitation and vacillation.

Agitation and vacillation, caused by what is known as views (*dṛṣṭi-saṃkhāta*) and by what is known as craving (*tṛṣṇā-saṃkhāta*) is only agitation and vacillation, it is only trembling, it is only shaking, like a stake planted in a heap of chaff; it is not unshakable like the vision of a stream-enterer (*sotāpanna*).

The same method applies to the eternalist view (*ekaccasassatavāda*) and so on.

mula_pali: 114. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
mula_english: "In that case, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and Brahmins who are annihilationists and who propound the annihilation, destruction, and non-existence of an existent being on seven grounds—that is merely the feeling, the agitated throbbing, of those esteemed ascetics and Brahmins who do not know, do not see, and are driven by craving."
commentary_pali: 105-117. Idāni mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ – ‘‘tatra bhikkhave’’tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevāti yena diṭṭhiassādena  diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ kevalaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃyeva taṃ  vedayitaṃ, tañca kho panetaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva. Diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva taṇhāsaṅkhātena ca paritassitena vipphanditameva calitameva kampitameva thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇusadisaṃ, na sotāpannassa dassanamiva niccalanti dasseti. Esa nayo ekaccasassatavādādīsupi.
commentary_english:
105-117. Now, in order to show the demarcation of boundaries, the teaching beginning with “*tatra bhikkhave* (there, monks)” is undertaken.

“The satisfaction of views (*diṭṭhiassāda*), the pleasure of views (*diṭṭhisukha*), the feeling of views (*diṭṭhivedayita*), on account of which those recluses and Brahmins, being joyful, proclaim the self (*attā*) and the world (*loka*) to be eternal (*sassata*) on four grounds— that is only the feeling of those who do not know and do not see the true nature (*yathābhūtaṃ sabhāvaṃ*) of *dharmas* as it really is; it is only the feeling of those who are entirely immersed in craving (*taṇhāgata*).” And “it is only the agitation and vacillation (*paritassitavipphandita*)".

It is only agitation and vacillation (*paritassitavipphandita*), only shaking, only trembling, like a stake (*khāṇu*) planted in a heap of chaff (*thusarāsi*); it is not unshakable like the vision (*dassana*) of a stream-enterer (*sotāpanna*).

The same method (*naya*) applies to the eternalist (*ekaccasassatavāda*) views, and so on.

mula_pali: 115. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
mula_english: 115. “And furthermore, monks, when those ascetics and Brahmins who advocate for nirvāṇa in this very life propound the ultimate nirvāṇa in this very life for an existing being based on five grounds, that is merely the feeling of those esteemed ascetics and Brahmins who do not know, do not see, are driven by craving (taṇhāgatānaṃ), and are agitated and trembling.
commentary_pali: 105-117. Idāni mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ – ‘‘tatra bhikkhave’’tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevāti yena diṭṭhiassādena  diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ kevalaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃyeva taṃ  vedayitaṃ, tañca kho panetaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva. Diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva taṇhāsaṅkhātena ca paritassitena vipphanditameva calitameva kampitameva thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇusadisaṃ, na sotāpannassa dassanamiva niccalanti dasseti. Esa nayo ekaccasassatavādādīsupi.
commentary_english:
105-117. Now, in order to show the demarcation of boundaries, the teaching beginning with "tatra bhikkhave" is undertaken.

“The satisfaction of views ( *dṛṣṭi-āsvāda*), the pleasure of views (*dṛṣṭi-sukha*), the feeling of views, on account of which those venerable ascetics and Brahmins, being joyful, proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world to be eternal (*śāśvata*) on four grounds— that is only the feeling of those who do not know and do not see the true nature (*yathābhūtaṃ sabhāvaṃ*) of phenomena (*dhamma*) as it really is; it is only the feeling of those who are entirely immersed in craving (*tṛṣṇā*)." And “it is only agitation and vacillation ( *paritassita-vipphandita*)".

Designated by views (*dṛṣṭi-saṅkhāta*) and also designated by craving (*tṛṣṇā-saṅkhāta*), it is only agitation and vacillation, only shaking, only trembling, like a stake planted in a heap of chaff, it is not unshakable like the vision (*darśana*) of a stream-enterer (*sotāpanna*).

The same method applies to the eternalist views and so on (*ekaccasassatavādādīsupi*).

mula_pali: 116. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
mula_english: "And furthermore, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who speculate about the future (*aparantakappika*), who hold fixed views about the future (*aparantānudiṭṭhino*), who, concerning the future (*aparantaṃ ārabbha*), assert various conceptual theorems (*anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti*) on forty-four grounds (*catucattārīsāya vatthūhi*), that too is only the feeling of those revered ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who do not know (*ajānataṃ*), do not see (*apassataṃ*), the agitation and vacillation (*paritassitavipphanditameva*) of those immersed in craving (*taṇhāgatānaṃ*).
commentary_pali: 105-117. Idāni mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ – ‘‘tatra bhikkhave’’tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevāti yena diṭṭhiassādena  diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ kevalaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃyeva taṃ  vedayitaṃ, tañca kho panetaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva. Diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva taṇhāsaṅkhātena ca paritassitena vipphanditameva calitameva kampitameva thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇusadisaṃ, na sotāpannassa dassanamiva niccalanti dasseti. Esa nayo ekaccasassatavādādīsupi.
commentary_english:
105-117. Now, in order to show the demarcation of boundaries, the teaching beginning with "Tatra Bhikkhave (there, monks)" is undertaken.

“The satisfaction of views ( *dṛṣṭi-āsvāda*), the pleasure of views (*dṛṣṭi-sukha*), the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭi-vedayita*), on account of which those recluses and *brāhmaṇas*, being delighted, proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world (*loka*) to be eternal (*śāśvata*) on four grounds— that is only the feeling of those who do not know and do not see the true nature (*yathābhūtaṃ sabhāvaṃ*) of *dharmas* as it really is; it is only the feeling of those who are entirely immersed in craving (*taṇhā*).” And that is only agitation and vacillation (*paritassita-vipphandita*).

Indeed, agitation and vacillation (*paritassitena vipphandita*) through what is designated as view (*dṛṣṭi-saṅkhāta*) and what is designated as craving (*taṇhā-saṅkhāta*), is only trembling and shaking, like a stake planted in a heap of chaff; it is not unshakable like the vision of a stream-enterer (*sotāpanna*).

The same method applies to the eternalist theories (*ekaccasassatavāda*) and so on.

mula_pali: 117. ‘‘Tatra , bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca  pubbantāparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
mula_english: “And furthermore, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who are speculators about the past (*pūrvānta*), speculators about the future (*aparānta*), or speculators about both the past and the future (*pūrvāntāparānta*), those holding fixed views about the past and future, assert various conceptual theses regarding the past and future based on sixty-two grounds; even that is merely the feeling of those venerable ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who do not know, do not see, are immersed in craving (*tṛṣṇāgata*), and are agitated and vacillating.
commentary_pali: 105-117. Idāni mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ – ‘‘tatra bhikkhave’’tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevāti yena diṭṭhiassādena  diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ kevalaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃyeva taṃ  vedayitaṃ, tañca kho panetaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva. Diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva taṇhāsaṅkhātena ca paritassitena vipphanditameva calitameva kampitameva thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇusadisaṃ, na sotāpannassa dassanamiva niccalanti dasseti. Esa nayo ekaccasassatavādādīsupi.
commentary_english:
105-117. Now, in order to show the delimitation, the teaching beginning with "Tatra Bhikkhave (There, Monks)" is undertaken.

“The satisfaction of views ( *dṛṣṭi-āsvāda*), the pleasure of views (*dṛṣṭi-sukha*), the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭi-vedayita*), on account of which those recluses and Brahmins, being delighted, proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world (*loka*) to be eternal (*śāśvata*) on four grounds—that is only the feeling of those who do not know and do not see the true nature (*sabhāva*) of the *dharmas* as it really is (*yathābhūta*); it is only the feeling of those who are entirely immersed in craving (*tṛṣṇā*).” And that is only agitation and vacillation.

Caused by view (*dṛṣṭi*) and by craving (*tṛṣṇā*), it is agitation and vacillation, it is only trembling and shaking, like a stake (*khāṇu*) planted in a heap of chaff (*thusarāśi*). It is not unshakable like the vision (*darśana*) of a stream-enterer (*sotāpanna*).

The same method applies to all the views of those who assert some things are eternal (*ekaccasassatavāda*), and so on.

mula_pali: 118. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā  sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
mula_english: Therein, monks, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of eternalism (sassatavādā) declare the self (ātmā) and the world (loka) to be eternal (sassataṃ) in four ways (catūhi vatthūhi), that too is conditioned by contact (phassapaccayā).
commentary_pali: 118-130. Puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādi paramparapaccayadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ . Tattha tadapi phassapaccayāti yena diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ vedayitaṃ phassapaccayāti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
118-130.
Furthermore, beginning with “There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of eternalism ( *sassatavādā*)…," is for the purpose of showing the chain of conditions.

There, "that too is conditioned by contact ( *phassapaccayā*)," by this the Master shows that the satisfaction, the pleasure, or the feeling of views ( *diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena*), on account of which these recluses and Brahmins joyously proclaim the self ( *attānam*) and the world ( *lokañca*) to be eternal ( *sassataṃ*) on four grounds, is a palpitation of craving ( *taṇhā*) and views, a feeling conditioned by contact.

This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 119. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
mula_english: "In that case, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who are partly eternalists (*ekaccasassatikā*) and partly non-eternalists (*ekaccaasassatikā*), who proclaim the self (*attānam*) and the world (*lokam*) to be partly eternal (*sassataṃ*) and partly non-eternal (*asassataṃ*) on four grounds (*catūhi vatthūhi*)—that too is conditioned by contact (*phassapaccayā*)."
commentary_pali: 118-130. Puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādi paramparapaccayadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ . Tattha tadapi phassapaccayāti yena diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ vedayitaṃ phassapaccayāti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Furthermore, beginning with "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of eternalism," is started in order to show the succession of conditions.

There, "that too is conditioned by contact ( *phassa-paccayā* )" shows that the feeling, agitated by craving and views, on account of which these beings, born of joy, propound the self and the world as eternal based on four grounds—that satisfaction of views ( *diṭṭhi-assāda* ), pleasure of views ( *diṭṭhi-sukha* ), or feeling of views ( *diṭṭhi-vedayita* ) is also conditioned by contact.

This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 120. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
mula_english: "There, mendicants, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are Finitists and Infinitists proclaim the finitude and infinitude of the world on four grounds ( *catūhi vatthūhi*), that too is conditioned by contact (*phassapaccayā*).
commentary_pali: 118-130. Puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādi paramparapaccayadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ . Tattha tadapi phassapaccayāti yena diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ vedayitaṃ phassapaccayāti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
118-130.

Furthermore, the passage beginning with "There, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who are proponents of eternalism" was initiated to show the sequence of conditions.

Therein, by "that too is conditioned by contact (phassapaccaya)," the Master shows that the satisfaction, pleasure, or feeling of views ( *diṭṭhi*) on account of which these recluses and *brāhmaṇas*, experiencing joy (*somanassa*), proclaim the self (*atman*) and the world to be eternal (*sassataṃ*) on four grounds (catūhi vatthūhi), is a palpitation (*pariphanditaṃ*) of craving (*taṇhā*) and views (*diṭṭhi*), a feeling (*vedayitaṃ*) conditioned by contact (*phassa*).

This method applies to all the other cases.

mula_pali: 121. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
mula_english: "There, monks, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are Eel-Wrigglers, when asked a question about this or that matter, resort to evasive statements and endless equivocation on four grounds, that is also due to sense-contact."
commentary_pali: 118-130. Puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādi paramparapaccayadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ . Tattha tadapi phassapaccayāti yena diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ vedayitaṃ phassapaccayāti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Furthermore, the passage beginning with "There, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists..." was commenced in order to show the succession of conditions.

Therein, by "and that too is conditioned by contact ( *phassapaccaya*)," the Master shows that the feeling ( *vedayitaṃ* ) which is agitated by craving ( *taṇhā* ) and views ( *diṭṭhi* ), namely the satisfaction ( *assāda* ), pleasure ( *sukha* ), or feeling ( *vedayita* ) of views ( *diṭṭhi* ), on account of which those who are born of joy proclaim the self ( *attā* ) and the world ( *loka* ) to be eternal ( *sassataṃ* ) on four grounds, is also conditioned by contact ( *phassapaccaya* ).

This method applies everywhere. ( *esa nayo sabbattha*).

mula_pali: 122. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
mula_english: "There, monks, when those ascetics and Brahmins, who are Chance-Originationists, propound the chance origin of the self (ātman) and the world on two grounds, that too is conditioned by contact (sparśa-pratyayā)."
commentary_pali: 118-130. Puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādi paramparapaccayadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ . Tattha tadapi phassapaccayāti yena diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ vedayitaṃ phassapaccayāti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Furthermore, regarding "there, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of eternalism," etc., this was begun to show the successive conditions.

There, by "that too is conditioned by contact ( *phassapaccaya*)," he shows that the feeling ( *vedayitaṃ*), agitated by craving and views, on account of which these recluses and Brahmins, born of joy, proclaim the self (*āttānaṃ*) and the world to be eternal (*sassataṃ*) on four grounds, is also conditioned by contact (*phassapaccaya*).

This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 123. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti  aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
mula_english: “There, monks, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the past (*pūrvānta*), who hold fixed views about the past, assert various conceptual theorems (*adhimutti-padāni*) referring to the past based on eighteen grounds (*aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi*), that too is conditioned by contact (*phassapaccayā*).
commentary_pali: 118-130. Puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādi paramparapaccayadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ . Tattha tadapi phassapaccayāti yena diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ vedayitaṃ phassapaccayāti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Furthermore, "There, mendicants, those ascetics and brahmins who are proponents of eternalism," etc., was begun in order to show the continuous conditioning.

There, "that too is conditioned by contact": by this, he shows that the feeling agitated by craving and views—on account of the satisfaction of views ( *dṛṣṭi-āsvāda*), the pleasure of views (*dṛṣṭi-sukha*), the sensation of views (*dṛṣṭi-vedayita*)—these beings, born of joy, declare the self (*ātman*) and the world to be eternal based on four grounds; that too is a feeling conditioned by contact (*sparśa-pratyaya*).

This method applies in all instances. ( *esa nayo sabbattha*)

mula_pali: 124. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ saññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
mula_english: "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of percipient immortality and proclaim the self to survive percipient after death on sixteen grounds, that too is conditioned by contact."
commentary_pali: 118-130. Puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādi paramparapaccayadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ . Tattha tadapi phassapaccayāti yena diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ vedayitaṃ phassapaccayāti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
118-130.
Furthermore, the passage beginning with "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of eternalism..." was initiated to show the sequence of conditions.

There, by this the Master shows that the satisfaction, pleasure, or feeling of views on account of which these recluses and *brāhmaṇas* joyously proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world to be eternal on four grounds, is a palpitation of craving (*tṛṣṇā*) and views, a feeling conditioned by contact (*sparśa-pratyaya*).

This method applies to all the other cases.

mula_pali: 125. ‘‘Tatra , bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ asaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
mula_english: ‘When those ascetics and Brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of Unconscious Post-Mortem Survival declare the self to survive unconscious after death in eight ways, that too is conditioned by contact.
commentary_pali: 118-130. Puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādi paramparapaccayadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ . Tattha tadapi phassapaccayāti yena diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ vedayitaṃ phassapaccayāti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
118-130.
Furthermore, the passage beginning with "There, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of eternalism..." was begun to show a succession of conditions.

There, "also conditioned by contact (*phassa-paccayā*)," indicates that the satisfaction, pleasure, or feeling of views (*dṛṣṭi*) on account of which those who are born of joy (*saumanassajātā*) proclaim the self (*ātmā*) and the world (*loka*) to be eternal (*śāśvata*) on four grounds (*catūhi vatthūhi*), is a feeling conditioned by contact, agitated by craving (*tṛṣṇā*) and views (*dṛṣṭi*).

This method applies everywhere (*esa nayo sabbattha*).

mula_pali: 126. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
mula_english: "In that case, bhikkhus, when those ascetics and Brahmins who hold a theory of survival after death as neither conscious nor unconscious (nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā) propound that the self survives after death as neither conscious nor unconscious (nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ) on eight grounds, that too is conditioned by contact (phassapaccayā)."
commentary_pali: 118-130. Puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādi paramparapaccayadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ . Tattha tadapi phassapaccayāti yena diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ vedayitaṃ phassapaccayāti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
118-130.
Furthermore, the passage beginning with "There, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of eternalism" was begun in order to show a succession of conditions.

There, by "that too is conditioned by contact ( *phassa-paccayā*)," he (the Buddha) indicates that the feeling ( *vedayitaṃ* ) agitated by craving ( *taṇhā* ) and views ( *diṭṭhi* ), by which, through the satisfaction of views, the pleasure of views, and the sensation of views, those beings born of joy propound the self ( *attā* ) and the world to be eternal on four grounds, is also conditioned by contact.

This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 127. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
mula_english: There, mendicants, those ascetics and Brahmins who are annihilationists, propound the annihilation (uccheda), destruction (vināsa), and extermination (vibhava) of an existing being (sato sattassa) on seven grounds; that too, is conditioned by contact (phassapaccayā).
commentary_pali: 118-130. Puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādi paramparapaccayadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ . Tattha tadapi phassapaccayāti yena diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ vedayitaṃ phassapaccayāti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
118-130. Furthermore, "There, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who are proponents of eternalism," etc., was begun in order to show the succession of conditions.

There, by this the Master shows that the satisfaction, pleasure, or feeling of views on account of which those recluses and *brāhmaṇas* joyously proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world to be eternal, is a palpitation of craving (*tṛṣṇā*) and views, a feeling conditioned by contact (*sparśa-pratyayā*).

This method applies to all the other cases.

mula_pali: 128. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
mula_english: "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of *dṛṣṭadharmanirvāṇa* (Nibbana Here and Now), propound the supreme *dṛṣṭadharmanirvāṇa* (Nibbana Here and Now) for an existing being on five grounds, even that is due to contact (*sparśapratyaya*)."
commentary_pali: 118-130. Puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādi paramparapaccayadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ . Tattha tadapi phassapaccayāti yena diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ vedayitaṃ phassapaccayāti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Furthermore, the section beginning with "Here, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of eternalism..." was started to show the succession of conditions.

There, by saying "there, that too is conditioned by contact ( *phassa-paccayā*)," the Blessed One shows that the feeling ( *vedayitaṃ*) that is agitated by craving (*taṇhā*) and views (*diṭṭhi*), on account of the satisfaction (*assāda*), pleasure (*sukha*), or sensation (*vedayita*) of views, due to which those who are born of joy proclaim the self (*attā*) and the world (*loka*) to be eternal (*sassataṃ*) based on four grounds.

This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 129. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā  aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
mula_english: “There, mendicants, those ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the future, who hold settled views about the future, assert on forty-four grounds various conceptual theorems referring to the future—that too is conditioned by contact.
commentary_pali: 118-130. Puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādi paramparapaccayadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ . Tattha tadapi phassapaccayāti yena diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ vedayitaṃ phassapaccayāti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
118-130.
Furthermore, the passage that begins with “There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of eternalism..." was started to show a series of conditions.

There, by this the Master shows that the satisfaction, pleasure, or feeling of views on account of which these recluses and *brāhmaṇas*, joyously proclaim the self (*ātman*) and the world to be eternal on four grounds, is a palpitation of craving (*tṛṣṇā*) and views (*dṛṣṭi*), a feeling conditioned by contact (*sparśa-pratyaya*).

This method applies to all the other cases.

mula_pali: 130. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā  ca pubbantāparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
mula_english: "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the past (*pūrvānta-kalpikā*), speculators about the future (*aparantakalpikā*), or speculators about the past and future (*pūrvāntāparāntakalpikā*), who hold settled views about the past and future (*pūrvāntāparāntānudiṭṭhinaḥ*), assert various conceptual theorems (*adhimukti-padāni*) referring to the past and future, on sixty-two grounds (*dvāṣaṣṭiyā vastūhi*)—that too is conditioned by contact (*sparśa-pratyayā*)."
commentary_pali: 118-130. Puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādi paramparapaccayadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ . Tattha tadapi phassapaccayāti yena diṭṭhiassādena diṭṭhisukhena diṭṭhivedayitena te somanassajātā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ vedayitaṃ phassapaccayāti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Furthermore, the passage beginning with "Here, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who are proponents of eternalism" was initiated to show the sequence of conditions.

There, it is shown that even that is conditioned by contact (*phassa-paccayā*): "Even that – by means of the satisfaction of views (*diṭṭhi-assādena*), the pleasure of views (*diṭṭhi-sukhena*), the feeling of views (*diṭṭhi-vedayitena*) – those who are born of joy proclaim the self (*attānaṃ*) and the world (*lokaṃ*) to be eternal (*sassataṃ*) on four grounds, even that feeling (*vedayitaṃ*) is agitated by craving (*taṇhā*) and views (*diṭṭhi*), [and is] conditioned by contact (*phassa-paccayā*)."

This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 131. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: Monks, it is impossible for those ascetics and Brahmins who adhere to the eternalist theory (sassatavādā), and who proclaim the self (ātmā) and the world (loka) to be eternal based on four grounds (catūhi vatthūhi), to experience feeling (paṭisaṃvedissanti) without contact (phassā).
commentary_pali: 131-143. Idāni tassa paccayassa diṭṭhivedayite balavabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha te vata aññatra phassāti te vata samaṇabrāhmaṇā taṃ vedayitaṃ vinā phassena paṭisaṃvedissantīti kāraṇametaṃ natthīti. Yathā hi patato gehassa upatthambhanatthāya thūṇā nāma balavapaccayo hoti, na taṃ thūṇāya anupatthambhitaṃ ṭhātuṃ sakkoti, evameva phassopi vedanāya balavapaccayo, taṃ vinā idaṃ diṭṭhivedayitaṃ natthīti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Now, in order to show the strength of the condition for the feeling of views, he says again, "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists," and so forth.

There, indeed, those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* might (claim that) apart from contact (*sparśa*), they will experience that feeling without contact. This reason is not (possible).

Just as a pillar is a strong condition for supporting a falling house, and it cannot stand unsupported by that pillar, so too, contact (*sparśa*) is a strong condition for feeling (*vedanā*), and without it, this feeling of views does not exist; (this) he shows.

This method applies in every case.

mula_pali: 132. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekacca asassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: “And there, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are partial-eternalists and partial-non-eternalists, who proclaim the self (ātman) and the world to be partly eternal (śāśvata) and partly non-eternal (aśāśvata) in four ways, it is not possible that they could experience that feeling without contact (sparśa).
commentary_pali: 131-143. Idāni tassa paccayassa diṭṭhivedayite balavabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha te vata aññatra phassāti te vata samaṇabrāhmaṇā taṃ vedayitaṃ vinā phassena paṭisaṃvedissantīti kāraṇametaṃ natthīti. Yathā hi patato gehassa upatthambhanatthāya thūṇā nāma balavapaccayo hoti, na taṃ thūṇāya anupatthambhitaṃ ṭhātuṃ sakkoti, evameva phassopi vedanāya balavapaccayo, taṃ vinā idaṃ diṭṭhivedayitaṃ natthīti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Now, in order to show the strength of the condition for the feeling of views ( *dṛṣṭivedayite* ) , he says again, "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists ( *sassatavādā* ) , etc."

There, indeed, it is impossible that those ascetics and Brahmins would experience that feeling apart from contact ( *sparśa* ).

Just as a pillar is a strong condition for supporting a falling house, and it cannot stand without being supported by the pillar, so too, contact ( *sparśa* ) is a strong condition for feeling ( *vedanā* ); he shows that without that, this feeling of views ( *dṛṣṭivedayita* ) does not exist.

This method applies to all cases.

mula_pali: 133. ‘‘Tatra , bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: 133. "Therefore, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who advocate that the world is both finite and infinite (*antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti*) based on four grounds, it is impossible (*netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati*) that they could experience that feeling without contact (*aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissanti*).
commentary_pali: 131-143. Idāni tassa paccayassa diṭṭhivedayite balavabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha te vata aññatra phassāti te vata samaṇabrāhmaṇā taṃ vedayitaṃ vinā phassena paṭisaṃvedissantīti kāraṇametaṃ natthīti. Yathā hi patato gehassa upatthambhanatthāya thūṇā nāma balavapaccayo hoti, na taṃ thūṇāya anupatthambhitaṃ ṭhātuṃ sakkoti, evameva phassopi vedanāya balavapaccayo, taṃ vinā idaṃ diṭṭhivedayitaṃ natthīti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Now, in order to show the strength of the condition for the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭivedayita*), he says again, "There, *bhikṣus*, those *śramaṇa*s and *brāhmaṇa*s who are eternalists (*śāśvatavāda*)."

There, indeed, they say that apart from contact (*sparśa*), those *śramaṇa*s and *brāhmaṇa*s will experience that feeling without contact. This reason is not possible.

Just as a pillar is a strong condition for supporting a falling house, and it cannot stand without being supported by the pillar, in the same way, contact (*sparśa*) is a strong condition for feeling (*vedanā*), and without it, this feeling of views does not exist. This he shows.

This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 134. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ catūhi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: Monks, those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who are eternalists and equivocators, when questioned on various matters, resort to evasive speech and eternalist equivocation based on four grounds. It is impossible that they can experience feeling independently of contact (*sparśa*).
commentary_pali: 131-143. Idāni tassa paccayassa diṭṭhivedayite balavabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha te vata aññatra phassāti te vata samaṇabrāhmaṇā taṃ vedayitaṃ vinā phassena paṭisaṃvedissantīti kāraṇametaṃ natthīti. Yathā hi patato gehassa upatthambhanatthāya thūṇā nāma balavapaccayo hoti, na taṃ thūṇāya anupatthambhitaṃ ṭhātuṃ sakkoti, evameva phassopi vedanāya balavapaccayo, taṃ vinā idaṃ diṭṭhivedayitaṃ natthīti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Now, in order to show the strength of the condition for the feeling of views ( *dṛṣṭivedayita* ) regarding that condition, he says again, "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists," and so forth.

There, indeed, apart from contact (*sparśa*), those ascetics and Brahmins will experience that feeling without contact—such a reason does not exist.

Just as a pillar is a strong condition for supporting a falling house, and it cannot stand without being supported by the pillar, in the same way, contact (*sparśa*) is a strong condition for feeling (*vedanā*), and he shows that without it, this feeling of views (*dṛṣṭivedayita*) does not exist.

This method applies to all instances.

mula_pali: 135. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: Monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of spontaneous origination, who propound a self (ātman) and the world as spontaneously originated based on two grounds, that they will experience that feeling apart from contact (sparśa)—this is not possible.
commentary_pali: 131-143. Idāni tassa paccayassa diṭṭhivedayite balavabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha te vata aññatra phassāti te vata samaṇabrāhmaṇā taṃ vedayitaṃ vinā phassena paṭisaṃvedissantīti kāraṇametaṃ natthīti. Yathā hi patato gehassa upatthambhanatthāya thūṇā nāma balavapaccayo hoti, na taṃ thūṇāya anupatthambhitaṃ ṭhātuṃ sakkoti, evameva phassopi vedanāya balavapaccayo, taṃ vinā idaṃ diṭṭhivedayitaṃ natthīti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Now, in order to show the strength of the condition for the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭivedayita*), he says again, "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists (*śāśvatavāda*)" etc.

There, indeed, it is impossible that those ascetics and Brahmins would experience that feeling without contact (*sparśa*), believing it is apart from contact.

Just as a prop is a strong condition for supporting a collapsing house, and the house cannot stand without being supported by the prop, in the same way, contact (*sparśa*) is a strong condition for feeling (*vedanā*), and he shows that without it, there is no "feeling of views (*dṛṣṭivedayita*)".

This method applies to all cases.

mula_pali: 136. ‘‘Tatra , bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who speculate about the past, adhere to views about the past, and, concerning the past, express various tenets based on conviction in eighteen ways – that they could experience feeling apart from contact is not possible."
commentary_pali: 131-143. Idāni tassa paccayassa diṭṭhivedayite balavabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha te vata aññatra phassāti te vata samaṇabrāhmaṇā taṃ vedayitaṃ vinā phassena paṭisaṃvedissantīti kāraṇametaṃ natthīti. Yathā hi patato gehassa upatthambhanatthāya thūṇā nāma balavapaccayo hoti, na taṃ thūṇāya anupatthambhitaṃ ṭhātuṃ sakkoti, evameva phassopi vedanāya balavapaccayo, taṃ vinā idaṃ diṭṭhivedayitaṃ natthīti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Now, in order to show the strength of the condition for the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭivedayita*) concerning that condition, he says again, "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists..."
There, indeed, it is impossible that those ascetics and Brahmins would experience that feeling apart from contact, saying, "apart from contact."
Just as a pillar is a strong condition for supporting a falling house, and it cannot stand un-supported by the pillar, so too, contact (*sparśa*) is a strong condition for feeling (*vedanā*), and he shows that without it, this feeling of views does not exist.
This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 137. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā  saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ saññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: Monks, it is impossible that those ascetics and Brahmins who are annihilationists, proponents of perception, who describe the self as perceptual annihilation in sixteen ways, could experience that feeling without contact (sparśa).
commentary_pali: 131-143. Idāni tassa paccayassa diṭṭhivedayite balavabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha te vata aññatra phassāti te vata samaṇabrāhmaṇā taṃ vedayitaṃ vinā phassena paṭisaṃvedissantīti kāraṇametaṃ natthīti. Yathā hi patato gehassa upatthambhanatthāya thūṇā nāma balavapaccayo hoti, na taṃ thūṇāya anupatthambhitaṃ ṭhātuṃ sakkoti, evameva phassopi vedanāya balavapaccayo, taṃ vinā idaṃ diṭṭhivedayitaṃ natthīti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Now, in order to show the strength of the condition for the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭivedayita*) , he again says, "There, *bhikṣus*, those *śramaṇas* and *brāhmaṇas* who are eternalists (*śaśvatavādā*)..." and so forth.

There, indeed, if they were apart from contact (*sparśa*), those *śramaṇas* and *brāhmaṇas* would experience that feeling (*vedayita*) without contact (*sparśa*)—such a reason does not exist.

Just as a pillar is a strong condition for supporting a falling house, and it cannot stand without being supported by that pillar, in the same way, contact (*sparśa*) is a strong condition for feeling (*vedanā*), and without it, this feeling of views (*dṛṣṭivedayita*) does not exist. This he shows.

This method applies to all the other cases.

mula_pali: 138. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā, uddhamāghātanaṃ asaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: Monks, those ascetics and brahmins who are annihilationists, proponents of the doctrine of non-sentient existence after death, who proclaim the self to be non-sentient after annihilation based on eight grounds, it is impossible that they could experience feeling without contact.
commentary_pali: 131-143. Idāni tassa paccayassa diṭṭhivedayite balavabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha te vata aññatra phassāti te vata samaṇabrāhmaṇā taṃ vedayitaṃ vinā phassena paṭisaṃvedissantīti kāraṇametaṃ natthīti. Yathā hi patato gehassa upatthambhanatthāya thūṇā nāma balavapaccayo hoti, na taṃ thūṇāya anupatthambhitaṃ ṭhātuṃ sakkoti, evameva phassopi vedanāya balavapaccayo, taṃ vinā idaṃ diṭṭhivedayitaṃ natthīti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Now, in order to show the strength of the condition for the feeling of views (*dṛṣṭivedayita*) regarding that condition, he says again, "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists..."

There, indeed, [they say] apart from contact (*sparśa*). Those ascetics and Brahmins will experience that feeling without contact (*sparśa*)—such a reason is not possible.

Just as a prop is a strong condition for supporting a falling house, which cannot stand without being supported by the prop, in the same way, contact (*sparśa*) is a strong condition for feeling (*vedanā*), and without it, this "feeling of views" does not exist. This is what it shows.

This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 139. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: Monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of the annihilation [of consciousness] after death, who proclaim the self to be the state of neither-perception-nor-non-perception after the annihilation [of consciousness], [and do so] with eight grounds, it is not possible that they could experience that feeling without contact.
commentary_pali: 131-143. Idāni tassa paccayassa diṭṭhivedayite balavabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha te vata aññatra phassāti te vata samaṇabrāhmaṇā taṃ vedayitaṃ vinā phassena paṭisaṃvedissantīti kāraṇametaṃ natthīti. Yathā hi patato gehassa upatthambhanatthāya thūṇā nāma balavapaccayo hoti, na taṃ thūṇāya anupatthambhitaṃ ṭhātuṃ sakkoti, evameva phassopi vedanāya balavapaccayo, taṃ vinā idaṃ diṭṭhivedayitaṃ natthīti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Now, in order to show the strength of the condition for the feeling of views, he says again, "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists," and so on.

There, indeed, apart from contact, those ascetics and Brahmins will experience that feeling without contact—such a reason does not exist.

Just as a pillar is a strong condition for supporting a falling house, and it cannot stand without being supported by that pillar, so too, contact is a strong condition for feeling, and without that, this "feeling of views" does not exist, he shows.

This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 140. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are annihilationists, who proclaim the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of an existing being on seven grounds—it is impossible that they could experience [anything] apart from contact (sparśa)."
commentary_pali: 131-143. Idāni tassa paccayassa diṭṭhivedayite balavabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha te vata aññatra phassāti te vata samaṇabrāhmaṇā taṃ vedayitaṃ vinā phassena paṭisaṃvedissantīti kāraṇametaṃ natthīti. Yathā hi patato gehassa upatthambhanatthāya thūṇā nāma balavapaccayo hoti, na taṃ thūṇāya anupatthambhitaṃ ṭhātuṃ sakkoti, evameva phassopi vedanāya balavapaccayo, taṃ vinā idaṃ diṭṭhivedayitaṃ natthīti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Now, in order to show the strength of the condition for the feeling of views ( *dṛṣṭivedayita* ) regarding that condition, he says again: "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists (*śāśvatavāda*)."

There, indeed, is it possible that those ascetics and Brahmins could experience that feeling (*vedayita*) without contact (*sparśa*)? Such a reason does not exist.

Just as a pillar is a strong condition (*balavatpratyaya*) for supporting a collapsing house, and it cannot stand without being supported by the pillar, in the same way, contact (*sparśa*) is a strong condition (*balavatpratyaya*) for feeling (*vedanā*), and without it, this feeling of views (*dṛṣṭivedayita*) does not exist.

This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 141. ‘‘Tatra , bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: There, *bhikkhus*, those ascetics and Brahmins who advocate present-life nirvāṇa, propounding the highest present-life nirvāṇa of an existing being on five grounds—that they would experience that feeling apart from contact (*sparśa*) is not possible.
commentary_pali: 131-143. Idāni tassa paccayassa diṭṭhivedayite balavabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha te vata aññatra phassāti te vata samaṇabrāhmaṇā taṃ vedayitaṃ vinā phassena paṭisaṃvedissantīti kāraṇametaṃ natthīti. Yathā hi patato gehassa upatthambhanatthāya thūṇā nāma balavapaccayo hoti, na taṃ thūṇāya anupatthambhitaṃ ṭhātuṃ sakkoti, evameva phassopi vedanāya balavapaccayo, taṃ vinā idaṃ diṭṭhivedayitaṃ natthīti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Now, in order to show the strength of the condition for the feeling of views, he says again: "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists," and so forth.

There, indeed, apart from contact, those ascetics and Brahmins will experience that feeling without contact—such a reason does not exist.

Just as a pillar is a strong condition for supporting a falling house, and it cannot stand without being supported by that pillar, so too contact is a strong condition for feeling, and without it, this feeling of views does not exist, he shows.

This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 142. ‘‘Tatra , bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: 142. "And there, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who speculate about the future, who hold settled views about the future, assert on forty-four grounds various conceptual theorems referring to the future—it is not possible that they could experience feeling apart from contact.
commentary_pali: 131-143. Idāni tassa paccayassa diṭṭhivedayite balavabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha te vata aññatra phassāti te vata samaṇabrāhmaṇā taṃ vedayitaṃ vinā phassena paṭisaṃvedissantīti kāraṇametaṃ natthīti. Yathā hi patato gehassa upatthambhanatthāya thūṇā nāma balavapaccayo hoti, na taṃ thūṇāya anupatthambhitaṃ ṭhātuṃ sakkoti, evameva phassopi vedanāya balavapaccayo, taṃ vinā idaṃ diṭṭhivedayitaṃ natthīti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Now, in order to show the strength of the condition for the feeling of views, he says again: "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists," and so on.

There, indeed, if it were apart from contact (*sparśa*), would those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* experience that feeling without contact? Such a case is impossible.

Just as a pillar is a strong condition for supporting a collapsing house, and it cannot stand unsupported by the pillar, so too, contact (*sparśa*) is a strong condition for feeling (*vedanā*), and without it, this feeling of views does not exist, he shows.

This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 143. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: “And when those ascetics and Brahmins, who speculate about the past (pūrvānta), speculate about the future (aparantaka), speculate about the past and the future (pūrvāntāparantakappika), holding firmly to views about the past and the future (pūrvāntāparantānudiṭṭhino), assert various conceptual constructs (adhimuttipadāni) based on the past and the future, with sixty-two grounds (dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi)—it is impossible that they could experience (paṭisaṃvedissanti) feeling apart from contact (sparśa)."
commentary_pali: 131-143. Idāni tassa paccayassa diṭṭhivedayite balavabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha te vata aññatra phassāti te vata samaṇabrāhmaṇā taṃ vedayitaṃ vinā phassena paṭisaṃvedissantīti kāraṇametaṃ natthīti. Yathā hi patato gehassa upatthambhanatthāya thūṇā nāma balavapaccayo hoti, na taṃ thūṇāya anupatthambhitaṃ ṭhātuṃ sakkoti, evameva phassopi vedanāya balavapaccayo, taṃ vinā idaṃ diṭṭhivedayitaṃ natthīti dasseti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
commentary_english:
Now, in order to show the strength of the condition for the feeling of views ( *dṛṣṭivedayita* ) regarding that condition, he says again: "There, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists ( *śāśvatavādā* )" and so forth.

There, indeed, [they claim that] apart from contact ( *sparśa* ), those ascetics and Brahmins will experience that feeling without contact ( *sparśa* ). This reason is not possible.

Just as a pillar ( *sthūṇā* ) is a strong condition for supporting a falling house, which cannot stand without being supported by that pillar, in the same way, contact (*sparśa*) is a strong condition for feeling ( *vedanā* ), and without it, there is no "feeling of views ( *dṛṣṭivedayita* )". This is what it shows.

This method applies everywhere.

mula_pali: 144. ‘‘Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā…pe… yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā… yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā… yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā  adhiccasamuppannikā… yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā… yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā… yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā… yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā… yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā… yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā… yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā… yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā  ca pubbantāparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, sabbe te chahi phassāyatanehi phussa phussa paṭisaṃvedenti tesaṃ vedanāpaccayā taṇhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṃ, upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti.
mula_english: 144. “Therein, monks, those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of eternalism (sassatavādā), who propound the self (attānam) and the world (lokam) to be eternal (sassataṃ) on four grounds; and those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists regarding some things and non-eternalists regarding other things; and those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of the finitude and infinitude of the world; and those ascetics and Brahmins who are endless equivocators; and those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of fortuitous origination; and those ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the past; and those ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of percipient survival after death; and those ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of non-percipient survival after death; and those ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient survival after death; and those ascetics and Brahmins who are annihilationists (ucchedavādā); and those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of *nirvāṇa* in this very life (diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā); and those ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the future; and those ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the past and also about the future; and those who hold views about the past and future, relying on the past and future, assert various kinds of dogmatic views based on sixty-two grounds—all of them repeatedly experience these feelings through contact by means of the six sense bases (phassāyatanehi). Conditioned by feeling (vedanā), there is craving (taṇhā); conditioned by craving, there is clinging (upādānaṃ); conditioned by clinging, there is becoming (bhavo); conditioned by becoming, there is birth (jāti); conditioned by birth, there are aging and death (jarāmaraṇaṃ), sorrow (soka), lamentation (parideva), pain (dukkha), grief (domanassa), and despair (upāyāsā). Thus does this whole mass of suffering originate (sambhavanti).
commentary_pali: 144. Idāni tatra bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikātiādinā nayena sabbadiṭṭhivedayitāni sampiṇḍeti. Kasmā? Upari phasse pakkhipanatthāya. Kathaṃ? Sabbe te chahi phassāyatanehi phussa phussa paṭisaṃvedentīti. Tattha cha phassāyatanāni nāma – cakkhuphassāyatanaṃ, sotaphassāyatanaṃ, ghānaphassāyatanaṃ, jivhāphassāyatanaṃ, kāyaphassāyatanaṃ, manophassāyatananti imāni cha. Sañjāti-samosaraṇa-kāraṇa-paṇṇattimattatthesu hi ayaṃ  āyatanasaddo pavattati. Tattha – ‘‘kambojo assānaṃ āyatanaṃ, gunnaṃ dakkhiṇāpatho’’ti  sañjātiyaṃ pavattati, sañjātiṭṭhāneti attho. ‘‘Manorame āyatane, sevanti naṃ vihaṅgamā’’ti (a. ni. 5.38) samosaraṇe. ‘‘Sati satiāyatane’’ti (a. ni. 3.102) kāraṇe. ‘‘Araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭīsu sammantī’’ti (saṃ. ni. 1.255) paṇṇattimatte. Svāyamidha sañjātiādiatthattayepi yujjati. Cakkhādīsu hi phassapañcamakā dhammā sañjāyanti samosaranti, tāni ca tesaṃ kāraṇanti āyatanāni. Idha pana ‘‘cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso’’ti (saṃ. ni. 2.43) iminā nayena phassasīseneva desanaṃ āropetvā phassaṃ ādiṃ katvā paccayaparamparaṃ dassetuṃ phassāyatanādīni vuttāni. Phussa phussa paṭisaṃvedentīti phusitvā phusitvā paṭisaṃvedenti. Ettha ca kiñcāpi āyatanānaṃ  phusanakiccaṃ viya vuttaṃ, tathāpi na tesaṃ phusanakiccatā veditabbā. Na hi āyatanāni phusanti, phassova taṃ taṃ ārammaṇaṃ phusati, āyatanāni pana phasse upanikkhipitvā dassitāni; tasmā sabbe te cha phassāyatanasambhavena phassena rūpādīni ārammaṇāni phusitvā taṃ diṭṭhivedanaṃ paṭisaṃvedayantīti evamettha attho veditabbo. Tesaṃ vedanāpaccayā taṇhātiādīsu vedanāti cha phassāyatanasambhavā vedanā. Sā rūpataṇhādibhedāya taṇhāya upanissayakoṭiyā paccayo hoti. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘tesaṃ vedanāpaccayā taṇhā’’ti. Sā pana catubbidhassa upādānassa upanissayakoṭiyā ceva sahajātakoṭiyā ca paccayo hoti. Tathā upādānaṃ bhavassa. Bhavo jātiyā upanissayakoṭiyā paccayo hoti. Jātīti panettha savikārā pañcakkhandhā daṭṭhabbā, jāti jarāmaraṇassa ceva sokādīnañca upanissayakoṭiyā paccayo hoti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthārato pana paṭiccasamuppādakathā visuddhimagge vuttā. Idha panassa payojanamattameva veditabbaṃ. Bhagavā  hi vaṭṭakathaṃ kathento – ‘‘purimā, bhikkhave, koṭi na paññāyati avijjāya, ‘ito pubbe avijjā nāhosi, atha pacchā samabhavī’ti evañcetaṃ, bhikkhave, vuccati, atha ca pana paññāyati ‘‘idappaccayā avijjā’’ti (a. ni. 10.61) evaṃ avijjāsīsena vā, purimā, bhikkhave, koṭi  na paññāyati bhavataṇhāya…pe… ‘‘idappaccayā bhavataṇhā’’ti (a. ni. 10.62) evaṃ taṇhāsīsena vā, purimā, bhikkhave, koṭi na paññāyati bhavadiṭṭhiyā…pe… ‘‘idappaccayā bhavadiṭṭhī’’ti evaṃ diṭṭhisīsena vā kathesi’’. Idha pana diṭṭhisīsena kathento vedanārāgena uppajjamānā diṭṭhiyo kathetvā vedanāmūlakaṃ paṭiccasamuppādaṃ kathesi. Tena idaṃ dasseti – ‘‘evamete diṭṭhigatikā, idaṃ dassanaṃ gahetvā tīsu bhavesu catūsu yonīsu pañcasu gatīsu sattasu viññāṇaṭṭhitīsu navasu sattāvāsesu ito ettha etto idhāti sandhāvantā saṃsarantā yante yuttagoṇo viya, thambhe upanibaddhakukkuro viya, vātena vippannaṭṭhanāvā viya ca vaṭṭadukkhameva anuparivattanti, vaṭṭadukkhato sīsaṃ ukkhipituṃ na sakkontī’’ti.
commentary_english:
144.
