mula_pali: 374. ‘‘Atthi pana, bhante, maggo atthi paṭipadā etesaṃ dhammānaṃ sacchikiriyāyā’’ti? ‘‘Atthi kho, mahāli, maggo atthi paṭipadā etesaṃ dhammānaṃ sacchikiriyāyā’’ti.
mula_english: “But, venerable sir, is there a path, is there a practice for the realization of these things?” “There is indeed a path, Mahāli, there is a practice for the realization of these things.”
commentary_pali: 374-375. Tato bhagavantaṃ pucchanto ‘‘atthi pana bhante’’tiādimāha. Aṭṭhaṅgikoti pañcaṅgikaṃ turiyaṃ viya aṭṭhaṅgiko gāmo viya ca aṭṭhaṅgamattoyeva hutvā aṭṭhaṅgiko, na aṅgato añño maggo nāma atthi. Tenevāha – ‘‘seyyathidaṃ, sammādiṭṭhi…pe… sammāsamādhī’’ti. Tattha  sammādassanalakkhaṇā sammādiṭṭhi. Sammā abhiniropanalakkhaṇo sammāsaṅkappo. Sammā pariggahaṇalakkhaṇā sammāvācā. Sammā samuṭṭhāpanalakkhaṇo sammākammanto. Sammā vodāpanalakkhaṇo sammāājīvo.  Sammā paggahalakkhaṇo sammāvāyāmo. Sammā upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇā sammāsati. Sammā samādhānalakkhaṇo sammāsamādhi. Etesu ekekassa tīṇi tīṇi  kiccāni honti. Seyyathidaṃ, sammādiṭṭhi tāva aññehipi attano paccanīkakilesehi saddhiṃ micchādiṭṭhiṃ pajahati, nirodhaṃ ārammaṇaṃ karoti, sampayuttadhamme ca passati tappaṭicchādakamohavidhamanavasena asammohato. Sammāsaṅkappādayopi tatheva micchāsaṅkappādīni pajahanti, nirodhañca ārammaṇaṃ karonti, visesato panettha sammāsaṅkappo sahajātadhamme abhiniropeti. Sammāvācā sammā pariggaṇhati. Sammākammanto sammā samuṭṭhāpeti. Sammāājīvo sammā vodāpeti. Sammāvāyāmo sammā paggaṇhati. Sammāsati sammā upaṭṭhāpeti. Sammāsamādhi sammā padahati. Api cesā sammādiṭṭhi nāma pubbabhāge nānākkhaṇā nānārammaṇā hoti, maggakkhaṇe ekakkhaṇā ekārammaṇā. Kiccato pana ‘‘dukkhe ñāṇa’’ntiādīni cattāri nāmāni labhati. Sammāsaṅkappādayopi pubbabhāge nānākkhaṇā nānārammaṇā honti. Maggakkhaṇe ekakkhaṇā ekārammaṇā. Tesu sammāsaṅkappo kiccato ‘‘nekkhammasaṅkappo’’tiādīni tīṇi nāmāni labhati. Sammā vācādayo tisso viratiyopi honti, cetanādayopi honti, maggakkhaṇe pana viratiyeva. Sammāvāyāmo sammāsatīti idampi dvayaṃ kiccato sammappadhānasatipaṭṭhānavasena cattāri nāmāni labhati. Sammāsamādhi pana pubbabhāgepi maggakkhaṇepi sammāsamādhiyeva. Iti  imesu aṭṭhasu dhammesu bhagavatā nibbānādhigamāya paṭipannassa yogino bahukārattā paṭhamaṃ sammādiṭṭhi desitā. Ayañhi ‘‘paññāpajjoto paññāsattha’’nti (dha. sa. 20) ca vuttā. Tasmā etāya pubbabhāge vipassanāñāṇasaṅkhātāya sammādiṭṭhiyā avijjandhakāraṃ vidhamitvā kilesacore ghātento khemena  yogāvacaro nibbānaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘nibbānādhigamāya paṭipannassa yogino bahukārattā paṭhamaṃ sammādiṭṭhi desitā’’ti. Sammāsaṅkappo pana tassā bahukāro, tasmā tadanantaraṃ vutto. Yathā hi heraññiko hatthena parivaṭṭetvā parivaṭṭetvā cakkhunā kahāpaṇaṃ olokento – ‘‘ayaṃ cheko, ayaṃ kūṭo’’ti jānāti. Evaṃ yogāvacaropi pubbabhāge vitakkena vitakketvā vipassanāpaññāya olokayamāno – ‘‘ime dhammā kāmāvacarā, ime dhammā rūpāvacarādayo’’ti pajānāti. Yathā vā pana purisena koṭiyaṃ gahetvā parivaṭṭetvā parivaṭṭetvā dinnaṃ mahārukkhaṃ tacchako vāsiyā tacchetvā kamme upaneti, evaṃ vitakkena vitakketvā vitakketvā dinne dhamme yogāvacaro paññāya – ‘‘ime kāmāvacarā, ime rūpāvacarā’’tiādinā nayena paricchinditvā kamme upaneti . Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘sammāsaṅkappo pana tassā bahukāro, tasmā tadanantaraṃ vutto’’ti. Svāyaṃ yathā sammādiṭṭhiyā evaṃ sammāvācāyapi upakārako. Yathāha – ‘‘pubbe kho, visākha, vitakketvā vicāretvā pacchā vācaṃ bhindatī’’ti, (ma. ni. 1.463) tasmā tadanantaraṃ sammāvācā vuttā. Yasmā pana – ‘‘idañcidañca karissāmā’’ti paṭhamaṃ vācāya saṃvidahitvā loke kammante payojenti; tasmā vācā kāyakammassa upakārikāti sammāvācāya anantaraṃ sammākammanto vutto. Catubbidhaṃ pana vacīduccaritaṃ, tividhañca kāyaduccaritaṃ pahāya ubhayaṃ sucaritaṃ pūrentasseva yasmā ājīvaṭṭhamakaṃ sīlaṃ pūreti, na itarassa, tasmā tadubhayānantaraṃ sammāājīvo vutto. Evaṃ visuddhājīvena pana ‘‘parisuddho me ājīvo’’ti ettāvatā ca paritosaṃ katvā suttapamattena viharituṃ na yuttaṃ, atha kho ‘‘sabbiriyāpathesu idaṃ vīriyaṃ samārabhitabba’’nti dassetuṃ tadanantaraṃ sammāvāyāmo vutto. Tato ‘‘āraddhavīriyenapi kāyādīsu catūsu vatthūsu  sati sūpaṭṭhitā kātabbā’’ti dassanatthaṃ tadanantaraṃ sammāsati  desitā. Yasmā panevaṃ sūpaṭṭhitā sati samādhissupakārānupakārānaṃ dhammānaṃ gatiyo samannesitvā pahoti ekattārammaṇe cittaṃ samādhātuṃ, tasmā sammāsatiyā anantaraṃ sammāsamādhi desitoti veditabbo. Etesaṃ dhammānaṃ sacchikiriyāyāti etesaṃ sotāpattiphalādīnaṃ paccakkhakiriyatthāya.
commentary_english:
374-375. Then, inquiring of the Blessed One, he said, "Is there, Venerable Sir…" etc.

*Aṭṭhaṅgiko* means that just as a musical instrument with five parts is *pañcaṅgika*, or just as a village with eight parts is *aṭṭhaṅgiko*, so too, being merely eight parts, it is *aṭṭhaṅgiko*; there is no other path called *maggo* apart from the parts.

Therefore, he said, "That is to say, right view...pe...right concentration." (seyyathidaṃ, sammādiṭṭhi…pe… sammāsamādhī).

Herein, right view (sammādiṭṭhi) is characterized by right seeing.

Right intention (sammāsaṅkappo) is characterized by right application [of the mind].

Right speech (sammāvācā) is characterized by right acceptance.

Right action (sammākammanto) is characterized by right origination.

Right livelihood (sammāājīvo) is characterized by right cleansing.

Right effort (sammāvāyāmo) is characterized by right exertion.

Right mindfulness (sammāsati) is characterized by right establishment.

Right concentration (sammāsamādhi) is characterized by right steadiness.

Among these, each has three functions.

That is to say, right view, indeed, abandons wrong view (micchādiṭṭhi) together with the other defilements that are its adversaries; it makes cessation (nirodha) its object; and it sees the associated phenomena without confusion (asammohato) by dispelling the delusion (moha) that obscures them.

Likewise, right intention (sammāsaṅkappo) and the others abandon wrong intention and so on; they make cessation their object; and in particular, right intention applies itself to the co-arisen phenomena.

Right speech rightly accepts.

Right action rightly originates.

Right livelihood rightly cleanses.

Right effort rightly exerts.

Right mindfulness rightly establishes.

Right concentration rightly steadies.

Moreover, this right view, in the prior part, has diverse moments and diverse objects; in the moment of the path (maggakkhaṇe), it has a single moment and a single object.

However, in terms of function (kiccato), it obtains four names, beginning with "knowledge of suffering" (dukkhe ñāṇa).

Right intention and the others also have diverse moments and diverse objects in the prior part.

In the moment of the path, it has a single moment and a single object.

Among these, right intention, in terms of function, obtains three names, beginning with "intention of renunciation" (nekkhammasaṅkappo).

Right speech and the other three are also abstinences (viratiyo), and they are also volitions (cetanādayo); however, in the moment of the path, they are only abstinences.

This pair, right effort and right mindfulness, also obtain four names in terms of function, as right exertion and mindfulness.

Right concentration, however, is right concentration both in the prior part and in the moment of the path.

Thus, among these eight factors (dhammesu), because of the great benefit (bahukārattā) to the yogi who has embarked upon the attainment of *nirvāṇa*, right view (sammādiṭṭhi) was taught first by the Blessed One (bhagavatā).

For it is said to be "the lamp of wisdom, the weapon of wisdom."

Therefore, by means of this right view, reckoned as the knowledge of insight (vipassanāñāṇa) in the prior part, the yogāvacara, dispelling the darkness of ignorance (avijjandhakāraṃ), slaying the thieves of defilements (kilesacore ghātento), attains *nirvāṇa* safely.

Therefore, it was said, "Because of the great benefit to the yogi who has embarked upon the attainment of *nirvāṇa*, right view was taught first."

Right intention, however, is of great benefit to that, therefore it was mentioned immediately after.

Just as a goldsmith, turning a *kahāpaṇa* over and over in his hand, examines it with his eye, knowing, "This is genuine, this is counterfeit,"

so too, the yogāvacara, pondering with thought (vitakkena vitakketvā) in the prior part, examining with the wisdom of insight (vipassanāpaññāya), understands, "These phenomena are of the sense-sphere, these phenomena are of the form-sphere, and so on."

Or just as a carpenter, having received a large tree given to him after a man has turned it over and over, taking it by the end, shapes it with an axe and applies it to his work, so too, the yogāvacara, having pondered with thought (vitakkena vitakketvā) the phenomena given to him, distinguishing with wisdom, "These are of the sense-sphere, these are of the form-sphere," and so on, applies them to his work.

Therefore, it was said, "Right intention, however, is of great benefit to that, therefore it was mentioned immediately after."
Just as right view is helpful, so too is right speech.

As it is said: "First, having thought and reflected, afterwards one utters speech," (M.

N.

1.

463) Therefore, right speech is stated immediately after that.

Since people first make an agreement in speech, saying "We will do this and that," and then apply themselves to actions in the world; therefore, because speech is helpful to bodily action, right action is stated immediately after right speech.

Since, having abandoned the four kinds of verbal misconduct and the three kinds of bodily misconduct, one fulfills both kinds of good conduct, one fulfills the eightfold path of livelihood, not another; therefore, right livelihood is stated immediately after those two.

Thus, with purified livelihood, it is not fitting to be content with merely thinking, "My livelihood is purified," and to live with scattered mindfulness, but to show that "this effort should be undertaken in all activities," right effort is stated immediately after that.

Then, in order to show that "even with aroused effort, mindfulness should be well established in the four foundations of mindfulness, beginning with the body," right mindfulness is taught immediately after that.

Since, when mindfulness is thus well established, it is possible to investigate the tendencies of dharmas that are helpful and unhelpful to *samādhi*, and to concentrate the mind on a single object, therefore it should be understood that right *samādhi* is taught immediately after right mindfulness.

"For the realization of these *dharmas*": for the purpose of directly experiencing these fruits, beginning with stream-entry.

mula_pali: 375. ‘‘Katamo  pana, bhante, maggo katamā paṭipadā etesaṃ dhammānaṃ sacchikiriyāyā’’ti? ‘‘Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo. Seyyathidaṃ – sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati sammāsamādhi. Ayaṃ kho, mahāli, maggo ayaṃ paṭipadā etesaṃ dhammānaṃ sacchikiriyāya.
mula_english: ‘And, Lord, what is this path (*mārga*), what is this method (*pratipadā*) for the realization of these things (*dharmānām sākṣātkriyāyāḥ*)?’ ‘Just this very noble eightfold path (*ārya-aṣṭāṅgika-mārga*): namely, right view (*samyag-dṛṣṭi*), right intention (*samyak-saṃkalpa*), right speech (*samyag-vāc*), right action (*samyak-karmānta*), right livelihood (*samyag-ājīva*), right effort (*samyag-vyāyāma*), right mindfulness (*samyak-smṛti*), right concentration (*samyak-samādhi*). This is the path, Mahali, this is the way to the realization of these things.’
commentary_pali: 374-375. Tato bhagavantaṃ pucchanto ‘‘atthi pana bhante’’tiādimāha. Aṭṭhaṅgikoti pañcaṅgikaṃ turiyaṃ viya aṭṭhaṅgiko gāmo viya ca aṭṭhaṅgamattoyeva hutvā aṭṭhaṅgiko, na aṅgato añño maggo nāma atthi. Tenevāha – ‘‘seyyathidaṃ, sammādiṭṭhi…pe… sammāsamādhī’’ti. Tattha  sammādassanalakkhaṇā sammādiṭṭhi. Sammā abhiniropanalakkhaṇo sammāsaṅkappo. Sammā pariggahaṇalakkhaṇā sammāvācā. Sammā samuṭṭhāpanalakkhaṇo sammākammanto. Sammā vodāpanalakkhaṇo sammāājīvo.  Sammā paggahalakkhaṇo sammāvāyāmo. Sammā upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇā sammāsati. Sammā samādhānalakkhaṇo sammāsamādhi. Etesu ekekassa tīṇi tīṇi  kiccāni honti. Seyyathidaṃ, sammādiṭṭhi tāva aññehipi attano paccanīkakilesehi saddhiṃ micchādiṭṭhiṃ pajahati, nirodhaṃ ārammaṇaṃ karoti, sampayuttadhamme ca passati tappaṭicchādakamohavidhamanavasena asammohato. Sammāsaṅkappādayopi tatheva micchāsaṅkappādīni pajahanti, nirodhañca ārammaṇaṃ karonti, visesato panettha sammāsaṅkappo sahajātadhamme abhiniropeti. Sammāvācā sammā pariggaṇhati. Sammākammanto sammā samuṭṭhāpeti. Sammāājīvo sammā vodāpeti. Sammāvāyāmo sammā paggaṇhati. Sammāsati sammā upaṭṭhāpeti. Sammāsamādhi sammā padahati. Api cesā sammādiṭṭhi nāma pubbabhāge nānākkhaṇā nānārammaṇā hoti, maggakkhaṇe ekakkhaṇā ekārammaṇā. Kiccato pana ‘‘dukkhe ñāṇa’’ntiādīni cattāri nāmāni labhati. Sammāsaṅkappādayopi pubbabhāge nānākkhaṇā nānārammaṇā honti. Maggakkhaṇe ekakkhaṇā ekārammaṇā. Tesu sammāsaṅkappo kiccato ‘‘nekkhammasaṅkappo’’tiādīni tīṇi nāmāni labhati. Sammā vācādayo tisso viratiyopi honti, cetanādayopi honti, maggakkhaṇe pana viratiyeva. Sammāvāyāmo sammāsatīti idampi dvayaṃ kiccato sammappadhānasatipaṭṭhānavasena cattāri nāmāni labhati. Sammāsamādhi pana pubbabhāgepi maggakkhaṇepi sammāsamādhiyeva. Iti  imesu aṭṭhasu dhammesu bhagavatā nibbānādhigamāya paṭipannassa yogino bahukārattā paṭhamaṃ sammādiṭṭhi desitā. Ayañhi ‘‘paññāpajjoto paññāsattha’’nti (dha. sa. 20) ca vuttā. Tasmā etāya pubbabhāge vipassanāñāṇasaṅkhātāya sammādiṭṭhiyā avijjandhakāraṃ vidhamitvā kilesacore ghātento khemena  yogāvacaro nibbānaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘nibbānādhigamāya paṭipannassa yogino bahukārattā paṭhamaṃ sammādiṭṭhi desitā’’ti. Sammāsaṅkappo pana tassā bahukāro, tasmā tadanantaraṃ vutto. Yathā hi heraññiko hatthena parivaṭṭetvā parivaṭṭetvā cakkhunā kahāpaṇaṃ olokento – ‘‘ayaṃ cheko, ayaṃ kūṭo’’ti jānāti. Evaṃ yogāvacaropi pubbabhāge vitakkena vitakketvā vipassanāpaññāya olokayamāno – ‘‘ime dhammā kāmāvacarā, ime dhammā rūpāvacarādayo’’ti pajānāti. Yathā vā pana purisena koṭiyaṃ gahetvā parivaṭṭetvā parivaṭṭetvā dinnaṃ mahārukkhaṃ tacchako vāsiyā tacchetvā kamme upaneti, evaṃ vitakkena vitakketvā vitakketvā dinne dhamme yogāvacaro paññāya – ‘‘ime kāmāvacarā, ime rūpāvacarā’’tiādinā nayena paricchinditvā kamme upaneti . Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘sammāsaṅkappo pana tassā bahukāro, tasmā tadanantaraṃ vutto’’ti. Svāyaṃ yathā sammādiṭṭhiyā evaṃ sammāvācāyapi upakārako. Yathāha – ‘‘pubbe kho, visākha, vitakketvā vicāretvā pacchā vācaṃ bhindatī’’ti, (ma. ni. 1.463) tasmā tadanantaraṃ sammāvācā vuttā. Yasmā pana – ‘‘idañcidañca karissāmā’’ti paṭhamaṃ vācāya saṃvidahitvā loke kammante payojenti; tasmā vācā kāyakammassa upakārikāti sammāvācāya anantaraṃ sammākammanto vutto. Catubbidhaṃ pana vacīduccaritaṃ, tividhañca kāyaduccaritaṃ pahāya ubhayaṃ sucaritaṃ pūrentasseva yasmā ājīvaṭṭhamakaṃ sīlaṃ pūreti, na itarassa, tasmā tadubhayānantaraṃ sammāājīvo vutto. Evaṃ visuddhājīvena pana ‘‘parisuddho me ājīvo’’ti ettāvatā ca paritosaṃ katvā suttapamattena viharituṃ na yuttaṃ, atha kho ‘‘sabbiriyāpathesu idaṃ vīriyaṃ samārabhitabba’’nti dassetuṃ tadanantaraṃ sammāvāyāmo vutto. Tato ‘‘āraddhavīriyenapi kāyādīsu catūsu vatthūsu  sati sūpaṭṭhitā kātabbā’’ti dassanatthaṃ tadanantaraṃ sammāsati  desitā. Yasmā panevaṃ sūpaṭṭhitā sati samādhissupakārānupakārānaṃ dhammānaṃ gatiyo samannesitvā pahoti ekattārammaṇe cittaṃ samādhātuṃ, tasmā sammāsatiyā anantaraṃ sammāsamādhi desitoti veditabbo. Etesaṃ dhammānaṃ sacchikiriyāyāti etesaṃ sotāpattiphalādīnaṃ paccakkhakiriyatthāya.
commentary_english:
374-375.
Then, questioning the Blessed One, he said, "Is there, venerable sir," and so on.

*'Aṭṭhaṅgika*' means that it is just eight parts, like a five-part orchestra, or like a village of eight parts. The path is *aṭṭhaṅgika* as it is merely eight parts, and there is no other path apart from the parts.

Therefore, he said, "That is to say, right view…right concentration."

Herein, right view (sammādiṭṭhi) has the characteristic of right seeing.

Right intention (sammāsaṅkappa) has the characteristic of right directing.

Right speech (sammāvācā) has the characteristic of right grasping.

Right action (sammākammanta) has the characteristic of right establishing.

Right livelihood (sammāājīva) has the characteristic of right cleansing.

Right effort (sammāvāyāma) has the characteristic of right exertion.

Right mindfulness (sammāsati) has the characteristic of right establishing.

Right concentration (sammāsamādhi) has the characteristic of right composing.

Each of these has three functions.

That is to say, right view, first of all, abandons wrong view (micchādiṭṭhi) along with other defilements (kilesa) that are its adversaries, makes cessation (nirodha) its object (ārammaṇa), and sees the associated phenomena without confusion (asammohato) by eliminating the delusion (moha) that conceals it.

Likewise, right intention and the others abandon wrong intention (micchāsaṅkappa) and the others, and make cessation their object. However, in this case, right intention especially directs towards co-arisen phenomena.

Right speech rightly grasps.

Right action rightly establishes.

Right livelihood rightly cleanses.

Right effort rightly exerts.

Right mindfulness rightly establishes.

Right concentration rightly composes.

Moreover, this right view, in the prior stage, has diverse moments and diverse objects, but in the moment of the path (maggakkhaṇe), it has a single moment and a single object.

In terms of function, it obtains four names, such as "knowledge of suffering (dukkhe ñāṇa)."

Right intention and the others also have diverse moments and diverse objects in the prior stage.

In the moment of the path, it has a single moment and a single object.

Among these, right intention obtains three names in terms of function, such as "intention of renunciation (nekkhammasaṅkappo)."

Right speech and the other three are also abstinences (virati), and they are also volitions (cetanā), but in the moment of the path, they are only abstinences.

This pair, right effort and right mindfulness, also obtain four names in terms of function, as right effort and mindfulness, respectively.

Right concentration, however, is right concentration in both the prior stage and the moment of the path.

Thus, among these eight qualities, because the Blessed One greatly benefits the yogi who has embarked on attaining *nirvāṇa*, right view was taught first.

For this is also said to be "the lamp of wisdom (paññāpajjoto), the sword of wisdom (paññāsattha)." (Dha. Sa. 20)

Therefore, by dispelling the darkness of ignorance (avijjandhakāra) with this right view, which in the prior stage is reckoned as the knowledge of insight (vipassanāñāṇa), and by slaying the thieves of defilements, the yogāvacara attains *nirvāṇa* safely.

Therefore, it was said: "Because the Blessed One greatly benefits the yogi who has embarked on attaining *nirvāṇa*, right view was taught first."

Right intention, however, is of great benefit to that, therefore it was mentioned immediately after.

Just as a goldsmith, turning and turning a coin in his hand, examining it with his eye, knows, "This is genuine, this is counterfeit."

So also, the yogāvacara, reflecting and reflecting with thought in the prior stage, examining with insight-wisdom, understands, "These phenomena belong to the realm of desire (kāmāvacarā), these phenomena belong to the realm of form (rūpāvacarā)," and so on.

Or, just as a carpenter, having been given a large tree that a man has turned and turned by grasping it at the end, planes it with an axe and puts it to work, so also the yogāvacara, having been given phenomena that have been thought about and thought about with thought, distinguishing with wisdom in the manner, "These belong to the realm of desire, these belong to the realm of form," puts it to work.

Therefore, it was said: "Right intention, however, is of great benefit to that, therefore it was mentioned immediately after."
Just as right view is helpful, so too is right speech.

As it was said: "First, having thought and reflected, O Visākha, one then utters speech," (M.
N.
1.
463) Therefore, right speech was stated after that.

Since people first make an agreement in speech, saying "We will do this and that," and then apply themselves to actions in the world, speech is helpful to bodily action; therefore, right action was stated after right speech.

Since one who abandons the four kinds of verbal misconduct and the three kinds of bodily misconduct and fulfills both kinds of good conduct fulfills the eightfold means of livelihood, and not another, therefore, right livelihood was stated after those two.

Thus, with purified livelihood, it is not fitting to make contentment with "My livelihood is purified" and live heedlessly, but to show that "This effort should be undertaken in all activities," right effort was stated after that.

Then, "Even with aroused effort, mindfulness should be well-established in the four foundations of mindfulness, beginning with the body," therefore, right mindfulness was taught after that, for the purpose of showing that.

Since, with mindfulness thus well-established, one is able to investigate the courses of dharmas that are helpful and unhelpful to *samādhi* and to concentrate the mind on a single object, therefore, it should be understood that right *samādhi* was taught after right mindfulness.

"For the direct realization of these *dharmas*" means for the purpose of the direct realization of the fruits of stream-entry and so forth.

mula_pali: 376. ‘‘Ekamidāhaṃ, mahāli, samayaṃ kosambiyaṃ viharāmi ghositārāme . Atha kho dve pabbajitā – muṇḍiyo ca paribbājako jāliyo ca dārupattikantevāsī yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu. Upasaṅkamitvā mayā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho te dve pabbajitā maṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘kiṃ nu kho, āvuso gotama, taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīraṃ, udāhu aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti?
mula_english:
376. Once, Mahali, I was staying at Kosambī, in the Ghosita Park (ghositārāme).

Then two wanderers, Muṇḍiya and Jāliya, the pupil of the wooden-bowl ascetic (dārupattikantevāsī), came to me.

Having approached, they exchanged greetings with me.

After exchanging courteous greetings and polite conversation, they stood to one side.

Standing to one side, those two wanderers said to me: “How is it, friend Gotama (āvuso gotama), is the soul (jīvaṃ) the same as the body (sarīraṃ), or is the soul (jīvaṃ) one thing and the body (sarīraṃ) another?”
commentary_pali: 376-377.Ekamidāhanti idaṃ kasmā āraddhaṃ? Ayaṃ kira rājā – ‘‘rūpaṃ attā’’ti evaṃladdhiko, tenassa desanāya cittaṃ nādhimuccati. Atha bhagavatā tassa laddhiyā āvikaraṇatthaṃ ekaṃ kāraṇaṃ āharituṃ idamāraddhaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepattho – ‘‘ahaṃ ekaṃ samayaṃ ghositārāme viharāmi, tatra vasantaṃ maṃ te dve pabbajitā evaṃ pucchiṃsu. Athāhaṃ tesaṃ buddhuppādaṃ dassetvā tantidhammaṃ nāma kathento idamavocaṃ – ‘‘āvuso, saddhāsampanno nāma kulaputto evarūpassa satthu sāsane pabbajito, evaṃ tividhaṃ sīlaṃ pūretvā paṭhamajjhānādīni patvā ṭhito ‘taṃ jīva’ntiādīni vadeyya, yuttaṃ nu kho etamassā’’ti? Tato tehi ‘‘yutta’’nti vutte ‘‘ahaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, evaṃ jānāmi, evaṃ passāmi, atha ca panāhaṃ na vadāmī’’ti taṃ vādaṃ paṭikkhipitvā uttari khīṇāsavaṃ dassetvā ‘‘imassa evaṃ vattuṃ na yutta’’nti avocaṃ. Te mama vacanaṃ sutvā attamanā ahesunti. Evaṃ vutte sopi attamano ahosi . Tenāha – ‘‘idamavoca bhagavā. Attamano oṭṭhaddho licchavī bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandī’’ti.
commentary_english:
376-377. Once, they said, "Why was this begun? This king is one who has adopted the view that 'form is the self' (*rūpaṃ attā*), so his mind is not uplifted by the teaching (*desanāya cittaṃ nādhimuccati*)."

Then, in order for the Blessed One (*bhagavatā*) to reveal his view, this was begun in order to bring forth a reason.

Here is the condensed meaning (*saṅkhepattho*): "I was dwelling at Ghositārāma at one time. There, two renunciates (*pabbajitā*) asked me this:

Then, showing them the arising of a Buddha (*buddhuppādaṃ dassetvā*) and while speaking about something called the 'doctrine of the string' (*tantidhammaṃ nāma kathento*), I said this: "Friend (*āvuso*), a clansman (*kulaputto*) who is endowed with faith (*saddhāsampanno nāma*), who has gone forth in the dispensation (*sāsane pabbajito*) of a teacher (*satthu*) of such a kind, and who, having fulfilled the threefold morality (*tividhaṃ sīlaṃ pūretvā*) and having attained the first *jhāna* and so on (*paṭhamajjhānādīni patvā ṭhito*), might say things beginning with 'that is the life-principle' (*taṃ jīva*), is this fitting for him (*yuttaṃ nu kho etamassā*?" When they said, "It is fitting (*yutta*)," I said, "Friend (*āvuso*), I know this thus, I see it thus, but I do not say it." Having rejected that statement (*taṃ vādaṃ paṭikkhipitvā*), and having shown a further one whose outflows are ended (*khīṇāsavaṃ dassetvā*), I said, "It is not fitting for him to say this (*imassa evaṃ vattuṃ na yutta*)."

Having heard my word (*vacanaṃ sutvā*), they were delighted (*attamanā ahesunti*).

When this was said, he too was delighted (*attamanā ahosi*).

Therefore he said: "Thus spoke the Blessed One (*idamavoca bhagavā*)."

The Licchavi, elated and pleased (*attamano oṭṭhaddho licchavī*), rejoiced in the Blessed One's utterance (*bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandī*)."

mula_pali: 377. ‘‘‘Tena hāvuso, suṇātha sādhukaṃ manasi karotha bhāsissāmī’’ti. ‘Evamāvuso’ti kho te dve pabbajitā mama paccassosuṃ. Ahaṃ etadavocaṃ – idhāvuso tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho…pe… (yathā 190-212 anucchedesu evaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ). Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti…pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Yo kho, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati, kallaṃ nu kho tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā  ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti? Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati, kallaṃ tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti. Ahaṃ  kho panetaṃ, āvuso, evaṃ jānāmi evaṃ passāmi. Atha ca panāhaṃ na vadāmi – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vā…pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ  upasampajja viharati. Yo kho, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati, kallaṃ nu kho tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti? Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati , kallaṃ tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti. Ahaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, evaṃ jānāmi evaṃ passāmi. Atha ca panāhaṃ na vadāmi – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vā…pe… ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti…pe… yo kho, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati, kallaṃ nu kho tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti? Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati, kallaṃ na kallaṃ (sī. syā. kaṃ. ka.) tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti. Ahaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, evaṃ jānāmi evaṃ passāmi. Atha ca panāhaṃ na vadāmi – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vā…pe…  nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāti. Yo kho, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati, kallaṃ nu kho tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti? Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṃ jānāti evaṃ passati na kallaṃ tassetaṃ vacanāya – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vāti. Ahaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, evaṃ jānāmi evaṃ passāmi. Atha ca panāhaṃ na vadāmi – ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vā’’ti. Idamavoca bhagavā. Attamano oṭṭhaddho licchavī bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mula_english:
377.
“Then listen, friends, and attend closely; I will speak.”
“Yes, friend,” they said, and the two renunciates responded to me.
I said this: “Here, friends, a *Tathāgata* (Thus Come One) arises in the world, an *Arhat* (Worthy One), a *Sammāsambuddha* (Perfectly Enlightened One)…pe… (as it should be expanded in sections 190-212).
Thus, friends, a *bhikkhu* (monk) is perfected in morality…pe… he attains the first *jhāna* (absorption) and dwells in it.
Now, of one who thus knows and thus sees, friends, is it proper to say: ‘The *jīva* (soul) is the same as the *sarīra* (body)’, or ‘The soul is different from the body’?” Of one who thus knows and thus sees, friends, is it proper to say: ‘The soul is the same as the body’, or ‘The soul is different from the body’?”
“But I thus know and see, friends.”
Moreover, I do not say: ‘The soul is the same as the body’, or ‘The soul is different from the body’…pe… he attains the second *jhāna*…pe… the third *jhāna*…pe… he attains the fourth *jhāna* and dwells in it.
Now, of one who thus knows and thus sees, friends, is it proper to say: ‘The soul is the same as the body’, or ‘The soul is different from the body’?” Of one who thus knows and thus sees, friends, is it proper to say: ‘The soul is the same as the body’, or ‘The soul is different from the body’?”
“But I thus know and see, friends.”
Moreover, I do not say: ‘The soul is the same as the body’, or ‘The soul is different from the body’…pe… the mind bends and inclines towards knowledge and vision…pe… Now, of one who thus knows and thus sees, friends, is it proper to say: ‘The soul is the same as the body’, or ‘The soul is different from the body’?” Of one who thus knows and thus sees, friends, is it proper, is it not proper (sī.
syā.
kaṃ.
ka.) to say: ‘The soul is the same as the body’, or ‘The soul is different from the body’?”
“But I thus know and see, friends.”
Moreover, I do not say: ‘The soul is the same as the body’, or ‘The soul is different from the body’…pe… he understands: ‘There is nothing further here.’
Now, of one who thus knows and thus sees, friends, is it proper to say: ‘The soul is the same as the body’, or ‘The soul is different from the body’?” Of one who thus knows and thus sees, friends, is it not proper to say: ‘The soul is the same as the body’, or ‘The soul is different from the body’?”
“But I thus know and see, friends.”
Moreover, I do not say: ‘The soul is the same as the body’, or ‘The soul is different from the body.’”
This is what the Blessed One said.
Oṭṭhaddha the Licchavi, delighted, rejoiced in the Blessed One’s words.
commentary_pali: 376-377.Ekamidāhanti idaṃ kasmā āraddhaṃ? Ayaṃ kira rājā – ‘‘rūpaṃ attā’’ti evaṃladdhiko, tenassa desanāya cittaṃ nādhimuccati. Atha bhagavatā tassa laddhiyā āvikaraṇatthaṃ ekaṃ kāraṇaṃ āharituṃ idamāraddhaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepattho – ‘‘ahaṃ ekaṃ samayaṃ ghositārāme viharāmi, tatra vasantaṃ maṃ te dve pabbajitā evaṃ pucchiṃsu. Athāhaṃ tesaṃ buddhuppādaṃ dassetvā tantidhammaṃ nāma kathento idamavocaṃ – ‘‘āvuso, saddhāsampanno nāma kulaputto evarūpassa satthu sāsane pabbajito, evaṃ tividhaṃ sīlaṃ pūretvā paṭhamajjhānādīni patvā ṭhito ‘taṃ jīva’ntiādīni vadeyya, yuttaṃ nu kho etamassā’’ti? Tato tehi ‘‘yutta’’nti vutte ‘‘ahaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, evaṃ jānāmi, evaṃ passāmi, atha ca panāhaṃ na vadāmī’’ti taṃ vādaṃ paṭikkhipitvā uttari khīṇāsavaṃ dassetvā ‘‘imassa evaṃ vattuṃ na yutta’’nti avocaṃ. Te mama vacanaṃ sutvā attamanā ahesunti. Evaṃ vutte sopi attamano ahosi . Tenāha – ‘‘idamavoca bhagavā. Attamano oṭṭhaddho licchavī bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandī’’ti.
commentary_english:
376-377.

"Why was this begun?" (ekamidāhanti idaṃ kasmā āraddhaṃ?) Apparently, this king is of the view that "form is the self" (rūpaṃ attā'ti), therefore his mind is not uplifted by the teaching (desanāya cittaṃ nādhimuccati).

Then, the Blessed One (bhagavatā), in order to reveal his view (laddhiyā āvikaraṇatthaṃ), began this to bring forth a reason (ekaṃ kāraṇaṃ āharituṃ idamāraddhaṃ).

Here is a summary of the matter (saṅkhepattho): "At one time (ekaṃ samayaṃ), I was dwelling in Ghositārāma (ghositārāme viharāmi). There (tatra), two renunciates (dve pabbajitā) came to me and asked me thus (evaṃ pucchiṃsu):

Then I (ahaṃ), showing them the arising of a Buddha (buddhuppādaṃ dassetvā), while telling a story (tantidhammaṃ nāma kathento) said this (idamavocaṃ): 'Venerable ones (āvuso), a son of good family (kulaputto), endowed with faith (saddhāsampanno nāma), having gone forth into the teaching (sāsane pabbajito) of such a teacher (evarūpassa satthu), thus perfecting the threefold (tividhaṃ) virtue (sīlaṃ pūretvā), having attained the first jhāna (paṭhamajjhānādīni patvā) and so on, if he were to stand and say "that is the soul" ('taṃ jīva'ntiādīni vadeyya), would that be fitting for him (yuttaṃ nu kho etamassā'ti)?' Then, when they said (tehi vutte), 'Fitting (yutta)!' I said (ahaṃ avocaṃ), 'Indeed (kho pana), venerable ones (āvuso), I know thus (evaṃ jānāmi), I see thus (evaṃ passāmi), but yet (atha ca pana) I do not speak thus (ahaṃ na vadāmī'ti).' Rejecting that statement (taṃ vādaṃ paṭikkhipitvā), showing a further (uttari) one with destroyed outflows (khīṇāsavaṃ dassetvā), I said (avocaṃ), 'It is not fitting (na yuttaṃ) for him to speak thus (vattuṃ)".

Having heard my words (mama vacanaṃ sutvā), they were delighted (attamanā ahesunti).

When this was said (evaṃ vutte), he too (sopi) was delighted (attamano ahosi).

Therefore (tena), he said (āha): "Thus spoke the Blessed One (idamavoca bhagavā)."

Delighted (attamano), uplifted (oṭṭhaddho), the Licchavi (licchavī) rejoiced in the Blessed One's (bhagavato) utterance (bhāsitaṃ abhinandī'ti).

mula_pali: 481. Evaṃ  me sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā nāḷandāyaṃ viharati pāvārikambavane. Atha kho kevaṭṭo gahapatiputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho kevaṭṭo gahapatiputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘ayaṃ, bhante, nāḷandā iddhā ceva phītā ca bahujanā ākiṇṇamanussā bhagavati abhippasannā. Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ samādisatu, yo uttarimanussadhammā, iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karissati; evāyaṃ nāḷandā bhiyyoso mattāya bhagavati abhippasīdissatī’’ti. Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā kevaṭṭaṃ gahapatiputtaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘na kho ahaṃ, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhūnaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ desemi – etha tumhe, bhikkhave, gihīnaṃ odātavasanānaṃ uttarimanussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karothā’’ti.
mula_english:
Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One (bhagavā) was staying at Nāḷandā in Pāvārika’s mango grove.

Then Kevaṭṭa, the householder's son, approached the Blessed One (bhagavā); having approached, he paid homage to the Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ) and sat down to one side.

Seated to one side, Kevaṭṭa, the householder's son, said this to the Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ): “This Nāḷandā, venerable sir (bhante), is prosperous (iddhā), thriving (phītā), full of people (bahujanā), crowded with humans (ākiṇṇamanussā), and greatly devoted to the Blessed One (bhagavati abhippasannā).

It would be good, venerable sir (bhante), if the Blessed One (bhagavā) were to instruct a monk (bhikkhuṃ) to perform superhuman feats (uttarimanussadhammā) and miracles (iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ); in this way, this Nāḷandā would become even more greatly devoted to the Blessed One (bhagavati abhippasīdissatī).”

When this was said, the Blessed One (bhagavā) said this to Kevaṭṭa, the householder's son: “I do not, Kevaṭṭa, teach the Dhamma (dhammaṃ) to the monks (bhikkhūnaṃ) in this way, saying: ‘Come, monks (bhikkhave), perform superhuman feats (uttarimanussadhammā) and miracles (iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ) for the white-clothed lay followers (gihīnaṃ odātavasanānaṃ.’”
commentary_pali: 481.Evaṃme sutaṃ…pe… nāḷandāyanti kevaṭṭasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ apubbapadavaṇṇanā. Pāvārikambavaneti pāvārikassa ambavane. Kevaṭṭoti idaṃ tassa gahapatiputtassa nāmaṃ. So kira cattālīsakoṭidhano gahapatimahāsālo ativiya saddho pasanno ahosi. So saddhādhikattāyeva ‘‘sace eko bhikkhu aḍḍhamāsantarena vā māsantarena vā saṃvaccharena vā ākāse uppatitvā vividhāni pāṭihāriyāni dasseyya, sabbo jano ativiya pasīdeyya. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ yācitvā pāṭihāriyakaraṇatthāya ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ anujānāpeyya’’nti cintetvā bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evamāha. Tattha iddhāti samiddhā phītāti nānābhaṇḍaussannatāya vuddhippattā. Ākiṇṇamanussāti aṃsakūṭena aṃsakūṭaṃ paharitvā viya vicarantehi manussehi ākiṇṇā. Samādisatūti āṇāpetu ṭhānantare ṭhapetu. Uttarimanussadhammāti uttarimanussānaṃ dhammato, dasakusalasaṅkhātato vā manussadhammato uttari. Bhiyyosomattāyāti pakatiyāpi pajjalitapadīpo telasnehaṃ labhitvā viya atirekappamāṇena abhippasīdissati. Na kho ahanti bhagavā rājagahaseṭṭhivatthusmiṃ sikkhāpadaṃ paññapesi, tasmā ‘‘na kho aha’’ntiādimāha.
commentary_english:
481. Thus have I heard…pe… the Kevatta Sutta in Nāḷandā.

Here is the explanation of previously unencountered words.

"Pāvārikambavana" means in the mango grove of Pāvārika.

"Kevaṭṭa" is the name of that householder's son (gahapatiputta).

He was a householder Mahāsāla, a man with forty crores of wealth, very faithful and pleased.

He, being exceedingly full of faith, [thought:] "If a certain *bhikkhu* were to rise into the sky and display various miracles after either half a month, a month, or a year, all the people would be exceedingly pleased."

"What if I were to request the Blessed One and ask him to permit a *bhikkhu* for the sake of performing miracles?" Thinking thus, he approached the Blessed One and said this:

There, "iddhā" means prosperous, "phītā" means attained to growth by the abundance of various goods.

"Ākiṇṇamanussā" means crowded with people wandering around as if striking shoulder to shoulder.

"Samādisatu" means may he command, may he establish [him] in another place.

"Uttarimanussadhamma" means superior to the *dharma* of ordinary humans, or superior to the *manussadhamma* consisting of the ten wholesome actions.

"Bhiyyosomattāya" means even by nature, just like a lit lamp, having obtained oil, it will shine forth with exceeding measure.

"Na kho aha" – the Blessed One promulgated the training rule in connection with the incident of the Rājagaha seṭṭhi; therefore, he said, "na kho aha" and so on.

mula_pali: 482. Dutiyampi kho kevaṭṭo gahapatiputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘nāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ dhaṃsemi; api ca, evaṃ vadāmi – ‘ayaṃ, bhante, nāḷandā iddhā ceva phītā ca bahujanā ākiṇṇamanussā bhagavati abhippasannā. Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ samādisatu, yo uttarimanussadhammā  iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karissati; evāyaṃ nāḷandā bhiyyoso mattāya bhagavati abhippasīdissatī’’’ti. Dutiyampi kho bhagavā kevaṭṭaṃ gahapatiputtaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘na kho ahaṃ, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhūnaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ desemi – etha tumhe, bhikkhave, gihīnaṃ odātavasanānaṃ uttarimanussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karothā’’’ti. Tatiyampi kho kevaṭṭo gahapatiputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘nāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ dhaṃsemi; api ca, evaṃ vadāmi – ‘ayaṃ, bhante, nāḷandā iddhā ceva phītā ca bahujanā ākiṇṇamanussā  bhagavati abhippasannā. Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ samādisatu, yo uttarimanussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karissati. Evāyaṃ nāḷandā bhiyyoso mattāya bhagavati abhippasīdissatī’ti.
mula_english:
482.

For a second time, Kevaddha, the householder’s son, said this to the Blessed One: “I am not importuning the Blessed One, venerable sir; but I say this: ‘This Nāḷandā, venerable sir, is flourishing, prosperous, full of people, and crowded with humans who are devoted to the Blessed One.

It would be good, venerable sir, if the Blessed One would direct a certain monk to perform a superhuman miracle (uttarimanussadhamma iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ). In this way, this Nāḷandā would be even more devoted to the Blessed One.’”

For a second time, the Blessed One said this to Kevaddha, the householder’s son: “I do not teach the monks in this way, Kevaddha, saying, ‘Come, monks, perform superhuman miracles (uttarimanussadhamma iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ) for the white-clothed laypeople!’”

For a third time, Kevaddha, the householder’s son, said this to the Blessed One: “I am not importuning the Blessed One, venerable sir; but I say this: ‘This Nāḷandā, venerable sir, is flourishing, prosperous, full of people, and crowded with humans who are devoted to the Blessed One.

It would be good, venerable sir, if the Blessed One would direct a certain monk to perform a superhuman miracle (uttarimanussadhamma iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ).

In this way, this Nāḷandā would be even more devoted to the Blessed One.”
commentary_pali: 482.Na dhaṃsemīti na guṇavināsanena dhaṃsemi, sīlabhedaṃ pāpetvā anupubbena uccaṭṭhānato otārento nīcaṭṭhāne  na ṭhapemi, atha kho ahaṃ buddhasāsanassa vuddhiṃ paccāsīsanto kathemīti dasseti. Tatiyampi khoti yāvatatiyaṃ buddhānaṃ kathaṃ paṭibāhitvā kathetuṃ visahanto nāma natthi. Ayaṃ pana bhagavatā saddhiṃ vissāsiko vissāsaṃ vaḍḍhetvā vallabho hutvā atthakāmosmīti tikkhattuṃ kathesi.
commentary_english:
482. "Na dhaṃsemi": I do not corrupt by destroying virtues. I do not cause a breach of morality, gradually bring down from a high position, and establish in a low position. But rather, I speak expecting the growth of the Buddha's dispensation, this is what it shows.

"Tatiyampi kho": Even up to the third time, there is no one who dares to speak having rejected the words of the Buddhas.

However, this one, being intimate with the Blessed One, having increased intimacy, having become a favorite, and being desirous of benefit, spoke three times.

mula_pali: 483. ‘‘Tīṇi  kho imāni, kevaṭṭa, pāṭihāriyāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni. Katamāni tīṇi? Iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ, ādesanāpāṭihāriyaṃ , anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃ.
mula_english: The Lord said: ‘Kevaṭṭa, there are three kinds of marvel that I have declared, having realised them by my own insight. What are the three? The marvel of psychic power (*ṛddhi-prātihārya*), the marvel of telepathy (*ādeśanā-prātihārya*), the marvel of instruction (*anuśāsanī-prātihārya*).
commentary_pali: 483-484. Atha  bhagavā ayaṃ upāsako mayi paṭibāhantepi punappunaṃ yācatiyeva. ‘‘Handassa pāṭihāriyakaraṇe ādīnavaṃ dassemī’’ti cintetvā  ‘‘tīṇi kho’’tiādimāha. Tattha amāhaṃ bhikkhunti amuṃ ahaṃ bhikkhuṃ. Gandhārīti gandhārena nāma isinā katā, gandhāraraṭṭhe vā uppannā vijjā. Tattha kira bahū isayo vasiṃsu, tesu ekena katā vijjāti adhippāyo. Aṭṭīyāmīti aṭṭo pīḷito viya homi. Harāyāmīti lajjāmi. Jigucchāmīti gūthaṃ disvā viya jigucchaṃ uppādemi.
commentary_english:
483-484. Then, although this lay follower (*upāsaka*) was hindering me, he kept requesting again and again.

"I will show the disadvantage in the performance of a marvel," thinking thus, he said, "Three, indeed," etc., as the beginning.

There, I said, "I am a *bhikkhu*," to that *bhikkhu*.

*Gandhārī* means [that it] was made by a seer (*iṣi*) named *Gandhāra*, or a science (*vidyā*) that arose in the *Gandhāra* country.

There, it is said that many seers (*iṣi*) lived; the meaning is that the science (*vidyā*) was made by one of them.

"I am troubled" means I am as if troubled, oppressed.

"I am ashamed" means I am ashamed (*lajjāmi*).

"I feel disgust" means, as if having seen excrement (*gūtha*), I produce disgust.

mula_pali: 484. ‘‘Katamañca, kevaṭṭa, iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ? Idha, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti. Ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti; āvibhāvaṃ tirobhāvaṃ tirokuṭṭaṃ tiropākāraṃ tiropabbataṃ asajjamāno gacchati seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṃ karoti seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchati seyyathāpi pathaviyaṃ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṃ mahiddhike evaṃ mahānubhāve pāṇinā parāmasati parimajjati; yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti. ‘‘Tamenaṃ aññataro saddho pasanno passati taṃ bhikkhuṃ anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhontaṃ – ekopi hutvā bahudhā hontaṃ, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hontaṃ; āvibhāvaṃ tirobhāvaṃ; tirokuṭṭaṃ tiropākāraṃ tiropabbataṃ asajjamānaṃ gacchantaṃ seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṃ karontaṃ seyyathāpi  udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchantaṃ seyyathāpi pathaviyaṃ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamantaṃ seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṃ mahiddhike evaṃ mahānubhāve pāṇinā parāmasantaṃ parimajjantaṃ yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vattentaṃ. ‘‘Tamenaṃ so saddho pasanno aññatarassa assaddhassa appasannassa āroceti – ‘acchariyaṃ vata, bho, abbhutaṃ vata, bho, samaṇassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā. Amāhaṃ bhikkhuṃ addasaṃ anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhontaṃ – ekopi hutvā bahudhā hontaṃ, bahudhāpi  hutvā eko hontaṃ…pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vattenta’nti. ‘‘Tamenaṃ  so assaddho appasanno taṃ saddhaṃ pasannaṃ evaṃ vadeyya – ‘atthi kho, bho, gandhārī nāma vijjā. Tāya so bhikkhu anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti – ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti…pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vattetī’ti. ‘‘Taṃ  kiṃ maññasi, kevaṭṭa, api nu so assaddho appasanno taṃ saddhaṃ pasannaṃ evaṃ vadeyyā’’ti? ‘‘Vadeyya, bhante’’ti. ‘‘Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, kevaṭṭa, iddhipāṭihāriye ādīnavaṃ sampassamāno iddhipāṭihāriyena aṭṭīyāmi harāyāmi jigucchāmi’’.
mula_english:
484.
“And what, Kevatta, is the miracle of psychic power ( *iddhipāṭihāriya*)? Here, Kevatta, a monk experiences various kinds of psychic power (*anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ*).

Being one, he becomes many; being many, he becomes one. He appears and vanishes. He goes unhindered through a wall, through an enclosure, through a mountain, as though through space. He dives in and out of the earth as though it were water. He walks on water without sinking as though it were earth. Seated cross-legged, he travels in space like a bird. With his hand he touches and strokes the moon and sun, so powerful and mighty. He exercises mastery with the body as far as the Brahma world.

"Then a faithful believer sees that monk experiencing various kinds of psychic power—being one, becoming many; being many, becoming one; appearing and vanishing; going unhindered through a wall, through an enclosure, through a mountain as though through space; diving in and out of the earth as though it were water; walking on water without sinking as though it were earth; seated cross-legged, traveling in space like a bird; touching and stroking the moon and sun, so powerful and mighty, with his hand; exercising mastery with the body as far as the Brahma world.

"Then that faithful believer tells it to another who is skeptical and unbelieving, saying, 'It's amazing, sir! It's marvelous, sir! The power and might of that ascetic!

I saw a monk experiencing various kinds of psychic power—being one, becoming many; being many, becoming one…exercising mastery with the body as far as the Brahma world.’

"Then that skeptical unbeliever might say this to that faithful believer: 'Sir, there is a Gandhari charm ( *gandhārī nāma vijjā*).

It is by that the monk experiences various kinds of psychic power: being one, he becomes many; being many, he becomes one…exercising mastery with the body as far as the Brahma world.’

“What do you think, Kevatta? Might not that skeptic and unbeliever say that to that faithful believer?” “He might say so, sir.”

“That is why, Kevatta, seeing the danger in the miracle of psychic power (*iddhipāṭihāriya*), I am disgusted, ashamed, and repelled by the miracle of psychic power (*iddhipāṭihāriya*)."
commentary_pali: 483-484. Atha  bhagavā ayaṃ upāsako mayi paṭibāhantepi punappunaṃ yācatiyeva. ‘‘Handassa pāṭihāriyakaraṇe ādīnavaṃ dassemī’’ti cintetvā  ‘‘tīṇi kho’’tiādimāha. Tattha amāhaṃ bhikkhunti amuṃ ahaṃ bhikkhuṃ. Gandhārīti gandhārena nāma isinā katā, gandhāraraṭṭhe vā uppannā vijjā. Tattha kira bahū isayo vasiṃsu, tesu ekena katā vijjāti adhippāyo. Aṭṭīyāmīti aṭṭo pīḷito viya homi. Harāyāmīti lajjāmi. Jigucchāmīti gūthaṃ disvā viya jigucchaṃ uppādemi.
commentary_english:
483-484.
Then, although this blessed layman was being refused by me, he kept asking again and again.
Thinking, "I will show the fault in performing the miracle of the hand," he said, "Three, indeed," and so on.
There, I pointed out that bhikkhu to that bhikkhu.
*Gandhārī* means that [this *vidyā*] was made by a sage named *Gandhāra*, or it is a *vidyā* that arose in the *Gandhāra* country.
There, it is said that many sages lived; the meaning is that the *vidyā* was made by one of them.
"I am troubled" means I am like one who is afflicted with trouble.
"I am disgusted" means I feel shame.
"I am repelled" means, as if seeing excrement, I produce revulsion.

mula_pali: 485. ‘‘Katamañca, kevaṭṭa, ādesanāpāṭihāriyaṃ? Idha, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cittampi ādisati, cetasikampi ādisati, vitakkitampi ādisati, vicāritampi ādisati – ‘evampi te mano, itthampi te mano, itipi te citta’nti. ‘‘Tamenaṃ aññataro saddho pasanno passati taṃ bhikkhuṃ parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cittampi ādisantaṃ, cetasikampi ādisantaṃ, vitakkitampi ādisantaṃ, vicāritampi ādisantaṃ – ‘evampi te mano, itthampi te mano, itipi te citta’nti. Tamenaṃ so saddho pasanno aññatarassa assaddhassa appasannassa āroceti – ‘acchariyaṃ vata, bho, abbhutaṃ  vata, bho, samaṇassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā. Amāhaṃ bhikkhuṃ addasaṃ parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cittampi ādisantaṃ, cetasikampi ādisantaṃ, vitakkitampi ādisantaṃ, vicāritampi ādisantaṃ – ‘‘evampi te mano, itthampi te mano, itipi te citta’’’nti. ‘‘Tamenaṃ so  assaddho appasanno taṃ saddhaṃ pasannaṃ evaṃ vadeyya – ‘atthi kho, bho, maṇikā nāma vijjā; tāya so bhikkhu parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cittampi ādisati, cetasikampi ādisati, vitakkitampi ādisati, vicāritampi ādisati – ‘evampi te mano, itthampi te mano, itipi te citta’’’nti. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, kevaṭṭa, api nu so assaddho appasanno taṃ saddhaṃ pasannaṃ evaṃ vadeyyā’’ti ? ‘‘Vadeyya, bhante’’ti. ‘‘Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, kevaṭṭa, ādesanāpāṭihāriye ādīnavaṃ sampassamāno ādesanāpāṭihāriyena aṭṭīyāmi harāyāmi jigucchāmi’’.
mula_english:
What is the miracle of mind-reading, Kevatta? Here, Kevatta, a monk reads the minds of other beings, of other people, reads their mental states (*cetasika*), their thoughts (*vitakkita*) and ponderings (*vicārita*), and says: “That is how your mind (*manas*) is, that is how it inclines, that is in your heart (*citta*).”

Then another believer, serene in faith, sees that monk reading the minds (*citta*) of other beings, of other people, reading their mental states (*cetasika*), reading their thoughts (*vitakkita*), pondering their ideas (*vicārita*), and saying: “That is how your mind (*manas*) is, that is how it inclines, that is in your heart (*citta*).”

He tells this to someone else who is skeptical and unbelieving, saying: “It is wonderful, sir, it is marvellous, the great power (*mahiddhikatā*) and skill (*mahānubhāvatā*) of that ascetic!”

I saw a monk reading the minds (*citta*) of other beings, of other people, reading their mental states (*cetasika*), reading their thoughts (*vitakkita*), pondering their ideas (*vicārita*), and saying: “That is how your mind (*manas*) is, that is how it inclines, that is in your heart (*citta*).”

And that man, being skeptical and unbelieving, might say to that believer, serene in faith: “Sir, there is something called the *Maṇika* charm. It is by means of this that that monk can read the minds (*citta*) of others, can read their mental states (*cetasika*), can read their thoughts (*vitakkita*), can read their ponderings (*vicārita*)—’That is how your mind (*manas*) is, that is how your mind inclines, that is what is in your heart (*citta*)’."

What do you think, Kevatta, would not a skeptic say that to a believer?” “He would say so, Bhante.”

And that is why, Kevatta, seeing the danger (*ādīnava*) of such mind-reading miracles (*ādesanāpāṭihāriya*), I dislike, reject and despise mind-reading miracles (*ādesanāpāṭihāriya*).
commentary_pali: 485.Parasattānanti aññesaṃ sattānaṃ. Dutiyaṃ tasseva vevacanaṃ. Ādisatīti katheti. Cetasikanti somanassadomanassaṃ adhippetaṃ. Evampi te manoti evaṃ tava mano somanassito vā domanassito vā kāmavitakkādisampayutto vā. Dutiyaṃ tasseva vevacanaṃ. Itipi te cittanti iti tava cittaṃ, idañcidañca atthaṃ cintayamānaṃ pavattatīti attho. Maṇikā nāma vijjāti cintāmaṇīti evaṃ laddhanāmā loke ekā vijjā atthi. Tāya paresaṃ cittaṃ jānātīti dīpeti.
commentary_english:
485. *Parasattānanti* means of other beings (*aññesaṃ sattānaṃ*).

The second is a synonym of that.

*Ādisatīti* means he speaks (*katheti*).

*Cetasikanti* refers to pleasure and displeasure (*somanassadomanassaṃ adhippetaṃ*).

*Evampi te manoti* means thus your mind (*evaṃ tava mano*) is associated with pleasure (*somanassito*) or displeasure (*domanassito*) or sensual thoughts (*kāmavitakkādisampayutto*).

The second is a synonym of that.

*Itipi te cittanti* means thus your mind (*iti tava cittaṃ*), thinking about this and that matter (*idañcidañca atthaṃ cintayamānaṃ*), proceeds, this is the meaning (*pavattatīti attho*).

There is a knowledge (*ekā vijjā atthi*) in the world (*loke*) called *Maṇikā*, namely *Cintāmaṇī*, thus it has obtained its name (*evaṃ laddhanāmā*).

By that, he illuminates that he knows the mind of others (*tāya paresaṃ cittaṃ jānātīti dīpeti*).

mula_pali: 486. ‘‘Katamañca, kevaṭṭa, anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃ? Idha, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu evamanusāsati – ‘evaṃ vitakketha, mā evaṃ vitakkayittha, evaṃ manasikarotha, mā  evaṃ manasākattha, idaṃ pajahatha, idaṃ upasampajja viharathā’ti. Idaṃ vuccati, kevaṭṭa, anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃ. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, kevaṭṭa, idha tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho  …pe… (yathā 190-212 anucchedesu evaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ). Evaṃ kho, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti…pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Idampi vuccati, kevaṭṭa, anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃ…pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Idampi vuccati, kevaṭṭa, anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃ…pe… ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati  abhininnāmeti…pe… idampi vuccati, kevaṭṭa, anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃ…pe… nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāti…pe… idampi vuccati, kevaṭṭa, anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃ. ‘‘Imāni kho, kevaṭṭa, tīṇi pāṭihāriyāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā  sacchikatvā paveditāni’’.
mula_english:
486. “And what, Kevaddha, is the miracle of instruction (anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃ)? Here, Kevaddha, a monk instructs thus: ‘Think in this way, do not think in that way; apply your mind in this way, do not apply your mind in that way; abandon this, attain this and abide in it.’ This is called the miracle of instruction, Kevaddha.

“Furthermore, Kevaddha, here the Tathāgata arises in the world, a worthy one, a fully enlightened one… (as it should be related in detail as in sections 190-212).

Thus, Kevaddha, a monk is accomplished in virtue… and abides, having attained the first *jhāna*. This is also called the miracle of instruction, Kevaddha… and the second *jhāna*… and the third *jhāna*… and abides, having attained the fourth *jhāna*. This also is called the miracle of instruction, Kevaddha… he directs and inclines his mind to knowledge and vision (*ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti*)… this also is called the miracle of instruction, Kevaddha… he understands: ‘There is nothing further here’… this also is called the miracle of instruction, Kevaddha.

“These, Kevaddha, are the three miracles that I have declared, having realized them myself with direct knowledge (*sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni*).”
commentary_pali: 486.Evaṃ vitakkethāti nekkhammavitakkādayo evaṃ pavattentā vitakketha. Mā evaṃ vitakkayitthāti evaṃ kāmavitakkādayo pavattentā mā vitakkayittha. Evaṃ manasi karothāti evaṃ aniccasaññameva, dukkhasaññādīsu vā aññataraṃ manasi karotha. Māevanti ‘‘nicca’’ntiādinā nayena mā manasi karittha. Idanti idaṃ pañcakāmaguṇikarāgaṃ pajahatha. Idaṃ upasampajjāti idaṃ catumaggaphalappabhedaṃ lokuttaradhammameva upasampajja pāpuṇitvā nipphādetvā viharatha. Iti bhagavā iddhividhaṃ iddhipāṭihāriyanti dasseti, parassa cittaṃ ñatvā kathanaṃ ādesanāpāṭihāriyanti. Sāvakānañca buddhānañca satataṃ dhammadesanā anusāsanīpāṭihāriyanti. Tattha  iddhipāṭihāriyena anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃ mahāmoggallānassa āciṇṇaṃ, ādesanāpāṭihāriyena anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃ dhammasenāpatissa. Devadatte saṃghaṃ bhinditvā pañca bhikkhusatāni gahetvā gayāsīse buddhalīḷāya tesaṃ dhammaṃ desante hi bhagavatā pesitesu dvīsu aggasāvakesu dhammasenāpati tesaṃ cittācāraṃ ñatvā dhammaṃ desesi , therassa dhammadesanaṃ sutvā pañcasatā bhikkhū sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahiṃsu. Atha nesaṃ mahāmoggallāno vikubbanaṃ dassetvā dassetvā dhammaṃ desesi, taṃ sutvā sabbe arahattaphale patiṭṭhahiṃsu. Atha dvepi mahānāgā pañca bhikkhusatāni gahetvā vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā veḷuvanamevāgamiṃsu. Anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃ pana buddhānaṃ satataṃ dhammadesanā, tesu iddhipāṭihāriyaādesanāpāṭihāriyāni saupārambhāni sadosāni, addhānaṃ na tiṭṭhanti, addhānaṃ atiṭṭhanato na niyyanti. Anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃ anupārambhaṃ niddosaṃ, addhānaṃ tiṭṭhati, addhānaṃ tiṭṭhanato niyyāti. Tasmā bhagavā iddhipāṭihāriyañca ādesanāpāṭihāriyañca garahati, anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃyeva pasaṃsati.
commentary_english:
486. "Think thus" means think by initiating thoughts of renunciation (nekkhamma-vitakka), and so on.

"Do not think thus" means do not think by initiating thoughts of sensual pleasure (kāma-vitakka), and so on.

"Direct your mind thus" means direct your mind towards the perception of impermanence (anicca-sañña) or any one of the perceptions of suffering (dukkha-saññā), and so on.

"Do not thus" means do not direct your mind in the way of "permanence" ("nicca"), and so on.

"This" means abandon this lust for the five strands of sense pleasure (pañcakāmaguṇika-rāga).

"Attain this" means having attained and realized this supramundane Dharma itself, which is differentiated as the four paths and fruits, live (vihartha).

Thus, the Blessed One shows the miracle of psychic power (iddhi-pāṭihāriya) as the variety of psychic power, and knowing the mind of another and speaking is the miracle of revelation (ādesanā-pāṭihāriya).

The constant teaching of the Dharma by the disciples and the Buddhas is the miracle of instruction (anusāsanī-pāṭihāriya).

Of these, the miracle of instruction through psychic power was practiced by Mahā Moggallāna, and the miracle of instruction through revelation was practiced by Dhamma Senāpati.

When Devadatta, having split the Saṅgha and taken five hundred monks, was teaching them the Dharma in the Buddha's manner at Gayāsīsa, Dhamma Senāpati, one of the two chief disciples sent by the Blessed One, knew their mental conduct and taught them the Dharma. Having heard the elder's Dharma teaching, the five hundred monks were established in the fruit of stream-entry (sotāpatti-phala).

Then Mahā Moggallāna, having shown them transformations again and again, taught them the Dharma. Having heard that, all were established in the fruit of Arhatship.

Then the two great Nāgas, having taken the five hundred monks, ascended into the sky and came to Veḷuvana itself.

The miracle of instruction, however, is the constant teaching of the Dharma by the Buddhas. Among these, the miracles of psychic power and revelation are with effort (saupārambhāni) and with faults (sadosāni), they do not last long (addhānaṃ na tiṭṭhanti), and because they do not last long, they do not lead out (na niyyanti).

The miracle of instruction is without effort (anupārambhaṃ) and without faults (niddosaṃ), it lasts long (addhānaṃ tiṭṭhati), and because it lasts long, it leads out (niyyāti).

Therefore, the Blessed One despises the miracle of psychic power and the miracle of revelation, and praises only the miracle of instruction.

mula_pali: 487. ‘‘Bhūtapubbaṃ, kevaṭṭa, imasmiññeva bhikkhusaṅghe aññatarassa bhikkhuno evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi – ‘kattha nu kho ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti?
mula_english: 487. Once, Kevatta, in this very community of monks, a thought arose in the mind of a certain monk: "Where do these four great elements ( *cattāro mahābhūtā*)—the earth element (*pathavīdhātu*), the water element (*āpodhātu*), the fire element (*tejodhātu*), and the air element (*vāyodhātu*)—cease without remainder?"
commentary_pali: 487.Bhūtapubbanti idaṃ kasmā bhagavatā āraddhaṃ. Iddhipāṭihāriyaādesanāpāṭihāriyānaṃ aniyyānikabhāvadassanatthaṃ, anusāsanīpāṭihāriyasseva niyyānikabhāvadassanatthaṃ. Api ca sabbabuddhānaṃ mahābhūtapariyesako nāmeko bhikkhu hotiyeva. Yo mahābhūte pariyesanto yāva brahmalokā vicaritvā vissajjetāraṃ alabhitvā āgamma  buddhameva pucchitvā nikkaṅkho hoti. Tasmā buddhānaṃ mahantabhāvappakāsanatthaṃ, idañca kāraṇaṃ paṭicchannaṃ, atha naṃ vivaṭaṃ katvā desentopi bhagavā ‘‘bhūtapubba’’ntiādimāha. Tattha kattha nu khoti kismiṃ ṭhāne kiṃ āgamma kiṃ pattassa te anavasesā appavattivasena nirujjhanti. Mahābhūtakathā panesā sabbākārena visuddhimagge vuttā, tasmā sā tatova gahetabbā.
commentary_english:
487.

Why was this begun by the Blessed One with "bhūtapubbanti"?

[It was begun] in order to show the non-leading-out nature of the miracle of psychic power and the miracle of instruction, and in order to show the leading-out nature of the miracle of teaching.

Furthermore, there is certainly a *bhikṣu* by the name of *mahābhūtapariyesaka* for all Buddhas.

That one, seeking the great elements, after wandering as far as the *brahmaloka*, not obtaining a teacher, approaching the Buddha, asking the Buddha himself, becomes free from doubt (*nikkaṅkho*).

Therefore, for the purpose of revealing the greatness of the Buddhas, and this cause being hidden, then, making it open, even while teaching, the Blessed One said "bhūtapubba," etc.

There, where now, in what place, approaching what, to what attainment, do those remainders cease due to non-occurrence?

However, this discourse on the great elements (*mahābhūta*) has been spoken of in its entirety in the *Visuddhimagga*, therefore it should be taken from there.

mula_pali: 488. ‘‘Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu tathārūpaṃ samādhiṃ samāpajji, yathāsamāhite citte devayāniyo maggo pāturahosi. Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu yena cātumahārājikā devā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā cātumahārājike deve etadavoca – ‘kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti? ‘‘Evaṃ vutte, kevaṭṭa, cātumahārājikā devā taṃ bhikkhuṃ  etadavocuṃ – ‘mayampi kho, bhikkhu, na jānāma, yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātūti vāyodhātu. atthi kho (pī. evamuparipi). Atthi kho vāyodhātu. atthi kho (pī. evamuparipi), bhikkhu, cattāro mahārājāno amhehi abhikkantatarā  ca paṇītatarā ca. Te kho etaṃ jāneyyuṃ, yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
mula_english:
“Then, Kevatta, that monk attained to such a state of concentration (samādhi) that the way to the deva-realms appeared before him.

Then, Kevatta, that monk approached the devas of the Realm of the Four Great Kings (cātumahārājikā devā); having approached, he said to the devas of the Four Great Kings: “Friends (āvuso), where do these four great elements (cattāro mahābhūtā)—the earth element (pathavīdhātu), the water element (āpodhātu), the fire element (tejodhātu), and the air element (vāyodhātu)—cease without remainder?” When this was said, Kevatta, the devas of the Realm of the Four Great Kings said to that monk: “We also, monk (bhikkhu), do not know where these four great elements—the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element—cease without remainder.”

There is, indeed.

Thus, and so forth.

There is, indeed, the air element (vāyodhātu).

There is, indeed.

Thus, and so forth, monk, the Four Great Kings (cattāro mahārājāno) are loftier and wiser than us.

They may know where these four great elements—the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element—cease without remainder."
commentary_pali: 488.Devayāniyo maggoti pāṭiyekko devalokagamanamaggo nāma natthi, iddhividhañāṇasseva panetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tena hesa yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vattento devalokaṃ yāti. Tasmā ‘‘taṃ devayāniyo maggo’’ti vuttaṃ. Yena cātumahārājikāti samīpe ṭhitampi bhagavantaṃ apucchitvā dhammatāya codito devatā mahānubhāvāti maññamāno upasaṅkami. Mayampi kho, bhikkhu, na jānāmāti buddhavisaye pañhaṃ  pucchitā devatā na jānanti , tenevamāhaṃsu. Atha kho so bhikkhu ‘‘mama imaṃ pañhaṃ na kathetuṃ na labbhā, sīghaṃ kathethā’’ti tā devatā ajjhottharati, punappunaṃ pucchati, tā ‘‘ajjhottharati no ayaṃ bhikkhu, handa naṃ hatthato mocessāmā’’ti cintetvā ‘‘atthi kho bhikkhu cattāro mahārājāno’’tiādimāhaṃsu. Tattha abhikkantatarāti atikkamma kantatarā. Paṇītatarāti vaṇṇayasaissariyādīhi uttamatarā etena nayena sabbavāresu attho veditabbo.
commentary_english:
488.

The *devayāniyo maggo* is not a distinct path for going to the world of the gods; rather, it is a designation for the knowledge of psychic power.

Therefore, that one, controlling his body up to the Brahmā realm, goes to the world of the gods.

Therefore, it is said, "That is the *devayāniyo maggo*."

Because the deities near the Cātumahārājika heaven, without asking the Blessed One, impelled by righteousness, approached, thinking "they are of great power".

"We also, *bhikṣu*, do not know," thus the deities, asked a question regarding the sphere of the Buddha, do not know; therefore, they said thus.

Then that *bhikṣu* oppressed those deities, saying, "It is not possible not to tell me this question; tell it quickly." He asked again and again. Those deities, thinking, "This *bhikṣu* is oppressing us; come, let us release him from our hands," said, "There are four great kings (*cattāro mahārājāno*)."

There, *abhikkantatarā* means more surpassing in beauty.

*Paṇītatarā* means more excellent by means of beauty, authority, etc.; in this way, the meaning should be understood in all instances.

mula_pali: 489. ‘‘Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu yena cattāro mahārājāno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā cattāro mahārāje etadavoca – ‘kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā  nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu  āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti? Evaṃ vutte, kevaṭṭa, cattāro mahārājāno taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘mayampi kho, bhikkhu, na jānāma, yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu, āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātūti. Atthi kho, bhikkhu, tāvatiṃsā nāma devā amhehi abhikkantatarā ca paṇītatarā ca. Te kho etaṃ jāneyyuṃ, yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
mula_english:
489.
Then, Kevaṭṭa, that monk approached the Four Great Kings. Having approached, he said this to the Four Great Kings: ‘Where, friends, do these four great elements cease without remainder: namely, the earth element (*pathavīdhātu*), the water element (*āpodhātu*), the fire element (*tejodhātu*), and the air element (*vāyodhātu*)?’ When this was said, Kevaṭṭa, the Four Great Kings said this to that monk: ‘We also, monk, do not know where these four great elements cease without remainder: namely, the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’
But the Thirty-Three Gods (*tāvatiṃsā nāma devā*) are loftier and wiser than we are.
They may know where these four great elements cease without remainder: namely, the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.

mula_pali: 490. ‘‘Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu yena tāvatiṃsā devā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tāvatiṃse deve etadavoca – ‘kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti? Evaṃ vutte, kevaṭṭa, tāvatiṃsā devā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘mayampi kho, bhikkhu, na jānāma, yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātūti. Atthi kho, bhikkhu, sakko nāma devānamindo amhehi abhikkantataro ca paṇītataro ca. So kho etaṃ jāneyya, yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
mula_english:
490.
Then, Kevaṭṭa, that monk approached the Thirty-three Gods (Tāvatiṃsā devā). Having approached, he said this to the Thirty-three Gods: ‘Where, friends (āvuso), do these four great elements (cattāro mahābhūtā) – namely, the earth element (pathavīdhātu), the water element (āpodhātu), the fire element (tejodhātu), and the air element (vāyodhātu) – cease without remainder (aparisesā nirujjhanti)?’ When this was said, Kevaṭṭa, the Thirty-three Gods said this to that monk: ‘We also, monk (bhikkhu), do not know where these four great elements (cattāro mahābhūtā) – namely, the earth element (pathavīdhātu), the water element (āpodhātu), the fire element (tejodhātu), and the air element (vāyodhātu) – cease without remainder (aparisesā nirujjhanti).

There is, monk (bhikkhu), Sakka (śakko), the lord of the gods (devānamindo), who is more advanced and refined than us.

He would know where these four great elements (cattāro mahābhūtā) – namely, the earth element (pathavīdhātu), the water element (āpodhātu), the fire element (tejodhātu), and the air element (vāyodhātu) – cease without remainder (aparisesā nirujjhanti).’

mula_pali: 491. ‘‘Atha  kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu yena sakko devānamindo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavoca – ‘kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti? Evaṃ vutte, kevaṭṭa, sakko devānamindo taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca – ‘ahampi kho, bhikkhu, na  jānāmi, yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātūti. Atthi kho, bhikkhu, yāmā nāma devā…pe… suyāmo nāma devaputto…  tusitā nāma devā… santussito nāma devaputto… nimmānaratī  nāma devā … sunimmito nāma devaputto… paranimmitavasavattī nāma devā… vasavattī nāma devaputto amhehi abhikkantataro ca paṇītataro ca. So kho etaṃ jāneyya, yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
mula_english:
491.
Then, Kevaṭṭa, that monk approached Śakra, the lord of the gods; having approached, he said this to Śakra, the lord of the gods: ‘Where, friend, do these four great elements ( *cattāro mahābhūtā* )—the earth element ( *pathavīdhātu* ), the water element ( *āpodhātu* ), the fire element ( *tejodhātu* ), and the air element ( *vāyodhātu* )—cease without remainder ( *aparisesā nirujjhanti* )?’ When this was said, Kevaṭṭa, Śakra, the lord of the gods, said this to that monk: ‘I, too, monk, do not know where these four great elements—the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element—cease without remainder.

There are, monk, gods called the Yāmas… Suyāma is a son of the gods… There are gods called the Tuṣitas… Saṃtuṣita is a son of the gods… There are gods called the Nirmāṇaratis… Sunirmita is a son of the gods… There are gods called the Paranirmita-vaśavattins… Vaśavartin is a son of the gods, and is more advanced and refined than us.

He would know where these four great elements—the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element—cease without remainder.
commentary_pali: 491-493. Ayaṃ pana viseso – sakko kira devarājā cintesi ‘‘ayaṃ pañho buddhavisayo, na sakkā aññena vissajjituṃ, ayañca bhikkhu aggiṃ pahāya khajjopanakaṃ dhamanto viya, bheriṃ pahāya udaraṃ vādento viya ca, loke aggapuggalaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ pahāya devatā pucchanto vicarati, pesemi naṃ satthusantika’’nti. Tato punadeva so cintesi ‘‘sudūrampi gantvā satthu santikeva nikkaṅkho bhavissati . Atthi ceva puggalo nāmesa, thokaṃ tāva āhiṇḍanto kilamatu pacchā jānissatī’’ti. Tato taṃ ‘‘ahampi kho’’tiādimāha. Brahmayāniyopi devayāniyasadisova. Devayāniyamaggoti vā brahmayāniyamaggoti vā dhammasetūti vā ekacittakkhaṇikaappanāti vā sanniṭṭhānikacetanāti vā mahaggatacittanti vā abhiññāñāṇanti vā sabbametaṃ iddhividhañāṇasseva nāmaṃ.
commentary_english:
491-493. Now, in this connection, Śakra, the lord of the gods, thought: "This question is within the Buddha's domain; it cannot be answered by anyone else. And this monk, abandoning the fire, is fanning a firefly; abandoning the drum, he is playing on his belly; in the world, abandoning the foremost individual, the perfectly enlightened Buddha (sammāsambuddha), he wanders about questioning the deities. I shall send him to the Teacher's presence."

Then again, he thought: "Even having gone very far, he will become free from doubt only in the Teacher's presence.

There is indeed a person called such-and-such; let him wander about a little while and grow weary; afterwards he will know."

Then he spoke to him, beginning with "I too..."

The path of Brahmā is similar to the path of the gods (devayāniya).

Whether it is called the path of the gods (devayāniyamagga), or the path of Brahmā (brahmayāniyamagga), or the bridge of Dharma (dhammasetū), or one-pointed concentration in a single moment of consciousness (ekacittakkhaṇikaappanā), or conclusive intention (sanniṭṭhānikacetanā), or exalted consciousness (mahaggatacitta), or the knowledge of higher powers (abhiññāñāṇa), all of this is simply a name for the knowledge of the various kinds of psychic power (iddhividhañāṇa).

mula_pali: 492. ‘‘Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu yena vasavattī devaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā vasavattiṃ devaputtaṃ  etadavoca – ‘kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti? Evaṃ vutte , kevaṭṭa, vasavattī devaputto taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca – ‘ahampi kho, bhikkhu, na jānāmi yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātūti. Atthi kho, bhikkhu, brahmakāyikā nāma devā amhehi abhikkantatarā ca paṇītatarā ca. Te kho etaṃ jāneyyuṃ, yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
mula_english:
492.

Then, Kevatta, that monk approached the deva-son Vasavattī; having approached, he said this to the deva-son Vasavattī: ‘Where, friend, do these four great elements ( *cattāro mahābhūtā* )—the earth element (*pathavīdhātu*), the water element (*āpodhātu*), the fire element (*tejodhātu*), and the air element (*vāyodhātu*)—cease without remainder ( *aparisesā nirujjhanti*)?’ When this was said, Kevatta, the deva-son Vasavattī said this to that monk: ‘I, too, monk, do not know where these four great elements—the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element—cease without remainder.

But, monk, there are devas called Brahmakāyikas who are superior and more refined than us.

They may know where these four great elements—the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element—cease without remainder.’
commentary_pali: 491-493. Ayaṃ pana viseso – sakko kira devarājā cintesi ‘‘ayaṃ pañho buddhavisayo, na sakkā aññena vissajjituṃ, ayañca bhikkhu aggiṃ pahāya khajjopanakaṃ dhamanto viya, bheriṃ pahāya udaraṃ vādento viya ca, loke aggapuggalaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ pahāya devatā pucchanto vicarati, pesemi naṃ satthusantika’’nti. Tato punadeva so cintesi ‘‘sudūrampi gantvā satthu santikeva nikkaṅkho bhavissati . Atthi ceva puggalo nāmesa, thokaṃ tāva āhiṇḍanto kilamatu pacchā jānissatī’’ti. Tato taṃ ‘‘ahampi kho’’tiādimāha. Brahmayāniyopi devayāniyasadisova. Devayāniyamaggoti vā brahmayāniyamaggoti vā dhammasetūti vā ekacittakkhaṇikaappanāti vā sanniṭṭhānikacetanāti vā mahaggatacittanti vā abhiññāñāṇanti vā sabbametaṃ iddhividhañāṇasseva nāmaṃ.
commentary_english:
491-493. Now, this is the distinction: Śakra, the lord of the gods, thought, "This question is within the Buddha's domain; it cannot be answered by anyone else. And this *bhikṣu* has abandoned the fire and is fanning a firefly, as it were; he has abandoned the drum and is playing on his belly, as it were; he has abandoned the foremost individual in the world, the perfectly awakened *samyaksambuddha*, and is wandering about questioning the deities. I shall send him to the Teacher's presence."

Then again, he thought, "Even having gone very far, he will be without doubt only in the Teacher's presence.

There is indeed a person named such-and-such. Let him wander about a little while and become weary; afterwards, he will know."

Then he said to him, beginning with, "I too..."

The path to Brahma is similar to the path to the gods (*devayāniya*).

Whether it is called the path to the gods (*devayāniyamagga*), or the path to Brahmā (*brahmayāniyamagga*), or the bridge of *dharma* (*dharmasetū*), or one-moment-of-thought absorption (*ekacittakkhaṇikaappanā*), or conclusive intention (*sanniṭṭhānikacetanā*), or exalted thought (*mahaggatacitta*), or the knowledge of higher powers (*abhiññāñāṇa*), all of this is simply a name for the knowledge of the various kinds of psychic power (*iddhi-vidha-ñāṇa*).

mula_pali: 493. ‘‘Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu tathārūpaṃ samādhiṃ samāpajji, yathāsamāhite citte brahmayāniyo maggo pāturahosi. Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu yena brahmakāyikā devā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā brahmakāyike deve etadavoca – ‘kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti? Evaṃ vutte, kevaṭṭa, brahmakāyikā devā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘mayampi kho, bhikkhu, na  jānāma, yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātūti. Atthi kho, bhikkhu, brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro  kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ amhehi abhikkantataro ca paṇītataro ca. So kho etaṃ jāneyya, yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’’ti. ‘‘‘Kahaṃ panāvuso, etarahi so mahābrahmā’ti? ‘Mayampi kho, bhikkhu, na jānāma, yattha vā brahmā yena vā brahmā yahiṃ vā brahmā; api ca, bhikkhu, yathā nimittā dissanti, āloko sañjāyati, obhāso pātubhavati, brahmā pātubhavissati, brahmuno hetaṃ pubbanimittaṃ pātubhāvāya, yadidaṃ āloko sañjāyati, obhāso pātubhavatī’ti. Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, mahābrahmā nacirasseva pāturahosi .
mula_english:
493. "Then that monk, Kevatta, attained to such a state of concentration ( *samādhiṃ samāpajji*) that the path to the Brahma-world appeared in his mind which was thus concentrated.

Then that monk, Kevatta, approached the deities of Brahma's retinue (*brahmakāyikā devā*); having approached, he said to the deities of Brahma's retinue: ‘Where, friends (*āvuso*), do these four great elements (*cattāro mahābhūtā*)—namely, the earth element (*pathavīdhātu*), the water element (*āpodhātu*), the fire element (*tejodhātu*), and the air element (*vāyodhātu*)—cease without remainder (*aparisesā nirujjhanti*)?’ When this was said, Kevatta, the deities of Brahma's retinue said to that monk: ‘We, too, monk, do not know where these four great elements—namely, the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element—cease without remainder.

But there is Brahmā, monk, the Great Brahmā (*mahābrahmā*), the Conqueror (*abhibhū*), the Unconquered (*anabhibhūto*), the All-Seeing, the All-Powerful (*vasavattī*), the Lord (*issaro*), the Maker (*kattā*), the Creator (*nimmātā*), the Chief (*seṭṭho*), the Appointer (*sajitā*), the Ruler (*vasī*), the Father of all that have been and shall be (*pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ*). He is mightier and more glorious than we.

He would know where these four great elements cease without remainder—namely, the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’

‘But where, friend, is that Great Brahmā now?’ ‘We, too, monk, do not know where Brahmā is, how Brahmā is, or where Brahmā is; but, monk, just as signs appear, a light (*āloko*) arises, a radiance (*obhāso*) manifests, Brahmā will appear; this is the preliminary sign of Brahmā’s appearance, namely, that a light arises, a radiance manifests.’

Then, Kevatta, the Great Brahmā soon appeared.
commentary_pali: 491-493. Ayaṃ pana viseso – sakko kira devarājā cintesi ‘‘ayaṃ pañho buddhavisayo, na sakkā aññena vissajjituṃ, ayañca bhikkhu aggiṃ pahāya khajjopanakaṃ dhamanto viya, bheriṃ pahāya udaraṃ vādento viya ca, loke aggapuggalaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ pahāya devatā pucchanto vicarati, pesemi naṃ satthusantika’’nti.
