Ni.

6.

57) He says.

The blue class (*nīlābhijāti*) is made up of monks (*bhikkhū*). For monks (*bhikkhū*), he says, eat having thrown thorns (*kaṇṭake*) into the four requisites (*paccaya*).
“Monks have thorny behavior," (a.
ni.
6.
57) this is exactly its *pāli*.
Or alternatively, he says that some who have gone forth have thorny behavior.
The red class is made up of the one-robed he Nigaóþhas; he says.
for these are purer than the former two.
Householders wearing white clothes are disciples of the ascetics and belong to the turmeric class; he says.
Thus he makes his own lay supporters superior even to the Nigaóþhas.
The Ājīvakas and female Ājīvikas belong to the ultimate white class, he declares.
for these, he says, are purer than the previous four.
The ultimate white class is made up of Nanda Vaccha, Kisa Saòkiccha, and Makkhali Gosála; (a.
ni.
6.
57) He says.
for they are the purest of all.
He declares that there are eight stages in the life of man: the stage of feebleness; the stage of play; the stage of learning to walk; the erect stage; the stage of training; the recluse stage; the conqueror stage; and the prostrate stage.
The stage of feebleness : this lasts for seven days following the day of birth; for after coming out from the womb beings are feeble and dull. He says, this is the stage of feebleness.
The stage of play : those who have come from an evil destination often cry and howl; those who come from a good destination remember it and laugh. This is called the stage of play.
The stage of learning to walk : this is the stage when the child takes hold of its parents’ hands or feet, or a bed or chair, and places its feet on the ground. This is called the stage of learning to walk.
The erect stage : this is the stage when it is able to walk on its feet.
The stage of training : this is the stage when one has been trained in a craft.
The recluse stage : this is the time when one has renounced the household life and gone forth .
The conqueror stage : this is the time when, having served a teacher, one knows.
The monk, learned, victorious, does not say anything: thus he calls the monk who obtains nothing, the prostrate stage.
Forty-nine Ājīvaka hundreds means forty-nine hundred ways of Ājīvaka life.
Wandering mendicant hundreds means hundreds of wandering mendicant ordinations.
Nāga abodes hundreds means hundreds of Nāga *maṇḍalas*.
Sense faculty twenties means twenty hundred sense faculties.
Hell thirties means thirty hundred hells.
“Thirty-six realms of dust”: places where dust accumulates; he says this referring to the backs of the hands, bottom of the feet, etc.
“Seven spheres of percipient beings”: he says this referring to camels, oxen, donkeys, goats, cattle, deer, and buffaloes.
“Seven spheres of non-percipient beings”: he says this referring to rice, paddy, barley, wheat, millet, beans, and *kadrūsaka*.
“Seven kinds of jointed plants”: plants grown from joints; he refers to sugarcane, bamboo, reeds, etc.
“Seven kinds of gods”: there are many kinds of gods,
but he says there are seven.
Human beings, too, are of infinite kinds, but he says there are seven.
“Seven kinds of demons” : there are numerous kinds of demons, but he says there are seven.
“Seven great lakes”: he says this mentioning the Kaṇṇamuṇḍa, Rathakāra, Anotatta, Sìhappapáta, Chaddanta, Mandákinì, and Kuṇáladaha.
The toggle is allowable.
It falls, thus it is a great fall (papātāti mahāpapātā).
There are hundreds of falls, thus there are minor hundreds of falls (papātasatānīti khuddakapapātasatāni).
He sleeps, thus it is a great sleep (supināti mahāsupinā).
There are hundreds of dreams, thus there are minor hundreds of dreams (supinasatānīti khuddakasupinasatāni).
He is of a great aeon, thus he is among the great aeons (mahākappinoti mahākappānaṃ).
There, he describes the duration of a great aeon as the time it would take to drain a single great lake (mahāsarā) seven times by removing a single drop of water (udakabinduṃ) with the tip of a blade of *kuśa*-grass (*kusaggena*) once every hundred years (tattha ekamhā mahāsarā vassasate vassasate kusaggena ekaṃ udakabinduṃ nīharitvā sattakkhattuṃ tamhi sare nirudake kate eko mahākappoti vadati).
His theory asserts that when eighty-four hundred thousand of such great aeons have passed, the foolish (*bāle*) and the wise (*paṇḍite*) make an end to suffering (evarūpānaṃ mahākappānaṃ caturāsītisatasahassāni khepetvā bāle ca paṇḍite ca dukkhassantaṃ karontīti ayamassa laddhi).
The wise man, he says, cannot purify himself beforehand (paṇḍitopi kira antarā visujjhituṃ na sakkoti).
and the fool does not continue on beyond (bālopi tato uddhaṃ na gacchati).
By this moral discipline (śīlena), whether by the moral discipline of the naked ascetics (*acelakasīlena*) or by any other (sīlenāti acelakasīlena vā aññena vā yena kenaci).
“Observance” should be understood similarly (vatenāti tādiseneva vatena).
Through austerity, it is through the action of austerity (tapenāti tapokammena).
That the one who considers himself a wise man should “ripen unripened karma” i.e. that he should purify himself beforehand (aparipakkaṃ paripāceti nāma, yo ‘‘ahaṃ paṇḍito’’ti antarā visujjhati).
or “eliminate ripened karma whenever it comes up,” or that the one who considers himself a fool should continue on beyond the time stated to be the limits (paripakkaṃ phussa phussa byantiṃ karoti nāma yo ‘‘ahaṃ bālo’’ti vuttaparimāṇaṃ kālaṃ atikkamitvā yāti).
“that cannot be,” that cannot be (hevaṃ natthīti evaṃ natthi).
i.e. neither is able to do that (tañhi ubhayampi na sakkā kātunti dīpeti).
Measured by a *droṇa*, it is as if measured by a *droṇa* (doṇamiteti doṇena mitaṃ viya).
Pleasure and pain, it is pleasure and pain (sukhadukkheti sukhadukkhaṃ).
The limit having been made, it is with a limit made at a time that has been stated (pariyantakateti vuttaparimāṇena kālena katapariyante).
There is no decrease or increase, there are no decrease or increase (natthihāyanavaḍḍhaneti natthi hāyanavaḍḍhanāni).
“Saṃsāra’s limits … . can neither be shortened nor extended”: saṃsāra is not shortened for the wise man, nor extended for the fool (na saṃsāro paṇḍitassa hāyati, na bālassa vaḍḍhatīti attho).
Elevation and degradation, it is elevation and degradation (ukkaṃsāvakaṃseti ukkaṃsāvakaṃsā).
This is a term for decrease and increase (hāyanavaḍḍhanānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ).
Now, illustrating that meaning by way of a simile, he said, “Just as, for example…” and so on (idāni tamatthaṃ upamāya sādhento ‘‘seyyathāpi nāmā’’tiādimāha).
There, a ball of thread, it is a ball of thread that has been wound (tattha suttaguḷeti veṭhetvā katasuttaguḷe).
Because it flees as it is being unwound, having stood on a mountain (pabbate) or at the top of a tree (rukkagge), it goes as it is being unwound according to the measure of the thread (sutta), when the thread (sutte) is exhausted, it remains right there, it does not go (nibbeṭhiyamānameva paletīti pabbate vā rukkhagge vā ṭhatvā khittaṃ suttappamāṇena nibbeṭhiyamānameva gacchati, sutte khīṇe tattheva tiṭṭhati, na gacchati).
Just so, he shows that one does not go beyond the time that has been stated (evameva vuttakālato uddhaṃ na gacchatīti dasseti).

mula_pali: 169. ‘‘Itthaṃ kho me, bhante, makkhali gosālo sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno saṃsārasuddhiṃ byākāsi. Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṃ vā puṭṭho labujaṃ byākareyya, labujaṃ vā puṭṭho ambaṃ byākareyya; evameva kho me, bhante, makkhali gosālo sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno saṃsārasuddhiṃ byākāsi. Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, etadahosi – ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā vijite vasantaṃ apasādetabbaṃ maññeyyā’ti. So kho ahaṃ, bhante, makkhalissa gosālassa  bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ. Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano, anattamanavācaṃ anicchāretvā, tameva vācaṃ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ.
mula_english:
169. Thus, venerable sir, when I asked Makkhali Gosāla about a visible fruit of recluseship, he explained to me purification through wandering in *saṃsāra* (saṃsārasuddhiṃ).

Venerable sir, just as if one asked about a mango would speak about a breadfruit, or as if one asked about a breadfruit would speak about a mango, in the same way, when I asked Makkhali Gosāla about a visible fruit of recluseship, he explained to me purification through wandering in *saṃsāra* (saṃsārasuddhiṃ).

Then, venerable sir, I thought to myself: ‘One like myself should not think of troubling a *śramaṇa* or *brāhmaṇa* (samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā) living in his realm.’

So I neither applauded nor rejected Makkhali Gosāla’s words.

Without accepting his doctrine, without rejecting it, feeling dissatisfied and without uttering words of dissatisfaction, I got up from my seat and left.
commentary_pali: 167-169. Makkhalivāde  paccayoti hetuvevacanameva, ubhayenāpi vijjamānameva kāyaduccaritādīnaṃ saṃkilesapaccayaṃ, kāyasucaritādīnañca visuddhipaccayaṃ paṭikkhipati. Attakāreti attakāro. Yena attanā katakammena ime sattā  devattampi mārattampi brahmattampi sāvakabodhimpi paccekabodhimpi sabbaññutampi pāpuṇanti, tampi paṭikkhipati. Dutiyapadena yaṃ parakāraṃ parassa ovādānusāsaniṃ nissāya ṭhapetvā mahāsattaṃ avaseso jano manussasobhagyataṃ ādiṃ katvā yāva arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti, taṃ parakāraṃ paṭikkhipati. Evamayaṃ bālo jinacakke pahāraṃ deti nāma. Natthi purisakāreti yena purisakārena sattā vuttappakārā sampattiyo pāpuṇanti , tampi paṭikkhipati. Natthi balanti yamhi attano bale patiṭṭhitā sattā vīriyaṃ katvā tā sampattiyo pāpuṇanti, taṃ balaṃ paṭikkhipati. Natthi vīriyantiādīni sabbāni purisakāravevacanāneva. ‘‘Idaṃ no vīriyena idaṃ purisathāmena, idaṃ purisaparakkamena pavatta’’nti evaṃ pavattavacanapaṭikkhepakaraṇavasena panetāni visuṃ ādiyanti. Sabbe sattāti oṭṭhagoṇagadrabhādayo anavasese pariggaṇhāti. Sabbe pāṇāti ekindriyo pāṇo, dvindriyo pāṇotiādivasena vadati. Sabbe bhūtāti aṇḍakosavatthikosesu bhūte sandhāya vadati. Sabbe jīvāti sāliyavagodhumādayo sandhāya vadati. Tesu hi so virūhanabhāvena jīvasaññī. Avasā abalā avīriyāti tesaṃ attano vaso vā balaṃ vā vīriyaṃ vā natthi. Niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatāti ettha niyatīti niyatā. Saṅgatīti channaṃ abhijātīnaṃ tattha tattha gamanaṃ. Bhāvoti sabhāvoyeva. Evaṃ niyatiyā ca saṅgatiyā ca bhāvena ca pariṇatā nānappakārataṃ pattā. Yena hi yathā bhavitabbaṃ, so tatheva bhavati. Yena na bhavitabbaṃ, so na bhavatīti dasseti. Chasvevābhijātīsūti chasu eva abhijātīsu ṭhatvā sukhañca dukkhañca paṭisaṃvedenti. Aññā sukhadukkhabhūmi natthīti dasseti. Yonipamukhasatasahassānīti pamukhayonīnaṃ uttamayonīnaṃ  cuddasasatasahassāni aññāni ca saṭṭhisatāni aññāni ca chasatāni. Pañca ca kammunosatānīti pañcakammasatāni ca. Kevalaṃ takkamattakena niratthakaṃ diṭṭhiṃ dīpeti. Pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammānītiādīsupi eseva nayo. Keci panāhu – ‘‘pañca ca kammānīti pañcindriyavasena bhaṇati. Tīṇīti kāyakammādivasenā’’ti. Kamme ca upaḍḍhakamme cāti ettha panassa kāyakammañca vacīkammañca kammanti laddhi, manokammaṃ upaḍḍhakammanti. Dvaṭṭhipaṭipadāti dvāsaṭṭhi paṭipadāti vadati. Dvaṭṭhantarakappāti ekasmiṃ kappe catusaṭṭhi antarakappā nāma honti. Ayaṃ pana aññe dve ajānanto evamāha. Chaḷābhijātiyoti kaṇhābhijāti, nīlābhijāti, lohitābhijāti, haliddābhijāti, sukkābhijāti, paramasukkābhijātīti imā cha abhijātiyo vadati. Tattha orabbhikā, sākuṇikā, māgavikā, sūkarikā, luddā, macchaghātakā corā, coraghātakā, bandhanāgārikā, ye vā panaññepi keci kurūrakammantā, ayaṃ kaṇhābhijātīti (a. ni. 6.57) vadati. Bhikkhū nīlābhijātīti vadati, te kira catūsu paccayesu kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādanti. ‘‘Bhikkhū kaṇṭakavuttikā’’ti (a. ni. 6.57) ayañhissa pāḷiyeva. Atha vā  kaṇṭakavuttikā eva nāma eke pabbajitāti vadati. Lohitābhijāti nāma nigaṇṭhā ekasāṭakāti vadati. Ime kira purimehi dvīhi paṇḍaratarā. Gihī odātavasanā acelakasāvakā haliddābhijātīti vadati. Evaṃ attano paccayadāyake nigaṇṭhehipi jeṭṭhakatare karoti. Ājīvakā ājīvakiniyo sukkābhijātīti vadati. Te kira purimehi catūhi paṇḍaratarā. Nando, vaccho, kiso, saṅkiccho, makkhaligosālo, paramasukkābhijātīti (a. ni. 6.57) vadati. Te kira sabbehi paṇḍaratarā. Aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti mandabhūmi, khiḍḍābhūmi, padavīmaṃsabhūmi, ujugatabhūmi, sekkhabhūmi, samaṇabhūmi , jinabhūmi, pannabhūmīti imā aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti vadati. Tattha jātadivasato paṭṭhāya sattadivase sambādhaṭṭhānato nikkhantattā sattā mandā honti momūhā, ayaṃ mandabhūmīti vadati. Ye pana duggatito āgatā honti, te abhiṇhaṃ rodanti ceva viravanti ca, sugatito āgatā taṃ anussaritvā hasanti, ayaṃ khiḍḍābhūmi nāma. Mātāpitūnaṃ hatthaṃ vā pādaṃ vā mañcaṃ vā pīṭhaṃ vā gahetvā bhūmiyaṃ padanikkhipanaṃ padavīmaṃsabhūmi nāma. Padasā gantuṃ samatthakāle ujugatabhūmi nāma. Sippāni sikkhitakāle  sekkhabhūmi nāma. Gharā nikkhamma pabbajitakāle samaṇabhūmi nāma. Ācariyaṃ sevitvā jānanakāle jinabhūmi nāma. Bhikkhu ca pannako jino na kiñci āhāti evaṃ alābhiṃ samaṇaṃ pannabhūmīti vadati. Ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasateti ekūnapaññāsaājīvakavuttisatāni. Paribbājakasateti paribbājakapabbajjāsatāni. Nāgāvāsasateti nāgamaṇḍalasatāni. Vīse indriyasateti vīsatindriyasatāni. Tiṃse nirayasateti tiṃsa nirayasatāni. Rajodhātuyoti rajaokiraṇaṭṭhānāni, hatthapiṭṭhipādapiṭṭhādīni sandhāya vadati. Satta saññīgabbhāti oṭṭhagoṇagadrabhaajapasumigamahiṃse sandhāya vadati. Satta asaññīgabbhāti sālivīhiyavagodhūmakaṅguvarakakudrūsake sandhāya vadati. Nigaṇṭhigabbhāti gaṇṭhimhi jātagabbhā, ucchuveḷunaḷādayo sandhāya vadati. Satta devāti bahū devā. So pana sattāti vadati. Manussāpi anantā, so sattāti vadati. Sattapisācāti pisācā mahantamahantā sattāti vadati. Sarāti mahāsarā, kaṇṇamuṇḍarathakāraanotattasīhappapātachaddantamandākinīkuṇāladahe gahetvā vadati. Pavuṭāti gaṇṭhikā. Papātāti mahāpapātā. Papātasatānīti khuddakapapātasatāni. Supināti mahāsupinā. Supinasatānīti khuddakasupinasatāni. Mahākappinoti mahākappānaṃ. Tattha  ekamhā mahāsarā vassasate vassasate kusaggena ekaṃ udakabinduṃ nīharitvā sattakkhattuṃ tamhi sare nirudake kate eko mahākappoti vadati. Evarūpānaṃ mahākappānaṃ caturāsītisatasahassāni khepetvā bāle ca paṇḍite ca dukkhassantaṃ karontīti ayamassa laddhi. Paṇḍitopi kira antarā visujjhituṃ na sakkoti. Bālopi tato uddhaṃ na gacchati. Sīlenāti acelakasīlena vā aññena vā yena kenaci. Vatenāti tādiseneva vatena. Tapenāti tapokammena. Aparipakkaṃ paripāceti nāma, yo ‘‘ahaṃ paṇḍito’’ti antarā visujjhati. Paripakkaṃ phussa phussa byantiṃ karoti nāma yo ‘‘ahaṃ bālo’’ti vuttaparimāṇaṃ kālaṃ atikkamitvā yāti. Hevaṃ natthīti evaṃ natthi. Tañhi ubhayampi na sakkā  kātunti dīpeti. Doṇamiteti doṇena mitaṃ viya. Sukhadukkheti sukhadukkhaṃ. Pariyantakateti vuttaparimāṇena kālena katapariyante. Natthihāyanavaḍḍhaneti natthi hāyanavaḍḍhanāni. Na saṃsāro paṇḍitassa hāyati, na bālassa vaḍḍhatīti attho. Ukkaṃsāvakaṃseti ukkaṃsāvakaṃsā. Hāyanavaḍḍhanānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Idāni tamatthaṃ upamāya sādhento ‘‘seyyathāpi nāmā’’tiādimāha. Tattha suttaguḷeti veṭhetvā katasuttaguḷe. Nibbeṭhiyamānameva paletīti pabbate vā rukkhagge vā ṭhatvā khittaṃ suttappamāṇena nibbeṭhiyamānameva gacchati, sutte khīṇe tattheva tiṭṭhati, na gacchati. Evameva vuttakālato uddhaṃ na gacchatīti dasseti.
commentary_english:
167-169.

In the doctrine of Makkhali, *paccaya* means only *hetuvevacana*. By both [words], he rejects the real condition (*saṃkilesapaccaya*) for defilement, i.e. wrong bodily conduct (*kāyaduccarita*) etc., and the real condition (*visuddhipaccaya*) for purification, i.e. right bodily conduct (*kāyasucarita*) etc.

"Self-determination" means self-determination (*attakāro*).

He also rejects the *kamma* by which beings attain godhood (*devattaṃ*), the state of Māra (*mārattaṃ*), the state of Brahmā (*brahmattampi*), the enlightenment of a disciple (*sāvakabodhiṃ*), the enlightenment of a *paccekabuddha* (*paccekabodhiṃ*), or omniscience (*sabbaññutaṃ*).

By the second term, he rejects that determination by others (*parakāraṃ*) in dependence upon the exhortation and instruction (*ovādānusāsaniṃ*) of others, by which all people except the Great Being (*mahāsattaṃ*) attain from good fortune in the human state (*manussasobhagyataṃ*) up to arhatship (*arahattaṃ*).

Thus this fool strikes a blow at the Wheel of the Conqueror (*jinacakke*)!

"No personal determination" (*purisakāreti*): he rejects the personal determination (*purisakārena*) through which beings attain the aforementioned kinds of success (*sampattiyo*).

“No power” (*balanti*): he denies that beings can establish themselves upon their own power (*bale*), arouse their energy (*vīriyaṃ katvā*), and attain those kinds of success (*sampattiyo*).

"No energy," etc., all these are but synonyms for personal determination (*purisakāra*).

They are brought in separately in order to reject the claim: “This has occurred through our energy (*vīriyena*), this through personal strength (*purisathāmena*), and this through personal fortitude (*purisaparakkamena*)."

“All sentient beings” (*sabbe sattāti*): he includes camels (*oṭṭha*), oxen (*goṇa*), donkeys (*gadrabha*), etc., without exception (*anavasese*).

“All living beings” (*sabbe pāṇāti*): he says this with reference to creatures having one faculty (*ekindriyo pāṇo*) or two faculties (*dvindriyo pāṇo*), etc.

“All creatures” (*sabbe bhūtāti*): this refers to beings born from eggs (*aṇḍakosa*) or from the womb (*vatthikosesu bhūte*).

“All souls” (*sabbe jīvāti*): this refers to rice (*sāli*), barley (*yava*), wheat (*godhuma*), etc.

because they undergo growth (*virūhanabhāvena*), he regards them as having souls (*jīvasaññī*).

"Are helpless (*avasā*), powerless (*abalā*), devoid of energy (*avīriyāti*)": they have no self-control (*vaso*), power (*balaṃ*), or energy (*vīriyaṃ*).

"Necessity, circumstance, nature, and transformation" (*niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatāti*): here, *niyatīti* means fixed.

“Circumstance” (*saṅgatīti*) : going here and there (*tattha tattha gamanaṃ*) among the six classes (*channaṃ abhijātīnaṃ*).

“Nature” (*bhāvoti*): the inner nature (*sabhāvoyeva*).

Thus, having attained various forms (*nānappakārataṃ pattā*) through necessity (*niyatiyā*), circumstance (*saṅgatiyā*), nature (*bhāvena*), and transformation (*pariṇatā*).

Whatever will be will be (*yathā bhavitabbaṃ*); that is how it is (*tatheva bhavati*).

He shows that whatever will not be will not be (*na bhavatīti dasseti*).

“The six classes of men” (*chasvevābhijātīsūti*): abiding in the six classes of men (*chasu eva abhijātīsu ṭhatvā*), they experience pleasure (*sukhañca*) and pain (*dukkhañca*).

He shows that there is no other plane of pleasure and pain (*sukhadukkhabhūmi*).

"Hundreds of thousands of wombs, beginning with the womb (*yonipamukha*)" means 146,600 superior wombs (*paramukhayonīnaṃ uttamayonīnaṃ  cuddasasatasahassāni*) and 600 others, and 600 others.

"Five hundred kinds of *kamma*" means five hundred kinds of *kamma* (*pañcakammasatāni*).

He explains a senseless view (*niratthakaṃ diṭṭhiṃ dīpeti*) devised solely by mere reasoning (*takkamattakena*).

The same principle (*nayo*) applies in the case of five kinds of *kamma* (*pañca ca kammāni*), three kinds of *kamma* (*tīṇi ca kammāni*), etc.

But some say: “He speaks of five kinds of *kamma* by way of the five sense faculties (*pañcindriyavasena*).

and three kinds by way of bodily *kamma* (*kāyakammādivasena*)."

“Full *kamma* and half-*kamma* (*upaddhakamma*)”: here his theory (*laddhi*) is that bodily *kamma* (*kāyakammañca*) and verbal *kamma* (*vacīkammañca*) are full *kamma* (*kammanti*), and mental *kamma* (*manokammaṃ*) is half-*kamma* (*upaḍḍhakammanti*).

“Sixty-two pathways (*dvaṭṭhipaṭipadāti*)” means he speaks of sixty-two pathways (*dvāsaṭṭhi paṭipadāti vadati*).

“Sixty-two sub-aeons (*dvaṭṭhantarakappa*)" means in a single great aeon (*ekasmiṃ kappe*) there are sixty-four sub-aeons (*catusaṭṭhi antarakappā*) .

But since he does not know about two of these (*aññe dve ajānanto*), he says this (*evamāha*).

He declares that there are six classes of men (*chaḷābhijātiyoti*): the black (*kaṇhābhijāti*), the blue (*nīlābhijāti*), the red (*lohitābhijāti*), the yellow (*haliddābhijāti*), the white (*sukkābhijāti*), and the ultimate white (*paramasukkābhijāti*).

The black class (*kaṇhābhijāti*) is made up of butchers (*orabbhikā*), hunters (*sākuṇikā*), trappers (*māgavikā*), pig-butchers (*sūkarikā*), hunters (*luddā*), fishermen (*macchaghātakā*), thieves (*corā*), executioners of thieves (*coraghātakā*), prison wardens (*bandhanāgārikā*), and those in other cruel lines of work (*kurūrakammantā*).

(A.

N.

6.
57) He says.

The blue class (*nīlābhijāti*) is made up of *bhikkhus*. For bhikkhus, he says, eat having thrown thorns (*kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādanti*) into the four requisites (*catūsu paccayesu*).
“Monks are thorny behavior” (bhikkhū kaṇṭakavuttikā) it is said.
Ni.
6.
57) This is indeed his Pāḷi text.
Or alternatively, he says that some who have gone forth are indeed called thorny behavior (kaṇṭakavuttikā).
The Nigaṇṭhas of the red class (lohitābhijāti) are made up of the one-robed, he says.
For these are purer than the former two (ime kira purimehi dvīhi paṇḍaratarā).
Lay followers who wear white robes are *acelakas* and *haliddābhijāti*, he says.
Thus he makes his own lay supporters superior even to the Nigaṇṭhas (evaṃ attano paccayadāyake nigaṇṭhehipi jeṭṭhakatare karoti).
The Ājīvakas and Ājīvakinīs are of the white class (sukkābhijāti), he says.
For these, he says, are purer than the previous four (te kira purimehi catūhi paṇḍaratarā).
Nanda, Vaccha, Kisa, Saṅkiccha, Makkhali Gosāla, and Paramasukkhābhijāti, it is said.
Ni.
6.
57) He says.
For they are the purest of all (te kira sabbehi paṇḍaratarā).
There are eight stages in the life of man (aṭṭha purisabhūmiyo): the stage of feebleness (mandabhūmi), the stage of play (khiḍḍābhūmi), the stage of learning to walk (padavīmaṃsabhūmi), the erect stage (ujugatabhūmi), the stage of training (sekkhabhūmi), the recluse stage (samaṇabhūmi), the conqueror stage (jinabhūmi), and the prostrate stage (pannabhūmīti). These are the eight stages in the life of man, he says.
The stage of feebleness (mandabhūmi): this lasts for seven days following the day of birth; for after coming out from the confined place (sambādhaṭṭhānato), beings are feeble (mandā) and dull (momūhā), this is called the stage of feebleness, he says.
The stage of play (khiḍḍābhūmi): those who have come from an evil destination (duggatito āgatā) often cry and howl; those who come from a good destination (sugatito āgatā) remember it and laugh, this is called the stage of play.
The stage of learning to walk (padavīmaṃsabhūmi): this is the stage when the child takes hold of its parents’ hands or feet, or a bed or chair, and places its feet on the ground, this is called the stage of learning to walk.
The erect stage (ujugatabhūmi): this is the stage when it is able to walk on its feet.
The stage of training (sekkhabhūmi): this is the stage when one has been trained in a craft.
The recluse stage (samaṇabhūmi): this is the time when one has renounced the household life and gone forth.
The conqueror stage (jinabhūmi): this is the time when, having served a teacher (ācariyaṃ sevitvā), one knows.
A monk, a wise man, a conqueror does not say anything; thus he calls the *samaṇa* who has not obtained anything the prostrate stage (pannabhūmi), he says.
Forty-nine Ājīvaka hundreds (ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasateti): forty-nine hundreds of Ājīvaka ways of life (ekūnapaññāsaājīvakavuttisatāni).
Wandering mendicant hundreds (paribbājakasateti): hundreds of wandering mendicant renunciations (paribbājakapabbajjāsatāni).
Nāga dwelling hundreds (nāgāvāsasateti): hundreds of Nāga circles (nāgamaṇḍalasatāni).
Twenty sense faculty hundreds (vīse indriyasateti): twenty hundreds of sense faculties (vīsatindriyasatāni).
Thirty hell hundreds (tiṃse nirayasateti): thirty hundreds of hells (tiṃsa nirayasatāni).
Thirty-six realms of dust (rajodhātuyo): places where dust accumulates (rajaokiraṇaṭṭhānāni); he says this referring to the backs of the hands, bottom of the feet, etc. (hatthapiṭṭhipādapiṭṭhādīni sandhāya vadati).
Seven spheres of percipient beings (satta saññīgabbhāti): he says this referring to camels (oṭṭha), oxen (goṇa), donkeys (gadrabha), goats (aja), cattle (pasu), deer (miga), and buffaloes (mahiṃse).
Seven spheres of non-percipient beings (satta asaññīgabbhāti): he says this referring to rice (sāli), paddy (vīhi), barley (yava), wheat (godhūma), millet (kaṅgu), beans (varaka), and kadrūsaka.
Seven kinds of jointed plants (nigaṇṭhigabbhāti): plants grown from joints (gaṇṭhimhi jātagabbhā); he refers to sugarcane (ucchu), bamboo (veḷu), reeds (naḷādayo), etc.
Seven kinds of gods (satta devāti): there are many kinds of gods (bahū devā).
But he says there are seven (so pana sattāti vadati).
Human beings, too, are of infinite kinds (manussāpi anantā), but he says there are seven (so sattāti vadati).
Seven kinds of demons (sattapisācāti): there are numerous kinds of demons, but he says there are seven (pisācā mahantamahantā sattāti vadati).
Seven great lakes (sarāti mahāsarā): he says this mentioning the Kaṇṇamuṇḍa, Rathakāra, Anotatta, Sìhappapāta, Chaddanta, Mandākinī, and Kuṇāladahe (gahetvā vadati).
Pavuṭā means toggles (gaṇṭhikā).
papātāti mahāpapātā: It fell; greatly it fell.
papātasatānīti khuddakapapātasatāni: Hundreds of falls; small hundreds of falls.
supināti mahāsupinā: He dreamt; he greatly dreamt.
supinasatānīti khuddakasupinasatāni: Hundreds of dreams; small hundreds of dreams.
mahākappinoti mahākappānaṃ: Of a great aeon; of great aeons.
tattha ekamhā mahāsarā vassasate vassasate kusaggena ekaṃ udakabinduṃ nīharitvā sattakkhattuṃ tamhi sare nirudake kate eko mahākappoti vadati: There, he describes the duration of a great aeon as the time it would take to drain a single great lake seven times by removing a single drop of water with the tip of a blade of *kuśa*-grass once every hundred years.
evarūpānaṃ mahākappānaṃ caturāsītisatasahassāni khepetvā bāle ca paṇḍite ca dukkhassantaṃ karontīti ayamassa laddhi: His theory asserts that when eighty-four hundred thousand of such great aeons have passed, the foolish and the wise make an end to suffering.
paṇḍitopi kira antarā visujjhituṃ na sakkoti: The wise man, he says, cannot purify himself before this.
bālopi tato uddhaṃ na gacchati: and the fool does not continue on beyond.
sīlenāti acelakasīlena vā aññena vā yena kenaci: By this moral discipline of the naked ascetics or by any other.
vatenāti tādiseneva vatena: “Observance” should be understood similarly.
tapenāti tapokammena: By austerity; by ascetic practice.
aparipakkaṃ paripāceti nāma, yo ‘‘ahaṃ paṇḍito’’ti antarā visujjhati: That the one who considers himself a wise man should “ripen unripened *karma*” i.e. that he should purify himself beforehand.
paripakkaṃ phussa phussa byantiṃ karoti nāma yo ‘‘ahaṃ bālo’’ti vuttaparimāṇaṃ kālaṃ atikkamitvā yāti: or “eliminate ripened *karma* whenever it comes up,” or that the one who considers himself a fool should continue on beyond the time stated to be the limits.
hevaṃ natthīti evaṃ natthi: “that cannot be.”
tañhi ubhayampi na sakkā  kātunti dīpeti: i.e. neither is able to do that.
doṇamiteti doṇena mitaṃ viya: Measured by a *droṇa*; as if measured by a *droṇa*.
sukhadukkheti sukhadukkhaṃ: Pleasure and pain; pleasure and pain.
pariyantakateti vuttaparimāṇena kālena katapariyante: Made an end; by the stated measure and time, an end is made.
natthihāyanavaḍḍhaneti natthi hāyanavaḍḍhanāni: There is no decrease or increase; there are no decrease or increase.
na saṃsāro paṇḍitassa hāyati, na bālassa vaḍḍhatīti attho: “*Saṃsāra*'s limits … . can neither be shortened nor extended": *saṃsāra* is not shortened for the wise man, nor extended for the fool.
ukkaṃsāvakaṃseti ukkaṃsāvakaṃsā: Praise and disparagement; praise and disparagement.
hāyanavaḍḍhanānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ: This is a term for decrease and increase.
idāni tamatthaṃ upamāya sādhento ‘‘seyyathāpi nāmā’’tiādimāha: Now, to accomplish that meaning by a simile, he said, "Just as, for example..." and so on.
tattha suttaguḷeti veṭhetvā katasuttaguḷe: There, a ball of thread; having wrapped, a ball of thread is made.
nibbeṭhiyamānameva paletīti pabbate vā rukkhagge vā ṭhatvā khittaṃ suttappamāṇena nibbeṭhiyamānameva gacchati, sutte khīṇe tattheva tiṭṭhati, na gacchati: It flees only as it unwinds; having stood on a mountain or at the top of a tree and thrown, it goes only as it unwinds according to the measure of the thread; when the thread is exhausted, it stays right there, it does not go.
evameva vuttakālato uddhaṃ na gacchatīti dasseti: Just so, he shows that one does not go beyond the stated time.

mula_pali: 170. ‘‘Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ yena ajito kesakambalo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā ajitena kesakambalena saddhiṃ sammodiṃ. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ahaṃ, bhante, ajitaṃ kesakambalaṃ etadavocaṃ – ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho ajita, puthusippāyatanāni…pe… sakkā nu kho, bho ajita, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetu’nti?
mula_english:
“Venerable sir, on one occasion I approached Ajita Kesakambala; having approached Ajita Kesakambala, I exchanged greetings with him.

After exchanging courteous greetings and polite conversation, I sat down to one side.

Having sat down to one side, venerable sir, I said this to Ajita Kesakambala: ‘Just as these various crafts (puthusippāyatanāni)… and so on… is it possible, sir, to point out in the same way a visible fruit of the life of a recluse (sāmaññaphalaṃ) in this very life (diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ)?’”
commentary_pali: 170-172. Ajitavāde natthi dinnanti dinnaphalābhāvaṃ sandhāya vadati. Yiṭṭhaṃ vuccati mahāyāgo. Hutanti paheṇakasakkāro adhippeto. Tampi ubhayaṃ phalābhāvameva sandhāya paṭikkhipati. Sukatadukkaṭānanti sukatadukkaṭānaṃ, kusalākusalānanti attho. Phalaṃ vipākoti yaṃ phalanti vā vipākoti vā vuccati, taṃ natthīti vadati. Natthi ayaṃ lokoti paraloke ṭhitassa ayaṃ loko natthi, natthi paro lokoti idha loke ṭhitassāpi paro loko natthi, sabbe tattha tattheva ucchijjantīti dasseti. Natthi mātā natthi pitāti tesu sammāpaṭipattimicchāpaṭipattīnaṃ phalābhāvavasena vadati. Natthi sattā opapātikāti cavitvā upapajjanakā sattā nāma natthīti vadati. Cātumahābhūtikoti  catumahābhūtamayo. Pathavī pathavikāyanti ajjhattikapathavīdhātu bāhirapathavīdhātuṃ. Anupetīti anuyāyati. Anupagacchatīti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Anugacchatītipi attho. Ubhayenāpi upeti, upagacchatīti dasseti. Āpādīsupi eseva nayo. Indriyānīti  manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni ākāsaṃ pakkhandanti. Āsandipañcamāti nipannamañcena pañcamā, mañco ceva cattāro mañcapāde gahetvā ṭhitā cattāro purisā cāti attho. Yāvāḷāhanāti yāva susānā. Padānīti ‘ayaṃ evaṃ sīlavā  ahosi, evaṃ dussīlo’tiādinā nayena pavattāni guṇāguṇapadāni, sarīrameva vā ettha padānīti adhippetaṃ. Kāpotakānīti kapotavaṇṇāni, pārāvatapakkhavaṇṇānīti attho. Bhassantāti bhasmantā, ayameva vā pāḷi. Āhutiyoti yaṃ paheṇakasakkārādibhedaṃ dinnadānaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ chārikāvasānameva hoti, na tato paraṃ phaladāyakaṃ hutvā gacchatīti attho. Dattupaññattanti dattūhi bālamanussehi paññattaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – ‘bālehi abuddhīhi paññattamidaṃ dānaṃ, na paṇḍitehi. Bālā denti, paṇḍitā gaṇhantī’ti dasseti. Tattha pūraṇo ‘‘karoto na karīyati pāpa’’nti vadanto kammaṃ paṭibāhati. Ajito ‘‘kāyassa bhedā ucchijjatī’’ti vadanto vipākaṃ paṭibāhati. Makkhali ‘‘natthi hetū’’ti vadanto ubhayaṃ paṭibāhati. Tattha kammaṃ paṭibāhantenāpi vipāko paṭibāhito hoti, vipākaṃ paṭibāhantenāpi kammaṃ paṭibāhitaṃ hoti. Iti sabbepete atthato ubhayappaṭibāhakā ahetukavādā ceva akiriyavādā ca natthikavādā ca honti. Ye vā pana tesaṃ laddhiṃ gahetvā rattiṭṭhāne divāṭhāne nisinnā sajjhāyanti vīmaṃsanti, tesaṃ ‘‘karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ, natthi hetu, natthi paccayo, mato ucchijjatī’’ti tasmiṃ ārammaṇe micchāsati santiṭṭhati, cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti, javanāni javanti, paṭhamajavane satekicchā honti, tathā dutiyādīsu, sattame buddhānampi atekicchā anivattino ariṭṭhakaṇṭakasadisā. Tattha koci ekaṃ dassanaṃ okkamati, koci dve, koci tīṇipi, ekasmiṃ okkantepi, dvīsu  tīsu okkantesupi, niyatamicchādiṭṭhikova hoti; patto saggamaggāvaraṇañceva mokkhamaggāvaraṇañca, abhabbo tassattabhāvassa anantaraṃ saggampi gantuṃ, pageva mokkhaṃ. Vaṭṭakhāṇu nāmesa satto pathavigopako, yebhuyyena evarūpassa bhavato vuṭṭhānaṃ natthi.
commentary_english:
170-172.
In Ajita's doctrine, "there is no giving" ( *natthi dinnaṃ*), he speaks intending that there are no fruits of giving.
"A great sacrifice" ( *mahāyāgaḥ*) is called *yiṭṭhaṃ*.
"Meritorious offering" (*hutaṃ*) means that which is intended by gifts of honor (*paheṇakasakkāro*).
And even that, he refutes ( *paṭikkhipati*) by intending only the non-existence of the fruit (*phalābhāva*).
"Good deeds and bad deeds" (*sukatadukkaṭānaṃ*) means good (*kusala*) and bad (*akusala*).
"Fruit is result" (*phalaṃ vipāko*) means that which is called fruit (*phalaṃ*) or result (*vipāko*); he says, "there is no such thing" (*natthīti vadati*).
"There is no this world (*natthi ayaṃ loko*)" means that for one abiding in the other world (*paraloke ṭhitassa*), this world (*ayaṃ loko*) does not exist (*natthi*); "there is no other world (*natthi paro loko*)" means that even for one abiding in this world (*idha loke ṭhitassāpi*), the other world (*paro loko*) does not exist (*natthi*); he shows that all are annihilated (*ucchijjanti*) just there where they are (*tattha tattheva*).
"There is no mother, there is no father" (*natthi mātā natthi pitā*) he says intending, in those cases, that there are no fruits of right conduct (*sammāpaṭipatti*) and wrong conduct (*micchāpaṭipattīnaṃ*) towards them.
"There are no beings who are spontaneously born (*natthi sattā opapātikā*)" he says, meaning that there are no beings who, having passed away (*cavitvā*), reappear (*upapajjanakā sattā nāma natthīti vadati*).
"Consisting of the four great elements (*cātumahābhūtikoti*) " means consisting of the four great elements (*catumahābhūtamayo*).
"The earth returns to the body of earth" (*pathavī pathavikāyanti*) means the internal earth element (*ajjhattikapathavīdhātu*) returns to the external earth element (*bāhirapathavīdhātuṃ*).
"*Anupeti* " means follows (*anuyāyati*).
"*Anupagacchati*" is a synonym of that.
"*Anugacchati* " also means the same.
He approaches (*ubhayenāpi upeti*), he shows that he approaches (*upagacchatīti dasseti*).
The same method applies in the case of the other elements (*āpādīsupi eseva nayo*).
"The senses (*indriyāṇīti*)" means the senses including the mind as the sixth (*manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni*) pass over into space (*ākāsaṃ pakkhandanti*).
"*Āsandipañcamāti*" means with the couch as the fifth (*nipannamañcena pañcamā*); the meaning (*attho*) is the couch (*mañco ceva*) and four men standing holding the four legs of the couch (*cattāro mañcapāde gahetvā ṭhitā cattāro purisā cāti*).
"*Yāvāḷāhanāti*" means as far as the charnel ground (*yāva susānā*).
"*Padāni*" means the qualities and defects (*guṇāguṇapadāni*) that proceed in the way of "this one was virtuous (*ayaṃ evaṃ sīlavā ahosi*), this one was immoral (*evaṃ dussīlo*)", etc., or here (*ettha*) "traces" (*padāni*) means the body (*sarīrameva*) is intended (*adhippetaṃ*).
"*Kāpotakāni*" means having the color of pigeons (*kapotavaṇṇāni*), it means having the color of doves' wings (*pārāvatapakkhavaṇṇānīti attho*).
"*Bhassantāti*" means *bhasmantā*, or this itself (*ayameva vā*) is the text (*pāḷi*).
"*Āhutiyoti*" means whatever giving is a gift (*dinnadānaṃ*) that is a distinction of presents, honors, etc. (*paheṇakasakkārādibhedaṃ*), all of that (*sabbaṃ taṃ*) has ashes as its end (*chārikāvasānameva hoti*), and does not go (*gacchati*) beyond that (*na tato paraṃ*) having become fruit-yielding (*phaladāyakaṃ hutvā*), that is the meaning (*attho*).
"*Dattupaññattanti*" means designated (*paññattaṃ*) by givers who are foolish men (*dattūhi bālamanusssehi*).
This was said (*idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti*) - "giving is designated (*paññattamidaṃ dānaṃ*) by the foolish and unintelligent (*bālehi abuddhīhi*), not by the wise (*na paṇḍitehi*)."
"Fools give (*bālā denti*), the wise take (*paṇḍitā gaṇhantī*)," he shows (*dasseti*).
There, Pūraṇa, saying "in doing, evil is not done (*karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ*)," refutes action (*kammaṃ paṭibāhati*).
Ajita, saying "with the breakup of the body, one is annihilated (*kāyassa bhedā ucchijjatī*)," refutes result (*vipākaṃ paṭibāhati*).
Makkhali, saying "there is no cause (*natthi hetū*)," refutes both (*ubhayaṃ paṭibāhati*).
There, even by refuting action (*kammaṃ paṭibāhantenāpi*), result (*vipāko*) is refuted (*paṭibāhito hoti*), and even by refuting result (*vipākaṃ paṭibāhantenāpi*), action (*kammaṃ*) is refuted (*paṭibāhitaṃ hoti*).
Thus, all those (*iti sabbepete*) are in effect (*atthato*) rejecters of both (*ubhayappaṭibāhakā*), proponents of acausality (*ahetukavādā*), proponents of the inefficacy of action (*akiriyavādā*), and proponents of nihilism (*natthikavādā ca honti*).
Those who, having taken their doctrines (*tesaṃ laddhiṃ gahetvā*), sitting in their night quarters (*rattiṭṭhāne*) or day quarters (*divāṭhāne nisinnā*), recite and investigate (*sajjhāyanti vīmaṃsanti*), for them (*tesaṃ*) wrong mindfulness (*micchāsati*) is established (*santiṭṭhati*) with the object of "in doing, evil is not done (*karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ*), there is no cause (*natthi hetu*), there is no condition (*natthi paccayo*), when dead, one is annihilated (*mato ucchijjatī*)," in that object (*tasmiṃ ārammaṇe*), the mind (*cittaṃ*) becomes one-pointed (*ekaggaṃ hoti*), the impulsions run (*javanāni javanti*), at the first impulsion (*paṭhamajavane*) they are curable (*satekicchā honti*), and so (*tathā*) in the second etc. (*dutiyādīsu*), at the seventh (*sattame*) they are incurable (*atekicchā*) even by the Buddhas (*buddhānampi*), irreversible (*anivattino*), like *ariṭṭhakaṇṭaka*.
There, someone (*koci*) adopts one view (*ekaṃ dassanaṃ okkamati*), someone (*koci*) two (*dve*), someone (*koci*) three (*tīṇipi*), even with one adopted (*ekasmiṃ okkantepi*), with two or three adopted (*dvīsu tīsu okkantesupi*), he is indeed (*eva*) one with fixed wrong views (*niyatamicchādiṭṭhiko*); having attained (*patto*) an obstruction to the path to heaven (*saggamaggāvaraṇañceva*) and an obstruction to the path to liberation (*mokkhamaggāvaraṇañca*), he is incapable (*abhabbo*) of going to heaven (*saggampi gantuṃ*) immediately after that existence (*tassattabhāvassa anantaraṃ*), much less liberation (*pageva mokkhaṃ*).
*Vaṭṭakhāṇu* is the name (*nāmesa*) of a being (*satto*) who is a watchman of the earth (*pathavigopako*); generally (*yebhuyyena*) there is no arising (*vuṭṭhānaṃ natthi*) for one of such a nature (*evarūpassa bhavato*).

mula_pali: 171. ‘‘Evaṃ  vutte, bhante, ajito kesakambalo maṃ etadavoca – ‘natthi, mahārāja, dinnaṃ , natthi yiṭṭhaṃ, natthi hutaṃ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, natthi ayaṃ loko paraloko (syā.), natthi paro loko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā samaggatā (ka.), samaggatā (syā.) sammāpaṭipannā, ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ  abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedenti. Cātumahābhūtiko ayaṃ puriso, yadā kālaṅkaroti, pathavī pathavikāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati, āpo āpokāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati, tejo tejokāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati, vāyo vāyokāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati, ākāsaṃ indriyāni saṅkamanti. Āsandipañcamā purisā mataṃ ādāya gacchanti. Yāvāḷāhanā padāni paññāyanti. Kāpotakāni aṭṭhīni bhavanti, bhassantā āhutiyo. Dattupaññattaṃ yadidaṃ dānaṃ. Tesaṃ tucchaṃ musā vilāpo ye keci atthikavādaṃ vadanti. Bāle ca paṇḍite ca kāyassa bhedā ucchijjanti vinassanti, na honti paraṃ maraṇā’ti.
mula_english: 171. When this was said, venerable sir, Ajita Kesakambala told me this: ‘There is no such thing as giving (*dinnam*), great king, there is no offering (*yiṭṭhaṃ*), there is no sacrifice (*hutaṃ*), there is no fruit or result (*phalaṃ vipāko*) of good and bad actions (*sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ*), there is no this world (*ayaṃ loko*), no other world (*paro loko*), there is no mother (*mātā*), no father (*pitā*), there are no spontaneously born beings (*sattā opapātikā*), in the world there are no ascetics or Brahmins (*samaṇabrāhmaṇā*) who have attained right practice, who having directly known and realized this world and the other world with their own higher knowledge (*sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā*), proclaim it. This person (*ayaṃ puriso*) is composed of the four great elements (*cātumahābhūtiko*), and when he dies (*yadā kālaṅkaroti*), the earth element (*pathavī*) returns and merges with the earth body (*pathavikāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati*), the water element (*āpo*) returns and merges with the water body (*āpokāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati*), the fire element (*tejo*) returns and merges with the fire body (*tejokāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati*), the air element (*vāyo*) returns and merges with the air body (*vāyokāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati*), and the faculties (*indriyāni*) pass into space (*ākāsaṃ saṅkamanti*). Four men, with a bier as the fifth, take the dead body and depart (*āsandipañcamā purisā mataṃ ādāya gacchanti*). Footsteps are seen as far as the cremation ground (*yāvāḷāhanā padāni paññāyanti*). The bones become pigeon-colored (*kāpotakāni aṭṭhīni bhavanti*), and offerings are reduced to ashes (*bhassantā āhutiyo*). Giving is a doctrine of fools (*dattupaññattaṃ yadidaṃ dānaṃ*). Their talk is empty, false prattle, those who preach a doctrine of survival (*tesaṃ tucchaṃ musā vilāpo ye keci atthikavādaṃ vadanti*). Fools and wise alike, with the breakup of the body (*bāle ca paṇḍite ca kāyassa bhedā*), are annihilated and perish (*ucchijjanti vinassanti*), they do not exist after death (*na honti paraṃ maraṇā’ti*).

commentary_english:
170-172.

In Ajita's doctrine, there is no giving; he says this intending that there are no fruits of giving.

*Yiṭṭhaṃ* is called a great sacrifice ( *mahāyāga*).

*Hutaṃ* means a present or gift of honor is intended.

He rejects both, intending that there are no fruits.

*Sukatadukkaṭānaṃ* means of good deeds and bad deeds, the meaning is wholesome and unwholesome.

"Fruit is result ( *vipāka*)" means whatever is called fruit (*phala*) or result (*vipāka*), that does not exist, he says.

There is no present world means, for one living in the world beyond, this world does not exist, there is no world beyond means, for one living in this world, the world beyond does not exist. He shows: all are annihilated just where they are.

No mother, no father: He says this intending that there are no fruits of right conduct (*sammāpaṭipatti*) and wrong conduct (*micchāpaṭipatti*) towards them.

No beings who have taken rebirth: He says there are no beings who, having passed away (*cavitvā*), reappear (*upapajjanakā*).

*Cātumahābhūtika* means consisting of the four great elements ( *catumahābhūta*).

The earth ( *pathavī*) returns to and merges with the body of earth ( *pathavikāya*); the internal earth element (*ajjhattikapathavīdhātu*) [merges with] the external earth element (*bāhirapathavīdhātuṃ*).

*Anupeti* means it goes along with.

*Anupagacchati* is a synonym of that.

*Anugacchati* also has the same meaning.

He approaches it with both; he shows that he approaches it.

The same method applies in the case of the other elements (*āpādīsupi*).

The sense faculties (*indriyāni*)—the mind (*manas*) being the sixth— pass over into space (*ākāsaṃ pakkhandanti*).

*Āsandipañcamā* means, with the fifth being the reclining couch, the couch and four men standing holding the feet of the couch, that is the meaning.

*Yāvāḷāhana* means as far as the cemetery (*susānā*).

*Padāni* means qualities and non-qualities such as, ‘This one was moral, that one was immoral,’ etc., or it is intended that the body is what is meant by *padāni*.

*Kāpotakāni* means having the color of pigeons ( *kapota-vaṇṇāni*), the color of dove’s wings ( *pārāvatapakkha-vaṇṇāni*), that is the meaning.

*Bhassantā* means *bhasmantā*, or this itself is the Pāḷi text.

*Āhuti* means gifts given with presents, gifts of honor, etc., all of that has ashes as its end, it does not go beyond that yielding fruit, that is the meaning.

*Dattupaññattaṃ* means prescribed by foolish men (*bālamanussehi*).

This is said: 'Giving ( *dānaṃ*) is prescribed by fools who are without wisdom (*abuddhīhi*), not by the wise ( *paṇḍitehi*)'.

Fools give ( *denti*), the wise take ( *gaṇhanti*)', he shows.

Among these, Pūraṇa, with his statement “By doing so there is no evil,” denies action (*kamma*).

Ajita, with his statement “One is annihilated with the breakup of the body ( *kāyassa bhedā ucchijjatī*),” denies the result (*vipāka*).

Makkhali, with his statement “There is no cause ( *natthi hetū*),” denies both.

By denying action (*kamma*), one denies its result (*vipāka*), by denying the result (*vipāka*) one denies action (*kamma*).

Thus all these thinkers, by denying both, in effect espouse acausalism (*ahetukavādā*), the inefficacy of action (*akiriyavādā*), and moral nihilism (*natthikavādā*).

When people accept these theories and then recite and investigate them while sitting in their night-quarters (*rattiṭṭhāne*) or day-quarters (*divāṭhāne*), wrong mindfulness becomes established, taking as object: “No evil is done ( *karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ*),” or “There is no cause (*hetu* ) or condition ( *paccayo*),” or “The dead are annihilated (*mato ucchijjatī*).” The mind becomes one-pointed. The impulsions run their course. At the first impulsion these people are curable; and so too at the second, etc. But at the seventh they cannot be cured even by the Buddhas; they cannot be turned.

Someone might espouse one view among these, another two, another three. But whether one espouses one, two, or three views, one adopts a wrong view with fixed consequences. One has met an obstruction to the path to heaven (*saggamaggāvaraṇa*) and an obstruction to the path to liberation (*mokkhamaggāvaraṇa*). It is impossible for him to reach heaven (*sagga*) immediately following this present existence, much less to reach liberation (*mokkha*).

This being is called a stump in the round of existence (*vaṭṭakhāṇu*), a watchman of the earth (*pathavigopako*). Generally, one like this does not emerge from existence (*bhava*).

mula_pali: 172. ‘‘Itthaṃ kho me, bhante, ajito kesakambalo sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno ucchedaṃ byākāsi. Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṃ vā puṭṭho labujaṃ byākareyya , labujaṃ vā puṭṭho ambaṃ byākareyya; evameva kho me, bhante, ajito kesakambalo sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno ucchedaṃ byākāsi. Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, etadahosi – ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā vijite vasantaṃ apasādetabbaṃ maññeyyā’ti. So kho ahaṃ, bhante, ajitassa kesakambalassa bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ. Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano anattamanavācaṃ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṃ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ.
mula_english:
“Thus, venerable sir, when I asked Ajita Kesakambala about a visible fruit of recluseship, he explained to me annihilation (uccheda).

Just as if one asked about a mango (ambaṃ) would speak about a breadfruit (labujaṃ), or as if one asked about a breadfruit (labujaṃ) would speak about a mango (ambaṃ), in the same way, when I asked Ajita Kesakambala about a visible fruit of recluseship, he explained to me annihilation (uccheda).

Then, venerable sir, I thought to myself: ‘One like myself should not think of troubling a *śramaṇa* or *brāhmaṇa* living in his realm.’

So I neither rejoiced in the statement of Ajita Kesakambala nor did I reject it.

Without accepting his doctrine, without rejecting it, being displeased, without expressing my displeasure in words, but pondering over that same statement, without overturning it, I got up from my seat and left.
commentary_pali: 170-172. Ajitavāde natthi dinnanti dinnaphalābhāvaṃ sandhāya vadati. Yiṭṭhaṃ vuccati mahāyāgo. Hutanti paheṇakasakkāro adhippeto. Tampi ubhayaṃ phalābhāvameva sandhāya paṭikkhipati. Sukatadukkaṭānanti sukatadukkaṭānaṃ, kusalākusalānanti attho. Phalaṃ vipākoti yaṃ phalanti vā vipākoti vā vuccati, taṃ natthīti vadati. Natthi ayaṃ lokoti paraloke ṭhitassa ayaṃ loko natthi, natthi paro lokoti idha loke ṭhitassāpi paro loko natthi, sabbe tattha tattheva ucchijjantīti dasseti. Natthi mātā natthi pitāti tesu sammāpaṭipattimicchāpaṭipattīnaṃ phalābhāvavasena vadati. Natthi sattā opapātikāti cavitvā upapajjanakā sattā nāma natthīti vadati. Cātumahābhūtikoti  catumahābhūtamayo. Pathavī pathavikāyanti ajjhattikapathavīdhātu bāhirapathavīdhātuṃ. Anupetīti anuyāyati. Anupagacchatīti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Anugacchatītipi attho. Ubhayenāpi upeti, upagacchatīti dasseti. Āpādīsupi eseva nayo. Indriyānīti  manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni ākāsaṃ pakkhandanti. Āsandipañcamāti nipannamañcena pañcamā, mañco ceva cattāro mañcapāde gahetvā ṭhitā cattāro purisā cāti attho. Yāvāḷāhanāti yāva susānā. Padānīti ‘ayaṃ evaṃ sīlavā  ahosi, evaṃ dussīlo’tiādinā nayena pavattāni guṇāguṇapadāni, sarīrameva vā ettha padānīti adhippetaṃ. Kāpotakānīti kapotavaṇṇāni, pārāvatapakkhavaṇṇānīti attho. Bhassantāti bhasmantā, ayameva vā pāḷi. Āhutiyoti yaṃ paheṇakasakkārādibhedaṃ dinnadānaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ chārikāvasānameva hoti, na tato paraṃ phaladāyakaṃ hutvā gacchatīti attho. Dattupaññattanti dattūhi bālamanussehi paññattaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – ‘bālehi abuddhīhi paññattamidaṃ dānaṃ, na paṇḍitehi. Bālā denti, paṇḍitā gaṇhantī’ti dasseti. Tattha pūraṇo ‘‘karoto na karīyati pāpa’’nti vadanto kammaṃ paṭibāhati. Ajito ‘‘kāyassa bhedā ucchijjatī’’ti vadanto vipākaṃ paṭibāhati. Makkhali ‘‘natthi hetū’’ti vadanto ubhayaṃ paṭibāhati. Tattha kammaṃ paṭibāhantenāpi vipāko paṭibāhito hoti, vipākaṃ paṭibāhantenāpi kammaṃ paṭibāhitaṃ hoti. Iti sabbepete atthato ubhayappaṭibāhakā ahetukavādā ceva akiriyavādā ca natthikavādā ca honti. Ye vā pana tesaṃ laddhiṃ gahetvā rattiṭṭhāne divāṭhāne nisinnā sajjhāyanti vīmaṃsanti, tesaṃ ‘‘karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ, natthi hetu, natthi paccayo, mato ucchijjatī’’ti tasmiṃ ārammaṇe micchāsati santiṭṭhati, cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti, javanāni javanti, paṭhamajavane satekicchā honti, tathā dutiyādīsu, sattame buddhānampi atekicchā anivattino ariṭṭhakaṇṭakasadisā. Tattha koci ekaṃ dassanaṃ okkamati, koci dve, koci tīṇipi, ekasmiṃ okkantepi, dvīsu  tīsu okkantesupi, niyatamicchādiṭṭhikova hoti; patto saggamaggāvaraṇañceva mokkhamaggāvaraṇañca, abhabbo tassattabhāvassa anantaraṃ saggampi gantuṃ, pageva mokkhaṃ. Vaṭṭakhāṇu nāmesa satto pathavigopako, yebhuyyena evarūpassa bhavato vuṭṭhānaṃ natthi.
commentary_english:
170-172.
"There is no giving" (natthi dinnaṃ): He says this intending that there are no fruits of giving (dinnaphalābhāvaṃ sandhāya vadati).
"Sacrifice" (yiṭṭhaṃ) is called a great offering (mahāyāgo).
"Offerings" (hutaṃ): This means gifts and honoring (paheṇakasakkāro adhippeto).
He rejects both, intending only the absence of result (tampi ubhayaṃ phalābhāvaṃ eva sandhāya paṭikkhipati).
"Well-done and ill-done" (sukatadukkaṭānaṃ): This means "good and bad" (kusalākusalānaṃ), is the meaning (attho).
"Result is consequence" (phalaṃ vipāko): He says, "That which is called 'result' (phalaṃ) or 'consequence' (vipāko) does not exist" (yaṃ phalanti vā vipāko ti vā vuccati, taṃ natthi iti vadati).
"There is no this world" (natthi ayaṃ loko): He shows, "For one abiding in the next world (paraloke ṭhitassa), this world (ayaṃ loko) does not exist; there is no next world (natthi paro loko): for one abiding in this world (idha loke ṭhitassāpi), the next world (paro loko) does not exist; all are annihilated just there" (sabbe tattha tattheva ucchijjanti iti dasseti).
"There is no mother, there is no father" (natthi mātā natthi pitā): He says this intending that there are no fruits of right and wrong conduct towards them (tesu sammāpaṭipattimicchāpaṭipattīnaṃ phalābhāva vasena vadati).
"There are no beings who are spontaneously born" (natthi sattā opapātikā): He says that there are no beings who, having passed away, reappear (cavitvā upapajjanakā sattā nāma natthi iti vadati).
"Possessing the four great elements" (cātumahābhūtiko): Made of the four great elements (catumahābhūtamayo).
"Earth returns to earth" (pathavī pathavikāyanti): The internal earth element (ajjhattika pathavī dhātu) [returns to] the external earth element (bāhira pathavī dhātuṃ).
"Goes along with" (anupeti iti): Follows (anuyāyati).
"Does not go along with" (anupagacchati iti): It is a synonym of that (tasseva vevacanaṃ).
"Goes along with" (anugacchati iti api): Is also the meaning (attho).
He approaches with both (ubhayenāpi upeti), he shows that he goes along with it (upagacchati iti dasseti).
The same method (eseva nayo) applies to the other elements (āpādīsupi).
"The senses" (indriyāni iti): The six senses including mind (manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni) pass over into space (ākāsaṃ pakkhandanti).
"A couch with five" (āsandipañcamāti): With a lying-down couch as the fifth, the couch and the four men standing holding the four legs of the couch, is the meaning (nipannamañcena pañcamā, mañco ceva cattāro mañcapāde gahetvā ṭhitā cattāro purisā ca iti attho).
"As far as the charnel ground" (yāvāḷāhanāti): As far as the cemetery (yāva susānā).
"Traces" (padāni iti): 'This one was thus virtuous (ayaṃ evaṃ sīlavā ahosi), this one was thus immoral (evaṃ dussīlo’ti ādinā nayena pavattāni guṇāguṇapadāni), according to this method, the virtues and non-virtues which proceed are traces; or here, the traces are just the body,' is the intended meaning (sarīrameva vā ettha padānīti adhippetaṃ).
"Bluish-grey" (kāpotakāni iti): Pigeon-colored (kapotavaṇṇāni), the color of dove's wings (pārāvatapakkha vaṇṇāni), is the meaning (attho).
"Disappearing" (bhassantāti): Reduced to ashes (bhasmantā), or this is just the reading (ayam eva vā pāḷi).
"Offerings" (āhutiyo iti): The gifts of giving, which are offerings, gifts of honor, etc. (yaṃ paheṇakasakkārādibhedaṃ dinnadānaṃ), all of that terminates in ashes (sabbaṃ taṃ chārikāvasānam eva hoti), and does not go beyond as yielding fruit (na tato paraṃ phaladāyakaṃ hutvā gacchati iti attho).
"Prescribed by givers" (dattupaññattanti): Prescribed by foolish givers (dattūhi bālamanussehi paññattaṃ).
This was said (idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti): 'Giving is prescribed by fools who are unwise (bālehi abuddhīhi paññattaṃ idaṃ dānaṃ), not by the wise (na paṇḍitehi).'
Fools give (bālā denti), the wise take (paṇḍitā gaṇhanti)' (iti dasseti).
There, Pūraṇa (tattha pūraṇo), saying "By doing there is no evil done" (‘‘karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ’’ iti vadanto), refutes action (kammaṃ paṭibāhati).
Ajita (ajito), saying "With the breakup of the body one is annihilated" (‘‘kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati’’ iti vadanto), refutes consequence (vipākaṃ paṭibāhati).
Makkhali (makkhali), saying "There is no cause" (‘‘natthi hetū’’ iti vadanto), refutes both (ubhayaṃ paṭibāhati).
There, by refuting action (tattha kammaṃ paṭibāhantenāpi), consequence is also refuted (vipāko paṭibāhito hoti), and by refuting consequence (vipākaṃ paṭibāhantenāpi), action is also refuted (kammaṃ paṭibāhitaṃ hoti).
Thus, all these thinkers (iti sabbe pete), in effect, are both deniers (atthato ubhayappaṭibāhakā), proponents of no-cause (ahetukavādā), proponents of the inefficacy of action (akiriyavādā ca), and proponents of nihilism (natthikavādā ca honti).
Those who, taking up their views (ye vā pana tesaṃ laddhiṃ gahetvā), seated in their day-quarters or night-quarters (rattiṭṭhāne divāṭhāne nisinnā), recite and investigate (sajjhāyanti vīmaṃsanti), wrong mindfulness becomes established in them, taking as its object "By doing, there is no evil done, there is no cause, there is no condition, the dead are annihilated" (tesaṃ ‘‘karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ, natthi hetu, natthi paccayo, mato ucchijjati’’ iti tasmiṃ ārammaṇe micchāsati santiṭṭhati), the mind is one-pointed (cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti), the impulsions run their course (javanāni javanti), in the first impulsion they are curable (paṭhamajavane satekicchā honti), likewise in the second, etc. (tathā dutiyādīsu), in the seventh, even by the Buddhas, they are incurable (sattame buddhānampi atekicchā), unretreating, like a fishbone stuck in the throat (anivattino ariṭṭhakaṇṭaka sadisā).
There, someone may espouse one view (tattha koci ekaṃ dassanaṃ okkamati), someone two (koci dve), someone three (koci tīṇi pi), even if one has espoused one (ekasmiṃ okkantepi), even if in two or three (dvīsu tīsu okkantesupi), one is certainly of wrong view (niyata micchādiṭṭhiko va hoti); one has attained an obstruction to the path to heaven (patto saggamaggāvaraṇañ ca eva), and an obstruction to the path to liberation (mokkhamaggāvaraṇañ ca), one is incapable of going to heaven immediately after that state of existence (abhabbo tassattabhāvassa anantaraṃ saggampi gantuṃ), let alone liberation (pageva mokkhaṃ).
A stump in the round (vaṭṭakhāṇu nāma esa satto), a watchman of the earth (pathavigopako), generally, there is no arising for such a one (yebhuyyena eva rūpassa bhavato vuṭṭhānaṃ natthi).

mula_pali: 173. ‘‘Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ yena pakudho kaccāyano tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā pakudhena kaccāyanena saddhiṃ sammodiṃ. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ahaṃ, bhante, pakudhaṃ kaccāyanaṃ etadavocaṃ – ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho kaccāyana, puthusippāyatanāni…pe… sakkā nu kho, bho kaccāyana, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetu’nti?
mula_english: “Venerable sir, on one occasion I went to see Pakudha Kaccāyana. Upon arriving, I exchanged courteous greetings with Pakudha Kaccāyana. After exchanging greetings and polite conversation, I sat down to one side. Sitting to one side, venerable sir, I said this to Pakudha Kaccāyana: ‘Just as there are these various vocational skills, Kaccāyana… is it possible, Kaccāyana, to describe a visible fruit of the ascetic life in this very life ( *diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ*)?’”
commentary_pali: 173-175. Pakudhavāde akaṭāti akatā. Akaṭavidhāti akatavidhānā. Evaṃ karohīti kenaci kārāpitāpi na hontīti attho. Animmitāti iddhiyāpi na nimmitā. Animmātāti animmāpitā, keci animmāpetabbāti padaṃ vadanti, taṃ neva pāḷiyaṃ, na aṭṭhakathāyaṃ dissati. Vañjhādipadattayaṃ vuttatthameva. Na iñjantīti esikatthambho viya ṭhitattā na calanti. Na vipariṇamantīti pakatiṃ na jahanti. Na aññamaññaṃ byābādhentīti na aññamaññaṃ upahananti. Nālanti na samatthā. Pathavikāyotiādīsu pathavīyeva pathavikāyo, pathavisamūho vā. Tatthāti tesu jīvasattamesu kāyesu. Sattannaṃ tveva kāyānanti yathā muggarāsiādīsu pahataṃ satthaṃ muggādīnaṃ antarena pavisati, evaṃ sattannaṃ kāyānaṃ antarena chiddena vivarena satthaṃ pavisati. Tattha ahaṃ imaṃ jīvitā voropemīti kevalaṃ saññāmattameva hotīti dasseti.
commentary_english:
173-175.
In the Pakudha doctrine, they are unmade and not made.
They are of an unmade nature, not of a made nature.
The meaning is that they are not made to do anything by anyone, saying, "Do it this way."
Uncreated: not created even by supernormal power ( *iddhi*).
"Uncreated": not caused to be created. Some say the phrase is "should not be caused to be created," but this is not found in the Pāḷi or in the commentary (*aṭṭhakathā*).
The three words beginning with "barren" have only the meaning already stated.
They do not alter, do not change. Because they are steady, standing firm like a pillar, “they do not alter,” i.e. do not undergo transmutation.
and “do not change,” i.e. do not abandon their original nature (*pakatiṃ*).
“They won’t disturb one another;” i.e., they do not injure one another.
They are not able; they are not capable (*na samatthā*).
The body of earth, etc. The body of earth is the earth itself, or the assemblage of earth (*pathavisamūho*) because earth is one part of the body.
There, i.e., in those seven living bodies.
There is no killer, etc. Just as, when one strikes a heap of beans with a sword, the sword enters in between the beans, so the sword enters the space, the interstice, between the seven bodies (*kāyānaṃ*).
Therein he shows: “I am taking his life,” that is only a mere idea (*saṃjñāmattameva*).

mula_pali: 174. ‘‘Evaṃ vutte, bhante, pakudho kaccāyano maṃ etadavoca – ‘sattime, mahārāja, kāyā akaṭā akaṭavidhā animmitā animmātā vañjhā kūṭaṭṭhā  esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā. Te na iñjanti , na vipariṇamanti, na aññamaññaṃ byābādhenti, nālaṃ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā. Katame satta? Pathavikāyo, āpokāyo, tejokāyo, vāyokāyo, sukhe, dukkhe, jīve sattame  – ime satta kāyā akaṭā akaṭavidhā animmitā animmātā vañjhā kūṭaṭṭhā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā. Te na iñjanti, na vipariṇamanti, na aññamaññaṃ byābādhenti, nālaṃ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā. Tattha natthi hantā vā ghātetā vā, sotā vā sāvetā vā, viññātā vā viññāpetā vā. Yopi tiṇhena satthena sīsaṃ chindati, na koci kiñci kañci (kaṃ.) jīvitā voropeti; sattannaṃ tveva sattannaṃ yeva (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī.) kāyānamantarena satthaṃ vivaramanupatatī’ti.
mula_english:
174.

"When this was said, venerable sir, Pakudha Kaccāyana said this to me: 'These seven, O Great King, are bodies that are unmade ( *akaṭā*), not made ( *akaṭavidhā*), uncreated ( *animmitā*), without a creator (*animmātā*), barren (*vañjhā*), standing firm as a mountain peak (*kūṭaṭṭhā*), steadfast as a pillar (*esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā*).

They do not move (*iñjanti*), do not change (*vipariṇamanti*), do not obstruct each other (*aññamaññaṃ byābādhenti*), and are not capable of causing each other pleasure (*sukhāya*) or pain (*dukkhāya*) or pleasure and pain (*sukhadukkhāya*).

Which are the seven? The earth-body (*pathavikāyo*), the water-body (*āpokāyo*), the fire-body (*tejokāyo*), the air-body (*vāyokāyo*), pleasure (*sukhe*), pain (*dukkhe*), and the life principle (*jīve*) as the seventh – these seven bodies are unmade (*akaṭā*), not made (*akaṭavidhā*), uncreated (*animmitā*), without a creator (*animmātā*), barren (*vañjhā*), standing firm as a mountain peak (*kūṭaṭṭhā*), steadfast as a pillar (*esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā*).

They do not move (*iñjanti*), do not change (*vipariṇamanti*), do not obstruct each other (*aññamaññaṃ byābādhenti*), and are not capable of causing each other pleasure (*sukhāya*) or pain (*dukkhāya*) or pleasure and pain (*sukhadukkhāya*).

In this regard, there is no killer (*hantā*) or one who causes killing (*ghātetā*), no hearer (*sotā*) or one who causes hearing (*sāvetā*), no knower (*viññātā*) or one who causes knowing (*viññāpetā*).

Even if someone cuts off a head with a sharp sword (*tiṇhena satthena sīsaṃ chindati*), no one takes anyone's life (*na koci kiñci jīvitā voropeti*); the sword merely passes through the space (*vivaramanupatati*) between the seven bodies (*sattannaṃ kāyānaṃ antarena sattthaṃ*)’."
commentary_pali: 173-175. Pakudhavāde akaṭāti akatā. Akaṭavidhāti akatavidhānā. Evaṃ karohīti kenaci kārāpitāpi na hontīti attho. Animmitāti iddhiyāpi na nimmitā. Animmātāti animmāpitā, keci animmāpetabbāti padaṃ vadanti, taṃ neva pāḷiyaṃ, na aṭṭhakathāyaṃ dissati. Vañjhādipadattayaṃ vuttatthameva. Na iñjantīti esikatthambho viya ṭhitattā na calanti. Na vipariṇamantīti pakatiṃ na jahanti. Na aññamaññaṃ byābādhentīti na aññamaññaṃ upahananti. Nālanti na samatthā. Pathavikāyotiādīsu pathavīyeva pathavikāyo, pathavisamūho vā. Tatthāti tesu jīvasattamesu kāyesu. Sattannaṃ tveva kāyānanti yathā muggarāsiādīsu pahataṃ satthaṃ muggādīnaṃ antarena pavisati, evaṃ sattannaṃ kāyānaṃ antarena chiddena vivarena satthaṃ pavisati. Tattha ahaṃ imaṃ jīvitā voropemīti kevalaṃ saññāmattameva hotīti dasseti.
commentary_english:
173-175.

In Pakudha's doctrine, there is no creating ( *akaṭāti*), and no created (*akatā*).

There is no means of creating (*akaṭavidhāti*), and no means of being created (*akatavidhānā*).

Thus, even if someone were to cause them to be made by someone else saying "Do this!" (*evaṃ karohīti kenaci kārāpitāpi na hontīti attho.*), it would not happen.

Uncreated (*animmitāti*), without a creator; “Uncreated”: not created by supernormal power (*iddhiyāpi na nimmitā*).

"Not created" (*animmātāti*) means "not caused to be created" (*animmāpitā*). Some say the word is "should not be created" (*animmāpetabbāti padaṃ vadanti*), but that is not found in the Pāḷi or in the commentary (*taṃ neva pāḷiyaṃ, na aṭṭhakathāyaṃ dissati*).

The three terms beginning with "barren" (*vañjhādipadattayaṃ*) have only the meaning already stated (*vuttatthameva*).

They do not alter, do not change (*na iñjantīti*). Because they are steady, standing firm like a pillar, “they do not alter,” i.e. do not undergo transmutation, (*esikatthambho viya ṭhitattā na calanti*).

and “do not change” (*na vipariṇamantīti*), i.e. do not abandon their original nature (*pakatiṃ na jahanti*).

“They won’t disturb one another;” (*na aññamaññaṃ byābādhentīti*) i.e. they won't injure one another (*na aññamaññaṃ upahananti*).

They are not able (*nālanti*) i.e., they are not capable (*na samatthā*).

The body of earth, etc. (*pathavikāyotiādīsu*) The body of earth is the earth itself (*pathavīyeva pathavikāyo*), or the assemblage of earth (*pathavisamūho vā*).

Therein (*tatthāti*) (they are) in those seven life-substances bodies (*tesu jīvasattamesu kāyesu*).

There is no killer, etc. (*sattannaṃ tveva kāyānanti*) Just as, when one strikes a heap of beans with a sword, the sword enters in between the beans (*yathā muggarāsiādīsu pahataṃ satthaṃ muggādīnaṃ antarena pavisati*), so the sword enters the space, the interstice, between the seven bodies (*evaṃ sattannaṃ kāyānaṃ antarena chiddena vivarena satthaṃ pavisati*).

Therein he shows: “I am taking his life” (*tattha ahaṃ imaṃ jīvitā voropemīti*), that is only a mere idea (*kevalaṃ saññāmattameva hotīti dasseti*).

mula_pali: 175. ‘‘Itthaṃ  kho me, bhante, pakudho kaccāyano sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno aññena aññaṃ byākāsi. Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṃ vā puṭṭho labujaṃ byākareyya, labujaṃ vā puṭṭho ambaṃ byākareyya; evameva kho me, bhante, pakudho kaccāyano sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno aññena aññaṃ byākāsi. Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, etadahosi – ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā vijite vasantaṃ apasādetabbaṃ maññeyyā’ti. So kho ahaṃ, bhante, pakudhassa kaccāyanassa bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ, anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano, anattamanavācaṃ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṃ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ.
mula_english:
“Thus, venerable sir, when I asked Pakudha Kaccāyana about a visible fruit of recluseship, he answered me in a completely irrelevant way.

Venerable sir, just as if one asked about a mango would speak about a breadfruit, or as if one asked about a breadfruit would speak about a mango, in the same way, when I asked Pakudha Kaccāyana about a visible fruit of recluseship, he answered me in a completely irrelevant way.

Then, venerable sir, I thought to myself: ‘One like myself should not think of troubling a *śramaṇa* or *brāhmaṇa* living in his realm.’

So I neither rejoiced in the statement of Pakudha Kaccāyana nor did I reject it. But though I neither rejoiced in it nor rejected it, I still felt dissatisfied, yet did not utter a word of dissatisfaction. Without accepting his doctrine, without embracing it, I got up from my seat and left.
commentary_pali: 173-175. Pakudhavāde akaṭāti akatā. Akaṭavidhāti akatavidhānā. Evaṃ karohīti kenaci kārāpitāpi na hontīti attho. Animmitāti iddhiyāpi na nimmitā. Animmātāti animmāpitā, keci animmāpetabbāti padaṃ vadanti, taṃ neva pāḷiyaṃ, na aṭṭhakathāyaṃ dissati. Vañjhādipadattayaṃ vuttatthameva. Na iñjantīti esikatthambho viya ṭhitattā na calanti. Na vipariṇamantīti pakatiṃ na jahanti. Na aññamaññaṃ byābādhentīti na aññamaññaṃ upahananti. Nālanti na samatthā. Pathavikāyotiādīsu pathavīyeva pathavikāyo, pathavisamūho vā. Tatthāti tesu jīvasattamesu kāyesu. Sattannaṃ tveva kāyānanti yathā muggarāsiādīsu pahataṃ satthaṃ muggādīnaṃ antarena pavisati, evaṃ sattannaṃ kāyānaṃ antarena chiddena vivarena satthaṃ pavisati. Tattha ahaṃ imaṃ jīvitā voropemīti kevalaṃ saññāmattameva hotīti dasseti.
commentary_english:
173-175.
In the *pakudha* doctrine, (they are) unmade and not making.
(They are) of unmade arrangement and not of an arrangement.
Thus, “Do this!” they are not made to do by anyone; this is the meaning.
Uncreated, not created even by supernormal power (*iddhiyā*).
Uncreated, not caused to be created. Some say the word is "should not be caused to be created" (*animmāpetabbāti*), but that is seen neither in the Pāli [text] nor in the commentary (*aṭṭhakathāyaṃ*).
The three words beginning with barren (*vañjhā*), etc., have only the meaning already stated.
They do not alter, do not change. Because they are steady, standing firm like a pillar, “they do not alter,” i.e. do not undergo transmutation,
and “do not change,” i.e. do not abandon their original nature (*pakatiṃ*).
“They won’t disturb one another;” that is, they will not injure one another.
They are not sufficient, they are not able.
The body of earth, etc. The body of earth is the earth itself, or the assemblage of earth (*pathavisamūho*)
Therein he shows: “I am taking his life,” that is only a mere idea (*saññāmattameva*).
Therein, in those bodies of the seventh living being (*jīvasattamesu kāyesu*).
There is no killer, etc. Just as, when one strikes a heap of beans with a sword (*sattham*), the sword enters in between the beans (*muggādīnaṃ*), so the sword (*sattham*) enters the space, the interstice, between the seven bodies.

mula_pali: 176. ‘‘Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ yena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃ ; upasaṅkamitvā nigaṇṭhena nāṭaputtena saddhiṃ sammodiṃ. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ahaṃ, bhante, nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ – ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho aggivessana, puthusippāyatanāni…pe… sakkā nu kho, bho aggivessana, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetu’nti?
mula_english:
“Venerable sir, on one occasion I approached Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta; after approaching Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta, I exchanged greetings with him. Having exchanged courteous greetings and amicable talk, I sat down to one side.

Having sat down to one side, venerable sir, I said this to Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta: ‘Just as these various vocational arts, Aggivessana… is it possible, Aggivessana, in this very life to describe the fruit of the ascetic life visible here and now?’”
commentary_pali: 176-178. Nāṭaputtavāde cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvutoti catukoṭṭhāsena saṃvarena saṃvuto. Sabbavārivāritocāti vāritasabbaudako paṭikkhittasabbasītodakoti attho. So kira sītodake sattasaññī hoti, tasmā na taṃ vaḷañjeti. Sabbavāriyuttoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena yutto. Sabbavāridhutoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena dhutapāpo. Sabbavāriphuṭoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena phuṭṭho. Gatattoti koṭippattacitto. Yatattoti saṃyatacitto. Ṭhitattoti suppatiṭṭhitacitto. Etassa vāde kiñci sāsanānulomampi atthi, asuddhaladdhitāya pana sabbā diṭṭhiyeva jātā.
commentary_english:
176-178.
In the doctrine of the Nāṭaputta, "restrained by the fourfold restraint" means restrained by a fourfold division of restraint.

"Restrained with regard to all water, etc." means: he rejects the use of all water and rejects all cold water.

It is said that he perceives sentient beings in cold water and thus does not use it.

"Endowed with all water-restraint" means: endowed with all prevention of evil.

"Purified by all water-restraint" means: one whose evil is shaken off by all prevention of evil.

"Touched by all water-restraint" means: touched by all prevention of evil.

"Gone to the Self" means: one whose mind has reached the summit.

"Self-controlled" : one who has subdued his mind (saṃyatacitto).

“Self-established” : one whose mind is well- established (suppatiṭṭhitacitto).

In his doctrine there is something that accords with the Buddha’s teaching; but because his theory is not pure, it is all counted as view.

mula_pali: 177. ‘‘Evaṃ  vutte, bhante, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto maṃ etadavoca – ‘idha, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvuto hoti. Kathañca, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvuto hoti? Idha, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho sabbavārivārito ca hoti, sabbavāriyutto ca, sabbavāridhuto ca, sabbavāriphuṭo ca. Evaṃ kho, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvuto hoti . Yato kho, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho evaṃ cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvuto hoti; ayaṃ vuccati, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto (syā. ka.) gatatto ca yatatto ca ṭhitatto cā’ti.
mula_english:
177.

"When this had been said, venerable sir, Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta said to me: 'Here, great king, a Nigaṇṭha is restrained by a fourfold restraint ( *cātuyāmasaṃvara-saṃvuto*).

And how, great king, is a Nigaṇṭha restrained by a fourfold restraint (*cātuyāmasaṃvara-saṃvuto*)? Here, great king, a Nigaṇṭha is restrained with regard to all water (*sabbavāri-vārito*); he is endowed with the avoidance of all evil (*sabbavāri-yutto*); he is cleansed by the avoidance of all evil (*sabbavāri-dhuto*); and he is suffused with the avoidance of all evil (*sabbavāri-phuṭo*).

In this way, great king, a Nigaṇṭha is restrained by a fourfold restraint (*cātuyāmasaṃvara-saṃvuto*).

Because, great king, a Nigaṇṭha is thus restrained by a fourfold restraint (*cātuyāmasaṃvara-saṃvuto*); this, great king, is what is called the Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta.

ka.

) perfected in himself (*gatatto*), controlled in himself (*yatatto*), and established in himself (*ṭhitatto*)."
commentary_pali: 176-178. Nāṭaputtavāde cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvutoti catukoṭṭhāsena saṃvarena saṃvuto. Sabbavārivāritocāti vāritasabbaudako paṭikkhittasabbasītodakoti attho. So kira sītodake sattasaññī hoti, tasmā na taṃ vaḷañjeti. Sabbavāriyuttoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena yutto. Sabbavāridhutoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena dhutapāpo. Sabbavāriphuṭoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena phuṭṭho. Gatattoti koṭippattacitto. Yatattoti saṃyatacitto. Ṭhitattoti suppatiṭṭhitacitto. Etassa vāde kiñci sāsanānulomampi atthi, asuddhaladdhitāya pana sabbā diṭṭhiyeva jātā.
commentary_english:
176-178.
In the doctrine of the Nāṭaputta, "restrained by the fourfold restraint (cātuyāmasaṃvara)" means restrained by a fourfold means of restraint.

"Restrained with regard to all water (sabbavārivārita)," etc., means one who has turned away from all water (vāritasabbaudaka), one who has rejected all cold water (paṭikkhittasabbasītodaka). Thus is the meaning.

It is said that he perceives sentient beings in cold water (sītodake sattasaññī hoti), and thus he does not use it (na taṃ vaḷañjeti).

"Endowed with all restraint (sabbavāriyutta)" means endowed with all prevention of evil (pāpavāraṇa).

"Purified by all restraint (sabbavāridhuta)" means one who has shaken off evil (dhutapāpo) by all prevention of evil (pāpavāraṇa).

"Permeated by all restraint (sabbavāriphuṭa)" means permeated by all prevention of evil (pāpavāraṇa).

"Gone to the Self (gatatta)" means one whose mind has reached the limit (koṭippattacitto).

"Self-controlled (yatatta)" means one who has subdued his mind (saṃyatacitto).

"Self-established (ṭhitatta)" means one whose mind is well-established (suppatiṭṭhitacitto).

In his doctrine (etassa vāde) there is something that accords with the Buddha’s teaching (sāsanānuloma); but because his theory is impure (asuddhaladdhitāya), it is all counted as mere view (diṭṭhiyeva jātā).

mula_pali: 178. ‘‘Itthaṃ  kho me, bhante, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno cātuyāmasaṃvaraṃ byākāsi. Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṃ vā puṭṭho labujaṃ byākareyya, labujaṃ vā puṭṭho ambaṃ byākareyya; evameva kho me, bhante, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno cātuyāmasaṃvaraṃ byākāsi. Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, etadahosi – ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā vijite vasantaṃ apasādetabbaṃ maññeyyā’ti . So kho ahaṃ, bhante, nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ. Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano anattamanavācaṃ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṃ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ.
mula_english:
178. "Thus, venerable sir, when I asked Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta about a visible fruit of recluseship (sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ), he explained to me the fourfold restraint (cātuyāmasaṃvaraṃ).

Just as, venerable sir, if one asked about a mango (ambaṃ) would speak about a breadfruit (labujaṃ), or if one asked about a breadfruit (labujaṃ) would speak about a mango (ambaṃ), in the same way, when I asked Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta about a visible fruit of recluseship (sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ), he explained to me the fourfold restraint (cātuyāmasaṃvaraṃ).

Then, venerable sir, I thought to myself: ‘How should one like myself think of troubling a *śramaṇa* or *brāhmaṇa* living in his realm?’

So I neither rejoiced in the statement of Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta, nor did I reject it.

Without accepting his doctrine, without rejecting it, feeling dissatisfied, without expressing my dissatisfaction, but keeping his words in mind, without overturning them, I got up from my seat and departed.
commentary_pali: 176-178. Nāṭaputtavāde cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvutoti catukoṭṭhāsena saṃvarena saṃvuto. Sabbavārivāritocāti vāritasabbaudako paṭikkhittasabbasītodakoti attho. So kira sītodake sattasaññī hoti, tasmā na taṃ vaḷañjeti. Sabbavāriyuttoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena yutto. Sabbavāridhutoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena dhutapāpo. Sabbavāriphuṭoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena phuṭṭho. Gatattoti koṭippattacitto. Yatattoti saṃyatacitto. Ṭhitattoti suppatiṭṭhitacitto. Etassa vāde kiñci sāsanānulomampi atthi, asuddhaladdhitāya pana sabbā diṭṭhiyeva jātā.
commentary_english:
176-178. In the doctrine of the Nāṭaputta, "restrained with the fourfold restraint (cātuyāmasaṃvara saṃvuta)" means restrained with a fourfold restraint (catukoṭṭhāsena saṃvarena saṃvuto).

"Restrained with regard to all water (sabbavārivāritocāti)" means restrained with regard to all water (vāritasabbaudako), rejecting all cold water (paṭikkhittasabbasītodako); this is the meaning (attho).

It is said that he perceives sentient beings in cold water (so kira sītodake sattasaññī hoti), and thus does not use it (tasmā na taṃ vaḷañjeti).

"Endowed with all restraints (sabbavāriyutto)" means endowed with all protections from evil (sabbena pāpavāraṇena yutto).

"Purified by all restraints (sabbavāridhuto)" means one whose evil is shaken off by all protections from evil (sabbena pāpavāraṇena dhutapāpo).

"Touched by all restraints (sabbavāriphuṭo)" means touched by all protections from evil (sabbena pāpavāraṇena phuṭṭho).

"Gone to the essence (gatatto)" means one whose mind has reached the extreme point (koṭippattacitto).

"Self-controlled (yatatto)" means one who has subdued his mind (saṃyatacitto).

"Self-established (ṭhitatto)" means one whose mind is well-established (suppatiṭṭhitacitto).

In his doctrine (etassa vāde) there is something that accords with the Buddha’s teaching (kiñci sāsanānulomampi atthi); but because his theory is not pure (asuddhaladdhitāya), it is all counted as view (sabbā diṭṭhiyeva jātā).

mula_pali: 179. ‘‘Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ yena sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā sañcayena belaṭṭhaputtena saddhiṃ sammodiṃ. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ahaṃ bhante, sañcayaṃ belaṭṭhaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ – ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho sañcaya, puthusippāyatanāni…pe… sakkā nu kho, bho sañcaya, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetu’nti?
mula_english: “Venerable sir, on one occasion I approached Sañjaya Belaṭṭhaputta; having approached Sañjaya Belaṭṭhaputta, I exchanged greetings with him ( *sammodiṃ*). After exchanging courteous conversation and greetings, I sat down to one side (*ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ*). Sitting to one side, venerable sir, I said this to Sañjaya Belaṭṭhaputta: ‘Just as there are these various crafts and skills... could you, Sañjaya, in the same way describe the fruit of the ascetic life visible in this very life (*diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetu*)?’”
commentary_pali: 179-181. Sañcayavādo amarāvikkhepe vuttanayo eva.
commentary_english: The same principle applies to *sañcayavāda* regarding *amarāvikkhepa*.
