"Vajjesūti akusaladhammesu": "In faults" means in unwholesome things (*akusaladhamma*).

"Bhayadassāvīti bhayadassī": "Seeing danger" means seeing danger.

"Samādāyāti sammā ādiyitvā": "Having undertaken" means having rightly taken up.

"Sikkhati sikkhāpadesūti sikkhāpadesu taṃ taṃ sikkhāpadaṃ samādiyitvā sikkhati": "He trains himself by undertaking the precepts of training" means in the precepts of training, he trains himself by undertaking each and every precept of training.

"Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana visuddhimagge vutto": This is a brief explanation; the detailed explanation is found in the *Visuddhimagga*.

"Kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena parisuddhājīvoti ettha ācāragocaraggahaṇeneva ca kusale kāyakammavacīkamme gahitepi yasmā idaṃ ājīvapārisuddhisīlaṃ nāma na ākāse vā rukkhaggādīsu vā uppajjati, kāyavacīdvāresuyeva pana uppajjati; tasmā tassa uppattidvāradassanatthaṃ kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalenāti vuttaṃ": "He comes to be endowed with wholesome bodily and verbal action, his livelihood is purified" - Here, although wholesome bodily and verbal action are included by the very taking up of "proper behavior and resort," since this moral discipline of purified livelihood does not arise in space or among the treetops, but arises only in the doors of body and speech, therefore, in order to show the doors where it arises, it is said: "He comes to be endowed with wholesome bodily and verbal action."

"Yasmā pana tena samannāgato, tasmā parisuddhājīvo": And since he is endowed with that, his livelihood is purified.

"Samaṇamuṇḍikaputtasuttantavasena (ma. ni. 2. 260) vā evaṃ vuttaṃ": Or, it was said thus according to the *Samaṇamuṇḍikaputta Suttanta*.

"Tattha hi ‘‘katame ca, thapati, kusalā sīlā? kusalaṃ kāyakammaṃ, kusalaṃ vacīkammaṃ, parisuddhaṃ ājīvampi kho ahaṃ thapati sīlasmiṃ vadāmī’’ti vuttaṃ": There, indeed, it was said, "And what, householder, are wholesome moralities? Wholesome bodily action, wholesome verbal action, and purified livelihood, householder, I declare to be morality."

"Yasmā pana tena samannāgato, tasmā parisuddhājīvoti veditabbo": Therefore, it should be understood that because he is endowed with that, his livelihood is purified.

"Sīlasampannoti brahmajāle vuttena tividhena sīlena samannāgato hoti": "Endowed with morality" means he is endowed with the threefold morality spoken of in the *Brahmajāla* .

"Indriyesu guttadvāroti manacchaṭṭhesu indriyesu pihitadvāro hoti": "Guarded as to the doors of the senses" means he is one whose doors are shut in the six senses, with the mind as the sixth.

"Satisampajaññena samannāgatoti abhikkante paṭikkantetiādīsu sattasu ṭhānesu satiyā ceva sampajaññena ca samannāgato hoti": "Endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension" means he is endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension in the seven instances, beginning with "in going forward, in going backward."

"Santuṭṭhoti catūsu paccayesu tividhena santosena santuṭṭho hoti": "Content" means he is content with the threefold contentment in the four requisites.

mula_pali: 193. ‘‘So evaṃ pabbajito samāno pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, kāyakammavacīkammena  samannāgato kusalena, parisuddhājīvo sīlasampanno, indriyesu guttadvāro guttadvāro, bhojane mattaññū (ka.), satisampajaññena samannāgato, santuṭṭho.
mula_english: 193. "And having thus gone forth, he lives restrained by the restraint of the *Pātimokkha*, possessed of proper conduct and resort, seeing danger in the slightest faults. Having undertaken the precepts, he trains himself in the precepts, endowed with wholesome bodily and verbal action, his livelihood is purified, and he is perfected in morality (*śīlasampanno*). He guards the doors of his senses (*indriyesu guttadvāro*), is moderate in eating (*bhojane mattaññū*), endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension (*satisampajaññena samannāgato*), and is content (*santuṭṭho*)."
commentary_pali: 192-193.Appaṃ vāti sahassato heṭṭhā bhogakkhandho appo nāma hoti, sahassato paṭṭhāya mahā. Ābandhanaṭṭhena ñātiyeva ñātiparivaṭṭo. Sopi vīsatiyā heṭṭhā appo nāma hoti, vīsatiyā paṭṭhāya mahā. Pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvutoti pātimokkhasaṃvarena samannāgato. Ācāragocarasampannoti ācārena ceva gocarena ca sampanno. Aṇumattesūti appamattakesu. Vajjesūti akusaladhammesu. Bhayadassāvīti bhayadassī. Samādāyāti sammā ādiyitvā. Sikkhati sikkhāpadesūti sikkhāpadesu taṃ taṃ sikkhāpadaṃ samādiyitvā sikkhati. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana visuddhimagge vutto. Kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena parisuddhājīvoti ettha ācāragocaraggahaṇeneva ca kusale kāyakammavacīkamme gahitepi yasmā idaṃ ājīvapārisuddhisīlaṃ nāma na ākāse vā rukkhaggādīsu vā uppajjati, kāyavacīdvāresuyeva pana uppajjati; tasmā tassa uppattidvāradassanatthaṃ kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalenāti vuttaṃ. Yasmā pana tena samannāgato, tasmā parisuddhājīvo. Samaṇamuṇḍikaputtasuttantavasena  (ma. ni. 2.260) vā evaṃ vuttaṃ. Tattha hi ‘‘katame ca, thapati, kusalā sīlā? Kusalaṃ  kāyakammaṃ, kusalaṃ vacīkammaṃ, parisuddhaṃ ājīvampi kho ahaṃ thapati sīlasmiṃ vadāmī’’ti vuttaṃ. Yasmā pana tena samannāgato, tasmā parisuddhājīvoti veditabbo. Sīlasampannoti brahmajāle vuttena tividhena sīlena samannāgato hoti. Indriyesu guttadvāroti manacchaṭṭhesu indriyesu pihitadvāro hoti. Satisampajaññena samannāgatoti abhikkante paṭikkantetiādīsu sattasu ṭhānesu satiyā ceva sampajaññena ca samannāgato hoti. Santuṭṭhoti catūsu paccayesu tividhena santosena santuṭṭho hoti.
commentary_english:
192-193. A hoard of wealth less than a thousand is said to be small, from a thousand onward, large.

A relative is just a circle of relatives because of the nature of being bound together.

That too, less than twenty is said to be small, from twenty onward, large.

*Pātimokkha-saṃvara-saṃvuto* means endowed with the restraint of the *Pātimokkha*.

*Ācāra-gocara-sampanno* means endowed with both proper conduct (*ācāra*) and proper resort (*gocara*).

*Aṇumattesu* means in very small matters (*appamattakesu*).

*Vajjesu* means in unwholesome things (*akusaladhammesu*).

*Bhayadassāvī* means seeing danger (*bhayadassī*).

*Samādāya* means having rightly taken up (*sammā ādiyitvā*).

*Sikkhati sikkhāpadesu* means he trains himself by undertaking each precept of training among the precepts of training (*sikkhāpadesu taṃ taṃ sikkhāpadaṃ samādiyitvā sikkhati*).

This is a summary here; the detailed explanation, however, is stated in the *Visuddhimagga*.

*Kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena parisuddhājīvo* means that here, even though wholesome bodily and verbal action are included by the taking up of proper conduct and resort, since this moral discipline of purified livelihood does not arise in space, among treetops, and so forth, but arises only in the doors of body and speech; therefore, in order to show the doors where it arises, it is said: "endowed with wholesome bodily and verbal action."

And since he is endowed with that, his livelihood is purified (*tasmā parisuddhājīvo*).

According to the *Samaṇamuṇḍikaputta Suttanta* (M.

N.

2.
260), it was said thus:

"What are the wholesome moralities, householder? Wholesome bodily action, wholesome verbal action; even purified livelihood, householder, I say is morality."

Since he is endowed with that, therefore his livelihood should be understood as purified (*parisuddhājīvo*).

*Sīlasampanno* means he is endowed with the threefold morality stated in the *Brahmajāla*.

*Indriyesu guttadvāro* means he has guarded doors in the six sense faculties, with mind as the sixth (*manacchaṭṭhesu indriyesu pihitadvāro hoti*).

*Satisampajaññena samannāgato* means he is endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension in the seven instances beginning with going forward and going back (*abhikkante paṭikkantetiādīsu sattasu ṭhānesu satiyā ceva sampajaññena ca samannāgato hoti*).

*Santuṭṭho* means he is content with the four requisites with the threefold contentment (*catūsu paccayesu tividhena santosena santuṭṭho hoti*).

mula_pali: 194. ‘‘Kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti? Idha, mahārāja, bhikkhu pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti. Nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ. ‘‘Adinnādānaṃ  pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ. ‘‘Abrahmacariyaṃ pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ. ‘‘Musāvādaṃ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṃvādako lokassa. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ. ‘‘Pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti; ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṃ  bhedāya; amutra  vā sutvā na imesaṃ akkhātā, amūsaṃ bhedāya. Iti bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātā, sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā, samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ. ‘‘Pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti; yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ. ‘‘Samphappalāpaṃ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti kālena sāpadesaṃ pariyantavatiṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ. ‘‘Bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā  paṭivirato hoti…pe… ekabhattiko hoti rattūparato virato vikālabhojanā. Naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā paṭivirato hoti. Mālāgandhavilepanadhāraṇamaṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti. Uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato hoti. Jātarūparajatapaṭiggahaṇā  paṭivirato hoti. Āmakadhaññapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti. Āmakamaṃsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti. Itthikumārikapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti. Dāsidāsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti. Ajeḷakapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti. Kukkuṭasūkarapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti. Hatthigavassavaḷavapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti. Khettavatthupaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti . Dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogā paṭivirato hoti. Kayavikkayā paṭivirato hoti. Tulākūṭakaṃsakūṭamānakūṭā paṭivirato hoti. Ukkoṭanavañcananikatisāciyogā paṭivirato hoti. Chedanavadhabandhanaviparāmosaālopasahasākārā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
194.
“And how, great king, is a *bhikkhu* perfected in morality (*śīlasampanno* *hoti*)? Here, great king, a *bhikkhu*, abandoning the killing of living beings (*pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya*), abstains from killing living beings (*pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti*).

He dwells having laid down the rod ( *nihitadaṇḍo*) and weapon (*nihitasattho*), conscientious (*lajjī*), full of kindness (*dayāpanno*), sympathetic for the welfare of all living beings (*sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati*).

This pertains to his moral discipline (*idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ*).

“Having abandoned taking what is not given (*adinnādānaṃ pahāya*), he abstains from taking what is not given (*adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti*), taking only what is given (*dinnādāyī*), expecting only what is given (*dinnapāṭikaṅkhī*), by not stealing (*athenena*) he abides with a pure mind (*sucibhūtena attanā viharati*).

This pertains to his moral discipline (*idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ*).

“Having abandoned unchastity (*abrahmacariyaṃ pahāya*), he lives a celibate life (*brahmacārī hoti*), aloof (*ārācārī*), abstaining from the vulgar practice of sexual intercourse (*virato methunā gāmadhammā*).

This pertains to his moral discipline (*idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ*).

“Having abandoned false speech (*musāvādaṃ pahāya*), he abstains from falsehood (*musāvādā paṭivirato hoti*). He speaks only the truth (*saccavādī*), he lives devoted to truth (*saccasandho*); trustworthy (*theto*) and reliable (*paccayiko*), he does not deceive anyone in the world (*avisaṃvādako lokassa*).

This pertains to his moral discipline (*idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ*).

“Having abandoned malicious speech (*pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāya*), he abstains from malicious speech (*pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti*); he does not repeat elsewhere what he has heard here in order to divide others from the people here (*ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṃ bhedāya*), nor does he repeat here what he has heard elsewhere in order to divide these from the people there (*amutra vā sutvā na imesaṃ akkhātā, amūsaṃ bhedāya*);

thus he is a reconciler of those who are divided (*bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātā*) and a promoter of friendships (*sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā*). Rejoicing (*samaggārāmo*), delighting (*samaggarato*), and exulting in concord (*samagganandī*), he speaks only words that are conducive to concord (*samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti*).

This pertains to his moral discipline (*idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ*).

“Having abandoned harsh speech (*pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya*), he abstains from harsh speech (*pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti*). He speaks only such words as are gentle (*nelā*), pleasing to the ear (*kaṇṇasukhā*), endearing (*pemanīyā*), going to the heart (*hadayaṅgamā*), polite (*porī*), amiable (*bahujanakantā*) and agreeable to the manyfolk (*bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti*).

This pertains to his moral discipline (*idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ*).

“Having abandoned idle chatter (*samphappalāpaṃ pahāya*), he abstains from idle chatter (*samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti*). He speaks at the right time (*kālavādī*), speaks what is factual (*bhūtavādī*) and beneficial (*atthavādī*), speaks on the Dhamma (*dhammavādī*) and the Discipline (*vinayavādī*). His words are worth treasuring (*nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti*); they are timely (*kālena*), backed by reasons (*sāpadesaṃ*), measured (*pariyantavatiṃ*), and connected with the good (*atthasaṃhitaṃ*).

This pertains to his moral discipline (*idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ*).

“He abstains from damaging seed and plant life (*bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā paṭivirato hoti*)…pe… He eats only in one part of the day (*ekabhattiko hoti*), refraining from food at night (*rattūparato*) and from eating at improper times (*virato vikālabhojanā*).

He abstains from dancing (*naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā paṭivirato hoti*), singing, instrumental music, and from witnessing unsuitable shows.

He abstains from wearing garlands (*mālāgandhavilepanadhāraṇamaṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti*), embellishing himself with scents, and beautifying himself with unguents.

He abstains from high and luxurious beds and seats (*uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato hoti*).

He avoids accepting gold and silver (*jātarūparajatapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti*).

He avoids accepting raw grain (*āmakadhaññapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti*).

He avoids accepting raw meat (*āmakamaṃsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti*).

He avoids accepting women and girls (*itthikumārikapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti*).

He avoids accepting male and female slaves (*dāsidāsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti*).

He avoids accepting goats and sheep (*ajeḷakapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti*).

He avoids accepting fowl and swine (*kukkuṭasūkarapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti*).

He avoids accepting elephants, cattle, horses and mares (*hatthigavassavaḷavapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti*).

He avoids accepting fields and lands (*khettavatthupaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti*).

He abstains from running messages and errands (*dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogā paṭivirato hoti*).

He abstains from buying and selling (*kayavikkayā paṭivirato hoti*).

He abstains from dealing with false weights, false metals, and false measures (*tulākūṭakaṃsakūṭamānakūṭā paṭivirato hoti*).

He abstains from the crooked ways of bribery, deception, and fraud (*ukkoṭanavañcananikatisāciyogā paṭivirato hoti*).

He abstains from mutilating, executing, imprisoning, robbery, plunder, and violence (*chedanavadhabandhanaviparāmosaālopasahasākārā paṭivirato hoti*).

This pertains to his moral discipline (*idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ*)."
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having thus laid down the outline, distributing it in due order, he said, "And how, O great king, does a *bhikṣu* become endowed with virtue (śīla)?" and so on.
There, this also exists in his virtue; that is, abstaining from taking life (*prāṇātipātā veramaṇi*) is one virtue in the virtue of that *bhikṣu*—this is the meaning.
Or, this is a comprehensive expression in the sense of individual statements.
Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*mahā-aṭṭhakathā*), this meaning has been stated: "This is the virtue of that *śramaṇa*."
The remainder should be understood in the way already described in the *Brahmajāla*.
This exists in his virtue; that is, this is his virtue—this is the meaning.

mula_pali: 195. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhaṃ anuyuttā viharanti. Seyyathidaṃ – mūlabījaṃ khandhabījaṃ phaḷubījaṃ aggabījaṃ bījabījameva pañcamaṃ, iti evarūpā bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā  paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
“Furthermore, some ascetics and *brāhmaṇas*, while living on food offered in faith, remain addicted to activities involving the destruction of seed and plant life (*bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhaṃ anuyuttā viharanti*).

That is to say: root-seeds (*mūlabījaṃ*), stem-seeds (*khandhabījaṃ*), joint-seeds (*phaḷubījaṃ*), cutting-seeds (*aggabījaṃ*), and seed-seeds (*bījabījameva*) as the fifth. From such destruction of seed and plant life, he refrains.

This is part of his moral conduct (*sīlasmiṃ*).
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having set forth the topic in this way, distributing it step by step, he said, "And how, great king, does a *bhikṣu* become accomplished in morality ( *śīla-sampanno* )?" and so on.
Therein, this also exists in his morality ( *śīlasmiṃ* ); that is, abstaining from killing living beings (*prāṇātipātā veramaṇi*) is one aspect of morality (*sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho*).
Or, this is a comprehensive term in the sense of individual expression.
Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṃ*), this meaning has been stated: "This is the morality (*śīla*) of that ascetic (*samaṇassa*)."
The remainder should be understood in the manner already described in the *Brahmajāla*.
This exists in his morality (*sīlasmiṃ*); that is, this is his morality (*idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho*).

mula_pali: 196. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ sannidhikāraparibhogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti. Seyyathidaṃ – annasannidhiṃ pānasannidhiṃ vatthasannidhiṃ yānasannidhiṃ sayanasannidhiṃ gandhasannidhiṃ āmisasannidhiṃ, iti vā iti evarūpā sannidhikāraparibhogā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
“Furthermore, some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered by the faithful, remain addicted to the enjoyment of stored-up goods (*sannidhikāraparibhoga*).

That is to say, they enjoy stored-up food (*annasannidhi*), stored-up drinks (*pānasannidhi*), stored-up clothing (*vatthasannidhi*), stored-up carriages (*yānasannidhi*), stored-up beds (*sayanasannidhi*), stored-up perfumes (*gandhasannidhi*), and stored-up meat (*āmisasannidhi*). He abstains from such enjoyment of stored-up goods.

This also pertains to his virtue (*śīla*).
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Thus, setting aside the *mātikaṃ*, dividing it sequentially, he said, "And how, great king, is a *bhikkhu* accomplished in virtue ( *śīlasampanno* )?" and so forth.
There, this also exists in his virtue; that is, this abstinence from killing living beings (*prāṇātipātā veramaṇi*) is one virtue (*śīla*) among his virtues, this is the meaning.
Or, this is an expression in the sense of individuality (*paccattavacanatthe*), a generality (*bhummaṃ*).
Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*Mahāaṭṭhakathā*) it is said that this is the meaning of the virtue of that *śamaṇa*.
The remainder should be understood in the same way as stated in the *Brahmajāla*.
This exists in his virtue; that is, this is his virtue, this is the meaning.

mula_pali: 197. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ visūkadassanaṃ anuyuttā viharanti. Seyyathidaṃ  – naccaṃ gītaṃ vāditaṃ pekkhaṃ akkhānaṃ  pāṇissaraṃ vetāḷaṃ kumbhathūṇaṃ sobhanakaṃ caṇḍālaṃ vaṃsaṃ dhovanaṃ hatthiyuddhaṃ assayuddhaṃ mahiṃsayuddhaṃ usabhayuddhaṃ ajayuddhaṃ meṇḍayuddhaṃ kukkuṭayuddhaṃ vaṭṭakayuddhaṃ daṇḍayuddhaṃ muṭṭhiyuddhaṃ nibbuddhaṃ uyyodhikaṃ balaggaṃ senābyūhaṃ anīkadassanaṃ iti vā iti evarūpā visūkadassanā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
"Furthermore, some ascetics and *brāhmaṇas*, while living on food given in faith (*saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni*), remain addicted to attending unsuitable shows (*visūkadassanaṃ anuyuttā viharanti*), such as: dancing (*naccaṃ*), singing (*gītaṃ*), instrumental music (*vāditaṃ*), displays (*pekkhaṃ*), recitations (*akkhānaṃ*), hand-music (*pāṇissaraṃ*), *vetāḷaṃ*, *kumbhathūṇaṃ*, *sobhanakaṃ*, *caṇḍālaṃ*, *vaṃsaṃ*, *dhovanaṃ*, elephant fights (*hatthiyuddhaṃ*), horse fights (*assayuddhaṃ*), buffalo fights (*mahiṃsayuddhaṃ*), bull fights (*usabhayuddhaṃ*), goat fights (*ajayuddhaṃ*), ram fights (*meṇḍayuddhaṃ*), cock fights (*kukkuṭayuddhaṃ*), quail fights (*vaṭṭakayuddhaṃ*), stick fights (*daṇḍayuddhaṃ*), boxing (*muṭṭhiyuddhaṃ*), *nibbuddhaṃ*, *uyyodhikaṃ*, *balaggaṃ*, array of troops (*senābyūhaṃ*), and military reviews (*anīkadassanaṃ*). He abstains from attending such unsuitable shows.

This pertains to his moral discipline (*sīlasmiṃ*).
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having thus laid down the outline, dividing it sequentially, he said, "And how, great king, does a *bhikṣu* become endowed with morality (*śīla*)?" etc.

There, this also exists in his morality (*śīla*), that is, this abstaining from killing living beings (*prāṇātipātā veramaṇi*) is one aspect of morality (*śīla*) for him; this is the meaning.

Or, this is a comprehensive expression in the sense of individual statements.

Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*Mahā-aṭṭhakathā*) it is said, "This too is the morality (*śīla*) of that *śramaṇa*," this itself is the meaning that is stated.

The rest should be understood in the same way as stated in the *Brahmajāla*.

This exists in his morality (*śīla*), this is his morality (*śīla*); this is the meaning.

mula_pali: 198. ‘‘Yathā  vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ jūtappamādaṭṭhānānuyogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti. Seyyathidaṃ – aṭṭhapadaṃ dasapadaṃ ākāsaṃ parihārapathaṃ santikaṃ khalikaṃ ghaṭikaṃ salākahatthaṃ akkhaṃ paṅgacīraṃ vaṅkakaṃ mokkhacikaṃ ciṅgulikaṃ pattāḷhakaṃ rathakaṃ dhanukaṃ akkharikaṃ manesikaṃ yathāvajjaṃ iti vā iti evarūpā jūtappamādaṭṭhānānuyogā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english: "Furthermore, some venerable ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered in faith, remain addicted to various games and pursuits that are grounds for negligence, such as aṭṭhapada, dasapada, ākāsa, parihārapatha, santika, khalika, ghaṭika, salākahattha, akkha, paṅgacīra, vaṅkaka, mokkhacika, ciṅgulika, pattāḷhaka, rathaka, dhanuka, akkharika, manesika, and yathāvajja. He abstains from such games and pursuits that are grounds for negligence. This pertains to his virtue (śīla)."
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having set forth the outline in this way, distributing it sequentially, he said, "And how, great king, does a *bhikṣu* become endowed with virtue (śīla)?" and so forth.

Therein, this also exists within his virtue; that is, this abstinence from taking life (*prāṇātipātā veramaṇi*) of a *bhikṣu* is one virtue (śīla). This is the meaning.

Or, this is an expression in the sense of individualization, an abundance.

Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*mahāaṭṭhakathā*), this meaning is stated: "This is the virtue (śīla) of that *śramaṇa*."

The remainder should be understood in the same way as stated in the *Brahmajāla*.

This exists within his virtue; this is his virtue (śīla). This is the meaning.

mula_pali: 199. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ uccāsayanamahāsayanaṃ anuyuttā viharanti. Seyyathidaṃ – āsandiṃ pallaṅkaṃ gonakaṃ cittakaṃ paṭikaṃ paṭalikaṃ tūlikaṃ vikatikaṃ uddalomiṃ ekantalomiṃ kaṭṭissaṃ koseyyaṃ kuttakaṃ hatthattharaṃ assattharaṃ rathattharaṃ ajinappaveṇiṃ kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇaṃ sauttaracchadaṃ ubhatolohitakūpadhānaṃ iti vā iti evarūpā  uccāsayanamahāsayanā  paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
“Or he might say: ‘Whereas some recluses and *brāhmaṇas*, while living on food offered in faith, enjoy the use of high and luxurious beds and seats, such as: spacious couches (*āsandiṃ*); thrones with animal figures carved on the supports (*pallaṅkaṃ*); long-haired coverlets (*gonakaṃ*); multi-colored patchwork coverlets (*cittakaṃ*); white woollen coverlets (*paṭikaṃ*); woollen coverlets embroidered with flowers (*paṭalikaṃ*); quilts stuffed with cotton (*tūlikaṃ*); woollen coverlets embroidered with animal figures (*vikatikaṃ*); woollen coverlets with hair on both sides (*uddalomiṃ*) or on one side (*ekantalomiṃ*); bedspreads embroidered with gems (*kaṭṭissaṃ*); silk coverlets (*koseyyaṃ*); dance-hall carpets (*kuttakaṃ*); elephant rugs (*hatthattharaṃ*), horse rugs (*assattharaṃ*), or chariot rugs (*rathattharaṃ*); rugs of antelope-skins (*ajinappaveṇiṃ*); choice spreads made of *kadali*-deer hides (*kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇaṃ*); couches with awnings (*souttaracchadaṃ*), or with red cushions at both ends (*ubhatolohitakūpadhānaṃ*)—the ascetic Gotama refrains from such high and wide beds.

Thus he is perfected in morality (*idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ*).
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having laid down the topic in this way, and dividing it sequentially, he said, "And how, O great king, is a *bhikṣu* (monk) accomplished in virtue (sīla)?" and so forth.

Therein, this also exists in his virtue; that is, this abstinence from killing living beings (*prāṇātipātā veramaṇī*) is one virtue in the virtue of that *bhikṣu* (monk)—such is the meaning.

Or, this is the sense of individual expression, the sense of the aggregate.

Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*mahāaṭṭhakathā*) it is said, "This is the virtue of that *śramaṇa* (mendicant)"; this is the meaning stated.

The rest should be understood according to the method stated in the *Brahmajāla*.

This exists in his virtue; this is his virtue—such is the meaning.

mula_pali: 200. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ maṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānānuyogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti. Seyyathidaṃ – ucchādanaṃ parimaddanaṃ nhāpanaṃ sambāhanaṃ ādāsaṃ añjanaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ mukhacuṇṇaṃ mukhalepanaṃ hatthabandhaṃ sikhābandhaṃ daṇḍaṃ nāḷikaṃ asiṃ khaggaṃ (sī. pī.), asiṃ khaggaṃ (syā. kaṃ.), khaggaṃ asiṃ (ka.) chattaṃ citrupāhanaṃ uṇhīsaṃ maṇiṃ vālabījaniṃ odātāni vatthāni dīghadasāni iti vā iti evarūpā maṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānānuyogā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
200. “Or, some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food given in faith, remain addicted to various forms of self-adornment and embellishment.

Specifically, they indulge in rubbing scented powders, massaging, bathing in perfumed water, shampooing, using mirrors, ointments, garlands, scents, unguents, cosmetics, bracelets, headbands, fancy sticks, bottles, swords, *khagga*, a sword, *khagga*, a sword, parasols, decorated sandals, turbans, gems, yak-tail fans, white robes with long fringes, and so forth. They refrain from such pursuits of self-adornment.

This, too, is part of his virtue (śīla).
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having established the topic in this way, [he] gradually explains, "And how, great king, does a *bhikṣu* become accomplished in virtue ( *śīlasampanno* )?" and so on.
Therein, this also exists in his virtue; that is, for that *bhikṣu*, refraining from killing (*pāṇātipātā veramaṇi*) is one virtue within virtue—this is the meaning.
Or, this is a plural [form] in the sense of individual statements.
Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*Mahā-aṭṭhakathā*), this too is the virtue of that *śramaṇa*; this very meaning has been stated.
The remainder should be understood in the way already described in the *Brahmajāla*.
This exists in his virtue; this is his virtue—this is the meaning.

mula_pali: 201. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ anuyuttā viharanti. Seyyathidaṃ – rājakathaṃ corakathaṃ mahāmattakathaṃ senākathaṃ bhayakathaṃ yuddhakathaṃ annakathaṃ pānakathaṃ vatthakathaṃ sayanakathaṃ mālākathaṃ gandhakathaṃ ñātikathaṃ yānakathaṃ gāmakathaṃ nigamakathaṃ nagarakathaṃ janapadakathaṃ itthikathaṃ itthikathaṃ purisakathaṃ kumārakathaṃ kumārikathaṃ (ka.) sūrakathaṃ visikhākathaṃ kumbhaṭṭhānakathaṃ pubbapetakathaṃ  nānattakathaṃ lokakkhāyikaṃ  samuddakkhāyikaṃ itibhavābhavakathaṃ iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānakathāya paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english: 201. ”‘Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered by the faithful, remain attached to such frivolous chatter, namely: talk about kings, robbers, ministers, armies, dangers, wars, food, drink, clothes, beds, garlands, perfumes, relatives, carriages, villages, towns and cities, countries, women, heroes, street- and well-gossip, talk of the departed, desultory chat, speculations about land and sea, talk about being and non-being, he refrains from such conversation. This pertains to his moral discipline.
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having set forth the outline in this way, gradually explaining, he said, "And how, O great king, does a *bhikṣu* become accomplished in virtue ( *śīla-sampanna*)?" and so forth.

Therein, this also occurs in his virtue (*śīla*): this, too, that for a *bhikṣu*, abstaining from taking life (*prāṇātipātā veramaṇi*), is one virtue (*ekaṃ śīlaṃ*)—this is the meaning.

Or, this is the meaning of individual expression (*paccattavacanatthe*) or a generality (*bhummaṃ*).

Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*mahāaṭṭhakathā*) this meaning is stated: "This, too, is the virtue (*śīla*) of that *śramaṇa*."

The remainder should be understood in the same way as stated in the *Brahmajāla*.

This occurs in his virtue (*śīla*): this is his virtue (*śīla*)—this is the meaning.

mula_pali: 202. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ viggāhikakathaṃ anuyuttā viharanti. Seyyathidaṃ  – na tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāsi, ahaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāmi, kiṃ tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānissasi, micchā paṭipanno tvamasi, ahamasmi sammā paṭipanno, sahitaṃ me, asahitaṃ te, pure vacanīyaṃ pacchā avaca, pacchā vacanīyaṃ pure avaca, adhiciṇṇaṃ te viparāvattaṃ, āropito te vādo, niggahito tvamasi, cara vādappamokkhāya, nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosīti iti vā iti evarūpāya viggāhikakathāya paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
"Or, some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food given in faith, remain engaged in disputes and arguments.

For example, they might say: ‘You don’t understand this *dharma* and *vinaya* (doctrine and discipline). I understand this *dharma* and *vinaya*. How could you understand this *dharma* and *vinaya*? You are practicing incorrectly. I am practicing correctly. I am consistent; you are not. You said what should have been said first, last; you said what should have been said last, first. What you took so long to think out has been refuted. Your argument has been overthrown; you are defeated. Go, try to save your doctrine—get out of that if you can!’ Thus, he refrains from such disputatious talk.

This, too, pertains to his moral conduct (*śīla*).
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having laid down the topic in this way, gradually explaining, he said, "And how, great king, does a *bhikṣu* become endowed with virtue (śīla)?" and so on.

Therein, this is also his virtue; that is, for that *bhikṣu*, abstaining from killing living beings is one virtue within virtue—this is the meaning.

Or, this is a collective [term] in the sense of individual statements.

Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*Mahā-aṭṭhakathā*) it is said, "This too is the *śīla* of that renunciate," this itself is the meaning that was stated.

The remainder should be understood according to the method stated in the *Brahmajāla*.

This is his virtue within virtue; this is his virtue—this is the meaning.

mula_pali: 203. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogaṃ  anuyuttā viharanti. Seyyathidaṃ – raññaṃ, rājamahāmattānaṃ, khattiyānaṃ, brāhmaṇānaṃ, gahapatikānaṃ, kumārānaṃ – ‘idha gaccha, amutrāgaccha, idaṃ hara, amutra idaṃ āharā’ti iti vā iti evarūpā dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
203. "Whereas some venerable ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food given in faith, remain addicted to engaging in the practice of running errands and messages, such as for kings (rajñam), high ministers (rājamahāmattānam), nobles (khattiyānam), Brahmins (brāhmaṇānam), householders (gahapatikānam), or young men (kumārānam)—'Go here, go there, take this, bring that from there'—he abstains from such errand-running.

This pertains to his morality (śīlasmiṃ).
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having thus laid down the outline, distributing it systematically, he said, "And how, great king, does a *bhikṣu* become accomplished in virtue ( *śīlasampanna*)?" and so on.

Therein, this also occurs in his virtue; that is, for that *bhikṣu*, abstaining from injury to living beings (*prāṇātipātā veramaṇi*) is one virtue (*śīla*). This is the meaning.

Or, this is a comprehensive term in the sense of individual expression.

Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*mahāaṭṭhakathā*), this meaning itself is stated: "This is the virtue (*śīla*) of that *śramaṇa*."

The remainder should be understood in the same way as stated in the *Brahmajāla*.

This occurs in his virtue; this is his virtue. This is the meaning.

mula_pali: 204. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te kuhakā ca honti lapakā ca nemittikā ca nippesikā ca lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīṃsitāro ca. Iti evarūpā kuhanalapanā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ’’.
mula_english:
“Or, some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on the food offered in faith, remain addicted to scheming (*kuhakā*), chattering (*lapakā*), hinting (*nemittikā*), belittling (*nippesikā*), and pursuing gain with gain (*lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīṃsitāro*).

He abstains from such kinds of scheming and talking (*kuhanalapanā paṭivirato hoti*).

This pertains to his moral discipline (*idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ*).”
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having set forth the outline in this way, distributing it sequentially, he said, "And how, great king, is a *bhikṣu* (monk) accomplished in virtue ( *śīla-sampanna*)?" and so on.

Therein, "This also belongs to him in virtue," means, "This abstaining from the destruction of life (*prāṇātipātā veramaṇi*) is one virtue (*śīla*) of the *bhikṣu* in virtue (*śīla*)."

Or, this is a plural in the sense of individual expression.

Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*Mahā-aṭṭhakathā*), it is said, "This also is the virtue (*śīla*) of that *śramaṇa* (recluse)," this is the meaning that was stated.

The remainder should be understood by the method stated in the *Brahmajāla*.

"This belongs to him in virtue (*śīla*)," means, "This is his virtue (*śīla*)."

mula_pali: 205. ‘‘Yathā  vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti. Seyyathidaṃ – aṅgaṃ nimittaṃ uppātaṃ supinaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ mūsikacchinnaṃ aggihomaṃ dabbihomaṃ thusahomaṃ kaṇahomaṃ taṇḍulahomaṃ sappihomaṃ  telahomaṃ  mukhahomaṃ lohitahomaṃ aṅgavijjā vatthuvijjā khattavijjā sivavijjā bhūtavijjā bhūrivijjā ahivijjā visavijjā vicchikavijjā mūsikavijjā sakuṇavijjā vāyasavijjā pakkajjhānaṃ saraparittāṇaṃ migacakkaṃ iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
“Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, feeding on the food of the faithful, make their living by such base arts, such wrong means of livelihood as: palmistry (*aṅga*), divining by signs (*nimitta*), portents (*uppāta*), dreams (*supina*), body-marks (*lakkhaṇa*), mouse-gnawings (*mūsikacchinna*), fire-oblations (*aggihoma*), oblations from a ladle (*dabbihoma*), of husks (*thusahoma*), rice-powder (*kaṇahoma*), rice-grains (*taṇḍulahoma*), ghee (*sappihoma*) or oil (*telahoma*), from the mouth (*mukhahoma*) or of blood (*lohitahoma*), reading the finger-tips (*aṅgavijjā*), house- and garden-lore (*vatthuvijjā*), skill in charms (*khattavijjā*), ghost-lore (*sivavijjā*), earth-house lore (*bhūtavijjā*), snake-lore (*bhūrivijjā*), poison-lore (*ahivijjā*), rat-lore (*visavijjā*), bird-lore (*vicchikavijjā*), crow-lore (*mūsikavijjā*), foretelling a person’s life-span (*sakuṇavijjā*), charms against arrows (*vāyasavijjā*), knowledge of animals’ cries (*pakkajjhānaṃ*), the he refrains from such base arts and wrong means of livelihood.

This pertains to his moral discipline (*sīlasmiṃ*).
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having thus set aside the outline, he proceeds to explain step by step, saying, "And how, great king, is a *bhikṣu* accomplished in virtue (śīla)?" etc.

There, "This is his virtue (śīla)" means that this, for him, the *bhikṣu*, is abstinence (*veramaṇi*) from taking life (*pāṇātipātā*), virtue (*śīla*), one virtue (*śīla*).

Or, this is said in the sense of individual expression.

Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*Mahā-aṭṭhakathā*) it is said, "This is the virtue (*śīla*) of that *śramaṇa*; this is the meaning."

The remainder should be understood in the same way as stated in the *Brahmajāla*.

"This is his virtue (śīla)" means, "This is his virtue (śīla)."

mula_pali: 206. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti. Seyyathidaṃ – maṇilakkhaṇaṃ vatthalakkhaṇaṃ daṇḍalakkhaṇaṃ satthalakkhaṇaṃ asilakkhaṇaṃ usulakkhaṇaṃ dhanulakkhaṇaṃ āvudhalakkhaṇaṃ itthilakkhaṇaṃ purisalakkhaṇaṃ kumāralakkhaṇaṃ kumārilakkhaṇaṃ dāsalakkhaṇaṃ dāsilakkhaṇaṃ hatthilakkhaṇaṃ assalakkhaṇaṃ mahiṃsalakkhaṇaṃ usabhalakkhaṇaṃ golakkhaṇaṃ ajalakkhaṇaṃ meṇḍalakkhaṇaṃ kukkuṭalakkhaṇaṃ vaṭṭakalakkhaṇaṃ godhālakkhaṇaṃ kaṇṇikalakkhaṇaṃ kacchapalakkhaṇaṃ migalakkhaṇaṃ iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english: “Whereas some recluses and *brāhmaṇas*, while living on the food offered by the faithful, earn their living by a wrong means of livelihood, by such debased arts, for example, judging the marks of gems (*maṇilakkhaṇaṃ*), garments (*vatthalakkhaṇaṃ*), staffs (*daṇḍalakkhaṇaṃ*), swords (*asilakkhaṇaṃ*), spears (*usulakkhaṇaṃ*), arrows (*dhanulakkhaṇaṃ*), weapons (*āvudhalakkhaṇaṃ*), women (*itthilakkhaṇaṃ*), men (*purisalakkhaṇaṃ*), boys (*kumāralakkhaṇaṃ*), girls (*kumārilakkhaṇaṃ*), male slaves (*dāsalakkhaṇaṃ*), female slaves (*dāsilakkhaṇaṃ*), elephants (*hatthilakkhaṇaṃ*), horses (*assalakkhaṇaṃ*), buffaloes (*mahiṃsalakkhaṇaṃ*), bulls (*usabhalakkhaṇaṃ*), cows (*golakkhaṇaṃ*), goats (*ajalakkhaṇaṃ*), rams (*meṇḍalakkhaṇaṃ*), cocks (*kukkuṭalakkhaṇaṃ*), quail (*vaṭṭakalakkhaṇaṃ*), iguanas (*godhālakkhaṇaṃ*), earrings (*kaṇṇikalakkhaṇaṃ*), tortoises (*kacchapalakkhaṇaṃ*), deer (*migalakkhaṇaṃ*), he refrains from such base arts and wrong means of livelihood. This pertains to his moral discipline (*sīlasmiṃ*).
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having set forth the outline in this way, distributing it sequentially, he said, "And how, great king, is a *bhikkhu* accomplished in virtue (*śīla-sampanna*)?" and so forth.

Therein, the meaning is: "This also exists in his virtue (*śīla*); that is, for this *bhikkhu*, abstaining from the taking of life (*prāṇātipātā veramaṇi*) is one virtue (*śīla*)."

Or, this [term] is a collective [noun] in the sense of individual expressions.

Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*Mahā-aṭṭhakathā*), it is said that this is the virtue (*śīla*) of that *śramaṇa*; this is the very meaning.

The remainder should be understood in the way already described in the *Brahmajāla*.

The meaning is: "This exists in his virtue (*śīla*); that is, this is his virtue (*śīla*)."

mula_pali: 207. ‘‘Yathā  vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya  micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti. Seyyathidaṃ – raññaṃ niyyānaṃ bhavissati, raññaṃ aniyyānaṃ bhavissati, abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ upayānaṃ bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ apayānaṃ bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ upayānaṃ bhavissati, abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ apayānaṃ bhavissati, abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ jayo bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ parājayo bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ jayo bhavissati, abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ parājayo bhavissati, iti imassa jayo bhavissati, imassa parājayo bhavissati iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
207.

“Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on the food offered in faith, earn their living by wrong means of livelihood, by such base arts, namely: ‘The king will march forth; the king will return; our king will advance and the enemy king will retreat; the enemy king will advance and our king will retreat; our king will triumph and the enemy king will be defeated; the enemy king will triumph and our king will be defeated; thus there will be victory for one and defeat for the other’— he abstains from such wrong means of livelihood, from such *tiryagvidyā* (base arts).

This pertains to his *śīla* (moral discipline).
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having thus laid down the topic and distributing it gradually, he said, "And how, great king, is a *bhikṣu* endowed with morality?" etc.
Therein, this also exists in his morality; that is, abstaining from killing living beings is one aspect of the *bhikṣu's* morality—this is the meaning.
Or, this is a collective term in the sense of individual expressions.
Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*Mahā-aṭṭhakathā*) it is said: "This is the morality of that *śramaṇa*; this itself is the meaning."
The remainder should be understood in the same way as stated in the *Brahmajāla*.
This exists in his morality; this is his morality—this is the meaning.

mula_pali: 208. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti. Seyyathidaṃ – candaggāho bhavissati, sūriyaggāho bhavissati, nakkhattaggāho bhavissati, candimasūriyānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, candimasūriyānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati, nakkhattānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, nakkhattānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati , ukkāpāto bhavissati, disāḍāho bhavissati, bhūmicālo bhavissati, devadudrabhi bhavissati, candimasūriyanakkhattānaṃ uggamanaṃ ogamanaṃ saṃkilesaṃ vodānaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipāko  candaggāho bhavissati, evaṃvipāko sūriyaggāho bhavissati, evaṃvipāko  nakkhattaggāho bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ candimasūriyānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ candimasūriyānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ nakkhattānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ nakkhattānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipāko ukkāpāto bhavissati, evaṃvipāko disāḍāho bhavissati, evaṃvipāko bhūmicālo bhavissati, evaṃvipāko devadudrabhi bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ candimasūriyanakkhattānaṃ uggamanaṃ ogamanaṃ saṃkilesaṃ vodānaṃ bhavissati iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
“Furthermore, some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food given in faith, maintain their lives by wrong livelihood, by base arts such as these:

Specifically, predicting: there will be a *candaggāho*, an eclipse of the moon; there will be a *sūriyaggāho*, an eclipse of the sun; there will be a *nakkhattaggāho*, an eclipse of a constellation; the *candimasūriyānaṃ* (moon and sun) will go on their proper course (*pathagamanaṃ*); the *candimasūriyānaṃ* will go astray (*uppathagamanaṃ*); the constellations (*nakkhattānaṃ*) will go on their proper course; the constellations will go astray; there will be a *ukkāpāto*, a fall of meteors; there will be a *disāḍāho*, a blaze in the sky; there will be a *bhūmicālo*, an earthquake; there will be a *devadudrabhi*, a thunder of the gods; there will be a rising (*uggamanaṃ*) and setting (*ogamanaṃ*), a darkening (*saṃkilesaṃ*) and brightening (*vodānaṃ*) of the moon, the sun and the stars; and 'such will be the *evaṃvipāko* outcome of these things'. He abstains from such wrong means of livelihood, from such base arts.

This pertains to his virtue (*sīlasmiṃ*).
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having thus laid down the outline, distributing it gradually, he said, "And how, O great king, is a *bhikṣu* endowed with virtue ( *śīla-sampanno*)?" and so on.

There, it occurs to him, "In virtue ( *śīla*), this is his virtue." And also, for that *bhikṣu*, abstinence (*veramaṇi*) from taking life (*pāṇātipātā*) is one virtue in virtue ( *śīla*), this is the meaning.

Or, this is the meaning in the context of individual expression.

Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*mahā-aṭṭhakathā*), this meaning is stated: "This is the virtue of that *śramaṇa*."

The remainder should be understood in the same manner as stated in the *Brahmajāla*.

It occurs to him, "In virtue ( *śīla*), this is his virtue," this is the meaning.

mula_pali: 209. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya  micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti. Seyyathidaṃ – suvuṭṭhikā bhavissati, dubbuṭṭhikā bhavissati, subhikkhaṃ bhavissati, dubbhikkhaṃ bhavissati, khemaṃ bhavissati, bhayaṃ bhavissati, rogo bhavissati, ārogyaṃ bhavissati, muddā, gaṇanā, saṅkhānaṃ, kāveyyaṃ, lokāyataṃ iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
“Or, some ascetics and *brāhmaṇas*, while living on food given in faith, make their living by wrong livelihood, by such base arts. Specifically, they predict: There will be good rainfall (suvuṭṭhikā bhavissati), there will be bad rainfall (dubbuṭṭhikā bhavissati), there will be a good harvest (subhikkhaṃ bhavissati), there will be a bad harvest (dubbhikkhaṃ bhavissati), there will be security (khemaṃ bhavissati), there will be danger (bhayaṃ bhavissati), there will be disease (rogo bhavissati), there will be health (ārogyaṃ bhavissati); or they make a living by accounting (muddā), computation (gaṇanā), calculation (saṅkhānaṃ), composing poetry (kāveyyaṃ), or worldly speculation (lokāyataṃ). He abstains from such wrong means of livelihood, from such debased arts.

This pertains to his moral discipline (sīlasmiṃ).
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.

Having thus laid down the topic and then dividing it sequentially, he said, "And how, O great king, does a *bhikṣu* become endowed with virtue (śīla)?" and so forth.

Therein, the meaning is: "This is also included in his virtue; that is, the *bhikṣu*'s abstinence from taking life (*prāṇātipātā veramaṇi*) is one virtue within virtue."

Or, this is a collective expression in the sense of individual statements.

Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*mahāaṭṭhakathā*), this meaning was stated: "This too is the virtue of that ascetic (śramaṇa)."

The remainder should be understood in the same way as stated in the *Brahmajāla*.

The meaning is: "This is included in his virtue; that is, this is his virtue."

mula_pali: 210. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti. Seyyathidaṃ – āvāhanaṃ vivāhanaṃ saṃvaraṇaṃ vivaraṇaṃ saṅkiraṇaṃ  vikiraṇaṃ subhagakaraṇaṃ dubbhagakaraṇaṃ viruddhagabbhakaraṇaṃ jivhānibandhanaṃ hanusaṃhananaṃ hatthābhijappanaṃ hanujappanaṃ kaṇṇajappanaṃ ādāsapañhaṃ kumārikapañhaṃ devapañhaṃ ādiccupaṭṭhānaṃ mahatupaṭṭhānaṃ abbhujjalanaṃ sirivhāyanaṃ iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
“Or, some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food given in faith, maintain their lives by wrong livelihood, by such base arts as:

Specifically: arranging *āvāhanaṃ* (sending for; inviting; calling; invocation), *vivāhanaṃ* (marriage), *saṃvaraṇaṃ* (engagements), *vivaraṇaṃ* (divorces), *saṅkiraṇaṃ* (arranging auspicious dates for the accumulation), *vikiraṇaṃ* (expenditure of money), *subhagakaraṇaṃ* (reciting charms to make people lucky), *dubbhagakaraṇaṃ* (unlucky), *viruddhagabbhakaraṇaṃ* (rejuvenating the fetuses of abortive women), *jivhānibandhanaṃ* (reciting spells to bind a man’s tongue), *hanusaṃhananaṃ* (to paralyze his jaws), *hatthābhijappanaṃ* (to make him lose control over his hands), *hanujappanaṃ* (causing deafness), *kaṇṇajappanaṃ* (getting answers with), *ādāsapañhaṃ* (a mirror), *kumārikapañhaṃ* (a girl-medium), *devapañhaṃ* (a *deva*), *ādiccupaṭṭhānaṃ* (worshipping the sun), *mahatupaṭṭhānaṃ* (Great Brahmā), *abbhujjalanaṃ* (breathing fire), *sirivhāyanaṃ* (invoking the goddess of luck); from such base arts and wrong means of livelihood he refrains.

This pertains to his moral discipline (*śīlasmin*).
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having thus laid down the topic, he then gradually explained, saying, "And how, great king, does a *bhikṣu* become accomplished in morality ( *śīla-sampanno* )?" etc.
Therein, "this too exists in his morality," meaning, "this abstinence from taking life (*prāṇātipātā veramaṇi*) is one aspect of the *bhikṣu*'s morality."
Or, this is an expression in the sense of individuality.
Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*mahāaṭṭhakathā*), this meaning itself has been stated: "This is the morality of that *śramaṇa*."
The rest should be understood according to the method stated in the *Brahmajāla*.
"This exists in his morality," meaning, "this is his morality."

mula_pali: 211. ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti . Seyyathidaṃ – santikammaṃ paṇidhikammaṃ bhūtakammaṃ bhūrikammaṃ vassakammaṃ vossakammaṃ vatthukammaṃ vatthuparikammaṃ ācamanaṃ nhāpanaṃ juhanaṃ vamanaṃ virecanaṃ uddhaṃvirecanaṃ adhovirecanaṃ sīsavirecanaṃ kaṇṇatelaṃ nettatappanaṃ natthukammaṃ añjanaṃ paccañjanaṃ sālākiyaṃ sallakattiyaṃ dārakatikicchā, mūlabhesajjānaṃ anuppadānaṃ, osadhīnaṃ paṭimokkho iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english: 211. Furthermore, some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on the food offered by the faithful, earn their living by wrong means of livelihood, by such base arts as: appeasing the *devas* (*śāntikarma*) and redeeming vows to them (*praṇidhikarma*); making earth-house spells (*bhūtakarma*); causing virility (*bhūrikamma*) or impotence (*vassakamma*); preparing and consecrating building-sites (*vatthukammaṃ vatthuparikammaṃ*); giving ritual rinsings (*ācamanaṃ*) and bathings (*nhāpanaṃ*); making sacrifices (*juhanaṃ*); giving emetics (*vamanaṃ*), purges (*virecanaṃ*), expectorants (*uddhaṃvirecanaṃ*) and phlegmagogues (*adhovirecanaṃ*); giving ear-medicine (*kaṇṇatelaṃ*), eye-medicine (*nettatappanaṃ*), nose-medicine (*natthukammaṃ*), ointments (*añjanaṃ*) and counter-ointments (*paccañjanaṃ*); eye-surgery (*sālākiyaṃ*), surgery (*sallakattiyaṃ*), pediatrics (*dārakatikicchā*), using balms to counter the side-effects of previous remedies (*mūlabhesajjānaṃ anuppadānaṃ*), dispensing herbs (*osadhīnaṃ paṭimokkho*). A monk refrains from such base arts and wrong means of livelihood. This pertains to his moral discipline.
commentary_pali: 194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento ‘‘kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ  bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto. Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.
commentary_english:
194-211.
Having established the summary in this way, distributing it gradually, he said, "And how, O great king, is a *bhikṣu* (monk) accomplished in virtue?" and so forth.
Therein, "This also exists in his virtue," means that this abstinence from killing living beings is one virtue in the virtue of that *bhikṣu*.
Or, this is a plural [term] in the sense of individual expression.
Indeed, in the Great Commentary (*Mahā-aṭṭhakathā*), this meaning itself is stated: "This is the virtue of that *śramaṇa* (ascetic)."
The remainder should be understood in the way already described in the *Brahmajāla*.
"This exists in his virtue," means this is his virtue.

mula_pali: 212. ‘‘Sa  kho so, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṃ sīlasampanno na kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ sīlasaṃvarato. Seyyathāpi – mahārāja, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto nihatapaccāmitto  na  kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ paccatthikato; evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṃ sīlasampanno na kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ sīlasaṃvarato. So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ anavajjasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti. Evaṃ kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti.
mula_english:
212. "And then, great king, that *bhikkhu* (monk) who is thus perfected in morality (*sīlasampanno*) sees no danger from any side owing to his being restrained by morality (*sīlasaṃvarato*).

Just as a head-anointed noble warrior (*khattiyo*) who has defeated his enemies sees no danger anywhere from his enemies (*paccatthikato*), so the *bhikkhu* who is thus possessed of moral discipline sees no danger anywhere in regard to his restraint by moral discipline (*sīlasaṃvarato*).

Possessing this aggregate of noble virtue (*ariyena sīlakkhandhena*), he experiences within himself a bliss that is blameless (*anavajjasukhaṃ*).

In this way, great king, the *bhikkhu* is possessed of moral discipline (*sīlasampanno hoti*).
commentary_pali: 212.Na kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ sīlasaṃvaratoti yāni asaṃvaramūlakāni bhayāni uppajjanti, tesu yaṃ idaṃ bhayaṃ sīlasaṃvarato bhaveyya, taṃ kutoci ekasaṃvaratopi na samanupassati. Kasmā? Saṃvarato asaṃvaramūlakassa bhayassa abhāvā. Muddhābhisittoti yathāvidhānavihitena khattiyābhisekena muddhani avasitto. Yadidaṃ paccatthikatoti yaṃ kutoci ekapaccatthikatopi bhayaṃ bhaveyya, taṃ na samanupassati. Kasmā? Yasmā nihatapaccāmitto. Ajjhattanti  niyakajjhattaṃ, attano santāneti attho. Anavajjasukhanti anavajjaṃ aninditaṃ kusalaṃ sīlapadaṭṭhānehi avippaṭisārapāmojjapītipassaddhidhammehi pariggahitaṃ kāyikacetasikasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti. Evaṃ kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hotīti evaṃ nirantaraṃ vitthāretvā dassitena tividhena sīlena samannāgato bhikkhu sīlasampanno nāma hotīti sīlakathaṃ niṭṭhāpesi.
commentary_english:
212. He sees no fear from anywhere, that is, due to moral restraint. Whatever fears arise rooted in non-restraint, he does not perceive that fear coming from even a single restraint.

Why? Because through restraint, there is an absence of fear rooted in non-restraint.

*Muddhābhisitto* means anointed on the head with a *kṣatriya* anointment, according to the prescribed ritual.

*Yadidaṃ paccatthikatoti* means he does not perceive whatever fear may come from any single adversary.

Why? Because he has defeated his enemies.

*Ajjhattaṃ* means specifically within oneself, in one's own continuum, that is the meaning.

*Anavajjasukhanti* means he experiences blameless, irreproachable, wholesome bodily and mental happiness (*kāyikacetasikasukhaṃ*) accompanied by such qualities as non-remorse (*avippaṭisāra*), gladness (*pāmojja*), rapture (*pīti*), tranquility (*passaddhi*), and other virtuous qualities (*dhamma*), which are grounded in moral conduct (*śīla*).

Thus, O great king, a *bhikṣu* is virtuous. Thus, having continuously expanded and shown the threefold virtue, the *bhikṣu* who is endowed with virtue is indeed called virtuous. Thus, he concluded the discourse on virtue.

mula_pali: 213. ‘‘Kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti? Idha, mahārāja, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī. Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhā domanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ, cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati. Sotena saddaṃ sutvā…pe… ghānena gandhaṃ ghāyitvā…pe… jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā…pe… kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ phusitvā…pe… manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī. Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhā domanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṃ, manindriye  saṃvaraṃ āpajjati. So iminā ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ abyāsekasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti. Evaṃ kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
mula_english:
213.

“And how, great king, does a *bhikkhu* guard the doors of the senses ( *indriyesu guttadvāro hoti*)? Here, great king, having seen a form ( *rūpaṃ*) with the eye ( *cakkhunā*), the *bhikkhu* does not grasp at the sign ( *nimitta*) or the details ( *anubyañjana*).

Since, if he left the eye faculty ( *cakkhundriyaṃ*) unrestrained ( *asaṃvutaṃ*) evil unwholesome states of covetousness ( *abhijjhā*) and grief ( *domanassā*) might invade him, he practises the way of its restraint ( *saṃvarāya paṭipajjati*), he guards the eye faculty ( *cakkhundriyaṃ*), he undertakes the restraint ( *saṃvaraṃ*) of the eye faculty ( *cakkhundriye*).

On hearing a sound ( *saddaṃ*) with the ear ( *sotena*)…On smelling an odour ( *gandhaṃ*) with the nose ( *ghānena*)…On tasting a flavour ( *rasaṃ*) with the tongue ( *jivhāya*)…On touching a tangible object ( *phoṭṭhabbaṃ*) with the body ( *kāyena*)…On cognizing a mind-object ( *dhammaṃ*) with the mind ( *manasā*), he does not grasp at its signs ( *nimitta*) and features ( *anubyañjana*).

Since, if he left the mind faculty ( *manindriyaṃ*) unrestrained ( *asaṃvutaṃ*), evil unwholesome states of covetousness ( *abhijjhā*) and grief ( *domanassā*) might invade him, he practises the way of its restraint ( *saṃvarāya paṭipajjati*), he guards the mind faculty ( *manindriyaṃ*), he undertakes the restraint ( *saṃvaraṃ*) of the mind faculty ( *manindriye*).

Possessing this noble ( *ariyena*) restraint ( *saṃvarena*) of the faculties ( *indriya*), he experiences within himself a bliss ( *sukhaṃ*) that is unsullied ( *abyāseka*).

In this way, great king, the *bhikkhu* guards the doors of the senses ( *indriyesu guttadvāro hoti*).
commentary_pali: 213. Indriyesu  guttadvārabhājanīye cakkhunā rūpanti ayaṃ cakkhusaddo katthaci buddhacakkhumhi vattati, yathāha – ‘‘buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokesī’’ti (mahāva. 9). Katthaci sabbaññutaññāṇasaṅkhāte samantacakkhumhi, yathāha – ‘‘tathūpamaṃ dhammamayaṃ, sumedha, pāsādamāruyha samantacakkhū’’ti (mahāva. 8). Katthaci dhammacakkhumhi ‘‘virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādī’’ti (mahāva. 16) hi ettha ariyamaggattayapaññā. ‘‘Cakkhuṃ udapādi ñāṇaṃ udapādī’’ti (mahāva. 15) ettha pubbenivāsādiñāṇaṃ paññācakkhūti vuccati. ‘‘Dibbena cakkhunā’’ti (ma. ni. 1.284) āgataṭṭhānesu dibbacakkhumhi vattati. ‘‘Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe cā’’ti ettha pasādacakkhumhi vattati. Idha panāyaṃ pasādacakkhuvohārena cakkhuviññāṇe vattati, tasmā cakkhuviññāṇena rūpaṃ disvāti ayametthattho. Sesapadesu yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā, taṃ sabbaṃ visuddhimagge vuttaṃ. Abyāsekasukhanti kilesabyāsekavirahitattā abyāsekaṃ asammissaṃ parisuddhaṃ adhicittasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedetīti.
commentary_english: 213. Guarding the doors of the senses, seeing a form with the eye: here, the word "eye" (cakkhu) occurs sometimes referring to the Buddha-eye (buddhacakkhu), as it is said: "He surveyed the world with the eye of a Buddha (buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokesī)" (Mahāvaṃsa 9). Sometimes, it refers to the universal eye (samantacakkhu), which is the knowledge of omniscience (sabbaññutañāṇa), as it is said: "Ascend the palace of Dhamma, O greatly wise one, O universal eye! (tathūpamaṃ dhammamayaṃ, sumedha, pāsādamāruyha samantacakkhū)" (Mahāvaṃsa 8). Sometimes, it refers to the Dhamma-eye (dharmacakkhu), which is the wisdom (paññā) of the lower three paths (ariyamaggattaya), as it is said: "There arose in him the dust-free, stainless eye of Dhamma (virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādī)" (Mahāvaṃsa 16). In the phrase "Vision arose, knowledge arose (cakkhuṃ udapādi ñāṇaṃ udapādī)" (Mahāvaṃsa 15), the knowledge of past lives (pubbenivāsādiñāṇa) is called the wisdom-eye (paññācakkhu). In places where "with the divine eye (dibbena cakkhunā)" (Majjhima Nikāya 1.284) occurs, it refers to the divine eye (dibbacakkhu). In the phrase "depending on the eye and forms (cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe cā)", it refers to the eye as a sense organ (pasādacakkhu). Here, the word "eye" (cakkhu) is used to signify eye-consciousness (cakkhuviññāṇa) in the conventional sense of the eye as a sense organ (pasādacakkhuvohārena), therefore the meaning here is: "Having seen a form with eye-consciousness (cakkhuviññāṇena rūpaṃ disvā)". Everything else that needs to be said concerning the other terms has been said already in the *Visuddhimagga*. "Abyāseka sukha" means that one experiences the pure (parisuddhaṃ) happiness of higher consciousness (adhicittasukhaṃ), which is unmixed (asammissaṃ) and unblemished (abyāsekaṃ), being devoid of the blemish of defilements (kilesabyāsekavirahitattā).

mula_pali: 214. ‘‘Kathañca , mahārāja, bhikkhu satisampajaññena samannāgato hoti? Idha, mahārāja, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī  hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti. Evaṃ kho, mahārāja , bhikkhu satisampajaññena samannāgato hoti.
mula_english:
214. “And how, great king, is a *bhikkhu* accomplished in mindfulness and clear comprehension (*satisampajañña*)? Here, great king, a *bhikkhu* acts with clear awareness (*sampajānakārī*) when going forward and returning; acts with clear awareness when looking ahead and looking aside; acts with clear awareness when bending and stretching; acts with clear awareness when wearing the outer cloak (*saṅghāṭi*), the bowl (*patta*), and the robe (*cīvara*); acts with clear awareness when eating, drinking, chewing, and savoring; acts with clear awareness when defecating and urinating; acts with clear awareness when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and remaining silent.

In this way, great king, a *bhikkhu* is accomplished in mindfulness and clear comprehension (*satisampajañña*).
commentary_pali: 214. Satisampajaññabhājanīyamhi abhikkante paṭikkanteti ettha tāva abhikkantaṃ vuccati gamanaṃ, paṭikkantaṃ nivattanaṃ, tadubhayampi catūsu iriyāpathesu labbhati. Gamane tāva purato kāyaṃ abhiharanto abhikkamati nāma . Paṭinivattanto paṭikkamati nāma. Ṭhānepi ṭhitakova kāyaṃ purato onāmento abhikkamati nāma, pacchato apanāmento paṭikkamati nāma. Nisajjāya nisinnakova āsanassa purimaaṅgābhimukho saṃsaranto abhikkamati nāma, pacchimaaṅgapadesaṃ paccāsaṃsaranto paṭikkamati nāma. Nipajjanepi eseva nayo. Sampajānakārī hotīti sampajaññena sabbakiccakārī. Sampajaññameva vā kārī. So hi abhikkantādīsu sampajaññaṃ karoteva. Na katthaci sampajaññavirahito hoti. Tattha sātthakasampajaññaṃ, sappāyasampajaññaṃ, gocarasampajaññaṃ asammohasampajaññanti catubbidhaṃ sampajaññaṃ. Tattha abhikkamanacitte uppanne cittavaseneva agantvā – ‘‘kinnu me ettha gatena attho atthi natthī’’ti atthānatthaṃ pariggahetvā atthapariggaṇhanaṃ sātthakasampajaññaṃ. Tattha  ca atthoti cetiyadassanabodhisaṅghatheraasubhadassanādivasena dhammato vuḍḍhi. Cetiyaṃ vā bodhiṃ vā disvāpi hi buddhārammaṇaṃ, saṅghadassanena saṅghārammaṇaṃ, pītiṃ uppādetvā tadeva khayavayato sammasanto arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. There disvā tesaṃ ovāde patiṭṭhāya, asubhaṃ disvā tattha paṭhamajjhānaṃ uppādetvā tadeva khayavayato sammasanto arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tasmā etesaṃ dassanaṃ sātthakanti vuttaṃ. Keci pana āmisatopi vuḍḍhi atthoyeva, taṃ nissāya brahmacariyānuggahāya paṭipannattāti vadanti. Tasmiṃ pana gamane sappāyāsappāyaṃ pariggahetvā sappāyapariggaṇhanaṃ sappāyasampajaññaṃ. Seyyathidaṃ – cetiyadassanaṃ tāva sātthakaṃ, sace pana cetiyassa mahāpūjāya dasadvādasayojanantare parisā sannipatanti, attano vibhavānurūpā itthiyopi purisāpi alaṅkatapaṭiyattā cittakammarūpakāni  viya sañcaranti. Tatra cassa iṭṭhe ārammaṇe lobho hoti, aniṭṭhe paṭigho, asamapekkhane moho uppajjati, kāyasaṃsaggāpattiṃ vā āpajjati. Jīvitabrahmacariyānaṃ vā antarāyo hoti, evaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ asappāyaṃ hoti. Vuttappakāraantarāyābhāve sappāyaṃ. Bodhidassanepi eseva nayo. Saṅghadassanampi sātthaṃ. Sace pana antogāme mahāmaṇḍapaṃ kāretvā sabbarattiṃ dhammassavanaṃ karontesu manussesu vuttappakāreneva janasannipāto  ceva antarāyo ca hoti, evaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ asappāyaṃ hoti. Antarāyābhāve sappāyaṃ. Mahāparisaparivārānaṃ therānaṃ dassanepi eseva nayo. Asubhadassanampi sātthaṃ, tadatthadīpanatthañca idaṃ vatthu – eko kira daharabhikkhu sāmaṇeraṃ gahetvā dantakaṭṭhatthāya gato. Sāmaṇero maggā okkamitvā purato gacchanto asubhaṃ disvā paṭhamajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā tadeva pādakaṃ katvā saṅkhāre sammasanto tīṇi phalāni sacchikatvā uparimaggatthāya kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariggahetvā aṭṭhāsi. Daharo taṃ apassanto sāmaṇerāti pakkosi. So ‘mayā pabbajitadivasato paṭṭhāya bhikkhunā saddhiṃ dve kathā nāma na kathitapubbā. Aññasmimpi divase upari visesaṃ nibbattessāmī’ti cintetvā kiṃ, bhanteti paṭivacanamadāsi. ‘Ehī’ti ca vutte ekavacaneneva āgantvā, ‘bhante, iminā tāva maggeneva gantvā mayā ṭhitokāse muhuttaṃ  puratthābhimukho ṭhatvā olokethā’ti āha. So tathā katvā tena pattavisesameva pāpuṇi. Evaṃ ekaṃ asubhaṃ dvinnaṃ janānaṃ atthāya jātaṃ. Evaṃ sātthampi panetaṃ purisassa mātugāmāsubhaṃ asappāyaṃ, mātugāmassa ca purisāsubhaṃ asappāyaṃ, sabhāgameva sappāyanti evaṃ sappāyapariggaṇhanaṃ sappāyasampajaññaṃ nāma. Evaṃ pariggahitasātthakasappāyassa pana aṭṭhatiṃsāya kammaṭṭhānesu attano cittaruciyaṃ kammaṭṭhānasaṅkhātaṃ  gocaraṃ uggahetvā bhikkhācāragocare taṃ gahetvāva gamanaṃ gocarasampajaññaṃ nāma. Tassāvibhāvanatthaṃ idaṃ catukkaṃ veditabbaṃ – Idhekacco bhikkhu harati, na paccāharati; ekacco paccāharati, na harati; ekacco pana neva harati, na paccāharati; ekacco harati ca, paccāharati cāti. Tattha yo bhikkhu divasaṃ caṅkamena nisajjāya ca āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṃ parisodhetvā tathā rattiyā paṭhamayāme, majjhimayāme seyyaṃ kappetvā pacchimayāmepi nisajjacaṅkamehi vītināmetvā pageva cetiyaṅgaṇabodhiyaṅgaṇavattaṃ katvā bodhirukkhe udakaṃ āsiñcitvā, pānīyaṃ paribhojanīyaṃ paccupaṭṭhapetvā ācariyupajjhāyavattādīni sabbāni khandhakavattāni samādāya vattati. So sarīraparikammaṃ katvā senāsanaṃ pavisitvā dve tayo pallaṅke usumaṃ gāhāpento kammaṭṭhānaṃ anuyuñjitvā bhikkhācāravelāyaṃ uṭṭhahitvā kammaṭṭhānasīseneva pattacīvaramādāya senāsanato nikkhamitvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontova cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ gantvā, sace buddhānussatikammaṭṭhānaṃ hoti, taṃ avissajjetvāva cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ pavisati. Aññaṃ ce kammaṭṭhānaṃ hoti, sopānamūle ṭhatvā hatthena gahitabhaṇḍaṃ viya taṃ ṭhapetvā buddhārammaṇaṃ pītiṃ gahetvā cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ āruyha, mahantaṃ cetiyaṃ  ce, tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditabbaṃ. Khuddakaṃ cetiyaṃ ce, tatheva padakkhiṇaṃ katvā aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu vanditabbaṃ. Cetiyaṃ vanditvā bodhiyaṅgaṇaṃ pattenāpi buddhassa bhagavato sammukhā viya nipaccākāraṃ dassetvā bodhi vanditabbā. So evaṃ cetiyañca bodhiñca vanditvā paṭisāmitaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā paṭisāmitabhaṇḍakaṃ hatthena gaṇhanto viya nikkhittakammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā gāmasamīpe kammaṭṭhānasīseneva cīvaraṃ pārupitvā gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pavisati. Atha naṃ manussā disvā ayyo no āgatoti paccuggantvā  pattaṃ gahetvā āsanasālāya vā gehe vā  nisīdāpetvā yāguṃ datvā yāva bhattaṃ na niṭṭhāti, tāva pāde dhovitvā telena makkhetvā purato te nisīditvā pañhaṃ vā pucchanti, dhammaṃ vā sotukāmā honti. Sacepi na kathāpenti, janasaṅgahatthaṃ dhammakathā nāma kātabbā yevāti aṭṭhakathācariyā vadanti. Dhammakathā hi kammaṭṭhānavinimuttā nāma natthi, tasmā kammaṭṭhānasīseneva dhammakathaṃ kathetvā kammaṭṭhānasīseneva āhāraṃ paribhuñjitvā anumodanaṃ katvā nivattiyamānehipi manussehi anugatova gāmato nikkhamitvā tattha te nivattetvā maggaṃ paṭipajjati. Atha naṃ puretaraṃ nikkhamitvā bahigāme katabhattakiccā sāmaṇeradaharabhikkhū disvā paccuggantvā pattacīvaramassa gaṇhanti. Porāṇakabhikkhū kira amhākaṃ upajjhāyo ācariyoti na mukhaṃ oloketvā vattaṃ karonti, sampattaparicchedeneva karonti. Te taṃ pucchanti – ‘‘bhante, ete manussā tumhākaṃ kiṃ honti, mātipakkhato sambandhā pitipakkhato’’ti? Kiṃ disvā pucchathāti? Tumhesu etesaṃ pemaṃ bahumānanti. Āvuso, yaṃ mātāpitūhipi dukkaraṃ, taṃ ete amhākaṃ karonti, pattacīvarampi no etesaṃ santakameva, etesaṃ ānubhāvena neva bhaye bhayaṃ, na chātake chātakaṃ jānāma. Īdisā nāma amhākaṃ upakārino natthīti tesaṃ guṇe kathento gacchati. Ayaṃ vuccati harati na paccāharatīti. Yassa pana pageva vuttappakāraṃ vattapaṭipattiṃ karontassa kammajatejodhātu pajjalati, anupādinnakaṃ muñcitvā upādinnakaṃ gaṇhāti, sarīrato sedā muñcanti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ vīthiṃ nārohati, so pageva pattacīvaramādāya vegasā cetiyaṃ vanditvā gorūpānaṃ nikkhamanavelāyameva gāmaṃ yāgubhikkhāya pavisitvā yāguṃ labhitvā āsanasālaṃ gantvā pivati, athassa dvattikkhattuṃ  ajjhoharaṇamatteneva kammajatejodhātu upādinnakaṃ muñcitvā anupādinnakaṃ gaṇhāti, ghaṭasatena nhāto viya tejodhātu pariḷāhanibbānaṃ patvā kammaṭṭhānasīsena yāguṃ paribhuñjitvā pattañca mukhañca dhovitvā antarābhatte kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikatvā avasesaṭṭhāne piṇḍāya caritvā kammaṭṭhānasīsena āhārañca paribhuñjitvā tato paṭṭhāya poṅkhānupoṅkhaṃ upaṭṭhahamānaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā  āgacchati, ayaṃ vuccati paccāharatina haratīti. Edisā ca bhikkhū yāguṃ pivitvā vipassanaṃ ārabhitvā buddhasāsane arahattappattā nāma gaṇanapathaṃ vītivattā. Sīhaḷadīpeyeva tesu tesu gāmesu āsanasālāyaṃ vā na taṃ āsanamatthi, yattha yāguṃ pivitvā arahattappattā bhikkhū natthīti. Yo pana pamādavihārī hoti, nikkhittadhuro sabbavattāni bhinditvā pañcavidhacetokhīlavinibandhacitto viharanto – ‘‘kammaṭṭhānaṃ nāma atthī’’ti saññampi akatvā gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pavisitvā ananulomikena gihisaṃsaggena saṃsaṭṭho caritvā ca bhuñjitvā ca tuccho nikkhamati, ayaṃ vuccati neva harati na paccāharatīti. Yo panāyaṃ – ‘‘harati ca paccāharati cā’’ti vutto, so gatapaccāgatavattavaseneva veditabbo. Attakāmā hi kulaputtā sāsane pabbajitvā dasapi vīsampi tiṃsampi cattālīsampi paññāsampi satampi ekato vasantā katikavattaṃ katvā viharanti, ‘‘āvuso, tumhe na iṇaṭṭā, na bhayaṭṭā, na jīvikāpakatā pabbajitā, dukkhā muccitukāmā panettha pabbajitā, tasmā gamane uppannakilesaṃ gamaneyeva niggaṇhatha, tathā ṭhāne, nisajjāya, sayane uppannakilesaṃ sayaneva niggaṇhathā’’ti. Te evaṃ katikavattaṃ katvā bhikkhācāraṃ  gacchantā aḍḍhausabhausabhaaḍḍhagāvutagāvutantaresu pāsāṇā honti, tāya saññāya kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontāva gacchanti. Sace kassaci gamane kileso uppajjati, tattheva naṃ niggaṇhāti. Tathā asakkonto tiṭṭhati, athassa pacchato āgacchantopi tiṭṭhati. So ‘‘ayaṃ bhikkhu tuyhaṃ uppannavitakkaṃ jānāti, ananucchavikaṃ te eta’’nti attānaṃ paṭicodetvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā tattheva ariyabhūmiṃ okkamati; tathā asakkonto nisīdati. Athassa pacchato āgacchantopi nisīdatīti soyeva nayo. Ariyabhūmiṃ okkamituṃ asakkontopi taṃ kilesaṃ vikkhambhetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontova gacchati, na kammaṭṭhānavippayuttena cittena pādaṃ uddharati, uddharati ce, paṭinivattitvā purimapadesaṃyeva eti. Ālindakavāsī mahāphussadevatthero viya. So  kira ekūnavīsativassāni gatapaccāgatavattaṃ pūrento eva vihāsi, manussāpi addasaṃsu antarāmagge kasantā ca vapantā ca maddantā ca kammāni ca karontā theraṃ tathāgacchantaṃ disvā – ‘‘ayaṃ thero punappunaṃ nivattitvā gacchati, kinnu kho maggamūḷho, udāhu  kiñci pamuṭṭho’’ti samullapanti. So taṃ anādiyitvā kammaṭṭhānayuttacitteneva samaṇadhammaṃ karonto vīsativassabbhantare arahattaṃ pāpuṇi, arahattappattadivase cassa caṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ adhivatthā devatā aṅgulīhi dīpaṃ ujjāletvā aṭṭhāsi. Cattāropi mahārājāno sakko ca devānamindo brahmā ca sahampati upaṭṭhānaṃ agamaṃsu. Tañca obhāsaṃ disvā vanavāsī mahātissatthero taṃ dutiyadivase pucchi – ‘‘rattibhāge āyasmato santike obhāso ahosi, kiṃ so obhāso’’ti? Thero vikkhepaṃ karonto obhāso nāma dīpobhāsopi hoti, maṇiobhāsopīti evamādimāha. Tato ‘paṭicchādetha tumhe’ti nibaddho ‘āmā’ti paṭijānitvā  ārocesi. Kāḷavallimaṇḍapavāsī mahānāgatthero viya ca. Sopi kira gatapaccāgatavattaṃ pūrento – paṭhamaṃ tāva bhagavato mahāpadhānaṃ pūjessāmīti sattavassāni ṭhānacaṅkamameva adhiṭṭhāsi. Puna soḷasavassāni gatapaccāgatavattaṃ pūretvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇi.
