Then, cool streams (*sītā vāridhārā*) well up from that very lake (*udakarahadā*) and drench (*abhisandeyya*), steep (*parisandeyya*), fill (*paripūreyya*), and pervade (*paripphareyya*) that very lake (*udakarahadaṃ*) with cool water (*sītena vārinā*), so that there would be no part of the whole lake (*sabbāvato udakarahadassa*) untouched (*apphuṭaṃ*) by the cool water (*sītena vārinā*). In the same way (*evameva kho*), great king (*mahārāja*), a *bhikkhu* drenches (*abhisandeti*), steeps (*parisandeti*), fills (*paripūreti*), and pervades (*parippharati*) this very body (*kāyaṃ*) with the rapture and pleasure (*pītisukhena*) born of concentration (*samādhijena*), so that there is no part of his whole body (*sabbāvato kāyassa*) untouched (*apphuṭaṃ*) by the rapture and pleasure born of concentration (*samādhijena pītisukhena*). This (*idaṃpi kho*), great king (*mahārāja*), is a visible fruit (*sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ*) of the ascetic life, more excellent (*abhikkantatarañca*) and sublime (*paṇītatarañca*) than the previous visible fruits of the ascetic life (*purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi*)."
commentary_pali: 228-229. Dutiyajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ ubbhidodakoti ubbhinnaudako, na heṭṭhā ubbhijjitvā uggacchanakaudako. Antoyeva pana ubbhijjanakaudakoti attho. Āyamukhanti āgamanamaggo. Devoti megho. Kālena kālanti kāle kāle, anvaddhamāsaṃ vā anudasāhaṃ vāti attho. Dhāranti vuṭṭhiṃ. Na anuppaveccheyyāti na ca paveseyya, na vasseyyāti attho. Sītā vāridhārā ubbhijjitvāti sītaṃ dhāraṃ uggantvā rahadaṃ pūrayamānaṃ ubbhijjitvā. Heṭṭhā uggacchanaudakañhi uggantvā uggantvā bhijjantaṃ udakaṃ khobheti, catūhi disāhi pavisanaudakaṃ purāṇapaṇṇatiṇakaṭṭhadaṇḍakādīhi udakaṃ khobheti, vuṭṭhiudakaṃ dhārānipātapubbuḷakehi udakaṃ khobheti. Sannisinnameva pana hutvā iddhinimmitamiva uppajjamānaṃ udakaṃ imaṃ padesaṃ pharati, imaṃ padesaṃ na pharatīti natthi, tena aphuṭokāso nāma na hotīti. Tattha rahado viya karajakāyo. Udakaṃ viya dutiyajjhānasukhaṃ. Sesaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
228-229.
*Ubhidodaka* means that the water bursts forth, meaning *ubbhinnodaka*, it is not water that rises up having burst forth from below.
But *antoyeva pana ubbhijjanakaudakoti attho* means that the water bursts forth from within.
*Āyamukha* means the path of arrival (*āgamanamārga*).
*Deva* means a cloud (*megha*).
*Kālena kālaṃ* means at different times, either every half-month or every ten days, such is the meaning.
*Dhāranti* means they bear or bring rain (*vṛṣṭi*).
*Na anuppaveccheyyāti* means one should not let it enter, nor should one cause it to enter; *na vasseyyāti attho* means one should not cause it to rain, such is the meaning.
*Sītā vāridhārā ubbhijjitvāti* means that a cool stream of water, having sprung up, bursts forth, filling the lake (*rahadaṃ pūrayamānaṃ ubbhijjitvā*).
Indeed, water that rises from below (*heṭṭhā uggacchanaudakaṃ*) having risen again and again, agitates the water; water that enters from the four directions (*catūhi disāhi pavisanaudakaṃ*) agitates the water with old leaves, grass, wood, sticks, and so on; rainwater (*vṛṣṭiudakaṃ*) agitates the water with streams of falling drops and bubbles.
But, having just settled down, water arising as if created by *iddhi* pervades this region; it is not that it does not pervade this region, therefore it is called un-scattered or un-separated.
There, the body of the *karaja* is like a lake (*rahado viya karajakāyo*).
The happiness of the second *dhyāna* is like water (*udakaṃ viya dutiyajjhānasukhaṃ*).
The remainder should be understood in the same manner as previously (*sesaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ*).

mula_pali: 230. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, mahārāja, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti – ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti, tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. So imameva kāyaṃ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mula_english:
230. “Furthermore, great king, with the fading away of rapture ( *pītiyā ca virāgā*), a *bhikṣu* dwells in equanimity (*upekkhako*), mindful (*sato*) and clearly comprehending (*sampajāno*), and experiences happiness (*sukhaṃ*) with the body (*kāyena*). Thus he enters and dwells in the third *jhāna* ( *tatiyaṃ dhyānaṃ*), of which the noble ones (*ariyā*) declare: ‘He dwells happily with equanimity and mindfulness (*upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī*)’.

And with this joy devoid of rapture (*nippītikena sukhena*), he drenches, steeps, saturates, and suffuses this very body (*kāyaṃ*) so that there is no part of his entire body (*sabbāvato kāyassa*) which is not suffused by this happiness devoid of rapture (*nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti*).
commentary_pali: 230-231. Tatiyajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ  uppalāni ettha santīti uppalinī. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo. Ettha ca setarattanīlesu yaṃ kiñci uppalaṃ uppalameva. Ūnakasatapattaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ, satapattaṃ padumaṃ. Pattaniyamaṃ vā vināpi setaṃ padumaṃ, rattaṃ puṇḍarīkanti ayamettha vinicchayo. Udakānuggatānīti udakato na uggatāni. Anto nimuggaposīnīti udakatalassa anto nimuggāniyeva hutvā posīni, vaḍḍhīnīti attho. Sesaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
230-231. Because there are lotuses (*uppala*) here similar to the happiness of the third *jhāna* (tritiyajjhāna), therefore it is called "Uppalinī."

And the same rule applies to the other two sections.

Here, any lotus (*uppala*) whether it is white (śeta), red (ratta), or blue (nīla), is simply a lotus (*uppala*).

A *puṇḍarīka* is a *padma* lotus (*paduma*) with fewer than a hundred petals; a *paduma* is a lotus with a hundred petals.

Or, without restriction of the petals, a white (śeta) one is a *paduma* lotus, and a red (ratta) one is a *puṇḍarīka*: this is the distinction here.

"Not risen out of the water" means not risen from the water (udakato).

"Grows submerged inside" means having become submerged inside the water surface (udakatalassa), they grow; that is the meaning (attho).

The remainder should be understood in the same manner as above (purimanayeneva).

mula_pali: 231. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, uppaliniyaṃ vā paduminiyaṃ vā puṇḍarīkiniyaṃ vā appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā  udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni antonimuggaposīni, tāni yāva caggā yāva ca mūlā sītena vārinā abhisannāni parisannāni abhisandāni parisandāni (ka.) paripūrāni paripphuṭāni paripphuṭṭhāni (pī.), nāssa kiñci sabbāvataṃ uppalānaṃ vā padumānaṃ vā puṇḍarīkānaṃ vā sītena vārinā apphuṭaṃ assa; evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti. Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṃ  sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
mula_english:
231. "Just as, great king, in a pond of *utpala* (blue lotus), or *padma* (red lotus), or *puṇḍarīka* (white lotus), there might be some blue lotuses, red lotuses, or white lotuses, born in the water, grown in the water, thriving without rising from the water, nourished immersed within; and cool water would drench, steep, saturate and pervade them from their tips to their roots, so that there would be no part of all those lotuses untouched by the cool water; in the same way, great king, a *bhikkhu* (monk) drenches, steeps, saturates and suffuses this very body with joy devoid of rapture, so that there is no part of his whole body untouched by the joy devoid of rapture.

Furthermore, great king, this is a visible fruit of the contemplative life (*sāmaññaphala*), more excellent and sublime than the previous visible fruits of the contemplative life."
commentary_pali: 230-231. Tatiyajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ  uppalāni ettha santīti uppalinī. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo. Ettha ca setarattanīlesu yaṃ kiñci uppalaṃ uppalameva. Ūnakasatapattaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ, satapattaṃ padumaṃ. Pattaniyamaṃ vā vināpi setaṃ padumaṃ, rattaṃ puṇḍarīkanti ayamettha vinicchayo. Udakānuggatānīti udakato na uggatāni. Anto nimuggaposīnīti udakatalassa anto nimuggāniyeva hutvā posīni, vaḍḍhīnīti attho. Sesaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
230-231.

*Uppalinī* means that there are *uppala* lotuses here similar to the pleasure of the third *dhyāna*.

And the same rule applies to the other two sections.

Here, whatever *uppala* lotus is white, red, or blue, is simply an *uppala* lotus.

*Puṇḍarīka* is a *padma* lotus with fewer petals than one hundred; *paduma* is a *padma* lotus with one hundred petals.

Or, regardless of the number of petals, a white one is a *paduma* lotus, and a red one is a *puṇḍarīka* lotus; this is the distinction here.

*Udakānuggatāni* means that they do not emerge from the water.

*Anto nimuggaposīnī* means that they are submerged within the surface of the water, thus nourished and grown; this is the meaning.

The rest should be understood according to the previous method.

mula_pali: 232. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, mahārāja, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, so imameva kāyaṃ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā  nisinno hoti, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mula_english: “Furthermore, great king, with the abandoning of pleasure (*sukha*) and the abandoning of pain (*dukkha*), and with the previous disappearance of joy (*saumanasya*) and grief (*daurmanasya*), a *bhikkhu* enters and dwells in the fourth *jhāna*, which is neither painful nor pleasant and features the purity of mindfulness due to equanimity (*upekkhā-sati-pārisuddhi*). He sits having suffused this very body with a pure, bright mind, so that there is no part of his entire body that is not suffused with a pure, bright mind.
commentary_pali: 232-233. Catutthajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātenāti ettha nirupakkilesaṭṭhena parisuddhaṃ, pabhassaraṭṭhena pariyodātanti veditabbaṃ. Odātena vatthenāti idaṃ utupharaṇatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiliṭṭhavatthena hi utupharaṇaṃ na hoti, taṅkhaṇadhotaparisuddhena utupharaṇaṃ balavaṃ hoti. Imissāya hi upamāya vatthaṃ viya karajakāyo, utupharaṇaṃ viya catutthajjhānasukhaṃ. Tasmā yathā sunhātassa purisassa parisuddhaṃ vatthaṃ sasīsaṃ pārupitvā nisinnassa sarīrato utu sabbameva vatthaṃ pharati. Na koci vatthassa aphuṭokāso hoti. Evaṃ catutthajjhānasukhena bhikkhuno  karajakāyassa na koci okāso aphuṭo hotīti. Evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Imesaṃ pana catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ anupadavaṇṇanā ca bhāvanānayo ca visuddhimagge vuttoti idha na vitthārito. Ettāvatā cesa rūpajjhānalābhīyeva, na arūpajjhānalābhīti na veditabbo. Na hi aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu cuddasahākārehi ciṇṇavasībhāvaṃ vinā upari abhiññādhigamo hoti. Pāḷiyaṃ pana rūpajjhānāniyeva āgatāni. Arūpajjhānāni āharitvā kathetabbāni.
commentary_english:
232-233.

In the simile of the bliss of the fourth *jhāna*, regarding "with a perfectly pure mind, exceedingly bright," here "perfectly pure" should be understood in the sense of being free from defilements, and "exceedingly bright" in the sense of being radiant.

The white cloth is mentioned for the purpose of showing suffusion by heat.

For there is no suffusion by heat with a soiled cloth; with a clean cloth that has just been washed the suffusion by heat is strong.

For in this simile the material body is like the cloth and the happiness of the fourth *jhāna* is like the suffusion by heat.

Therefore, just as when a man has bathed well and is sitting covered from the head down by a clean cloth, the heat from his body suffuses the entire cloth

so that there is no part of the cloth not suffused by heat,

similarly, there is no part of the *bhikkhu*'s material body that is not suffused by the happiness of the fourth *jhāna*.

It is in this way that the meaning should be seen here.

A step-by-step explanation of the four *jhānas*, and of the method of developing them, is given in the *Visuddhimagga*. Thus they are not explained in detail here.

It should not be thought that at this point only the one who gains the material-form *jhānas* has been shown, but not the one who gains the immaterial *jhānas*.

For there can be no achievement of the higher direct knowledges (*abhijñā*) without achieving mastery in fourteen ways over the eight meditative attainments (*samāpatti*).

In the text only the material-form *jhānas* have come down,

but the immaterial *jhānas* should be brought in and explained.

mula_pali: 233. ‘‘Seyyathāpi , mahārāja, puriso odātena vatthena sasīsaṃ pārupitvā nisinno assa, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa odātena vatthena apphuṭaṃ assa; evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṃ hoti. Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi  sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
mula_english:
“Just as, great king, a man might sit having covered his head with a white cloth, such that no part of his whole body would be untouched by the white cloth; just so, great king, a *bhikkhu* sits, having pervaded this very body with a pure, bright mind (*parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena*), such that no part of his whole body is untouched by the pure, bright mind.

This, great king, is a visible fruit of the ascetic life (*sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ*), more excellent (*abhikkantatarañca*) and more sublime (*paṇītatarañca*) than the previous visible fruits of the ascetic life.
commentary_pali: 232-233. Catutthajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātenāti ettha nirupakkilesaṭṭhena parisuddhaṃ, pabhassaraṭṭhena pariyodātanti veditabbaṃ. Odātena vatthenāti idaṃ utupharaṇatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiliṭṭhavatthena hi utupharaṇaṃ na hoti, taṅkhaṇadhotaparisuddhena utupharaṇaṃ balavaṃ hoti. Imissāya hi upamāya vatthaṃ viya karajakāyo, utupharaṇaṃ viya catutthajjhānasukhaṃ. Tasmā yathā sunhātassa purisassa parisuddhaṃ vatthaṃ sasīsaṃ pārupitvā nisinnassa sarīrato utu sabbameva vatthaṃ pharati. Na koci vatthassa aphuṭokāso hoti. Evaṃ catutthajjhānasukhena bhikkhuno  karajakāyassa na koci okāso aphuṭo hotīti. Evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Imesaṃ pana catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ anupadavaṇṇanā ca bhāvanānayo ca visuddhimagge vuttoti idha na vitthārito. Ettāvatā cesa rūpajjhānalābhīyeva, na arūpajjhānalābhīti na veditabbo. Na hi aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu cuddasahākārehi ciṇṇavasībhāvaṃ vinā upari abhiññādhigamo hoti. Pāḷiyaṃ pana rūpajjhānāniyeva āgatāni. Arūpajjhānāni āharitvā kathetabbāni.
commentary_english:
232-233.

In the simile of the happiness of the fourth *jhāna* (catutthajjhāna), "with a pure mind, perfectly white" (*parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena*)—here, "pure" (*parisuddhaṃ*) should be understood in the sense of being without defilement (*nirupakkilesaṭṭhena*), and "perfectly white" (*pariyodātaṃ*) in the sense of being radiant (*pabhassaraṭṭhena*).

"With a white cloth" (*odātena vattheṇa*)—this was said for the purpose of showing suffusion by heat (*utupharaṇatthaṃ*).

For there is no suffusion by heat (*utupharaṇaṃ*) with a soiled cloth (*kiliṭṭhavatthena*); with a clean cloth (*taṅkhaṇadhotaparisuddhena*) that has just been washed, the suffusion by heat (*utupharaṇaṃ*) is strong (*balavaṃ hoti*).

For in this simile (*imissāya hi upamāya*), the material body (*karajakāyo*) is like the cloth (*vatthaṃ viya*), and the happiness of the fourth *jhāna* (catutthajjhānasukhaṃ) is like the suffusion by heat (*utupharaṇaṃ viya*).

Therefore, just as when a man (*purisassa*) has bathed well (*sunhātassa*) and is sitting covered from the head down (*sasīsaṃ pārupitvā nisinnassa*) by a clean cloth (*parisuddhaṃ vatthaṃ*), the heat (*utu*) from his body (*sarīrato*) suffuses the entire cloth (*sabbameva vatthaṃ pharati*),

so that there is no part of the cloth (*vatthassa*) not suffused by heat (*aphuṭokāso hoti*),

similarly, there is no part of the *bhikkhu*'s material body (*karajakāyassa*) that is not suffused by the happiness of the fourth *jhāna* (*catutthajjhānasukhena*) (*na koci okāso aphuṭo hotīti*).

It is in this way (*evamettha*) that the meaning (*attho*) should be seen (*daṭṭhabbo*).

A step-by-step explanation (*anupadavaṇṇanā*) of these four *jhānas* (*imesaṃ pana catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ*), and of the method of developing them (*bhāvanānayo ca*), is given in the *Visuddhimagga*, thus they are not explained in detail here (*idha na vitthārito*).

It should not be thought (*na veditabbo*) that at this point (*ettāvatā*) only the one who gains the material-form *jhānas* (*rūpajjhānalābhīyeva*) has been shown, but not the one who gains the immaterial *jhānas* (*na arūpajjhānalābhīti*).

For there can be no achievement of the higher direct knowledges (*upari abhiññādhigamo hoti*) without achieving mastery (*vasībhāvaṃ vinā*) in fourteen ways (*cuddasahākārehi*) over the eight meditative attainments (*aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu*).

In the text (*pāḷiyaṃ pana*) only the material-form *jhānas* (*rūpajjhānāniyeva*) have come down (*āgatāni*),

but the immaterial *jhānas* (*arūpajjhānāni*) should be brought in and explained (*āharitvā kathetabbāni*).
